Subject: Your Sister's House
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Fri, 1 Apr 1994 04:18:42 -0800 (PST)
Cc: socal-raves@ucsd.edu, izzy4lm@mvs.oac.ucla.edu (Janelle Wong),
        usuz@mcl.mcl.ucsb.edu (suzy plotkin),

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 5930      
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Wow, well...I just got home and I wanted to get this out right now . I have 
always been biased about hte quality of the parties that the sisters put
on, but they outdid themselves tonight, the rest did them SO much good.

The site (which I understand just might be a semi-regular location for them)
was a warehouse in the "industrial wasteland" section of SF (I dunno, do we
call this China Basin?), and was an awesome display - it is normally the
humble abode for six people, who all live in little nooks and crannies way
up above...like treehouses, but gone completely mad...a huge playground of
ladders and platforms and...wow...and the sisters spruced it up (which didn't
even need decoration) with trees (YES trees), flowers, great projections
(at least at first), and a huge glowing YSH sign.

Ethan's sound system was in full effect, busting out Autechre when I arrived
(consult the IDM list if you are not familiar with this band (: ). As I 
unserstand it, Ethan's sound system (or a piece of it_) took a nasty crash,
ruining two hundred dollars worth of records (HIS records) as well as 
damaging his turntable. Thank you very much, Ethan, for the use of your
beautiful sound system, and I am very sorry about the accident. :( And
Bryce, you are wonderful for going home to get your turntable.

Susan started off the evening with some acidy dubby tribal funk house (that's
me, inventing those labels...) while the discussion group focused on the 
medical uses of marijuana - Pebbles, the panelist, was apparently involved in
a court case or is still involved in one, regarding her rights to use the
herb medicinally. She freaked me out, but she has a wonderful collection of
political buttons and bumper stickers out for display (ex: "The difference
between Bush and God is that God doesn't think he is Bush")...satisfied the
political scientist in me, anyway.

Tara took over after 90 minutes from Susan...I thought it would be funk, down
and dirty...but the first 30 minutes or so weren't that at all...once I pointed
it out to Bryce that I thought we would hear funk from her...she started 
cranking the funk. She eventually ended with some hilariously bitchy house
diva tune that she said was her favorite track, only costing her 99 cents. It
put her in a great mood, and all throughout my set she would sneak up behind
me and say, "you go, girl!".

By this point, my fingertips were numb and I was thrust behind the wheels of
steel. :) I got to play my new kitschy ragtime house record followed by what
I thought was today's great find at the vinyl solution in san mateo - ye ke ye
ke by Mory Kante...a great cheesy Steve Masters classic - sorry if you had to
suffer through it, but at least I know Susie liked it! :) By this time my game
plan had been thrown completely out of the window, and although I feel like I
made a lot of mistakes (plus had difficulty carrying out a single theme in my
set, instead opting for a huge variety), I know I did at least a FEW good
things, and I am proud of myself. Doesn't mean I have reached my goal though.

Anyway, Jan Cooley pumped up her renowned house after me, and I left about a
half hour into her set. She played a test pressing of the new Daisy Glow
record (I had the pleasure of meeting the author, Kelix, who accompanied
Jan. When he approached me I happened to be playing a Twitch remix of a 
Daisy Glow song, which I love, and he thanked me profusely for playing it)...
it's cool in that it breaks the regional boundaries...it evokes an overwhelming
urge to pigeonhole it as "New York House", with it's Aretha Franklin wails and
Xpress 2 horns, but hey, it's coming from SF. The boundaries are blurring.

OK, here come my thank you's...this would be a good time to hit the delete key
if you're sick of me indulging myself:

Socal-Ravers: I felt a certain emptiness without you, you are very important
to me and I missed your energy. The vrave link-up with Dub (a new ambient
club which opened tonight, featuring socal ravers and friends) and the 
presence of a certain ex-girlfriend of the tallest socal-raver, her dancing her
ass off right in front of me, were comforting and I really felt like you guys
were there.  Joe: I have three words for you: Smith and Mighty.

SFRavers: Your support means a lot to me, thank you for being a large part of
why this party has always felt so good.  

YSH possee: I want to publicly thank all the sisters, especially Susan and
Maui (and honorary sister Sean) for persevering when it looked like this 
party would just die.  I hope that someday they will know the kind of impact
that they have had on people.

So those are my big ups. I must also send a big fat fuck you to the random
girl who asked me to play some fucking cheesy Murk song...and loudly 
interrupted me while i had one hand on the volume and the other on the
crossfader...on my very last mix of the evening. Grrr. The raspberry of the
evening goes to Jon Drukman, who, had he sacrificed mere moments of sleep, 
would have been treated to The Snowball Effect.

OK, I am very tired...I could write for hours...one last thought. Susan 
remarked that she and I are similar in that we both have trouble narrowing
down our likes into one main style of dance music. Instead, we both tend to
be what you would nicely call "eclectic" or insultingly call "all over the
place". My question to you is - how much does variety within a set mean to you
as dancers?

Good night, and remember, your sisters love you all....MMMMWWWWAHHHHHH!



Tamara Palmer                                            Women Respond To Bass

izzypk3@mvs.oac.ucla.edu  (yes, i is a college student)
urbmag@netcom.com   (open for your comments about URB Magazine!)

Top 10 Reasons to Jump for Joy at the Return of YSH (in no particular order)

* Susan's into dubby acid that is so seriously spaced out that even the
        most serious Rotterdam headbanger (no, this is not an ethnic
        slur, it's a musical reference) would get something positive out 
        of it.

* Peace's banner 

* some of the nicest people in San Francisco dance there

* Sound*Vision 

* use of a non-club location

* is it just me or does the YSH-going-crowd not smoke a lot of cigarettes?

* $20 worth of fun and vibe for only $5

* "the little things" like candles, flowers, interesting hand outs

* starts at 10 so us 9-to-5-ers can party down and still get a decent night's
	sleep

* with all the different women who have played there, the lineup is always 
	changing so YSH always delivers something new  (even though I don't
	like Tara's chosen style of music, I really have to say that she is 
	GREAT!  Tamara is still hard to classify (yay!!) and is putting out 
	an energetic groove -- and don't be so darn hard on yourself.  I 
	didn't stay for Jan because I had to go home and sleep.)


Laura

From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)

Subject: YSH report
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

The Sisters are Back
====================

  "Your Sisters House" back on-line again for the first time in
thie new rave year.    This time,  with a killer space,  an old
warehouse in SF,  somewhere near the China Basin area.

   Things got started early this time,  and we arrived sometime
around 10 pm.   At first,  few people showed up,   but later on,
things were just the right size.    The dance floor got kinda crowded,
but the environment was really great.   Not hot and stuffy,   but
rather cool an pleasant.

   When I arrived,  Susan was spinning,   and she never let me down,
spinning a constant beat,  really great new and refreshing tunes.
It's really good to hear some new talant,  and the "Sisters" certainly
didn't lack that at all.

   All ths usual crowd was there,  heavily attended by the SFR folks,
and as usual,  the attitude was "Luv phasers all the way".

   As usual,  I danced my butt off,  and feel very much stronger now
that I'm completly healed.       

   Outside,  a fire was lit in an old barbeque,  and some folks were
chilling out by the fire.    It was a really nice evening.   Not too
cold,   and was just right.

   Saw a lot of new faces this time,   some from the Universal Groove
gig also happening on the same night.

   It's hard to tell how many people showed up,   but I estimate
somewhere between 40 and 60 people (correct me if I'm wrong),  but
for the first "YSH" of the year,   I would say it was well attended.

   Although I didn't make the discussion group because of Brian's party
at Ameba,   I couldn't say how that turned out.

   At any rate,  WELCOME BACK Sisters....


Crunch

Subject: MDMA Research:  SoCal volunteers needed

MDMA RESEARCH: UPDATE ON THE HARBOR-UCLA PROJECT
BY CHARLES S. GROB, M.D.

[This article was published in the Spring, 1994 issue of the newsletter of the
Multidisciplinary Association for Psychedelic Studies (MAPS), a
membership-based non-profit research and educational organization.  See the  
end of this message for more info about MAPS.]

Efforts are underway to initiate human research with MDMA
(3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine) at Harbor-ULCA Medical Center.
Comprehensive work-ups of several individuals with extensive histories of
past use of MDMA have been performed. These evaluations have focused on the
effects of MDMA use on serotonergic neurotransmitter function, and have
examined such parameters as sleep electroencephalograms (EEG), fenfluramine
challenge tests, SPECT brain scans and neuropsychological testing. Our
preliminary data (which we hope to report on in a subsequent MAPS newsletter)
has turned out to be quite fascinating. We believe this study will shed
considerable light on the psychophysiological mechanisms by which MDMA exerts
its unique effects.

We currently have FDA approval to conduct two studies of MDMA administration
in humans. The first study will be an examination of MDMA's general safety
parameters. It will involve a gradual ascending dose model to determine
threshold for subjective psychological effects as well as analgesia. This
study will be preparatory to eventual studies for which we hope to receive
permission to conduct with patients who have terminal medical illness. 


SAFETY AND DOSE-FINDING STUDY

The safety and dose-finding study in healthy volunteers will involve three
separate experimental sessions in the Clinical Studies Center at the
Harbor-UCLA Medical Center. The sessions will utilize each of two different
dosages of MDMA as well as an inactive placebo. Both subjects and research
personnel will be blind as to what is administered at each session. We will
start with what we consider to be a sub-threshold dose (0.25 mg/kg) and
gradually increase the dosages with successive subjects into the range we
anticipate will induce the unique MDMA effect.  Parameters to be examined in
this study include blood pressure, temperature, electrocardiograms, hepatic
function, renal function and thyroid function.  A variety of measures will be
utilized to quantify both acute psychological effect as well as
neuropsychological function. Non-invasive assessment of pain perception and
analgesia will also be pursued.  Given that this study is anticipated to be
preparatory to an extensive investigation of the use of MDMA as a putative
therapeutic modality in individuals with end-stage medical illness associated
with refractory pain and psychological distress, we will also work with the
guided imagery models we hope to eventually employ in these future studies.

SEROTONIN SYSTEM STUDY

Our second study of MDMA administration in humans will involve a careful
and extensive evaluation of effects on parameters of brain function. Given
the concerns of the past decade with the phenomena described as "serotonergic
neurotoxicity", it is imperative that we conduct objective and fair-minded
studies into the effects of MDMA on parameters influenced by serotonergic
neurotransmitter function.  Although there is laboratory evidence that low
dose MDMA causes no discernable lasting effect to brain structures, there
is no doubt on the basis of animal histopathological investigations that
repeated parenteral administration of high dosages of MDMA will exert
profound changes to serotonergic neuronal distribution.

What the implications of this animal data are to the functional status of
individual human beings who take MDMA, however, is not at all clear. Are
we looking at a "neurotoxic" phenomena which will inevitably lead to
deterioration of neuropsychiatric function over time, or are we in fact
observing the histopathological substrate for what may eventually be
recognized as therapeutic "neuroplasticity"? Without access to data from
research studies of human use of MDMA, we can only conjecture as to what
the implications may be. Fortunately, we have reached the point where it
is now possible to conduct the level of comprehensive, well-controlled
methodological studies into the effects of MDMA in human subjects which
will be essential to answer these critical questions.

The extensive investigation of MDMA effects on parameters of serotonergic
neurotransmitter function is under way at the Harbor-UCLA Medical Center.
My primary collaborator on this project is Dr. Russell Poland, a senior
researcher in the Department of Psychiatry.  Subjects enrolled in this
particular study will be required to come into the Clinical Studies Center
at Harbor-UCLA on six separate occasions. They will receive comprehensive
neuropsychiatric assessments to include neuroendocrine challenge tests, sleep
electroencephalograms, brain SPECT scans and neuropsychological testing.
Extensive investigation of these parameters we anticipate will provide for
us an enhanced understanding of the effects of MDMA use on serotonergic
neurotransmitter status and its functional consequences.

VOLUNTEERS NEEDED

We are currently recruiting subjects to take part in both of the studies
described above. We are looking for both male and female volunteers who would
be willing to invest the necessary time, energy and inconvenience that
participation would require.  We are particularly interested in identifying
prospective subjects who have used significant amounts of MDMA but have
relatively little experience with other drugs.  Our subjects will need to be
between the ages of 21 and 65, be in good medical and psychiatric health and
have had prior first hand experience with the self-administration of MDMA.
The criteria that subjects must be health professionals was recently waived
by the FDA with the stipulation that participants be sufficiently
knowledgeable of the controversy over MDMA's effects that true informed
consent be possible.  Anyone interested in participating in these studies
can call our research coordinator, Carla Edwards, at (310) 222-1663.

FUNDING NEEDED

Although  Dr. Poland and I recently received a small "in-house" grant from
the Harbor-UCLA Research and Education Institute, we must acquire significant
additional funding to carry out our investigational plans. This funding we
have obtained is actually specified for the study extensively evaluating
serotonergic parameters of brain function, and will enable us to collect
pilot data which we will use in a submission to a large government granting
agency. We are at this point without designated funding for the smaller
scale, dose-finding and safety study,  which is a necessary first step for
the work we hope to do with individuals with end-stage medical illness. It is
our strong hope, however, that together with the generous support of MAPS, we
will be able to identify sufficient funding sources which will allow this
work to begin. There is much at stake here.  There are many questions to be
asked and answered.  There are myths to be dispelled. There is new knowledge
to acquire and paths to explore.  This is an exciting time. With the
necessary funding support, we are ready to begin a series of research
investigations which we anticipate will begin to address these very important
issues. With the necessary funding support, we are ready to begin a series of
research investigations which we anticipate will begin to answer these
questions which must be addressed.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Tax-deductable donations to this project may be made through MAPS, 1801 Tippah  
Avenue, Charlotte, NC. 28205.  Phone (704) 358-9830, FAX (704) 358-1650,  
e-mail SYLVIAMAPS@aol.com.

Please specify how much of your donation you would like to have directed  
towards Dr. Grob's MDMA research.  Donors of $30 or more (even if 100%  
designated for the MDMA studies) will receive a one year membership in MAPS.

Becoming a member of the Multidisciplinary Association for Psychedelic
Studies, Inc. (MAPS) and receiving the MAPS newsletter is an excellent way to
stay abreast of the latest developments in psychedelic research around the
world.  In addition, your membership donation will be used to support
research into the medical uses of MDMA, LSD, marijuana, and a cornucopia of
other fascinating compounds.
 

MAPS is an IRS-approved non-profit corporation supported by tax-deductible
contributions from a membership of about seven hundred people and growing.
MAPS  works to develop the medical potential of MDMA and other psychedelics
by assisting researchers around the world to design, obtain governmental
approval for, fund,  conduct and report on psychedelic research.  MAPS is
also involved in research  exploring the medical use of marijuana.  MAPS'
primary goals are to help researchers conduct the studies necessary to
transform MDMA and marijuana into FDA-approved prescription medicines. For
MDMA, this is an estimated ten-year, $10 million project;  for marijuana,
a two-year, $500,000 task.

MAPS offers its members a quarterly newsletter reporting on MAPS-sponsored
and other psychedelic research in progress both in the US and abroad,
political developments that affect psychedelic research and use,  and
conferences, books and articles of interest.  In addition, MAPS offers for
sale various unique publications (for example the protocol submitted to the
FDA for the investigation of the use of MDMA in the treatment of pain and
distress in terminal cancer patients), videotapes (of a MAPS benefit held in
Berkeley in 1990 that featured Jerry Beck, Ram Dass, Bruce Eisner, Rick
Doblin,  Laura Huxley, Emerson Jackson, Mark Kleiman, Timothy Leary, Dennis
McKenna, Terence McKenna, Ralph Metzner, Andrew Weil, and Robert Zanger), and
audiotapes (of a MAPS seminar held in Prague in 1992 featuring Ram Dass, Ken
Ring and Richard Yensen discussing working with the terminally ill with
psychedelics).

I am a so called "newbie" in these parts but have been to a few events 
recently. YSH definitely  had it goin' on!

I hooked up with Ethan and Bryce about a week ago (via the list) and they 
among others have made me feel very welcome. 

I arrived at the space close to 10PM and things hadn't quite got going yet.
I said hi to Ethan and Bryce milled around a little and then found my 
self spinning some of Ethan's records for 25 mins or so until Susan took 
over and got the heavy beats going. 

Susan and I had a pleasant exchange and she told me that I was the first 
male DJ to spin at a YSH event. I must say I feel quite honored and the 
funny thing is it was just so casual and unplanned. There was a real warm 
and open vibe and that's what the "scene" (and Our world) needs!!!

Many thanks to the DJ's, YSH collective and SoundVision for a fun evening.

Onward to the promised land(s)...

					Ronan

"Evoloution is an interpaly between habit and creativity. And creativity 
involves the prodigous production of new forms"

						-Rupert Sheldrake

i apologize for the lack of rave-relation in this post, but its
pertinence to our culture is certain.


/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\
* ATTENTION * CONSUMERS * ATTENTION * CONSUMERS * ATTENTION * CONSUMERS*
/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\//\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/
  
Untested, unlabeled, genetically engineered hormones enter dairy goods.
^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
Starting on Feb. 3, 1994, milk, cheese, butter, ice cream, yogurt, beef,
and infant formula sold and consumed throughout the United States will
contain genetically engineered recombinant Bovine Growth Hormone (rBGH) 
- also know as Bovine Somatotropin (BST). Recently, the U.S. Food and  
Drug Administration (FDA) approved the use of rBGH in dairy cows without 
long-term testing of the hormone's health effects on the consumer.

What is it?
^^^^^^^^^^^
rBGH is a drug which acts to "rev up" the cows system, forcing them to 
produce a higher output of milk, but in the process makes them sick. 
The FDA and Monsanto Chemical (the giant chemical conglomerate that 
won the FDA approval) admit that the cows injected with rBGH suffer 
from increased udder infections (mastitis) and greater stress and 
disease. A multitude of health concerns are currently being debated 
on both sides of this issue and we welcome you to research and decide
about them individually.

Why do we need this in our dairy system?
^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
The simple answer is, WE DON'T. American dairy farmers already produce 
such a massive surplus of milk and cheese that taxpayers spend billions 
to buy up the excess. The use of rBGH to create an even greater milk 
surplus will cost the American taxpayer additional billions in dairy 
price supports. This overproduction of milk caused by rBGH will force 
30 percent of American dairy farmers out of business within 36 months 
of its introduction to the market. For each dairy farmer driven out of 
business, 25 other dairy-related jobs will also be lost.

So why has the FDA approved the use of this drug?
^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
It's happened because chemical and pharmaceutical giants like Monsanto,
Eli Lilly, American Cyanamid, and Upjohn have invested hundreds of 
millions of dollars developing a product that has absolutely no consumer 
benefit, and is potentially dangerous, BUT WILL EARN THEM BILLIONS. The 
risks associated with rBGH use has led the European Economic (EC) to 
make a preliminary decision to ban the use of rBGH until after the year 
2000.

How do we know what we are eating?
^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
You won't be able to avoid eating rBGH contaminated foods because the 
FDA refuses to require labeling of rBGH-derived foods. The FDA decision 
is an outrage considering that, according to recent surveys, more than 
90 percent of consumers favor labeling of rBGH products so they can avoid 
buying them.

How can we overcome this situation?
^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
A MASSIVE CONSUMER BOYCOTT is our only hope for defeat of this product
as well as the thousands of other harmful genetically engineered foods
to come.

The Vegetarian Awareness Committee of the State University of New York 
at Plattsburgh has utilized the following petition arranged by the Pure 
Food Campaign and will forward it to all the major dairy producers in the 
country. If you would like your name added to this petition, please send  
a message to the following address with "I OPPOSE rBGH", your full name,  
and zip code as whole body of the message. We the people can work further 
on-line.

                PICK1731@SPLAVA.CC.PLATTSBURGH.EDU

                                or

                     PICK1731@SNYPLAVA.BITNET  


Where can you get more information?
^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
All information listed here has been supplied by the Pure Food Campaign,
a project of the Foundation on Economic Trends, 1130 17th St., N.W.,
Suite 300, Washington, D.C., 20036 (1-800-451-7670). 

For a partial listing of producers, distributors, brand name companies, 
and supermarket chains that are free of synthetic rBGH please send a 
separate message to PICK1731@SPLAVA.CC.PLATTSBURGH.EDU with "rBGH-FREE 
LIST" as the body of the message.

--> PLEASE FORWARD THIS DOCUMENT TO ANY AND ALL PEOPLE YOU FEEL WOULD BE
--> INTERESTED AND PLEASE REMEMBER TO DELETE PREVIOUS HEADERS IN ORDER TO
--> KEEP THE FORWARDED MESSAGE IN ITS ORIGINAL FORM.

***************************************************************************

Referenced
Vendor
Address

Dear Dairy Vendor/Manufacturer/Seller:

We the undersigned, pledge to boycott foods contaminated with "recomb-
inant Bovine Growth Hormone" (rBGH), and other genetically engineered
food products.

We demand that all milk, dairy, and beef products be clearly labeled as
to whether or not they are derived from cows injected with synthetic
genetically engineered hormones.

We will refuse to purchase milk, dairy, or beef products that do not
bear a label stating that they are rBGH free.

We will patronize only those dairy and beef producers who have pledged,
in a written affidavit, to remain completely rBGH-free.

Signatures

This is going to be one of those "has this ever happened to you" postings -

 The last few times I've gone dancing since I got married , I've noticed 
something odd. It seems that the weight of the wedding ring on my left hand 
is distracting when I get into near-trance state. I think it has to do 
with the difference between the weight of my left and right hands, and the
different inertias of the two hands.

 When I do the trance-dance stuff , I like to use my hands as "vibe" 
sensors ( leaving off for now what "vibe" is defined as ...). The ring seems
to throw my left hand "antenna" out of sync with my right hand "antenna".

 The easiest solution - taking the ring off while I'm dancing - is 
unacceptable , as I might lose it ( even if it's on a chain around my 
neck ). Leaving it at home is not prefferable , since I'm proud to be
married . 

 So , I've asked my wife Mary to find me another ring to put on my right
hand , to balance my hands! I'm going to consider it my "rave ring"...

-------

 Anybody else out there have "problems" with jewelry while dancing?

		Larry "No Larry , just you ..." Ching 
			larryc@netcom.com

	It seems that this subject has never really been explored
	here on sfraves but I think if there ever was a place to talk
	about raving and sex/love this would be it.  First a few qualifiers,
	I'm using the term sexualove to try to be a little more accurate
	and to also side step some flames.  Sexualove is that special energy
	that you feel for (an)other(s) that would or could reach expression
	in a physical (sexual) way.  It doesn't mean that you have to actually
	"have sex" (but it could) but it is a "deeper" feeling then just the
	"platonic" emotions that have readily been shared.

	My questions are:

	1) How has your sex/love life, capacity, expression, etc. changed
	since you have been raving?

	2) For people who are single, do you find it easier or harder to get
	into a sexualove relationship now that you are a raver?

	3) For people in committed relationships, how has raving changed your
	sexualove cycles/behavior?

	4) Is making love to another raver "different" than making love to
	a "non-raver"?

	5) Does the Eros that is generated at some parties (like a Wicked)
	excite you or is it a turn off?

	6) Since you have become a raver, do you think that you are more or less
	open to exploring other sexualove lifestyles then the one you are
	currently practicing?

	7) Do you think ravers are more tolerant of other people's sexualove
	preferences?

	8) If you are at a party and the music is _really_ goin-off and
	a friend comes up to you (that you've wanted for sometime, I
	might add) and wants you to go with them to the chill-out room
	(obviously to make- out); do you go with them or do you stay on the
	dance-floor?

	9) For those of you who trance, how has this affected your sexualove
	life?  Do you enter trance states more easily while making love?  Does
	it get in the way of meeting perspective partners at a party (as in
	you look pretty funny with your eyes crossed :)

	10) How many of you now (or have) made love to music (house or
	otherwise) and how has this experience affected you?


I know some of these questions are pretty intimate, you can use some 
anonymous mailers to reply, if you don't want anyone to know who you are.

geoffw@nexsys.net asks:

> (a number of intimate questions about sex/love vis-a-vis raves
> and parties...>

hmmmm - 

Interesting point that came across my mind as well last week at the Mixmaster
Morris Ambient show. As I tranced to the music for hours and stared across
the carpeted floor literally covered with bodies I couldn't understand how
people were able to keep their expressions of sex/love down to such a muted
level.

Personally, one of the great draws of techno/rave music has been the tantric
rush I get from the big sub-bass slam beat. When I am dancing or listening
and move into a trance state, it seems to be always more grounded in the
earthy/sexual side of the spirit/soul than the lofty/religious ecstacy of
perhaps the Sufi trance dancers. Actually, I'm not that sure that these mind
sets are really that far apart, both being expressions of love and devotion
in their own ways...

As for making love to trance/dance/techno, I have unfortunately found few
partners in the last 20 years or so who were as interested as I in bedding
down to Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan, or Music for Airports, or any of the many
others disks in the library of this sort...(one girlfriend even complained
that Gershwin's "Rhapsody in Blue" had too come off the turntable one evening
because it was 'too compelling'...funny, I thought that was the whole point
of having the stereo on whilst in bed...

> 	My questions are:

> 
> 	2) For people who are single, do you find it easier or harder to get
> 	into a sexualove relationship now that you are a raver?

Hmm, well it seems to be harder to be in relationships with people who are
not in the scene, most of this has to do with the weird sleep cycles and
other forms of night-time activity (like prowling around on remote beaches
at 3 a.m.).  People are much more open and apparently available but if you
spend all of your time dancing...
> 
> 	3) For people in committed relationships, how has raving changed your
> 	sexualove cycles/behavior?

Not Applicable

> 
> 	4) Is making love to another raver "different" than making love to
> 	a "non-raver"?

Well *some* ravers are incredible. I think that once you learn to ride the
wave of the music, then this can apply to other aspects of your life like
love-making.  It seems like once you make love to a raver, you'll find it
hard to "go back" :)

> 
> 	5) Does the Eros that is generated at some parties (like a Wicked)
> 	excite you or is it a turn off?

For me, I absolutely _love_ it.

> 
> 	6) Since you have become a raver, do you think that you are more or less
> 	open to exploring other sexualove lifestyles then the one you are
> 	currently practicing?
> 

I would say more open.

> 	7) Do you think ravers are more tolerant of other people's sexualove
> 	preferences?
> 

There are bigots and homophobes in all groups but I think ravers as a whole
tend to be more tolerant.

> 	8) If you are at a party and the music is _really_ goin-off and
> 	a friend comes up to you (that you've wanted for sometime, I
> 	might add) and wants you to go with them to the chill-out room
> 	(obviously to make- out); do you go with them or do you stay on the
> 	dance-floor?

Well I asked this one because it has happened to me.  ( I opted to keep 
dancing, (being a trance-addict *does* have it's problems) But I've been
looking at this type of behavior lately and I'm not sure it is a good thing.
But I guess I will take each situation as it makes itself available.

> 
> 	9) For those of you who trance, how has this affected your sexualove
> 	life?  Do you enter trance states more easily while making love?  Does
> 	it get in the way of meeting perspective partners at a party (as in
> 	you look pretty funny with your eyes crossed :)

YES! Well um, hmm let's just say that with the right person, sex has taken
on a whole new meaning.  I don't know how much of this is the raving and how 
much is the tantra (is there a difference?)  As far as "going-off" at a party
well I've gotten used to being stared at so as long as I'm among family, I'm
not worried.


> 
> 	10) How many of you now (or have) made love to music (house or
> 	otherwise) and how has this experience affected you?

If you haven't tried it, you should, that's all I'll say.

Subject: Come/Unity tonight


I just talked with Martin O'Brian,  promoter of the Come/Unity rave
tonight,  and he gave me permission to give out the location...

It's held at the same place as the 4th of July Gathering.   Remember
the hill fire?   Same place.    Refreshing your memory,   take 580
out towards Livermore to Vasco Rd.   Go north for about 15 minutes
until you encounter your first stop sign at Camino Diablo Rd,  Right
onto Camino Diablo road,  look for sign saying "Sand Hills Ranch".
You're there... look for the parking folks to guide you to your parking
place.   Yowsa!!    First Outdoor of the year.....   BE THERE!!

CC


--- End of forwarded message from crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Sun, 3 Apr 1994 22:04:00 EST
From: Machine Media <0005995336@mcimail.com>
To: Multiple recipients of list NE-RAVES <NE-RAVES@umdd.umd.edu>
Subject: A Message of PLUR

DEAREST CYBERTRIBE:
        This cool kid (who would make inhuman look old ;) handed me this
flyer. It was badly photocopied on the top half of a piece cheap white
office paper. It was made with a typewriter with artless ballpoint
scribbles, this is what it said (all caps omitted):

        Why are you at this event? The rave scene is not just about
techno. This scene is not just about drugs. This scene is not just about
fashion. It is something special about unity and happiness. It is about
being yourself and being loved for it. It should be a harbor from our
society. But our scene is disintegrating! Old style ravers -- remember
when everyone hugged all the time -- not just to say hello and goodbye?
Remember when people just said hi for no other reason except to be your
friend? Remember how good that felt? Why don't we do it anymore? Newcomers
-- you are wanted and should know that this scene is about openness. We
all share a bond -- the desire to groove to a good beat all night long --
and no man is an island. Everyone needs friends and the outside world is
tough enough. We don't need fronts and attitudes in our scene. Open your
hearts and let the good feelings flow. Look around you, pick a person, ask
them their name, and make a friend. Eliminate boundaries. Open your hearts
and minds. Ravers unite and keep the scene alive!!!


        If U ask me the worlds greatest graphics company could not have
made a better flyer!

:D :) :) :D :) :D :) :D :) :D :) :D :) :D :) :D :) :D :) :D :) :D :) :D :)

PEACE OUT :)

I LOVE U ALL!!!

I got this at RED..
photocopied and on a small piece of paper...

one side said

Are you a radient being full of light and love?
>>Please Respond<<

the other side said

Some things to ask yourself:

ask yourself why you are here.
             what makes you happy and how you can obtain it.
             why you dance
             how wealthy you are
             What true wealth means to you
             How you can share that wealth with the world
             Whether you are being honest w/yourself and your friends
             Whether you will be comfortable with the choices you make
                 today later on in your life
             Why you go to these gatherings
             What these gatherings do for you
             What message the DJ is sending with his/her music
             Whether you trust your self
             Whether that trust should be given away blindly to every
                 person, promoter, or event that comes along
             Whether you know a promoter, why she/he is doing a party and
                 what their track record is
             Whether you are receiving value and where your dollars go.
                 Is a promoter taking more than giving?
             Whether promoters help those who can't afford the full tkt
                 price and why they would(n't)
             Whether you are asking more of others then you are prepared
                 to do yourself
             How you can help your scene grow and flourish-as well as
                 contribute to the success of the events you attend
             Whether you need rest, nourishment or water
             Whether healthy stuff is available should you need it
             Whether water is readily available.  Demand it if it isnt
             If you would like to share it
             What your reasons are for (not) doing the drugs you do
             Whether you know exactly what you are ingesting and what it
                 does to your body
             What the motives are behind the information that comes your
                 way
             If you need time alone to find your truth
             If you want to share that truth with others who are willing to
                listen
             How your lifestyle impacts out planet, live accordingly
             Why positive energy attracts positive energy
Ask yourself because ultimately the answers come from within

Live the light, love to all

Souls for total freedom, Montreal Div.

Feel free to copy, post, and distribute this information- its free!

(Special than to Ministry of Love for inspiring us to action)

________________________________________________________________________

I love it

I wish people would remember what this is about

It isnt about doing so much K that you cant move, and it isnt about having
every piece of clothing Addidas ever put out, and it isnt about knowing
everyone or being a promoter or a Dj or knowing the right people...it is
about having fun and loving everyone and dancin' to the beats...

After this weekend and that post I feel so loveydovey rave-ish

Peace to all

(I love this 'rave' stuff......)


john g.

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Mon, 4 Apr 1994 00:09:57 -0400
From: secret agent #33 <cmellow@world.std.com>
To: Multiple recipients of list NE-RAVES <NE-RAVES@umdd.umd.edu>
Subject: Re: A Message of PLUR

me and jeannie got this flyer in detroit over thanksgiving and i always
thought it was really cool.  good to see that the same type of flyers are
now circulating in the north east.  maybe someone should make up some
ne-raves messages of p.l.u.r. or whatever you want to call them.

this flyer was printed on acetate paper (the clear overhead projection
shit) :)

Underground Unite
what makes these underground events so special? it is the openness and
unity that can be expressed at them. we all share a bond...the desire to
groove to a good beat all night long...and no person should ever feel
isolated. in the underground, each individual is an interconnected part
of the experience.  everyone needs friends in an outside world which is
so tough.  this scene is about being yourself and being loved for it. it
is a harbor from our society. allow the freedom you experience at these
events let you rediscover your instinctive love for humanity. let's all
open our hearts and let the good feelings flow.  look around you, pick a
person, ask them their name and make a friend.  let's eliminate boundries
and open our hearts and minds.


i think everyone should make up their own version and print them out on
anything you have.  then give 'em to people :)

chris

armwaving-type aerobics.  theweight of the ring (about 8 grams) seemed

> >>>  My daughter & I had just finished a salad at Neiman-Marcus Cafe
> >>>in Dallas & decided to have a small dessert.  Because our family
> >>>are such cookie lovers, we decided to try the "Neiman-Marcus
> >>>Cookie". It was so excellent that I asked if they would give me
> >>>the recipe and they said with a small frown, "I'm afraid not."
> >>>Well, I said, would you let me buy the recipe?  With a cute
> >>>smile, she said, "Yes."  I asked how much, and she responded,
> >>>"Two fifty." I said with approval, just add it to my tab.
> >>>
> >>>  Thirty days later, I received my VISA statement from
> >>>Neiman-Marcus and it was $285.00.  I looked again and I
> >>>remembered I had only spent $9.95 for two salads and about $20.00
> >>>for a scarf.  As I glanced at the bottom of the statement, it
> >>>said, "Cookie Recipe - $250.00."  Boy, was I upset!! I called
> >>>Neiman's Accounting Dept. and told them the waitress said it was
> >>>"two fifty," and I did not realize she meant $250.00 for a cookie
> >>>recipe.  I asked them to take back the recipe and reduce my bill
> >>>and they said they were sorry, but all the recipes were
> >>>this expensive so not just everyone could duplicate any of their
> >>>bakery recipes....the bill would stand.  I waited, thinking of
> >>>how I could get even or even try and get any of my money back.
> >>>
> >>>I just said, "Okay, you folks got my $250.00 and now I'm going to
> >>>have $250.00 worth of fun." I told her that I was going to see to
> >>>it that every cookie lover had a $250.00 cookie recipe from
> >>>Neiman-Marcus for nothing. She replied, "I wish you wouldn't do
> >>>this." I said, "I'm sorry but this is the only way I feel I can
> >>>get even," and I will.
> >>>
> >>>  So, here it is, and please pass it to someone else or run a few
> >>>copies....I paid for it; now you can have it for free.
> >>>(Recipe may be halved.):
> >>>
> >>>2 cups butter                  4 cups flower
> >>>2 tsp. soda                    2 cups sugar
> >>>5 cups blended oatmeal**      24 oz. chocolate chips
> >>>2 cups brown sugar             1 tsp. salt
> >>>1  8 oz. Hershey Bar (grated)  4 eggs
> >>>2 tsp. baking powder           3 cups chopped nuts
> >>>2 tsp. vanilla                        (your choice)
> >>>
> >>>  Cream the butter and both sugars.  Add eggs and vanilla; mix
> >>>together with flour, oatmeal, salt, baking powder, and soda.  Add
> >>>chocolate chips, Hershey Bar and nuts.
> >>>  Roll into balls and place two inches apart on a cookie sheet.
> >>>Bake for 10 minutes at 375 degrees.  Makes 112 cookies.
> >>>
> >>>** measure oatmeal and blend in a blender to a fine powder.
> >>>
> >>>Have fun!!!  This is not a joke --- this is a true story..
> >>>
> >************************************************************
> >
> >>>  That's it. Please, pass it along to everyone you know, single
> >>>people, mailing lists, etc.....
>

Hello everyone,

This is just a quick report on the Mother Earth party Saturday and to give
you an idea of upcoming events.  Our one-year anniversary was a wonderful
reminder of why we started doing free outdoor parties in the first place
-- a small, intimate gathering of friends and like-minded folks who came
together to celebrate music, dance, and nature out in the fresh air of the
Berkeley Marina.  We were able to party until about 10:30 pm, when a
Berkeley cop showed up and asked us to leave (almost nervously, I
thought), which we did with no real disappointment, as we had planned on 
ending around 10 or 11 anyway.

Thanks to the 100 or so people who came throughout the course of the 
afternoon and evening, bringing food, bubbles (thanks Sean!), and great 
vibes all around!  

Super big thank you to Ethan and Bryce for *SoundVision*, which 
definitely lived up to all the descriptions I had heard of it!

As for upcoming tings...

* * * * *

VIVID
in memory of Gabriel Cesar
Friday, April 8
Wool, Ethan, Drew, James(SC), Scottie & Stonie
(415) 292-3289

* * * * *

Jazz Brunch at Chateau
with the BROUN FELLINIS and DJs
Saturday, April 9
noon til later
come be our guests and enjoy some good food and great acid jazz!
2545 Hillegass in Berkeley, email or call me for more info (510) 549-6233

* * * * *

Chateaupia End of the Semester Blow-Out
Saturday, April 30
featuring the Mother Earth DJs and guests

* * * * *

Mother Earth Sound System #2
middle of May sometime

* * * * *

June New Moon Festival Party

* * * * *

We'll keep you all fully posted!!!

Peace + respect,

			
			MOTHER EARTH SOUND SYSTEM
			*************************
			>>>respect your mother<<<
			*************************
			UNITE  CELEBRATE  SURVIVE

From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)

Subject: Des Moines cracks down on raves

  [My official opinion on the matter is that raves are a very safe
  place for kids to go--far better than the usual alternatives.
  Trying to tell bored kids to stay home is like trying to tell them
  that abstinence is the best way to deal with their sex drive. The
  best thing to do, in my opinion, is accept human nature instead of
  stifling it. Provide safety without disruptive interference.

  Is it not ironic that in parts of the city, it is very unsafe to
  walk around at night, while police will aggressively respond to a
  party that doesn't have the proper "permits"? What's wrong with this
  picture? -Sean]

DES MOINES, Iowa (AP) -- Dancing in the dark can get you arrested in
Des Moines.

The city is using a 1950s ordinance to crack down on all-night dance
parties known as ``raves.'' Officials say they're concerned about
safety, underage drinking and noise.

Organizers of raves say young people are being singled out unfairly.

``We just want to be able to dance longer -- that's the whole idea,''
Chris Goodwin said. ``We want to offer Des Moines something for the
youth to do.''

Raves, with their hard bass, techno-music and outrageous light shows,
became popular in Europe before reaching the United States.  They
caught on in 1992 in Des Moines, where raves have been held mostly in
warehouses.

City officials were investigating whether a planned rave had proper
noise and fire permits when they discovered an ordinance that barred
dancing after 2 a.m., said Cara Gill, an administrative assistant to
the city manager.

City Councilman Tom Vlassis said no one had been charged under the
ordinance for 10 years until the past month, when three people were
charged. The penalty is 30 days in jail or a $100 fine. The cases are
pending.

``It's not a move to stop raves. It's not a move to stop dances,''
Vlassis said. ``It's a move to define what the citizens of Des Moines
want and to help protect the citizens of Des Moines.''

For example, Gill said, raves shouldn't be allowed to operate all
night in residential areas if businesses there can't. And raves
shouldn't be allowed to play loud music all night if bars have to turn
down the volume.

Howdy , Brian and whoever else is reading this, I,m from Oz and read
your little article about "outdoor" raves as we call them and sounds
like you have a lot of trouble putting these things on. Down here
(in Adelaide) we don't seem to have all that much trouble with cops
etc and venues are much easier to find due to the fact that there is
a lot of open space around here. The way we seem to get around the
cop situation is by only letting out the location of the rave hours
before it actually begins by the way of a pre-arranged meeting place
around town. The best idea we have had was to put a rave out in the
middle of a vineyard in the Barrossa Valley, put up a marquee shove
in some speakers, lights etc and away you go, the cops didn't show
their faces at all and everyone had a good time. The best type of
venues are the ones you find accidentally. No alcohol is the best
medicine as far as no problems with d...heads are concerned just fly
high on your own adrenalin or maybe with some extra help from some
little tablet etc.! 
What is the music like over there? Down here in Adelaide we are
mainly into the Hardcore style of music (Lenny Dee etc) but some
pommie DJ that was down here called it a bit like Jungle music. By
the way Carl Cox is a fucking legend!!
If you liked to write back about your "rave" scene and tell me about
it cause I write for the local dance/rave magazine and could do an
article about how different our scene is compared to yours!
See Ya later!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!


--- End of forwarded message from Karl Cornel <cornel@ist.flinders.edu.au>

Wait a minute. What is illegal: organizing a dance (in which case
the three people are the organizers), or the physical dancing
(in which case the three people are three ravers who were dancing)?

If it's the latter, this is too funny. The article says the
orginance bars 'dancing after 2 a.m.'... what if you're dancing
at home??  8-)

If it's the former, that's too bad, but I really can't say I'm
surprised. I grew up in southern Minnesota (not all that far
from Des Moines) and you're talking about an area of the
country that closes liquor stores at 8pm and bars at 1am. And
doesn't allow liquor sales on Sunday. Get the picture? The
whole world isn't like S.F...

From: jocelyn@hal.com (Jocelyn Cordell)

To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: oh yeah!

I (we) need some help/info/input.

The SJ Women's Collective _will_ be hosting free, outdoor 
events every 3rd Sunday of the month. Yes, that means 
April 17. The location is La Raza picnic area in Hellyer 
park. This location has bathrooms, picnic tables, a 
barbeque pit, and a small, but more than sufficient, 
bandstand and dance floor. 

These events are being modeled after Emma's Easter 
Birthday Party- which happened this past weekend.
I would guess about 150 people showed up. Mei Lwun, 
Wool, Julius Papp, Harry Who, and Rick Preston laid the 
dope egg beats out on the grass for us to hunt for. 
There was no particular order- whoever brought records 
was welcome to play. We would like this open format to 
continue, though it does depend on people showing up.
(Here's where you come in) If you want to play, just let 
me know. Being a women's collective, we're especially 
interested in having some women play. with any luck at 
all, we'll be luring Tara our way for the next go, and
Harry Who has said that he would like to play as well.

And speaking of playing- there were lots of frisbees,
hackey-sacks, soccer balls, complete whiffle ball-n-bat
sets, dogs, food, kids, etc.... but NO alcohol!
(well, maybe I did see a few beers coiffed with the 
utmost of discretion and mellowness.) So, bring your toys,
kids, friends, anything and everything to share.
And, yes, the barbeque pit was on fire!

The park rangers stopped by to say a very courteous hello,
and went on their merry way. the police also stopped by, 
checked the permits, said hello, and went on their merry way.

If all goes well with the rangers and the cleanliness of the site, 
we are hoping to leave a rolling trash deposit ($100) to hold 
the site every 3rd Sunday. For the deposit, we have the space from
8 am 'til dusk; but we'll probably start around noon or one.
The SJ women's collective will also pick up the sound permits 
($165 per gig, non-refundable). 

Here's what we need help with: you guessed it: the equipment!
turntables & sound system. We have (owned outright) a 
generator (It's sitting in Emma's garage), but a generator 
does not a party make. Any ideas where we might find something 
fairly cheap? *wink*nudge*nudge* Scottie? Bryce? Ethan?

Any other ideas? Wanna spin? Let me know, and mark your calendars.

Take care-

Jocelyn

From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)
Message-Id: <199404051909.MAA27739@mail.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Easter Weekend rave report
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Weekend Rave report
-------------------

Sorry to be a tad late on this one,   but Internet Connections
between WELL and Netcom were flakey at best.    Anyway,   here 
is what happened this weekend through my eyes and experience.

After dancing my ass off at "Your Sisters House" (YSH) this last
Thursday,   and being as strong as I have ever been,   I was "Chomping
at the bit" to get into even more dancing and raving this weekend.

So I check the SFRaves calander and see the following events to
attend this weekend...

Saturday, April 2nd - The One-Year Reunion of the Mother Earth Sound System
        Brad  Scottie  Stonie  Markie
        around 3 pm to about 11 pm
        'This'll be a picnic-flavor party, complete with veggie BBQ and other
        goodies.  It'd be great if we could make this a pot-luck type
        gathering, so if you can bring some grub, please do!
        Remember, "Always free, always outdoors" 
        Location info: (510) 814-2402  (415) 487-7655

Saturday, April 2nd - Basics + Come/Unity
        Garth  Tony  Josh  Simon  Doran  Jeno  & Dubtribe  
        in the ambient room: jason  nick philip  jonah
        - planned for outdoors -
        415.905.9629  415.241.8815
        [no "first Wednesday" Come/Unity this month]

As seen above,   it looks like two really great events were planned,
so I could go to both,  and I did.

Unfortunately,   due to a lot of work I had to do this weekend,
I couldn't get down to the "One year Reunion of MESS until sometime
after 9 pm,   but when I arrived,   the scene was really hopping,
it was FREE,  and had a wonderful time warming up,  getting ready for
Basics + Come/Unity.   Unfortunately,  the pigs busted it up fairly early,
but did happen to get in a lot of dancing before that happened.

We arrived at the site (Which I will NOT disclose this time,  due
to a lot of flack I got from earlier postings),  which we had no problem
finding.

The site was really great...   A grassey park,   pretty far removed
from other places,  so noise shouldn't be a problem.  

The vibe was really great,   luv phasers were shooting all over the
place,  smiles and happy faces on just about everyone.    Really
fun time...  The cop that shut us down was fairly nice,   and after
the music stopped,  we were asked to sit around in a circle and were
thanked for showing up and having a good time.

Afterwards,  we had to go back to SF,  and pick up a few more friends 
before heading out to Come/Unity,  which was held out at the Livermore 
racetracks.   This was at the same place the Gathering was held last 
4th of July.   When we got to the site,  it was really windy, dusty 
and cool.    Lyons handled the security,  and all cars had to be 
searched for weapons,  and other things,  but we didn't mind that.    
The cost was a whopping $20 to get in (Rather steep in my opinion),  
but the sound system was totally awsome.

Huge banks of speakers really filled the area with clean bassey sounds,
and almost ANYWHERE in the area was suitable for dancing.   

Once I started dancing,  I didn't mind the cold and the wind,  and after
a while,  eventually the cold wind failed to cool me down.   It sure was 
great to be able to dance for hours at a time without over-heating,  but 
with  the intense sound energy and my insane dancing,   I had to eventually
stop and cool down.   Yow!  I went totally beserk...    

I must have missed DubTribe,  or been totally spaced out to have not
noticed them,  but the other DJ's  Simon especially really gave me
a total workout.   I think I danced his entire set non-stop.  Oh!
How I love those outside raves...

When Jeno went on,  I practically left the planet...  was out there 
among the stars somewhere.   As Dawn was approaching,  I was still going
strong,  all the way till the end,  then eventually, Jeno faded out the
music.    People yearned for more,  but when Mertin finally gave the
go-ahead for one more song,   the power had already been cut.

We finally packed our stuff,  and headed out to the car for the very long
2 hour drive back to SF.   Somehow I finally made it back,  and we head
for the new re-encarnation of Boogy Buffet,  now called "Light-n-up",
with a new type of acid jazz (Slighly different),   but no $2 breakfast
like before (I really miss that).   Light-n-up was held at 1015 Folsom
st.    Same as Boogey Buffet,   and promoted by Preston.

I also stopped by "Good Houskeeping" at 1190 Folsom st.   But the place
was practically deserted.   They did serve breakfast there,  but with
no money,   I headed back to Light-n-up.

This Easter Sunday was the opening night of Light-n-up,  so it wasn't
as crowded as the origional Boogy Buffet.   I suspect thats to change
as more and more people realize it's back again.

I also visited the End Up of course,   as it was a warm and beautiful
day.  It's really great to have 3 after-parties all within close walking 
distance to each other.

I finally left the End-up around 5 pm dancing all Sunday as well,
still going strong.    We went into Daylight time on Sunday as
well,  so had lots of daylight for my after-rave hike to the waterfalls
near where I live. 

I'm really glad to see the scene this year will be yet another raving
year for me,  and I yearn for the chance to travel to other places and
raves sometime this summer.

Keep the scene alive and kickin...
Cap'n Crunch

as some of you may know i am currently going to college down at cal
poly.  that would be 4 hours south of SF.  I work at the college radio
station here.  after a ton of work and all i have gotten all the things
together and had a house/acid/trance/tribal show. (yeah!!!)

It is called RHYTHUM ASYLUM and is on 10-11pm on monday nights

thru trial by fire im learning alot.  but i have two messages for the
net:

1) i would like to get as many differnt sounds and styles on the air as
possible so if any of the DJ's out there would like to get there set on
here is a formal (well kinda formal) request for it.  Dont really expect
any one to drive 4 hrs down here (if you want to great).  rather, maybe
a tape mixed for the show and an interview would be the best.  if your
intrested mail me.

2) for those of you that are involved in record labels (house music OR
ANYTHING ELSE) or involed with bands etc and you would like to get air
play talk to me and i'll get the stuff promo'd to the people here.  no
promises about pushing it thru.  KCPR is the station, it is somewhere in
the top 20 college ststions nation wide. mail me or call 805.782.4544
(my home)

this is a quick note on different styles in the mix;

i like it. recently in my mixing im tring more and more to mix stuff up
style wise.  im tring to get that sound that goes from acid to diva
sampled house and bach to acid or acid trance.  here is why other than i
simply like parts of both sounds.  acid is a harder edge that gets me
moving and trips me BUT too much dark stuff and i feel like a T800
(moive ref.)  now the houser and euro sounds are warmer and makes feel
warm and good BUT too much (especially diva) makes me feel like im in
saturday night fever (another moive ref) SO these sounds and feelings
balance each other out, like chocolate and peanut butter they can go
together nicly

(:-)
CHE

Subject: Basics-Jazid Up-"Bass Closing Party"
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I went to Jazid Up on Monday night....Yeah, it was clubby, yeah it was very
hot on the dance floor, yeah, the dance floor was crowded, but  Mark Farina
and Julius are the real SpinDocors.  They both were working it!!! Trancey,
funkadunk and ravey.........God, you gotta like horns...Brass and Big Bass. 
It touched my homesick Chicago soul. On a Monday night..packed from 11.00 to
4:00am. I drove back down to Monterey, and it felt like a ghost town. I'm
starting not to like my little paradise by the sea. Would someone please move
it 100 miles up the coast, so my Beemer doesn't die a premature death?

However, I've plans to create a rave scene here by throwing a few renegade
parties in the summer. I'm be asking some of you for advice, and invite you
all to a Big Sur Renegade, or a Carmel Valley Renegade party.  Would you come
down to celebrate the closing of Fort Ord? "A Bass Closing
Renegade"...........

Anyway, I did make it to Basics. Driving near 3 hours to get there, I pull
off before Vasco Rd and run right into Cap Crunch in a gas station.  I was
happy to be going back to the site of my first rave, Let Freedom Rave.....on
July 4th.  Now I know why my friends were so excited that it was my first
rave because it was so great. By comparison, (and comparisons can be so
cruel) I was disappointed in the Basics turnout. Fear of Rain? Easter
Weekend? Why didn't they come? I didn't feel a real connected vibe there
either ( or maybe just me?) 

Sound system was cranking, Simon and Josh wore me out. I'm still spitting the
dust out of my mouth. 

I'm going to Motion on Wed. to see Garth and Rick Preston. Hope to see some
sfravers there.  Oh well, another 500 mile weekend. See ya!!
Robertj..........Monterey Rave Posse...DJ Roadmaster.....Dj MotorHead, aka.

>From robcamp@seas.gwu.edu  Fri Apr  1 04:31:04 1994
From: "Robert N. Campanell" <robcamp@seas.gwu.edu>
Date: Fri, 1 Apr 94 07:30:56 -0500
To: ne-raves@umdd.umd.edu, sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Documentary about our community

  PLUR is a forthcoming documentary about the rave/house community.  It
  focuses on every aspect of the community and the people who have
  made it a central part of their lives for the past few years. 
  
  The theme of this documentary is look at the rave/house community in
  1994.  The primary audience is the community itself.  We
  intended to create an introspective documentary. Our goal is to
  give an accurate description of the positive contributions our
  community has made to society.
  
  The following is list of activities that people are doing that
  define the community.
  
  
                                Musicians
                              Computer nets
                                   DJs
                   Graphic Artists who make the flyers
             The people who treasure their flyer collections
                              Photographers
                             Event promoters
                             Scene promoters
                People who organize bus rides to events.
                  People who organize charitable events
                              Video Artists
                           Record store owners
                           Clothing designers
                            'Zine publishers
                              Smart drinks
                                     
  
  This documentary is being produced by Rob Campanell and Todd
  Porter Boedeker.  Rob will cover the east coast (DC, Balt.
  Philly, NYC) and Todd will cover the San Francisco area.  We
  intend to conduct interviews from April through May.  Expected
  completion date is September 1994.
  
  We intend to submit the documentary for broadcast on U Network, a
  national network of college television stations.  Both Rob and
  Todd have been involved with programs on U Network.  Rob is the
  producer of "Cyberia"; Todd has been the host of "Video
  Underground".  They have also produced and directed music videos for
  techno acts Paperboy 2000 and Axon.
  
  We would like your support for this project.  We have been
  involved in the community since it's early days here in the
  U.S.  We believe it's special and feel there is a need to present
  a sincere video document about the community.
  
  Our goal is to portray the rave/house community that we know, in the
  best way that we can, in 28 minutes.  It might not be as complete
  as some people would like, but we hope it will be sincere and
  honest.
  
  
  Rob Campanell
  Todd Porter Boedeker
  
  
  P.S.  A limited quanity of video will be available for purchase.  At 
  this point, we are focusing our efforts on getting the project completed.  
  We will post information on how to obtain a copy of the video at a later 
  date.
  


----------------------------------------------------------------------

>From sybex!afeinber@netcom.com Tue Apr  5 10:45:21 1994
Date:  Tue, 05 Apr 94 09:32:39 PDT
From: Alissa Feinberg <AFEINBER@sybex.com>
Sender: afeinber@sybex.com
To: <sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU>
Subject:  Re: Dancing & Jewelry

My wedding ring also used to throw me off (when I had a ring...we're 
still married but ringless). Oddly enough, part of the reason we're now 
ringless is that we were both having centering problems. Also our 
lifestyles just don't support ring-wearing.

In martial arts classes my instructors would insist on my taking off ALL 
jewelry, mostly because of the safety hazard, but I was also told that 
the jewelry would throw "off" my perception and awareness..

While dancing I did notice that I compensated, got used to it and 
became able to focus on other things again. For dancing or other 
non-threatening experiences it took a few months to get balanced out. 
In emergency situations (getting mugged) I didn't notice the jewelry at 
all.

In meditation these days I do notice my jewelry. It does seem to effect 
the flow of energy, especially on my ears where the pierces are not 
symmetrical. I have a tongue piercing (centered) which becomes 
REALLY enhanced during meditation, though in dancing it has never 
bothered except that I do worry if I'm playing with it that I'll bite my 
tongue! Over time I've been able to work with it by focusing on it and 
then forcing myself to move on to other things.

I think you'll probably get used to your ring, though the "rave ring" idea 
is great and you will be truly more balanced.

Alissa

From sfraves-owner  Wed Apr  6 11:16:49 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA12460; Wed, 6 Apr 94 11:16:49 PDT
Received: from pilot.njin.net by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA12453; Wed, 6 Apr 94 11:16:42 PDT
Received: by pilot.njin.net (5.59/SMI4.0/RU1.5/3.08) 
	id AA04155; Wed, 6 Apr 94 14:15:52 EDT
Date: Wed, 6 Apr 94 14:15:52 EDT
From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9404061815.AA04155@pilot.njin.net>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: You're on Film!
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Okay, so like I'm dancing, really jammin having a wonderful time, and
I realize that someone has been videotaping me. I don't mind...I've
thought of taping a few events myself.

But it disturbs me to think that I might end up in a video in a store
someday. That people outside the scene, who don't _understand_, might
be watching me and judging me.

I like to think of raves as a TAZ, a private space where one can be
totally free with one's mind and body. That's pretty hard to do when
there's a video camera pointed in your direction. It's worse when one
finds out that such videos have been copied and sold in stores to
anyone who wants to buy them.

Strictly speaking, selling such a videotape is illegal because it is
not news, people are clearly identifyable, and there is no release
form signed. That's invasion of privacy, and can be punished with some
fairly stiff penalties. As a photographer, it's pretty routine for me
to get model releases of people I photograph. Otherwise, distributing
or selling the photos is out of the question.  Some of these
videotapes don't seem to be made with the same consideration, and that
bothers me. If it were consentual (a very important word in my
vocabulary), that would be fine. But so far I've never seen a
videographer asking permission or getting model releases, or even an
event ticket that says "You may be taped without compensation."
(Which, by the way, only allows extremely limited use of the images.)

So far, I'm not a victim. I try and avoid videotapers, and I forgive
the disruption. But if I were victimized, I'd ask the producer not to
sell the tape, and aggressively pursue it in court if refused.

Well, that's my views on being taped...

Sean

 >

 > >   The theme of this documentary is look at the rave/house community in
 > 
 > >   The following is list of activities that people are doing that
 > >   define the community.
 > >      
 > >                                 Musicians
 > >                               Computer nets
 > >                                    DJs
 > >                    Graphic Artists who make the flyers>

 > >                               Photographers
 > >                              Event promoters
 > >                              Scene promoters
 > >                 People who organize bus rides to events.
 > >                   People who organize charitable events
 > >                               Video Artists
 > >                            Record store owners
 > >                            Clothing designers
 > >                             'Zine publishers
 > >                               Smart drinks
 >    
 
 Even more than the physical realities, even more than the enhanced 
 realities, even more than the ravers themselfs, there are the 'epic 
 adventures' some of us have taken to get to, or home from a party. 
 
 I remember 3500 kids at the santa rosa fairgrounds, all kicked on to the 
 highway at 7am, kicked out of a party they thought would go till 
 11. Camped out in an isuzu work truck with a broken speedo, searching 
 for a radio station we could stand, the pickup drove itself past 85-90 
 cars with 'if' stickers and flower stickers and drivers with sunglasses to 
 dim the morning sun, all trying to color between the lines, south 
 down 101, south back to the city, through farms with no fences, 'cause 
 the cows can't go that far from home.
 
 Out side the fairground gates there was an old man sitting at a stop 
 sign, probly on his way to the hardware store to buy a tool to fix 
 something, that gently asked me and my friend as we crossed in front of 
 his car, "What's goin' on at the fairgrounds this morning?" and Jon 
 turned and said with a smile, "Nothin' man. Just a dance party..."
 
 -baron

Hi!  There's been a little confusion about the time of the New Moon party, so
I called up Glen & Mona, who are organizing it, to ask what the deal.

According to Glen, the party will start about 4 or so in morning Sunday
morning...that's kind of like Sat. night, I guess!  Since the new moon
(astronomically speaking) is actually during the day sunday, Glen said
that the party will be more of a day party than before.  The idea is also
to take in the sunrise as well as all the beautiful stars!  And then
enjoy the fabulous weather on the beach all day Sunday.

Hope to see you all there!!!

There will be a VOCE gathering Fri. 4/8 at  8pm at OM Body Yoga Center
234c Fell St., S.F.

VOCE is an environment of consciousness in which individuals share their 
creative process. These activities are in the shamanic tradition of 
performance, celebration and listening. This organically expanding 
community of creative people is committed to the nurturing of the 
individual voice and self-esteem - personal healing through shared 
creativity.

Check it out. Great vibes. Small donation requested.

From: laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Thu, 7 Apr 1994 13:24:24 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: sfraves-request
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


A while ago sfraves was put under "majordomo" list management
software, which made the sfraves-request address obselete.

To get off sfraves mail majordomo@techno.stanford.edu and
put 

unsubs*ribe sfraves

in the body of your message, but replace the * in my example with a c

If you forget this method never fear, subscription information is
appended to the end of the weekly calendar that Larry posts.

I *think* there is a bug in majordomo that can prevent some addresses
from being properly unsubbed.  If you have trouble because of this
let Brian know, he can be reached at brian@techno.stanford.edu
(same address as the sfraves list, just his name, so it's fairly
easy to remember).

If you are having a real emergency, you can try contacting me and I
will prod Brian in person for you.



Wanting to be helpful,

Laura

Lotsa variety this weekend: housey (Wicked) to technoey (Apocalypse)
to trancey(Test), a benefit (Vivid), freebies (Spiral Jive, new moon
party), big parties (Wicked, Apocalypse), little parties (new moon,
maybe some of the others), indoor parties (Wicked, Test, etc), outdoor
parties (Spiral Jive, new moon party), etc etc.  So there's something
for everyone this weekend!


-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Friday, April 8th - Vivid 
        Wool  Ethan  James (SC)  Drew  Scottie & Stonie  Meme
        $5 w/canned food, in the hills of Santa Cruz.  
        profits will be donated to Santa Cruz shelter, The Pajaro Mission;
        This party is in memory of Gabriel Ceasar, who was killed at a party 
        in Santa Cruz one year ago.  415.292.3289

On Mon, 4 Apr 1994, Randy Tinkerman wrote:

> Why is sugar so much a part of raving?  Isn't that (bleached) stuff
> really unhealthy?

Because people like them.  I never really liked to chew on Blow Pops.  I 
thought they were too big and they make to want even more water.  I do 
like StarBursts though and original BubbleGum flavor Extra.

> Aren't there better things to use to keep your juice up & mouth wet?

Water is best and then when you're hungry, oranges and bananas are 
great.  I feel so energized after having a nice juicy orange and banana.

From sfraves-owner  Thu Apr  7 15:57:08 1994

	id AA09151; Thu, 7 Apr 94 15:57:08 PDT
Received: from pathogen.ecst.csuchico.edu by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA09132; Thu, 7 Apr 94 15:56:49 PDT
Received: (from unibrow@localhost) by pathogen.ecst.csuchico.edu (8.6.8/8.6.6) id PAA07508 for sfraves@techno.stanford.edu; Thu, 7 Apr 1994 15:56:44 -0700
From: Don Littlefield II <unibrow@ecst.csuchico.edu>
Message-Id: <199404072256.PAA07508@pathogen.ecst.csuchico.edu>
Subject: Weird thing happened...
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Thu, 7 Apr 1994 15:56:44 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 1000      
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Heya all,

This past weekend at Basics I had a very unusual experience (for me). 
Basically what happened was this.  I was dancing.....for how long, I 
dont know.  I remember groovin pretty hard though.  I dont know how much
time had passed, but someone bumped me.  And I opened my eyes (I dance 
with them shut).  I was looking at the hill behind the DJ and it was lit
up by the laser show.  I didnt know where the hell I was.  After a 
second or two I remembered where I was.  It was weird!!!!!!!!  
Like I was groovin so hard I actually forgot about everything that was 
going on around me and entered a dance zombie state.  I was dead sober too 
which made it even a more cool thing.  The only thing I can equate the 
feeling to is being knocked out by a nitrous hit and waking up not knowing 
what happened.  Anyway..  It was cool.    
-- 
                            Don Littlefield II
                         unibrow@ecst.csuchico.edu
                    Chico State University, California 


From sfraves-owner  Thu Apr  7 16:16:46 1994

Date: Thu, 07 Apr 1994 17:14:04 -0600
From: Luke Youngblood <LUKEY@wordperfect.com>
To: psiborg@halcyon.com, sunkim@sfsuvax1.sfsu.edu
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject:  Re: From the cookie monster -Reply
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

	I think that lack of food in general tends to do you in after you've
been at a party for 5 or 6 hours.  I mean, most people probably
haven't eaten since dinner Saturday evening, and the party started at
midnight, so by 6 or 7 in the morning, you're famished.  But, you
probably didn't realize you were famished because the walls are still
melting...  I like to bring quick energy snacks like candy bars and
stuff like that.  Fruit is really good, but it doesn't have very many
calories.  Calories are what you need if you're dancing for a long
time.  So, you could eat pasta all day before the party and get some
good long-lasting calories, or you could eat a Snickers or
something... (and be satisfied :)

>>> Peter J Schenk <psiborg@halcyon.com>  4/7/94, 04:34pm >>>

From: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf)
Date: Fri, 8 Apr 1994 02:22:19 -0700
In-Reply-To: Sun Kim <sunkim@sfsuvax1.sfsu.edu>
       "Question about 21+ places..." (Apr  7,  3:06pm)
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: Sun Kim <sunkim@sfsuvax1.sfsu.edu>, SF Raves <sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU>
Subject: Re: Question about 21+ places...
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

On Apr 7,  3:06pm, you proclaimed:
} Why are some clubs 18+ and others 21+?  If the only difference is that 
} one doesn't serve alcohol and the other does, then why are the clubs 21+ 
} since alcohol is usually looked down upon away?
} 
} (I don't know if I make sense but I hope someone can answer.)

Because for most established clubs their main source of income is
alcohol, so they don't even bother trying to get 18+ licenses.  Also,
the city has established a couple arcane loopholes to make getting an
18+ license hard - such as requiring the place to serve food 3 nights
a week, etc.  However, there are places which are 18+ all night, so no
one can tell me it's impossible for places that really care.  I do
remember that around the time of Alternity (October 92?) 1015 Folsom
had a sign in their window saying they were applying for their 18+
permit, but I guess nothing ever came of that.  

The 21+ schism is a lot more dangerous than most people realize, in my
mind, and I think it's contributed to a lot of the friction and
division in the scene here.  In effect, the scene has been sharply
divided between 21+ parties that go on every week (Wicked, anything at
174 King or 1015 Folsom, etc) and 18+ parties (Basics, 16th & Harrison
parties, outdoors, etc).  Only at a couple events - full moons,
Gatherings, Your Sisters' House, etc - do both groups actually have a
chance to interact.  The problem I see is that in my opinion each
fraction needs the other - the younger crowd needs the maturity and
wisdom of the older crowd, and the older crowd needs the dynamicism
and energy and creativity of the younger crowd.  Both groups have
stagnated in the absence of the other.  The clubs used to be a lot
less strict about their age limits, often letting in 18+ after 2am
when they couldn't serve alcohol anyways, but the police have gotten
more severe in their monitoring and punishing, (*3rd* offense -
$125,000!!)  so clubs have really tightened up.


	Unfortunately, those with the power to change this (the club
owners, who fought IN FAVOR of keeping the curfew laws in effect)
don't care, and those who have the power to influence those with the
power (I.e. YOU - the party-goers, the party-throwers, etc) mostly
don't think it matters much, either.  So the schism persists.  Even
though I've crossed the age barrier recently, I'm not going to give
any strictly 21+ place my business, unless they have been trying to
get an 18+ license or allow them in after a certain time.  Period.
I used to say things like the above, and still sneak into 21+ parties,
until someone called me on it amd I realized I was being a hypocrite
by going to 21+ parties.  It's not a problem, really - there are still 
lots of 18+ parties around anyways.  

	Sorry to vent my spleen.... 

	Brian
