On Thu, 7 Apr 1994, Luke Youngblood wrote:

> Date: Thu, 07 Apr 1994 17:14:04 -0600
> From: Luke Youngblood <LUKEY@wordperfect.com>
> To: psiborg@halcyon.com, sunkim@sfsuvax1.sfsu.edu
> Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
> Subject: Re: From the cookie monster -Reply
> 
> 	I think that lack of food in general tends to do you in after you've
> been at a party for 5 or 6 hours.  I mean, most people probably
> haven't eaten since dinner Saturday evening, and the party started at
> midnight, so by 6 or 7 in the morning, you're famished.  But, you
> probably didn't realize you were famished because the walls are still
> melting...  I like to bring quick energy snacks like candy bars and
> stuff like that.  Fruit is really good, but it doesn't have very many
> calories.  Calories are what you need if you're dancing for a long
> time.  So, you could eat pasta all day before the party and get some
> good long-lasting calories, or you could eat a Snickers or
> something... (and be satisfied :)
>  
> Actually, it depends on how long you've been dancing, what you ate 
before, and how much more time you are going to spend engaging in 
physical activity.  
Sounds like your glycogen levels have been depleted.  In order to prevent 
this from happening, eat lots of fruit and complex carbohydrates before 
you dance.  It takes the body longer to break these down; hence, the body 
receives energy in steady amounts for a long period of time.  Simple 
carbohydrates, like candy bars, will give you an immediate rush but will 
leave you feeling taxed when your blood sugar level comes crashing down.  
You really don't need this if you are already crashing from "other 
things".  Instead, drink high fructose drinks, like orange juice.  It has 
lots of carbs and calories and won't leave you exhausted after an already 
exhausting "workout".
Later,
Tanya>

Don "unibrow" recently posted a testimonial about trance dancing, here's
my two cents worth , also a question ...

 I got close to a similar state a few times at last week's Your Sister's
House , even before I indulged in smokables. It is really impressive
to get to that state unaided by chemicals , "natural" or manufactured.

 I haven't got as deep for as long as some folks - I tend to be too
concerned about other folks around me. Some folks dance as if other 
people have to watch out for them instead of vice-versa - raving
as a kind of diluted mosh pit. ( Maybe I'm letting one or two person's
dancing styles bug me too much ).

 Question: Is there a correlation to the who the DJ is and the ease of
  dropping into trance? Who are the best trance-induction DJs?

		Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

From: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White)
Message-Id: <199404081536.IAA12291@nexsys.nexsys.net>
To: larryc@netcom.com
Subject: RE: Weird thing happened ...
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

> 
>  Question: Is there a correlation to the who the DJ is and the ease of
>   dropping into trance? Who are the best trance-induction DJs?
> 
> 		Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

Well speaking as a person who trances (sometimes long and hard), there
is definitely a correlation to who the DJ is.  Now I belive that
different people like different things and each person has a different
"door" into the one, House. The DJs hold the keys, but different DJs can
open the doors of different types of people.  
For me, I have been the deepest with
Jeno, he has played sets that have touched me (I feel) down to an
almost genetic :) level, definitely down to a very subconscious one,
something akin to self hypnosis. The deepest trance that I _ever_
achieved was at a bonny doon full moon in the morning completely sober
at the hands of Jeno.  I'm also a meditator and I must say that I have
reached some deep states of consciousness on the dance floor, many of
them have been with the aid of Jeno.  Currently he is not playing stuff
that sends me directly to this state, (although he can still trance me
out pretty well, at the last Basics I had to be at church by 9 a.m. and
I _couldn't_ be late, so at 7:30 when I saw Jeno getting his crate
together, I got my posse together and bolted outta there cuz' if he got on
and dropped a beat of the good shit, I would _never_ make it out of
there on time :) but he is still a very capable trance DJ for me and
definitely one of my Shamen.  For me right now, the person that plays
the _sickist_  (by this I mean mind altering) is Markie.  I have had a
true out-of-body experience (like looking at yourself and others from
the celing of 1015) at the hands of Markie's spinning. But these are
just the people that can do it consistantly for me,  I have gone out
pretty well to our own Jon D. not to mention Toni, Ernie Munsen, Josh,
and others.  For me the DJ needs to be able to set up a "standing wave" 
of trance energy, this is hard to explaine but on a good night with Jeno,
I like catch this wave and I can ride it for hours, it's not just a tempo
or type of music thing, it's the ability to know _exactly_ what record to play
next, how to tweek the bass and treble and when to phase into it,  it is
alos case of building momentum, suspense and release, but without pushing
too hard too fast, Jeno knows how to bring you closer and cxlose to the edge
of exaustion, pull you back for a while push you a little closer and
just when you think you don't have an ounce of energy left, he drops the
phatest shit you've ever heard, your middle eye pops on, this energy rushes
up your spine, your eye cross and you enter deep trance, in this state, you
can dance for litterally hours with out the use or need of chemicals because
the energy system that you are using is pranic not chemical.
There are different states of trance as well, Jeno's music
tends to open the crown and third eye chakra, whereas the music that
Markie plays, sets off the sacral, heart and eye chakra respectively.
Wailing Diva house is almost entirely a heart  and first Chakra thing.  
It is the expression of agape, the kind of unconditional love for all of 
creation that is only arrived at after experiencing great a tribulation like
opression (because your black or gay or both) of some sort, or violence (
both emotional as well as physical)  where the 
fact that you are still alive to hear it is a personal victory.  It comes from
the same source as gospel music, which has a long history of being a trance
music (though unless you spent time in a black church you wouldn't know this).
In Black Christian churches (especially certain  pentacostal denominations)
there is a state that people reach that is called "gettin happy", where the
music (or preaching or both) over comes the individual and they are "filled
with the spirit", they may put their hands in the air, jump up and down,
shout out, walk up and down the ailes and make other rhymic motions.  There
are churches that have services that are set up to bring the congregation
to a state where this can be experienced.  The music is rthymic and starts out
slow but picks up tempo until it is around 120 BPM and then people start
going-off.  This kind of behaviour is understood, it is considered a blessing,
and people are not stared at or rediculed; in many ways, some black folks
have been "raving" (or trance dancing) for years.

A couple of personal energy boost favorites, tested extensively biking Mt.
Tam, are Power Bars(especially the chocolate) and Ultra Fuel(which is like
thick Gatorade.)  Most people hate the latter because its thick and sweet
containing complex sugars/simple carbohydrates--but when those calves HURT
and your body burns it can really help.  Power Bars are easier to get used
to.  If you taste one sitting at home you might not be impressed, but once
you eat one when you need it you'll be hooked--they are infinitely better
than a candy bar.  Of course there is never a substitue for LOTS of
water--most people just don't drink enough.

phuture

	So far, I have received about 4 responses to my survey,
	I'm a little surprised and don't know exactly what this means.
	I had expected to be either flamed by various factions or accoused
	of starting a flame war but I was not ready for... silence.
	The low tunrnout could be for one or more of the following reasons:

	1)The question's were way too intimate for most people and they
	were afraid to answer.

	2)It's spring break and people are either unsubbed or haven't plowed
	through those 100 messages to get to mine.

	3) Talking about these matters is _really_ uncomfortable for the people
	on the list.

	4) People on the list have not/ are not having enough sexuallove
	experiences that they feel that they can contribute to the survey.

	5) Folks just don't care.

	6) You are all perverts and don't want to "out" yourselves :) :)

In any event, for those of you who are shy, if you want to send me anonymous 
mail on the subject you can get info on how to do this by fingering:

	remailer@soda.berkeley.edu 

for those who don't have direct internet access a simple explanation is ...
This document describes some of the special features of the
hh remailer.  Because this remailer is essentially just a
modification of the standard Cypherpunk's Remailer, I recomend that you also
read soda.berkeley.edu:/pub/cypherpunks/remailer/hal's.remailer.gz.

= Where is this remailer running?

The following sites run this remailer package, and will work according to
the instructions below:

	hh@soda.berkeley.edu

I will describe the operations of this remailer using hh@soda.berkeley.edu
as the example, but all of the instructions below apply to all of the
remailers on the above list.  Just replace hh@soda.berkeley.edu with one of
the other account names.  They are listed in order of inception, and
probably also in order of stability.  Increase your security by spreading
your usage among them!

= What does this remailer do?

This remailer allows anyone who can send mail to post to Usenet newsgroups,
and also to send mail to anyone else on the Internet.  Both of these
functions can be anonymous (the identity of the sender is hidden from the
recipient) or non-anonymous (the identity of the sender is known to the
recipient).


= A note about header fields

This remailer/poster looks at the header of the mail you send it to decide
what to do.  Some mail programs don't allow easy editting of the header.  If
your program doesn't allow editting of the header, you can still use the
remailer.  To do this, send mail in the normal way, but start your message
like this:

	::
	Anon-Post-To: rec.fish

leaving no blank lines before the :: and a blank line after the header field
to be inserted.  The remailer will consider the line after the :: to be a
part of the header.  All of the instructions bellow can be used with actual
header fields or the :: format.

= Anonymous mail

This remailer is capable of sending anonymous mail.  To send mail to
foo@bar.com, send a message like this:

	To: hh@soda.berkeley.edu
	Anon-Send-To: foo@bar.com
	Subject: Ronald Sukenick

	I think you should read something by Ronald Sukenick.

and foo@bar.com will recieve the message, without knowing who sent it.

From sfraves-owner  Fri Apr  8 11:58:45 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA24366; Fri, 8 Apr 94 11:58:45 PDT
Received: from pilot.njin.net by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA24359; Fri, 8 Apr 94 11:58:38 PDT
Received: by pilot.njin.net (5.59/SMI4.0/RU1.5/3.08) 
	id AA24428; Fri, 8 Apr 94 14:58:32 EDT
Date: Fri, 8 Apr 94 14:58:32 EDT
From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9404081858.AA24428@pilot.njin.net>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: A State of Grace
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I probably would have left my first rave if it wasn't for this woman I
saw. She was dancing, and she was beautiful. But not in a sexual way,
for though she was attractive, her dance was everything. It was *all*
she was doing; absolute unity of without and within, perfect
expression, music and mind and body indistinguishable.

Watching her, I was enthralled. I had never seen such absolute purity
of purpose. It reminded me of myself, great chasms in my thought, such
division between heart and intellect and body, and here I was seeing
someone who had not only trancended that, but whose whole was now
merged with an outside thing--the music--to make something even more.
I wanted to experience that, to do this beautiful thing.

And that's why I stayed. I've found since that the trance state is not
only beautiful, but it is healing as well, and that it has profound
depths of what one may experience.

Trance can take one deep into the subconscious realm, or into places
totally new. It can remind us how extremely complex we are, and it can
show us what's in our hearts. It can teach us what it's like to be in
synergy, to have ourselves whole and directed. It can be within or
without. The journeys are as endless as we are.

The "vibe" is a part of this. It's when a lot of people reach the
trance state, but instead of turning inward, turn outward. Without
leaving that mind-music-body synergy, we realize what is happening,
that it is good and that it is shared. The thoughts of good and
sharing feed back to everyone, get turned outward, and feed back
again. The bounds of "me" and "them" dissolve, and for a while, we are
"one". It can be one of the most intense and moving things a person
may ever experience, and it has literally changed people's lives.

I will never forget that woman. Her image remains in my mind, a
doorway and a promise of what can be achieved. A promise that has been
fulfilled more than I ever imagined.

Happy trancing :)

Sean

My fav trance-inducing dj's whose names I have found out are Jeno, Markie,
and John Howard.  

On a related note, I happened to be watching, "rescue 911" at a friend's house
a while back and there was this story about a guy who was hanging out of a 
window of a highrise apartment that was on fire.  Smoke was pouring out from
behind him and it wasn't clear if he would be forced to jump to his death.
Two firepeople with scuba tanks and facial masks and the whole outfit
roped down from the roof into an adjacent window, broke the 
window and entered through it.  It was obvious that they were risking their
lives.  Well they rescued the guy and later they interviewed him.  He was 
basically saying  that he was so surprised that two humans who didn't even 
know him would actually put their own lives at risk to save his.  And he was 
crying and he just couldn't believe their kindness.  And I was crying too.
And it gave me the warm fuzzies all over.

All right so it wasn't related to raving but I just wanted to relate that 
story.  Hey, the warm fuzzies is a great feeling too.  Acts of human kindness
and compassion make my day.

ex-fractal surfer who wanders all over the place (topic-wise)

On Thu, 7 Apr 1994, Sun Kim wrote:

> Why are some clubs 18+ and others 21+?  If the only difference is that 
> one doesn't serve alcohol and the other does, then why are the clubs 21+ 
> since alcohol is usually looked down upon away?
> 
> (I don't know if I make sense but I hope someone can answer.)

well, I can't really make heads or tails of that whole bs.  Some clubs 
think it's a matter of economics.  They want to only let people in who 
can LEGALLY buy alcohol, and try to keep them drinking.  More drinks, 
more $$.  Other places (like Cactus Club) charge higher cover for their 
shows to those under 21.  There are others that do this; but I think if 
they want to make their quota of drinks per customer, they make us 
underaged folk buy drink tickets.  The only time this whole thing becomes 
a problem is when a band you really like plays at a 21+ place and won't 
let you in just because you are not 21.  That bites.  

enough of my .02...

Ps.  For energy, I too go for bananas and oranges.  But one think I've 
stumbled upon is a milkshake followed by some carbonated mineral water 
(like Calistoga).  The sugar high combined with the carbonation will keep 
you wired; and you don't get the caffiene jitters (when you slam 
coffee).  Do NOT try this before you're going to sleep though...

Subject: Suicide and hope
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Fri, 8 Apr 1994 17:20:00 -0700 (PDT)
In-Reply-To: <9404082025.AA29709@cadence.Cadence.COM> from "Noah Ruiz" at Apr 8, 94 01:25:41 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL21]
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 1272      
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


	OK, so Kurt Cobain is dead.  He's not the only one from the
music scene to back out of life.

	The traditional band 'scene' says, in effect, "We're lonely
and alienated, and we'll always we lonely and alienated, so we'll make
it into a kind of contest where we recognize each other in the only
backhanded way we know for being the most lonely and alienated of
all."

	The way you distinguish yourself in the 'scene' is by having
seen everything already so you can be cool by capping on anything
anyone else says -- and compliment only things that no one else knows
about so you're not in danger of actually being contradicted.

	This is better than doing nothing and vanishing into the sea
of infinite solitude (which most people fear totally), but not by
much.  I have withstood this empty silence -- sometimes it chokes me
so hard I get dry tears -- but withstanding pain doesn't make it go
away.

	And this is why there is hope for the house nation -- because
there exists at least a shadow of recognition that the pain of being
alone isn't something to celebrate and wallow in -- and sometimes, we
reach a bright fine moment when we connect with the world and everyone
else, and nothing needs to be said because a smile or a hug says it
all.

	Keep it alive.

// g

Ps.  For energy, I too go for bananas and oranges.  But one think I've
stumbled upon is a milkshake followed by some carbonated mineral water
(like Calistoga).  The sugar high combined with the carbonation will keep
you wired; and you don't get the caffiene jitters (when you slam
coffee).  Do NOT try this before you're going to sleep though...
-------------------------------------------------------------------------

I still say Spirulina Smoothies!!!  It's spirulina (wonderful for energy)
in a base of bananan, coconut, and pineaple juice (gives you everything
in the banana and oranges).  If that doesn't apeal to your tastes, try it
anyway, I usualy don't like pineapple/coconut-type tropical drinks but
this is blended just right with the spirulina and tastes great!

-Guthrie

From sfraves-owner  Sat Apr  9 05:13:03 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)

Received: from holonet.net (giskard.holonet.net) by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)

Received: from localhost (dmi@localhost) by holonet.net (David M. Ilstrup)
	id FAA27653; Sat, 9 Apr 1994 05:06:01 -0700
Message-Id: <199404091206.FAA27653@holonet.net>
Subject: Re: Cobain dead
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Sat, 9 Apr 94 5:05:59 PDT
From: "David M. Ilstrup" <dmi@holonet.net>
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


I guess it's just really suprising that Kurt Cobain's death is effecting me at
all, but considering that just about the best time out I've had in the last
several months was the New Year's show at the colloseum maybe it makes sense.
Actually I went to the show with the intention of seeing the Butthole Surfers
and was most pumped up for Jazzid Up later that night; Nirvana was an after-
thought. I won't repeat what Cobain said when he opened the show, because it
will probably just sound obscene and senseless :) But that's not really what it
was about. It was about breaking out of traps and freeing basic human spirit,
and it was about trust. If you've been in a mosh pit, you know what I mean 
about trust; you've got alot of agressive energy and so does everyone around 
you.You're frustrated and have no outlet for it, so you just start thrashing 
into everyone. It's not random, because if you aren't careful and the people 
around you aren't careful, you are going to get hurt really fast. At the same 
time, the music is really sending you off. When everyone connects this way, it 
can be wonderfully reassuring. It's sort of a spiritual reality check, where
you confirm the frustration that the people around you are feeling about the 
world,and realizing that you can make yourself very vunerable to complete 
strangers and have them respect your well being. I dunno, that's the way it 
feels to me. It's a real loss that K.C. is gone, but that energy is definitely
manifest in the rave scene and the music scene in general in the Bay Area. 
I don't think anyone has to do anything but what comes naturally to keep it 
alive. It's the un-natural that worries me...

-Dave

To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: apocalypse THEN
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Random thoughts:

I don't see why people hate the Haze so much.  Sure, I got
WELL searched by security but it beats the alternative (i.e.
being knifed).  And they let me bringin my own water, soy milk, 
candy, and even ink pens (they were confiscating pens from would-be 
taggers).

The space had that "someone's basement" feel to it, and I really
appreciated the couches all over the place.  Lots of good 
places to sit down.  And I didn't experience any sort of "bad vibe"
or "evil feeling" eminating from the building.

The only thing *wrong* with the Haze is a problem endemic to
San Francisco because of their ridiculous caberet laws.  Since
there are so few places for under-21's to go in ANY scene, kids
from ALL scenes turn up at the Haze regularly because they have
*no* other place to go.  So there are always a good number of people
there who could care less about the music or much else, they just
want and need a place to hang out.

Interestingly enough, the kids at the Haze were decent and even
friendly.  People said "excuse me" and smiled when they
bumped into me, no one pushed or shoved, random people talked
to me, and very few people actually seemed menacing.

Susie, Jo, Chris, and I got there around 12:30 just at the start
of R.A.W.'s breakbeat set.  It was GREAT and fun and DIFFERENT
for a while, but he played for over 2 hours and it got rather boring.
I think an hour and a bit would have been a lot better -- people were
getting annoyed with break break break and started leaving.  R.A.W.
can mix breaks wonderfully, but he just needs to think a bit about
VARIETY in his sets.  There are enough sub-styles of breaks to
avoid monotony in a set, he needs to either spin shorter sets or
vary what he's playing more.

Chris and Susie left just as R.A.W.'s set was ending, but Jo 
convinced me to stay and I'm really glad we did.  Demigod put
down the nicest hardcore + breaks set.  He'd play weird 
breaks for a few tracks, and then segue into a few SLAMMING hardcore
tunes.  It made me feel so happy, like when I used to go to parties
in grimy warehouses in Brooklyn in 1992.  After Demigod came Alex,
and the music stayed hard but got really trancey.  By this
time my body could not really dance anymore so I sat on Allen's
huge bean bag chair and just chatted and bounced around happily.

Upstairs they had some house DJs, I actually  never went up 
there but people said it was good.

For $5 this party is definately  worth checking out.  It just needs
some more "old time" ravers who are there for dancing not just
hanging to liven it up.  I seriously recommend giving this party
a chance.  It's not perfection, but it's interesting, varied,
and good for a night out.  With good support it could be really
nice.

Laura

From sfraves-owner  Sat Apr  9 17:40:57 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)

From: jvlraves@aol.com
X-Mailer: America Online Mailer
Message-Id: <9404092038.tn589785@aol.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Sat, 09 Apr 94 20:38:30 EDT
Subject: Re: How much life is left in the Rave Scene?
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

A topic that inevitably comes up, after exploring 'the scene' for a year more
is "How much is left for the rave scene", or It's not the same anymore", or a
person just gets tired of it.  Personally, I'm not tired of it, it's O.K.,
and I welcome change.
The music ALWAYS goes on in San Francisco.  I friend of mine, who happens to
be an alcohol and substance abuse counselor, is very interested in my
impressions of raves, clubs, et al.  He is 67 years old, goes not indulge in
nightclubs anymore, and is retired.  But his wisdom is worth a thousand
raves.
He listened to my diatribe about the great music, wild light shows, and the
people who love these venues.  He says that he went to parties in wharehouses
and SOMA clubs 20 - 25 years ago that sound very similar.  The music was
different.  The *enhancements* were different.  And there was a lot of sex in
dimly lit rooms.  (Sounds like a chill room, doesn't it?)  The difference may
be, perhaps the gentleless and happy vibe that we enjoy at today's parties. 
But it always goes on here.  HS Advice is not to feel that you missed a great
party, or that you've gotta be at this party tonight.  There will always be
another party.  And if you think you're out of control with the costly
enhancements - stop for 6 months.  If you can do that, then it probably isn't
a problem in your life.
My lover said, "yeah, just stop going out for 6 months, you seem so far away
these days."  That lasted 6 weeks, maybe.
But the perspective really helpee me.  It was a paradigm for that particular
part of my psyche.  It's always there, it's got to change, and it's only old
to you if you're old to it.  If you go for the dancing, and that's what it's
all about, pop music changes.  The clothing styles change.  The designer **
change too.  Have fun.  Make a contribution to the event, however small.  (A
smile to start)  And be careful.
Peace.

areas, both with fireplace. Large modern kitchen with dining
area on second floor and wooden-floor dining room with bar
on third floor. Carpet and marble flooring, high ceilings
and large picture windows. Modern-contemporary styling, clean,
and in like-new condition. Sunroom adjacent to first floor
bedroom and large two-deck patio (great for lots of potted
plants). Balcony off third floor. All with uninterrupted view
of the SF skyline! Safe, quiet neighborhood, one garage and
plenty of parking on the street. Lots of storage space.

The cost for all this should be about $500 per bedroom, plus
utilities.

It's located at 1580 15th street, cross street Lawton--four
blocks from Golden Gate Park, a long walk or short bike ride
to Haight Ashbury, and 2 blocks to a major MUNI route (N),
which takes you downtown or to the BART. Close to Lincoln
Way (out to 101) and Highway 1 (down to 280 or up to the
Golden Gate Bridge).

And...we want to hardwire the whole house to the Internet.
Are you tired of second-hand net access, shell accounts,
and disk quotas? We're ready to make the leap to a full
Internet connection. A totally wired household, running
a 56KB leased line net connection (?), a gopher/www public
server, whatever else turns you on. 


Here's what we're picturing:
* Incredibly intense house
* Run a LAN in the house, with terminals throughout.
* Connect via leased line (ISDN?) to the net, very likely
  through The Little Garden or Internex.
* Link up with other Bay Area Internet cooperatives such
  as Cyborganic and Nexus-Berkeley.
* Offer Internet introductions and SLIP connectivity to the
  community.
* Live cooperatively, at least to an extent. It would be nice
  if people were interested in doing group meals a couple
  times a week, throwing a party here and there, etc.

A little information about us:
Julie is 26, Jim is 25.
Jim works at home, Julie works at Wired Magazine.
This would NOT be a no alcohol, no drugs household. If you're
  not comfortable with someone smoking a joint, it probably
  wouldn't work out. 
We are more into music than television. There will be Grateful
  Dead music played in this house. If you can't stand this, it
  probably wouldn't work out. On the other hand, we are also
  into a wide variety of music from The Orb to Nirvana to John
  Zorn to Robert Johnson (and an occasional Gregorian chant).
We're into live music, raves and much more that SF has to offer
  but we also like to relax at home sometimes.

The house is available May 1, but we'll need to make a decision
immediately. If this sounds good to you, call us at 510-889-0362
(or call julie@work at 415-904-6458) or email us at
chinacat@netcom.com/julie@wired.com.

-- 
- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -
Jim Petersen                              Argue for your limitations...
chinacat@netcom.com                            And they are yours

this is not a test of the mailing system. this is a report on test, the event.
I thought the event was great. There was great music thanks to Ethan and 
Alex, who spun great sets. It was cool to see some familiar faces(Mommy, Daddy,
Big Sister, Ravi, and Steve). I thought the space was great, it has a lot of
potiential, though it was in the Tenderloin. Hopefully more events will take
place there. The event was $3 and I actually had money to go to this one:). 
The first level was the dance floor, pool tables, bars, and they even had 
pinball machines:). What was really great was that the DJs were spinning
out of an Utiltity/Janitorial closet. Downstairs was the basement where the
ambient room was. The second ambient DJ had the levels up too loud:(. T he
first DJ was great though. Who was she? I would like to know her name because
I am compiling a list of women DJs. She played a mixture of things from 
a -8 version of the Cocteau Twins toMiddle Eastern Music,to  Electronic Ambient
music. I thought she was wonderful. 

Anyway too bad the party had to stop at 2. (I didnt stick around if it was
moved downstairs or somewhere else). 

seaofsin

To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: aphex used DAT?
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

	Here it is- my observations from the APHEX TWIN show
	in SF on the NASA tour.

	
	1)	Richard James wasn't moving very much
		during his set. The amount of sounds
		he was producing would require lots of
		control over the equipment. He seemed hovered
		over only a Studio 440 SMPTE reader/sequencer.

	2)	His studio material soudned exactly like the
		live stuff with a few extra sounds added.

	3)	I bought Selected Ambient Work II and two of the
		trax on it were IDENTICAL to his live ones- note for
		note, beat for beat.

	4)	Finally I asked someone who had been working at the show
		and they said "yeah- i was working on stage when he started.
		He put a DAT in a player and off it went."

	Here are my conclusions:

	1)	He used a time-code DAT- a DAT tape with a stripe of
		SMPTE time code on it.

		His Studio 440 read the SMPTE time code and triggered
		some additional sounds adding a little to the set.

	2)	I'm not really upset about not seeing a live performance.
		I know that when my electronic music band performs it
		takes 3 people who have been rehearsing for YEARS
		to make a cohesive set on all electronic analog
		equipment.

	3)	The only reason I analyze his set like this is becase I
		am a eternal student of electronic music. I was really
		blown away by the idea that one person can control
		that many sounds from so few gear without moving around
		to control it at all.

		At least it doesn't seem that I'm crazy- in order to make
		that much sound you'd need about 3 people with lots of
		percussion and synth modules all clocked together to 
		generate a set like that.

		Its a shame that he had to resort to DAT show.

Myself, along with 3 friends, were planning on going out to TEST this 
saturday night.  Alex had told me about the idea a couple of months ago, 
and I have been anxiously awaiting its materialization.  We were all 
ready to go around 11, just needing to call the info line to get the 
location.

"The party will be strictly 21 and over, so bring a valid ID" 

Now, I'm not really upset that it was 21 and over (well, actually I am), 
but the real reason I am upset is that this information was not given 
until LATE saturday night, even on the flier.  What is the reason for 
this?  I can see NO excuse.  People under 21 are making 
plans to go to this party, and at the last minute, they are told they can't 
get in.  What is 
the point?  Was it not known that the party would be 21+ until saturday?  
I doubt it.  Can someone involved in this party please explain (Ethan? 
Bryce?)???

At  1:35 AM 4/11/94 -0700, Seth Joshua Horvitz wrote:

>I'm pissed.
...

>Now, I'm not really upset that it was 21 and over (well, actually I am), 
>but the real reason I am upset is that this information was not given 
>until LATE saturday night, even on the flier.  What is the reason for 
>this?  I can see NO excuse.  People under 21 are making 
>plans to go to ths party, and at the last minute, they are told they can't 
>get in.  What is 
>the point?  Was it not known that the party would be 21+ until saturday?  
>I doubt it.  Can someone involved in this party please explain (Ethan? 
>Bryce?)???

Please exclude bryce from any grief you may have about the above situation.
He posted directions at my request and in fact, neither he nor I promoted
this party. I always regret when a party is 21+.

Not to duck the issue however, please note the following:

Directions were posted by 8:30 pm.

Up until wednesday it was beleived that the party would be <21-friendly.
This however was contingent on the space in question receiving permits that
were in the application processing stage. That person felt very confident
about reciving the permit--cabaret, which in this case decided use of the
space in general as opposed to simply the 18+/21+ issue. However she, like
many others recently, was denied. Many permits are now being *revoked* in
what seems a decided backlash against the recent 18+ ruling.

We (I certainly count myself in this group!) have very high expectations of
our promoters. We expect them to find nice places that can accomodate
hundreds of people at high volumes all night and at a low cost for all
ages.
Spaces like this are hard to find and cost money. Show me a promoter (and
this goes for the _big ones_ I know too) and I'll show you someone who
loses money 1 out of every 2 (if not 4 out of every 5!) parties. These
people *are not* getting rich; rather they're providing the _substance_ of
the famed "keep it alive." 

A lot of the promoters I know (myself included) don't have the money or the
inclination to book the galleria or the concourse, which as we all know,
are: all ages, all night, high volume, high cost. In the case of _test_ the
promoters didn't have *any money.* It was either: throw the party as best
you could under the circumstances or, cancel the party. Net effect to you:
exactly the same. In any event, the party happened, lots of people had a
good time. I'm sorry you weren't there.

I should however add that, in truth, I was fairly pissed about the location
confusion as well cos really up until the last minute this party was
basically cancelled. 

Anyway, to sum it all up let me say this: We should hold our promoters to
very high standards but we should also forgive them their occasional
'failings.' 

And, most importantly, if you can do a better job, please do so, the scene
needs it.

take it easy
ethan


                                _______ 
 ethan miller                     nrg                            pgp me   
_________________________ 'one unbroken whole' _________________________   
                         
                (: positive energy can save the world :)
               __________________________________________

> 
> 
> 	Unfortunately, those with the power to change this (the club
> owners, who fought IN FAVOR of keeping the curfew laws in effect)
> don't care, and those who have the power to influence those with the
> power (I.e. YOU - the party-goers, the party-throwers, etc) mostly
> don't think it matters much, either.  So the schism persists.  Even
> though I've crossed the age barrier recently, I'm not going to give
> any strictly 21+ place my business, unless they have been trying to
> get an 18+ license or allow them in after a certain time.  Period.
> I used to say things like the above, and still sneak into 21+ parties,
> until someone called me on it amd I realized I was being a hypocrite
> by going to 21+ parties.  It's not a problem, really - there are still 
> lots of 18+ parties around anyways.  
> 
> 	Sorry to vent my spleen.... 
> 
> 	Brian

I understand your position but now that you are 21 AND a resident of SF
(which means you vote for whoever is on the Board of Supervisors you might
consider a more pro-active stance.  Ultimately the real culprets in this
issue are the SFPD.  They have decided to take the law into their own 
hands and enforce the 18 curfew ANYWAY.  So you might want to fax or phone 
the police commissioner or as I have suggested before set up voter registration
tables outside <21 parties.  If the tactics that the police are using succeed
it will only be a matter of time before ALL parties are shut down unless you
pay them off (which is what this is _really_ all about any ways)

I hear that there is going to be a series of renegade/break-ins planned for the
spring/summer months which, as far as I'm concerned, is all for the better.

If people try to obey the lawful process and the police still insist on
having it their way (In amerikkka the man with the money and guns make the
rules) then it is our duty to push back against this.  The police have 
absolutely no right to instill any form of social engineering.

From sfraves-owner  Mon Apr 11 11:28:09 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA15546; Mon, 11 Apr 94 11:28:09 PDT
Received: from pilot.njin.net by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA15527; Mon, 11 Apr 94 11:27:58 PDT
Received: by pilot.njin.net (5.59/SMI4.0/RU1.5/3.08) 
	id AA09116; Mon, 11 Apr 94 14:27:53 EDT
Date: Mon, 11 Apr 94 14:27:53 EDT
From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9404111827.AA09116@pilot.njin.net>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: And speaking of 21+ parties...bad time at Wicked
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I had a perfectly bad time at Wicked. You should, of course, take this
with a grain of salt, since all experiences are subjective. And this
is not a comment on the promoter, but on the party in general.

After I spent 15 minutes finding some legal parking that wasn't on a
totally dark street, I walked over to the King St. garage, a space I
went to once before and didn't like (and which other people have
complained about). It's too small and has poor ventilation. Very very
hot and smokey. You know, I read the other day that smoking has
dropped considerably in California, though you wouldn't know it from
the rave scene. If you're smoking in a closed space where people are
exercising, then basically you just don't give a fuck about anyone
else's health and what you're doing to them. Let's call a duck a duck,
eh?

So anyway, it was $15, which was too much for a party in a small space
like that with no visuals other than a few intellabeams. Acoustics
weren't very good either, with the bass overwhelming everything. Poor
Jeno was tweaking the knobs all night trying to get a good sound out
of that space. I didn't connect the directions with that particular
space, or I probably wouldn't have went. The Goons weren't being
gooney like the other time I went there (Which Crunch wrote all
about), so that was very cool.

I hooked up with a couple of friends of mine I was supposed to meet,
who had come with other friends, and after about a minute they danced
off and never acknowledged me again. Well, foo.

And for that matter, something really bothers me about the Wicked
crowd. I just don't feel like I belong. There *was* a big vibe going,
but it was a strange one; not much smile factor.

And people kept bumping into me. I'd find a nice spot and dance
without moving around a lot, and I'd get an elbow in the back, or
someone would accidentally swipe my head. No big deal, but they were
oblivious to it. A couple of people bumped me several times without
even acknowledgeing me. I'd move off to a less crowded spot and the
experience was repeated.

Friends and Family was even more crowded than this event, had just a
big a vibe, and a lot of people were clearly out of their heads, but
they were _nice_. If someone whopped you one, they apologised, or
turned and smiled. No such courtesy at Wicked.

So anyway, Markie was laying down one of his fat house grooves, so I
headed up cause I wanted to watch his technique. I found a clear spot
near the turntables, and watched (with a big fat grin on my face cause
he's so good) and bobbed a bit. After about 10 minutes, some woman
shoves by me very rudely, and dances next to me. She edges over and
bumps me. I look at her. She says something, but I can't hear it.
I figure she's apologising (wow), so I turn my attention back to
Markie. I get bumped again. And again. I turn and she's looking at me.
I lean over so she can yell in my ear, and she tells me that if I'm
not going to dance, go over there.

What?

I just shake my head and again turn back to Markie. She yells at me
again. Says this is her spot. I tell her to be nice, I want to watch
Markie. She repeats this a couple of times and I end up telling her
quite forcefully to FUCK OFF!

At which point I was having strong thoughts of FUCK THIS. Is this the
usual Wicked crowd or did I pick a bad night, or does one need to go
to Wicked 30 or 40 times before people are nice to you?

Well anyway except for that asshole, I really enjoyed watching Markie
do his stuff. I never realized before just how much he works at it,
and how much he samples. Cool beans.  I hung around for Jeno's set,
which I had high hopes for, but I left an hour into 122 BPM wailing
diva house, which the crowd really liked but which I wasn't in the
mood for.

In general, I got the impression that Wicked is a fraternity, that a
lot of the people there know each other, and I wasn't one of them. I
didn't meet any friendly people. And it wasn't just me, cause I was
emanating a lot of smile factor all night, trying to draw people out.
But it just didn't happen.

So I don't think I'll be going to Wicked anymore, unless it's with a
small crowd of my own, then I can get some good vibes. Don't know if
that will be possible, cause I don't age discriminate and Wicked is
usually in 21+ spaces.

After that I was just too bummed out to drive the two hours to the new
mooner. I hope it went well!

Sean

From sfraves-owner  Mon Apr 11 12:21:12 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA05799; Mon, 11 Apr 94 12:21:12 PDT
Received: from soda.berkeley.edu by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA05528; Mon, 11 Apr 94 12:20:27 PDT
Received: (laura@localhost) by soda.berkeley.edu (8.6.8/PHILMAIL-1.10) id MAA19577 for sfraves@techno.stanford.edu; Mon, 11 Apr 1994 12:20:19 -0700
Message-Id: <199404111920.MAA19577@soda.berkeley.edu>
From: laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Mon, 11 Apr 1994 12:20:11 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Testing TESTing 1-2-3
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

WOOSH!!!  Technophiles and electronic music junkies UNITE!  Now
THIS is a good idea.

The only bad thing about TEST was that they lost their space but got
saved by Cleo (of Cleo's in the Haight).  It seems that Cleo let the
TEST people have their party in a bar she owns in the Tenderloin.  So
it was a bar, and therefore HAD to be 21+, but it was better than there
being  no party at all.  Cleo should get some kind of award for what
she's done for the scene, from having gear in the Cafe to supporting 
Your Sister's House to letting TEST use the Art Deco.

ANYWAY, Cindy and I got there around 11 pm, just as things were getting 
started.  We chilled in the chill basement while a woman (who IS she?)
did weird things in the name of ambient.  If you slow Liz Frazer's voice
down enough she sounds like Brendan Perry.  Humm.  And they worked 
together on some This Mortal Coil stuff.  Humm.  Have you ever seen
Liz Frazer and Brendan Perrty together in the same place at the same
time?  *Maybe* they are the same person?  HUMMMM :-)

We went upstairs to hear Ethan (our techno daddy) put down thick 
layers of acid techno trance.  The dance floor filled up and Ethan
worked the energy levels up to that amazing "we're all in outer space"
level.  Even more remarkable because he was doing it in a BAR for
god's sake where random people would wander in beer in hand to hit
on tranced out dancers.  I can not WAIT to hear Ethan do it in a dark
warehouse at 4 am with one strobe and a single sweeping blue beam,
shades of Brooklyn, where you can feel the entire consciousness of
the room lift off and orbit out near Venus.  I mean, if Ethan can get
it together in a bar in the Tenderloin, you DON'T want to miss it in
more favorable surroundings like, oh, Bonny Doon or something.  I LOVED
IT ETHAN!  HEARING THAT TRANCE (oh so well mixed) MADE ME SOOO HAPPY.

Okay (calm down, dill weed, heh heh heh).

I danced myself into a sweat, and then shared a refreshing hard apple
cider with Cindy.  You know, like any other substance, alcohol when
used properly works just *fine* at a party.  By this time the Art Deco
was totally taken over by ravers and electronic music fans, and had a
great feel.  

Next came Alex, who took Ethan's power boost and just kept running 
with it.  Alex got the joy of spinning to a full floor, something that
was unhappily denied him on Friday night at the Haze.

At 2am Test closed up -- it would have been rude and disrespectful of
Cleo's hospitality to continue into the realm of illegality.  After all,
she *is* a businesswoman too.  Cindy and I left, but I think the party
might have moved deep into the basement (or bassment).

I hope things work out better for TEST space-wise next time.  It is a
brilliant party (made me want to take back all the positive things I said
about Apocalypse, I guess I was just so starved for a harder party that
it seemed like water to a person in a desert).  If any test organizers
are reading this *please* keep doig this, and *please* keep trying to 
find spaces that will allow you to do this as all ages.  Spring is
coming, maybe a TEST outdoor renegade?

All warm and fuzzy, purely from the spaced-out beats,

Love and community,

Laura

saw this band, Look People, with Dread Zeppelin in Ventura on Saturday.

if you get a chance, you've gotta check out Look People; they're from
  canada, and even have their own comic book :)
  they
're  'thrash jazz', and their act is a bunch of hard-driving thrash segments
  punctuated with carnival acts and childish pranks.

their drummer is a dwarf, their guitar player is 7 ft tall, and the lead
   singer has gotta have some of Frank Zappa's AND Peewee herman's blood
     in there somewhere; they may look funny, but they're tight as shit;
       absolutely perfect timing riff-wize...

they say they'll have e-mail soon; i'll post the addr if i get it

This is off of the newsgroup alt.fan.letterman. You know what
Madonna's like, if you don't want to read naughty words, hit "n"
now.

dykstra (dykstra@falcon.cc.ukans.edu) wrote:
: **********
: This is Greg Greenberg's posting, with a few lines fixed and
: spelling corrected by the VAX vms Spelling Checker.

: Thanks to GG for original post.  SGM
: **********

: I have graciously transcribed the Thursday Night Letterman for all of
: you to enjoy.  Why?  I don't know!  Why was Madonna such a bitch?  Please read
: it and enjoy it because it took way to long not to be read.  The conversation
: is almost verbatim, of course not all [applause] is noted, only the major
: ones. The bleeped out cuss words have been inserted, so those who don't
: approve, don't read on, they are in parenthesis.

: D is for Dave
: M is for Madonna
: P is for Paul

: Spelling is not accurate, but who cares, I've had enough of this for
: now.


: D	Our first guest tonight is one of the biggest stars in the world, in
: 	the past ten years she has sold over 80 million albums starred in
: 	countless films and slept with some of the biggest names in the 
: 	Entertainment industry.

: P	She's your guest!
: D	It's right there on her bio for heavens sake.  
: P	She's your guest.
: D	It's what it says
: P	She's your guest.
: D	Oh, she's, oh, everything's fine just relax will ya
: D	We're just trying to have fun

: D	Ok, Ladies and Gentleman, here she is Madonna

: M	I can't

: M	yes

: 	are you buying an NBA team, you buying the Bulls, you buying
: 	the Miami Heat, you buying a whya whya.. . .

: M	Untrue rumor, I mean that's like funny David Letterman

: [boos]

: 	luckiest man in the house!

: 	basketball.

: M	I always go there, and really I don't care, I mean

: 	games, you were, you were friends with Charles Barkely
: M	I wouldn't go that far
: D	You weren't friends with Charles Barkley?
: M	I don't think he understands the meaning of friendship.
: D	Oh, really he seems like he might be a hothead, that guy.

: D	Did you know him at all
: M	Hmmm,Hmm
: D	yeah
: M	Yeah

: M	(fuck)

: D	What a lovely young woman
: M	hmm, yes

: D	What happens when you take that out, will you ever take that out
: M	What happens whey you take it out?
: D	Yeah
: M	Both questions?
: D	Oh, come on, come on, what a, what a ,what am I speakin' Chinese
: 	here, now stop it.
: M	Listen, all you do is talk about my sex life on your show, so now you
: 	don't want to talk about my sex life when I'm on your show.
: D	Now what do you mean, do you mean because we refer to you
: 	periodically, we make jokes. . .
: M	Periodically?
: D	yeah
: M	You can't get through a show without talking about me or thinking
: 	about me.

: M	It's never a problem

: M	No
: D	Ok, we'll do a commercial. . .

: D	No , we'll. . . 
: M	Let's keep talking and film every second of it

: 	part of it. . .then we've , we've got something there, there,
: 	that's money in the bank, there [making hand gestures that signify
: 	money]
: M	Before, wait, wait, wait, before we cut to a commercial, I just want
: 	to know. . .um is that a rug?
: D	You talkin' about my hair?   well, alright what is that a swimcap? 
: 	What are you wearing

: [applause]

: D	Come on, Let's go [gets up and puts his dukes up] here we go, 

: [applause]

: D	come on

: [madonna gets up and takes his challenge]

: D	No, no,no, I got a bad neck, I can't, i can't just sit down
: D	Just sit down, Sit down, just have a seat
: M	Don't make me act a fool, Dave, alright
: [both laughing]
: D	Have a seat
: M	don't make me , do you want to touch my dress?
: D	I would, I would I would like to touch your dress, [touches dress]oh,
: 	very nice, very nice [sighs]
: [both sit down]
: D	I tell you what , we are going to do a commercial, and uh, we are
: 	going to wash her mouth out with soap. . .
: M	And he's going to smell my underwear
: D	and then we'll be right back
: M	and um. . .
: D	. . . kids, come on back

: Commercial Break

: D 	How do you do ladies and Gentleman, welcome back, Madonna is here, 
: 	Madonna and I are just sitting around smoking cigars and swapping
: 	recipes.
: M	[with cigar in mouth] yeah
: D	Also uh Counting Crows and the uh world champion grocery bagger, Did
: 	you have jobs like that when you were a kid?  Did you work in grocery 
: 	stores, bagging groceries, any of that?
: M	No
: D	Have you ever been in a grocery store?
: M	you really have , you really. . . 
: [both giggling]
: M	yeah [ to grocery store question]
: D	yeah?, good
: D	uh, and uh. . .
: M	You know you really changed since the last time I was on the show.
: D	Well we haven't seen you in like 6 years or 7 years
: M	You used to be really kind of , like, cool.
: D	I know, there is no bigger dweeb than me.
: M 	Money's made you soft
: D 	really, you think so?
: M	yeah
: D	in what sense?
: M 	Because you just kiss up to everybody on your show now
: [oohs from crowd]
: M	You do man, you're always kissing up to like all, I see all these,
: 	like you know movie stars coming here and you just  all  ga-ga,
: 	you should just give people a hard time.
: D	Yeah, I can suspend that behavior tonight if you'd like.
: [applause and laughter]
: M	[laughing] I believe you have already
: D	oh,  I know, now we're just kidding around, now explain to folks,
: 	we're just kidding around.
: M	Don't treat me special, Ok?
: D	Alright, sure
: M	I wouldn't want you to do that.
: D	Now what specifically are you getting at, what is driving you nuts 
: 	here? What's troubling ya?
: M 	About you or life in general?
: D  	We'll let's start with life in general
: M	No let's just get back to you.
: D	Ok,fine
: M	um
: D	First of all, you're not irritated at all, you're not irritated at
: 	all, I know this is a little act
: M	You are not irritating me.
: D	Ok, good
: M	Are you trying to?
: D	No, I'm not trying to irritate you
: M	Actually you do irritate me sometimes
: D	hmm, hmm
: D 	Well you kind of irritate me to.
: M	Really?
: D	You see we have so much in common
: M	I know
: M	Why are you always . . .Actually I brought something, to like make a	
: 	point.
:  . .
: D	Right, ok, good
: M	because you are always (fucking) with me on the show

Thanks, Ethan, for the explanation.  I hope I didn't sound too accusative 
in pointing out Bryce and your name.  I didn't mean to pin the blame on 
anyone, I just wanted some info.  

I can understand the situation that TEST was in, and I agree that in most 
cases, we have to blame the bunk SF laws and not the promoters.  I just 
wish the voice mail had indicated the age limit on wednesday instead of 
saturday night...

Also, since TEST seems to be the logical follow-up to SpaceLab, why not 
try to use the Trocadero, which is 18+?  If the upstairs space is too 
small, then how about downstairs?

References: <9404111827.AA09116@pilot.njin.net>
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.0.0 15dec93)

Subject: Re: And speaking of 21+ parties...bad time at Wicked
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Mime-Version: 1.0
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

The thing about King St. is it can be bad when it's too crowded and hot,
or it can be just about damn near perfect.

Wickeds have been drawing a cross-section of the club, street and rave
crowds for a long time.  Since King St. is so much smaller than 1015
Folsom, it's no wonder it got over-crowded.  

I am particularly sensitive to crowd dynamics which is why I wait for
that optimal time when the music and the crowd density and attention are
all converging.  It's cheaper than playing the lottery or the ponies and
overall a lot more fun!

At  2:32 PM 4/11/94 -0700, Seth Joshua Horvitz wrote:
>Thanks, Ethan, for the explanation.  I hope I didn't sound too accusative 
>in pointing out Bryce and your name.  I didn't mean to pin the blame on 
>anyone, I just wanted some info.  
>

>cases, we have to blame the bunk SF laws and not the promoters.  I just 
>wish the voice mail had indicated the age limiy instead of 
>saturday night...

>Also, since TEST seems to be the logical follow-up to SpaceLab, why not 
>try to use the Trocadero, which is 18+?  If the upstairs space is too 
>small, then how about downstairs?
>
>///////{{{{{{{{{{{(((((((((([[[[[[[[232]]]]]]]])))))))))}}}}}}}}}}}}\\\\\\\\
>Seth

It's all about money. Trocadero wanted $300 plus the bar. Downstairs they
try and get $3000 + $1500 bar guarantee. Unfortunately none of us (alex,
jonah, myself) have the draw to be able to count on covering those kind of
numbers....

Deco (where test was) keeps the bar and lets the promoters keep the door.

Really warehouses are the way to go, just very hard to find.

We are however trying, and you'll be happy to know that I've recently
struck a deal with Komotion (which is an artists collaborative
workspace/recording studio/party space in SF) to do parties there this
summer. They are absolutely *all ages* not just 18+.

take it easy
ethan

Date: Mon, 11 Apr 1994 16:59:02 -0700
From: scottie@uclink.berkeley.edu (Scott Everett Swiger)
Message-Id: <199404112359.QAA08986@uclink.berkeley.edu>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: VIVID
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


Hi folks, just a quick report on VIVID...it was a break-in (my first
break-in, and my first SC party) in an abandoned warehouse in SC, near
some offices and a gym so it went from about 1 to 6 am, but oh, how it
_went_!  This party reminded me of when I first started going to raves -
the crowd seemed relatively young (-21) and their energy, friendliness,
and high-spiritedness translated into a whopping Vibe - I haven't heard
that many whoops, screams, and cheers for a long time :)  About 150 
people attended, so I imagine the prmo
J

promoters were able to give some $ to the SC homeless shelter (this so,
Andy?).  My only real complaint was with the sound system, which was
sufficiently loud, but WAY too bassy, that muddy, reverberant bass that
vibrates your chest and hurts your ears.  The result was that for the 
first 4 hours, the music sounded remarkably similar, except when a break
would hit and you could actually hear the treble & midrange in the songs
for a short time, then back to the boom-boom-boom.  Another problem was
that the DJs were forced to play 40-45 min. sets, due to time constraints.

But don't get me wrong, these were just details in an otherwise wonderful
encounter with the South Bay house community, an experience that has
prompted Mother Earth Sound System to (more) seriously consider doing an
outdoor event down there in the future (so all you DJs and sound equipment
owners that are interested in a joint effort get in touch with us!  My # is
(510) 549-6233)

Anyway, things ended around 6:30, and we headed back north very pleasantly
surprised and satisfied.  Too bad throwing parties up here isn't as easy!
(Thank goodness for the beautiful outdoor sites around here, that allow
a bit of escape from the whole SF bureaucracy of party politics!)

Peace + respect to the Santa Cruz underground and all y'all!

			s   c   o   t   t   i   e
			*************************
			MOTHER EARTH SOUND SYSTEM
			*************************
			UNITE  CELEBRATE  SURVIVE

party was practically cancelled until someone hooked up with Cleo

on Wednesday that it was going to be 21+ because on Wednesday they
didn't know that they would end up at the Art Deco.

From lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM Mon Apr 11 17:08:13 1994

	id AA24757; Mon, 11 Apr 94 17:06:53 PDT

	id AA26679; Mon, 11 Apr 94 17:06:51 PDT
Date: Mon, 11 Apr 94 17:06:51 PDT
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9404120006.AA26679@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: janie@netcom.com
Subject: lighten-up
Status: RO


Well, lee and i decided to try out light-n up.  It was great fun.  
Considering that this is just the second week of the new season, critical 
mass was achieved (bearly, but achieved).  First off, they have made some 
physical changes at 1015...i.e., the upstairs room above the main bar in 
the sun room is now an outdoor balcony with tables and chairs.  
Unfortunately it was not open on Sunday but will be totally wonderful when 
it is.  They now have couches by the stage and removed the tables and 
chairs on the dance floor making the dance area larger.  The dark room
is much lighter now which makes it much more friendly.  Also, they have
replaced all beanbags with new ones!  

Markie was spinning in the dark room on Sunday and he was just 
an absolute madman.  Even the sun room had great music -- acid jazz.  
 
It was strange not to see too many of the old regulars from the past, but  
it's still a fun dress-up party, and i believe that in a few more weeks it 
will be right where it left off.   

Light-n up, boogie buffet, whatever you wish to call it -- Welcome back.

janie
 



From sfraves-owner  Mon Apr 11 21:19:08 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA26016; Mon, 11 Apr 94 21:19:08 PDT
Received: from mail.netcom.com (netcom4.netcom.com) by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA26005; Mon, 11 Apr 94 21:19:00 PDT
Received: from DialupEudora by mail.netcom.com (8.6.4/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id VAA04331; Mon, 11 Apr 1994 21:20:00 -0700
Date: Mon, 11 Apr 1994 21:20:00 -0700
Message-Id: <199404120420.VAA04331@mail.netcom.com>
X-Sender: jsl@localhost
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Subject: Wicked, GH, LU, 21+ (long)
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I went to Wicked (my favorite nightime event) this weekend to do some
promo, and of course have a good time.  I missed Markie's set :(, but came
in time to hear Jeno do the do.  Since I got there @ 4:00 and had to leave
by 6, I had to compact my good time into 120 minutes.  Success!  I talked
to a reliable source who said the boyz were in rare form for the most part.
I could not stay to hear Garth's set, but it was good to at least catch
geeno for a few.  Wicked is the shit!  A great party, a cool vibe, only for
the serious crackers.

GH was GOIN ON.  Although the numbers could use some improvement we had
Swing Kid & Leon spinning some deep trippy house beats.  This was the first
time I heard the Swing Kid and he is a really good DJ. He will be there
next week, so try not to miss him.  Leon is Leon, he really played a much
harder house set than I've heard him spin, but he was all that.  Al & James
I've ranted and raved enough about so...onto the front room!  We had Josh
doin the dub/soul/funk do, then Jason took over getting that deep soulful
groove along with some wicked funk, and then the Baroness took over to
bring things to the next level Chicago style.  That girl is the shit!  I
look forward to hearing her again this weekend @ GH.  Plus she's a really
nice and *real* person.  Loves her work and it shows.  I am continually
amazed at the amount of talent in SF,and the number of people just into
spinning.  Josh & Markie are probably the two DJ's who are *the* most
diverse in terms of music, style, etc.  Josh is a really smooth DJ who is
unparalleled when it comes to his work.  He and Markie are at THAT level,
and that's why it's always a pleasure to hear them spin.  It seems GH is
the place for grubbin and groovin, so stop by if your stomach is empty and
you want a kickin breakfast/brunch & brew! I met Larry & his lovely wife!
Man, it's so cool to see two people into each other!  Coolness!  Thanks for
coming!!!!

After GH ended, I strolled over to P's party @ 1015. Light-n-up was
cracker-jack central!  They ALL came out of the woodwork for that gig (I
HAD to steal that line Geoff; all props to ya for it tho!)!  When I got
there Mark Farina was fuckin it up!  Some bouncy, boomin Chi style grooves
that had the place rockin.  Even Markie got up to dance. I told P to open
that fuckin' roof to let that good air in, but the cops are WAITIN to shut
it down for the slightest reason, so until it cools off, that place will be
one hot house.  Cool party tho' and it continues to go on!

21+, King St., etc.
Contrary to what everyone thinks a party ought to be, I thought that Wicked
was *wicked*.  To address some of Sean's comments tho...Yeah, it is a posse
of sorts.  I would say that Wicked is being very true to their posse.  The
21+ *IS* the foundation of Wicked.  People have grown in the scene
listening to the boyz, and gettin' into the groove that is Wicked.  Just as
YSH has it's ideals and it's goals, and it's family, Wicked has theirs.
Nothin to bag on just because they have a loyal following.  Every party
does in one way or another.  In general I have always had a good time @
Wicked's.  I have not had such luck with the disorganized FMM, so I stopped
attending, and stopped talkin' about it (sorry for this brief lapse ;) ).
I am glad Wicked is still goin' although I do wish that they would feature
an SF DJ every once in a while (DM, puhleeze, there are others who spin
here hella more consistently than that Doc dude so..), but it's their gig,
and it is obvious their posse (damn near 1000) likes what they do so...I
guess I just don't understand the gripe Sean.  Yeah some woman bumped into
you and was rude, but like so many have pointed out to me there are some
general rules of etiquette, and when in Rome...Wicked is a dance party.  I
figure if you want to stand around and stare.gawk.talk why not do it near
the DJ booth, not in front of it?  There are plenty of places on either
side (including behind) that allow you to see all the manueverings of the
DJ, so I am perplexed as to why you did not choose those options after the
second bump...People can be really high on the music or other things and
may not *think* before they act/react.  So I know, whenever I am at a
Wicked to have that *long* fuse goin.  With 600-1000 people there it can
get messy.  There was no excuse for her behaviour, but then why bag on the
whole party just because of a tweek?  As for smoking and all the other
*rave* ecoutrements (lights, etc.), that ain't Wicked.  Personally I have
seen just about all the visuals I want to see, they are in the music!  I
don't need intellabeams and other shit to get me off.  Kickin beats, good
mixing, and motherfuckers goin off is what I need, and *expect* at a party.
Wicked did all of that + some.  I *HATE* smoke, I hate the smell of the
shit in my clothes, etc.  However, I have come to expect, reluctantly, that
there are alot of people who smoke on the scene.  I wish they wouldn't, but
they do.  I made a conscious choice to enter despite that, and accept the
consequences (laundry the next day and dark soot in my nose).

As for smile factor, it could be what you were giving off.  I saw penty of
people smiling and having a great time.  Lotsa hugs, lotsa smiles.  You get
what you give, in sincerity.  I understand how you feel about being "out of
it" (i.e. the family), but in some well established sub-scenes, you know as
well as I it can take a while to get comfortable, but once you do things
will happen.  It can be difficult; time is the answer IMHO.

I am *not* defending Wicked per se.  Just giving an alternative view of
what I consider a solid party.  I had a good time in my 120 minutes there.

21+ to me is very cool.  I like hangin' with 21+ cuz most of the people I
hang with are 21+.  It's not that I dislike 18+  (let's face it, the 18+
crowd comes and if they stick it out eventually become the 21+ crowd), it's
just that most of the real digs IMO are at the 21+ parties.  The
expectations are a bit higher in terms of music, and the DJ's have a bit
more flexibility to mix it up a bit, from what I've heard.  Also, if you've
grown up in a scene, your tastes may change over time.  Yeah I use to love
the tweaked out visuals and the overloading of the senses, but I could be
without all of that if the music is bumpin'.  It seems others feel the same
way.  Each type of club has it's own essence. 18+ can be really magical.
Witness the first Equinox.  All ages, and was so full of energy from
everyone that it just went ballistic. 18+ gives out that crucial energy a
party needs to get kickin, and should not be underestimated.  But neither
should an older crowd.  The energy and tastes may be different, but that's
all surface.  As long as what's underneath is real then there is room for
everyone to do what they want, how they want!  I just don't understand the
"don't smoke", "don't drink", "don't dose" mentality that people sometimes
bandy about.  I like to smoke, but not tobacco.  Love to have a few beers
in the night, and nothing beats a cold beer in the morning IMO.  And if
people wanna get loose, more power to them, as long as they respect others
and be somewhat considerate when they enter the next phase of
consciousness.

Man, it's just a party.  Light-n-up!

Chi style:  Charlotte is really good, and I have really been impressed with
her selection, etc.!  Mark F. is the man!.  I can't wait till Derek C.
Comes back so I can hear him do the do.  It is refreshing to hear that Chi
sound come to SF.  Just another ingredient in the Mix to make things even
more diverse!  Only in the Bay Area!  Fuck YEAH!!!!

Audi 5 & Pax,
John


=================================================================
                 Ain't no future in your frontin'

             --PGP Public key available upon request--
Best  : jsl@netcom.com
other : John_Lee.DPI@notes.worldcom.com

> 
> After I spent 15 minutes finding some legal parking that wasn't on a
> totally dark street,

I got there at about 1 am and parked on 2nd street in a reasonably
lighted (though dimly) place

> I walked over to the King St. garage, a space I
> went to once before and didn't like (and which other people have
> complained about). It's too small and has poor ventilation. Very very
> hot and smokey. You know, I read the other day that smoking has
> dropped considerably in California, though you wouldn't know it from
> the rave scene. If you're smoking in a closed space where people are
> exercising, then basically you just don't give a fuck about anyone
> else's health and what you're doing to them. Let's call a duck a duck,
> eh?

Well I don't like smoke and I don't like inhaling other's smoke but I like
the music and the crowd that goes to Wicked so i put up with it.

> 
> So anyway, it was $15, which was too much for a party in a small space
> like that with no visuals other than a few intellabeams. Acoustics
> weren't very good either, with the bass overwhelming everything. Poor
> Jeno was tweaking the knobs all night trying to get a good sound out
> of that space. I didn't connect the directions with that particular
> space, or I probably wouldn't have went. The Goons weren't being
> gooney like the other time I went there (Which Crunch wrote all
> about), so that was very cool.

It is true the sound was not as good as I have heard in that place, the
bass was _way_ to muddy and the highs weren't bright enough.

> 
> I hooked up with a couple of friends of mine I was supposed to meet,
> who had come with other friends, and after about a minute they danced
> off and never acknowledged me again. Well, foo.
> 
> And for that matter, something really bothers me about the Wicked
> crowd. I just don't feel like I belong. There *was* a big vibe going,
> but it was a strange one; not much smile factor.

There are plenty of smiles at wicked's but this is a psychedelic 
trance-dance party, most of the regulars a gettin busy dancing themselves
into oblivion.

> 
> And people kept bumping into me. I'd find a nice spot and dance
> without moving around a lot, and I'd get an elbow in the back, or
> someone would accidentally swipe my head. No big deal, but they were
> oblivious to it. A couple of people bumped me several times without
> even acknowledgeing me. I'd move off to a less crowded spot and the
> experience was repeated.

Yeah I got bumped alot to, it is newbies for the most part, they haven't
learned how to move through a crowd or dance without bumping into each other.

> 
> Friends and Family was even more crowded than this event, had just a
> big a vibe, and a lot of people were clearly out of their heads, but
> they were _nice_. If someone whopped you one, they apologised, or
> turned and smiled. No such courtesy at Wicked.
> 
> So anyway, Markie was laying down one of his fat house grooves, so I
> headed up cause I wanted to watch his technique. I found a clear spot
> near the turntables, and watched (with a big fat grin on my face cause
> he's so good) and bobbed a bit. After about 10 minutes, some woman
> shoves by me very rudely, and dances next to me. She edges over and
> bumps me. I look at her. She says something, but I can't hear it.
> I figure she's apologising (wow), so I turn my attention back to
> Markie. I get bumped again. And again. I turn and she's looking at me.
> I lean over so she can yell in my ear, and she tells me that if I'm
> not going to dance, go over there.
> 
> What?
> 
> I just shake my head and again turn back to Markie. She yells at me
> again. Says this is her spot. I tell her to be nice, I want to watch
> Markie. She repeats this a couple of times and I end up telling her
> quite forcefully to FUCK OFF!

Sean, Wicked IS NOT, I repeat NOT the party to just stand in front of the 
DJ and watch.  Mutha fuckers are always goin-off in front of the DJ and
It really pisses me off when I really getting into it and some (usually guy)
decides to just stand there and gawk at the DJ right in front of me.
I must admit she was rude, but I have wanted to do what she did to you, I just
have more restraint than she had.

> 
> At which point I was having strong thoughts of FUCK THIS. Is this the
> usual Wicked crowd or did I pick a bad night, or does one need to go
> to Wicked 30 or 40 times before people are nice to you?


Sean try calming down and dancing a bit, Wicked is a Psychedelic
Acid House Dance Party.  That is what the crowd comes there to do.
You notice there is not much of a chill out space there, it because it
is a DANCE party.

> 
> Well anyway except for that asshole, I really enjoyed watching Markie
> do his stuff. I never realized before just how much he works at it,
> and how much he samples. Cool beans.  I hung around for Jeno's set,
> which I had high hopes for, but I left an hour into 122 BPM wailing
> diva house, which the crowd really liked but which I wasn't in the
> mood for.

Wicked is a Acid House Party.

Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Before we stand on Sean's virtual toes for too long, let me just point
out that the clubber elbows-swanging-cigarette-jabbin'-plowin-through-da-
floor move is always well on display at Wicked (and ComeUnity too), and
it comes wid da territory -- but it comes down to *awareness*.  When the
*awareness quotient* goes up, you KNOW it.  And some of those club-types
turn out to be some of the most aware on the floor, when the time comes.
Sometimes the party needs to get hot'n'sweaty
'n'bumpy'n'crowdy before it gets OFF.  It's damn disappointing when it
doesn't, of course, but more times than not it does if you hang in there.

That's why timing and patience are an essential part of catching the groove.

imho

phred
