---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Tue, 12 Apr 94 01:37:14 MDT
From: Juggler <IH23%UTEP.bitnet@utepvm.ep.utexas.edu>
To: Vrave List <v-raves@gnu.ai.mit.edu>
Subject: Little Red Raver Girl fairy tale!!

                     Little Red Raver Girl
                            by
                      Noah "juggler" Lee
              (respect to the original of course)


[ed's note: This evolved from a trip to Albuquerque for the Orbital X
rave. We had to keep ourselves entertained on the four hour drive with
no radio or tape deck. Gotta do something!!]


   Once upon a time, cuz, heck, what better time than that, there lived
Little Red Raver Girl. She was a happy little girl who loved to wear
baggy overalls and the groobiest striped shirts. Her red pigtails and
keen shoes could charm the Blow-Pop (tm) out of any raver's mouth.

   Well, it seems that Little Red Raver Girls's promoter grandmother was
not feeling so hot cuz an event she was throwing wasn't going so great.
Little Red Raver Girl decided to take a skippity trip over to her grand-
ma's house to deliver some lollipops, a new whistle, and a hit of X. She
only wanted Grandma Promoter to feel better. :)

   Little Red Raver Girl set out into the scary city with a warning from
her tired out hippy mother, who warned her of the evils of the world. As
usual it went in one ear and out the other. Little Red Raver Girl only
wanted peaz and unity and didn't like to hear about the bad people out
there because they gave off such bad vibes.

  Hippity, trippy skipping down the avenue whistling some housy, funky
toon, Little Red Raver Girl hardly noticed the Big Bad Gothic Girl come
out of the shadows of an alley.

"Whoa!" said Little Red Raver Girl, "You put quite a fright into me!"

"Yeah, whats new?" angrily replied the Big Bad Gothic Girl.

"Hey, you wanna sticker? I got heart stickers!! Or how about a
lollipop?" asked Little Red Raver Girl.

"Nah, I don't want no stinking lollipop," gothically replied Big Bad
Gothic Girl. "Where you think you're headed to in this dark, cold,
miserable world of ours??"

"Well," said Little Red Raver Girl, "i'm off to see Grandma Promoter
to deliver some goodies so she can be happy and throw the phattest event
this side of the world."

"Big event eh?" interestingly replied Big Bad Gothic Girl. She thought
to herself, "Hmmmm....you know I bet if I get those goodies I could
throw a dark, scary event the way I want it."

"Well, I best be off now. Peace, love and unity to you Ms. Gothic Girl."

"Uhh...yeah, sure."

And Little Red Raver Girl was off. But so was Big Bad Gothic Girl.
Seeing as how she hung out in dark alleys all night she happened to know
a shortcut to Grandma Promoter's warehouse. She sped ahead to beat
Little Red Raver Girl there.

[here's a plot twist in the story! Oooooohhhh!!!]

Little Red Raver Girl continued on her way wondering why someone would
paint their face chalk white and wear all black clothing on such a
beautiful day. Just as she was daytripping this she ran into a funky
phresh young man stepping from a record store.

"Yowza!" exclaimed Little Bloo DJ Guy, "Sorry about the bumping action
there."

"Oh excuse me! I wasn't watching where I was going. Would you like a
sticker? A lollipop?"

"Yeah! Sure! Thanks a lot!"

"Here ya go," said Little Red Raver Girl as she stuck on a groovy frog
sticker onto Little Bloo DJ Guy's chest. She hands him a lollipop and
asks, "Are you a DJ by any chance?"

"I certainly am! In fact i'm supposed to be spinning later at Grandma
Promoters event. You going??"

"Yesssss!!! I'm her granddaughter! I'm Little Red Raver Girl! I bet you
are Little Bloo DJ Guy then!" exclaimed she. Quite a good guess too
seeing as how he had on a bloo hoody shirt with "Bloo DJ" in holographic
type on it. She's quite the quick witted one ya know. :)

"Yep! That's me! I'm sooo happy to meet you! Hey, I gotta run but i'm
going over to Grandma Promoter's Houze of Funky Toons for the Pre-Party,
so I hope I see you there," said Little Bloo DJ Guy.

"You sure will. Be seeing you later!" happily exclaimed Little Red Raver
Girl. And off went Little Bloo Dj Guy. Little Red Raver Girl breathed
a sigh, for Little Bloo DJ Guy was sooo sweet and just the nicest guy
she had met in the longest time. She really wanted to hear him spin
and get to know him better. "Maybe at the pre-show," she excitedly
thought.

[Meanwhile...]

   Back at Grandma Promoter's Houze of Funky Toons, the bass was
bumping as Grandma prepared for the rave and was stressing hard getting
ready for the show. Then, all of a sudden a "ding, dong, boom boom boom"
came from her specially designed doorbell.

"Who is it??" asked Grandma Promoter.

"Tis me! Little Red Raver Girl" replied a slightly gruff and not quite
happy voice.

"I best let her in to help me and cheer her up. She sounds as bad as
I do!" thought Grandma Promoter to herself and opened the door.

As soon as she had in leaped Big Bad Gothic Girl and she quickly tied
up Grandma Promoter in a extra long pair of fishnet stockings and
handcuffed her to the sink in the bathroom with her handcuff belt.

"You can't do this! It doesn't promote peace and unity!" cried Grandma
Promoter. "Lemme go and i'll hook you up with a hit of X and you can
dance all night with us and feel the groove. I guarantee you'll feel
better."

"Nice try grandma. Stuff it," and Big Bad Gothic Girl promptly
crammed a black candle into Grandma Promoter's mouth to quiet her down.
She then went on to change the music to something much less happy and
got into some of Grandma's  clothes. "Ick...these are soooo bright and
happy. I think i'll throw up."

At just about the time she was done there came a sound in the warehouse,
"ding, dong boom boom boom."

"Yeah, who is it??" asked Big Bad Gothic Girl who was now dressed like
Grandma Promoter.

"It's me!! Little Red Raver Girl!!" came the reply. "Let me in Grandma!
We need to change that music and make you feel phresh!"

Big Bad Gothic Girl opened the door and let Little Red Raver Girl in.

"Why Grandma! What a pale, icky, clammy white face you have!" said
Little Red Raver Girl.

"The better to scare you with my dear." came the reply.

"Why Grandma! What morbid, black fingernails you have!" exclaimed Little
Red Raver Girl.

"The better to scratch off your face with you little happy hippie wanna
be!!" yelled Big Bad Gothic Girl and she LEAPED from her baggies and
pounced on Little Red Raver Girl.

Just at that moment the door swung open and in sped Little Bloo DJ Guy
with his patented Bag O' DJ Music. He rapidly threw on the phattest of
toons and started spinning and cutting it up as best as he could.

As he did this, a strange feeling overcame Big Bad Gothic Girl. She
felt a pumping bass shaking her body. She felt a warmth overcome her
entire soul. She wanted to stop almost, but she couldn't help herself
from getting up off of Little Red Raver Girl and dance. She got down.
She boogied. She threw massive moves. Little Red Raver Girl rushed to
the john and freed Grandma Promoter. They went out to the dancefloor
right as a large crowd had gathered at the door. The pre-party was in
full effect and at the heart of it was Big Bad Gothic Girl dancing
everyone into amazement. She gave everyone a hug and some a kiss she
felt so good. The vibe was the best they had ever felt that night.
Grandma's event went off like never before and was of legend promoter
proportions. Little Bloo Dj Guy spun his best set and fell deeply in
love with Little Red Raver Girl to everyones happiness.

And they lived happily ever after.

T h e  E n d.

[The people in this story are totally fictional and any relation to any-
one in real life is purely coincidence. Heck, I made it up on a trip
for Christs sake!! :) Hope you liked it. You can reprint it, distribute
it to anywhere you want as long as you don't modify it and keep my
name attached to it as the author. Peace to all of you and keep the
vibe alive. - - - Juggler [Noah Lee - ih23@utep.bitnet]

From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9404121443.AA02776@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: Music
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Mark:
> I just got the William Orbit - Strange Cargo III disk and think it's some
> of the best tasting ear candy I've ever heard.  Are Strange Cargo and
> Strange Cargo II as good or better or how do they compare?

Strange Cargo I&II are definately worth having.  II is a little darker
than I, a nice mix of atmospheric ambience and new age electronics.  S.C. I
has some nice guitar work and plenty of electronics as well.  The
Orbit disk closest to S.C. III, however, is Bassomatic - diverse dance
music, also very well produced.  If you're really into sound
production, you'll probably enjoy *everything* William Orbit has done.
Also, look out for the remixes of Water From a Vine Leaf which offer techno
and ambient versions of the first cut off of S.C. III
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com

John S. Lee writes:

 > ...I guess I just don't understand the gripe Sean.  Yeah some woman
 > bumped into you and was rude, but like so many have pointed out to
 > me there are some general rules of etiquette, and when in
 > Rome...Wicked is a dance party.  I figure if you want to stand
 > around and stare.gawk.talk why not do it near the DJ booth, not in
 > front of it?  There are plenty of places on either side (including

I really wasn't in anyone's way. I was off to the side, specifically
because I'm tall and didn't want to block anyone's view (Geoff was
there too, he may have seen me). And I *was* dancing (to quote my own
post, I was "bobbing"). This person was just plain rude, as was
several others. Maybe I just don't do enough "E", but I'm not into
mosh. And I was in a *good* mood at that party. I was really up for
it. Oh, well. I know what to expect next time, so if I go and it does,
I won't complain about it.

Sean

Jeez, I thought  that raves were mosh as sublimated sex, which is
a massive improvement on mosh as violence.  I *like* mosh, it's like
body surfing with real bodies!  It's all part of inner peace through
sensory overload: it's about epinephrine & pheromones, we all make 'em 
ourselves, the other condiments can come later if at all.  Trances are
swell, but this "alone together" stuff can add up to no shared vibe,
which is a loss, imnsfho.

I think I'd best get me to a Wicked real soon now.  And if it's a good 
night, I'll have left without even caring where the dj's were.  If I wanted
to be a spectator, I'd just stay at my ternimal and post to mailing 
lists!  (hmmmmmmmmm.)

AstroBoy

From sfraves-owner  Tue Apr 12 11:15:03 1994

From: alves@bethe.ucdavis.edu (David Alves)

Hello, I was in Sacramento on Friday for a bachelor's party (very dirty ...)
but later went to Ooga Booga (a weekly in the calendar).

My brief report is that it wasn't bad.  I didn't pay attention to who
the dj was - it looked like one guy for a long time.  The music was
generic house that got a bit repetitive.  I just like more variety.
Decorations/lighting were minimal.  That is ok with me.

It was above a bowling alley in a new area that was good for a few hundred
people.  (this bowling alley has had after-hours dancing for years)
18+ and $6

It closed around 4:30-5:00 (not 6:00, like the door said) but this might
have been because of a *tired* looking dj.  Maybe some of you under-employed
SF djs could get a job ...?

People were young, beautiful, and very positive.                    
Dave

SF Rave report  by John Draper (Cap'n Crunch)
---------------------------------------------

  I don't know where to start,  there was so much going on.   I'll start off
with a report of a Golden Gate park rave at the Polo fields thats supposed
to start by 1 pm.    We get there,  but with the Soccer World Cup taking
place soon,  the fields are full of Soccer related activities,  and no sign
of the party.    After calling the info number,  in case it got moved,  we
confirm that its to take place there.   Upon our return,  my friend
recognizes the brightly colored speakers getting loaded on the fields, 
and a few familiar friends hanging around.   Apparently the organizers 
didn't make arrangements for the generator.   I left again to pick up a friend,
and by my return,  the sounds were starting,  but it wasn't that well attended,
but I enjoyed the clear sunney day in the park,  dancing,  warming up for the
evening,  fully intending to go to Wicked.

   In the evening,  I call the Wicked line and discover the location this time
to be at 174 King St.  (King St. garage).   Bummer!!  After such bad vibes 
from attending the last rave at the King St garage,  I had to have my lungs
pumped out after getting seriously ill due to the lack of proper ventilation.
Reports I've gotten from friends confirmed this,  even at 4 am,   it was hot
and crowded.    Instead,  I opted for another outdoor event "Earth House Hold"
scheduled for Saturdy evening.    Before leaving for SF to pick up a friend,
I get word that its to be located out at the Berkeley dump (Same place as
the Full Moon rave was held several months ago).    Just before heading out
there,  I call the info line again just to make sure everything is OK,   but
learned it got moved to the end of 24th St in Potrero district (Not one of
my favorite places,  but it was at least outside).

   I get there around 1:30 am and things were just starting.   This wasn't
one of those 500+ parties,   but the small crowd was just about right,  so
we danced until daylight.   On the way back to the car,  we get reports that
the New Moon rave is really happening,   but it's about a 2 hour drive through
winding roads to get to Pt Reyes Beach.    I somehow manage to get there by
about 9 pm to observe a small crowd,  2 sound systems,  beautiful surroundings,
and spend the early morning to mid afternoon there.   Darcy spun the most 
outragious German trance 140+ bpm that had me skittering about the sand
like an insane idiot.    After that,  someone else (I didn't get his name)
spun Ambient so I took a break from dancing,  and tossed the frisbee around
until the next DJ went on.    Funkey house music soon started to fill the
air,  and I was back dancing again.    Eventually,  the DJ segued into a
really groovy trancey set putting me in pure bliss as I was chilling around
the beach.

   Soon after that,  the park pigs came up and we had to shut down,  due to
the faschist rules they have on amplified sound.    We pack up and head back
to SF,  where I dropped my friend off so he can crash,   but I wanted to party
some more,  so headed over to Light-n-up.   By about 3 pm,   things were really
hopping.   This,  being the 2nd week of Light-n-up,  the crowd of people were 
really groovy,  and good vibes all around.   Markey Mark was spinning some
mixtures of Acid Jazz,  then sped things up into the more traditional housey
sounds when the dark room closed.   Light-n-up closed down shortly after 5 pm,
sp headed over to the EndUp because I still wanted to get in more dancing.

   After several hours,   Aaron picked me up,  we headed out to eat,  shower,
and get cleaned up.    At about 8 pm,  we head back to the End Up,  and danced
until they closed down the outside area (About 11:30 PM).  Shortly after that,
I head back,  being awake an entire weekend without sleep,  chalking up yet
another ravingful weekend in the Bay area.

Keep the scene alive.....
CC

 Would somebody please explain (for someone that's probably totally
ignorant of this) what Indo (or Endo) is exactly?  How's it used?
Side effects?  Thanks for your time.
------------------------------------------------------------------------

Marijuana.  Indo is slang for Indica, as in Cananbis Indica, one of the
three species of Marijuana.  Or slang for marijuana grown indoors instead
of outside (in-doe, get it?).  Depends on who you ask.

-Mark

in response to your  message about the 21+ problem,let me explain our 
situation.when trying to  put together a party ,youy have certain ideals 
that you try to reach ,such as getting a space thats all ages,having 
cooldoor people ,comfortable space ,free water,etc.we always do 
everything we can to live up to our own ideals.the space on saturday 
night was friendly,comfortable,we didnt have to pay rent thus the 3 
dollar door,the standard of music was excellent and we managed to keep it 
going after hours.the fact that we were slightly limited by 21+ thing was 
minor to anyone who made it there.have you ever considered getting a fake 
i.d.?most parties that we do ,including s.p.a.z. on wednesdays will have 
our own door staff.we will usually let anyone in as long as they show us 
any piece of paper that resembles an i.d. and we rarely check the actual 
dates.this is sometimes risky and when we feel it`s not safe,we become 
more careful,but 90% of the time we can operate that way.it's against the 
law,but so what.we want to have a party and we want everyone to come so 
we'll take the chance.on your end ,you could help us by getting a fake 
i.d. and reducing the risk.in the meantime ,we're working on getting a 
legal license to make s.p.a.z. an 18+ event,but this will take time and 
money,and we're currently making about $15 each a night.we'd appreciate 
any information about getting an all ages permit!!

planet 6 sound

Rave-o-RAma-Or Sticky Wicked,

I wrote last week about going to Basics, Jazid Up, Motion, Come/Unity...I was
on a  regular Rave-o-rama vacation for the Easter bunny this
year....Outfitted with my SFrave guide I stuttered off, "down the rabbit
hole,"  to parties that I can't attend during the week  while living in
Monterey. 

Well, I ended up at Wicked and (at the End Up on Sunday), and met, and talked
to more people. than ever before.  Wish I had know about Light-n-Up. The
guide said, "look for details." 

It  is probably my sixth Wicked party.  I had my fears about going to the
King Street garage, a return to "Summer and Smoke." But, it wasn't so bad.
Someone said the ventilation had been improved?  True?.  The sound has
sounded better there, but the spinning hasn't.

Three of my former students from Monterey were at the party. They came up and
couldn't believe I was there!! !Now they're twenty-five, living in the City,
and ravin'  It was bound to happen. I told them my friends of friends story
who took me to my first rave. We ended up dancing all night, and I stayed
over at one of their places. Now I've got another place to stay!!

I had more people ask me how old I was (42) and were really excited I was
there.  Some people get excited because they imagine, or  want their parents
to be there. They've imagined it before, and when they see me dancin, they
know at least, it's possible. Especially since I'm having a great time. The
smil-E look doesn't hurt either.

My other friends from the city showed up at 5:00am, and I saw two people from
Monterey there.  The world is definately getting smaller. I've danced or
practiced martial arts all week, so I'm really starting to get my rave legs.
I'll be trancin and dancin soon.

My house is for sale in Monterey. I plan to move to Santa Cruz, then rent a
room in the City for the summer. If you see a tall, old guy getting younger
by the moment, say hello. 

I'm still going to put on a Big Sur renegade. I promise you it will be a
magic party, at a magic spot. The dj's I've talked to already are into
it!!!I've gotten good responses back from the sound guys too!!!

I'm sorry I didn't meet Sean at Wicked, I really thought I would. Give it
another try Sean, and I'll see you down the road..........

.robertj-...............................Monterey Rave Posse....aka,
roadmaster, motorhead.......Thanks SF.

"only the shallow know themselves"

              or                                                ............
.rojohns@eis.calstate.edu

Editorial : Stimulants, Hallucinagens, and the Generation Gap

The Epidemiology, Attitudes, and Pharmacology 
  of LSD Use in the 1990s

MDMA: Its History and Pharmocology

LSD and Ecstasy: Pharmacology, Phenomenology and Treatment

Inward the Mind's I: Description, Diagnosis and Treatment of

The Role of the Laboratory in the Diagnosis of 
  LSD and Ecstasy Psychosis

LSD: History and Toxicity

The New Psychedelic Culture: LSD, Ecstasy, 
  "Rave" Parties and the Grateful Dead

Subject: Ten15 update

I think I have some good news for y'all!  There was much discussion 
recently regarding Ten15's problems with being open for after-hours  
i.e., past 3:30am).

This week Ira succeeded in persuading the Court that there's no reason we 
should be singled out (as we have been for the past several months).  So 
starting this week, the club is once again capable of throwing 
all-nighters. (Yeah! ;-} ! etc)

The staff has also been working to try to help improve our ability to 
give y'all a more copacetic environment, and yes, even Ira is coming 
around.  If you've been discouraged with us recently, I suggest giving the 
club another chance.  Swedish DJ Henrik (hope I spelt it right) has been 
truly amazing on the last two Fridays, providing me (the Lighting operator) 
with two of the most hypnotic "trips" I've ever taken without chemical 
inspiration! 

Hope to party with you soon!...Come by the booth and say hi!   

Kerry

>From BUEHRING@sonoma.edu Tue Apr 12 04:40:19 1994
Date: Tue, 12 Apr 1994 4:40:16 -0700 (PDT)
From: BUEHRING@sonoma.edu
To: SFRaves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU
Message-Id: <940412044016.21c0aaf3@sonoma.edu>
Subject: RE: VIVID
Status: OR


>Hi folks, just a quick report on VIVID...it was a break-in (my first
>break-in, and my first SC party) in an abandoned warehouse in SC, near
>some offices and a gym so it went from about 1 to 6 am, but oh, how it
>_went_!  This party reminded me of when I first started going to raves -
>the crowd seemed relatively young (-21) and their energy, friendliness,
>and high-spiritedness translated into a whopping Vibe - I haven't heard
>that many whoops, screams, and cheers for a long time :)  About 150 

Thanks, Scottie, for the kind words.  We were stoked that you and the
MESS crew made it down and joined us (+ you spun a groovin set :).


>Anyway, things ended around 6:30, and we headed back north very pleasantly
>surprised and satisfied.  Too bad throwing parties up here isn't as easy!

Throwing the party was far from easy!  About a week before the date, 
we lost our original location "in the hills."  Thus began a mad, daily
search for another location.  Legally obtaining a warehouse with less
than a week's time is next to impossible, so we decided to go with
an easy, outdoor location (in the Bonny Dune area).  But low and
behold on Friday the rain came pouring down.  Actually, we had a last-
resort location to fall back on, but late Friday afternoon, we recieved
word that it could not be used either.  The party was nearly called off.
But that evening we found a beautiful warehouse and it's doors were 
open!

Unfortunately, it was right next to a health club that closed at midnight
so we couldn't start setting up until then, and had to cut down
the set up to a bare minium.  Piecing together a sound system in a dark
warehouse, with little time, and with a hundred or so impatient people
running about is very stressful.  At this point, things seemed *very*
sketchy and chaotic.  But as soon as the first beat came on things got
moving.

The crowd did indeed have a pretty good vibe.  It was mostly a 
younger bunch but also with some mix to it.  The dance floor stayed
full all night with blasts of energy here and there.  There were no
problems, everyone was pretty mellow! 

We scrambled out of there at about 6:30 (before people started 
showing up at the health club).  Everyone who was left helped clean
up and the place was left like we were never there.

I am stoked that we pulled it off!:)


-James from Santa Cruz


ps. We were able to donate 3 gigantic bags of canned food to the homeless 
plus a cash contribution to The Pajaro Mission (feel free to write me for
details).  Thanks to all who attended!  

pss.  Also a thanks to Ethan (raging acid set) and Bryce who 
came down and helped us out:)

----------------------------------------------------------------------

I posted the Li'l Red Raver fairy tale to the alt.gothic newsgroup to see
the reactions (along with the heading "In case you're wondering, here's 
how goths figure in the imagination of the ravers").

Here are the reactions:

---
No, I think this is the image goths should be promoting of themselves.
Until that Big Bad Gothic Girl "got down", she was...interesting me...

Caoi'mhi'n.
---
Oh, I agree. I can actually go to raves and enjoy them, but I find goths
much more interesting. I keep picturing the BBGG dancing to Temple of
Love or some other such song that so offends the Ravers (they hate
that line about "Life is short and love is always over in the morning"
for some reason...) and I just want to end the story there... Still,
it's kinda interesting to imagine what the BBGG looked like when she
got down. Did she still wlk around the dance floor, waving her veil
around, raising her arms to the sky, etc., trying to fit it all into
the beat of the new Orb song? I wish I could imagine that.... Maybe
some more smart drinks and a little X will do he trick.
---
Ich!  I don't know about you folks, but it sure scared me.  Just
think...  If Goths could be converted to ravers!  The Horror!  Sure sent
a shiver down my spine (I liked that part of it though).  I can see it
now... Goth-Ravers: "hey little boy want a lolly?  It's laced with
strychnine!  Yummy yum yum!"
Ha Ha HA!
---
[rave horror story deleted]

AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAGGGGGGGGGGHHHHHHHHHHHHHH!!!!!!!!!

Back, back foul fiend, or be impaled on the blood blackened blade of
my sword-cane.

Perhaps we should give it 0.5 of a goth point for not having a happy ending ?
---

So there you go.

  Well, I don't know.  I guess I have this real personal reaction, but
I want to share it with you.  I hope you don't mind.

  Down here in LA at _Velvet_, I personally danced to gothic
(_Temple_of_Love_ by Sisters of Mercy), Techo ("Its time to start
running" by _The_Mesiah_ (?)), and even some housey beats (*mumble* by
_Dee_Lites_) this very weekend.  There were both Black&Whites
(gothics) and Smile&Stripes (housers) there in abundance.  We all
grooved together in one big family -- not all of us happy -- it was a
_real_ family.  Some of us were down right spoo-oo-oo-ooky.  But I
respect that, I have some understanding of that headspace.

  After all, *I* am one of those (ex?)goth's the goth's are scared
of.  In 1982 (when it still was 'Death Rock') I was danceing to
Bauhaus et al. at _Fetish_ on Melrose blvd., and in 1992 I was
danceing to Moby et al. at _Circa_92_ in the Shrine Auditorium.  These
days I am even more mushy and warm.  I house.  But it happens: one day
you discover that there really is happyness in the world, and some of
it can be yours.  And you begin.

  If this house nation is really gonna be inclusive, it has to include
even those who would exclude us.  Like the Big Bad Goth Girl.  That is
one reason this (radical?) fairytail is so right -- unlike the Big Bad
Wolf who is mercylessly axed to death, the Big Bad Goth Girl just
grows into another member of the house family.  All the ravers accept
her into their party.

  It is harder in real life.  It is hard to transform your self from
goth to house.  It is hard to accept goth (or any other "not-with-it
folks") into your house.  But still we try, grow and learn, all ways
trying to honor, love, and respect others, to live in peace, and of
course, dance our asses right off!

from deep within the house nation, with love,

j'
--

Well, to let you in on a big secret, goths actually _do_ smile and have
a good time and feel such things as happiness. They even joke amongst
themselves (hence the reference to "goth points" in the responses....)
What "scared" them about the story was just the fact that they tend to
be very introspective people and tend to find other such people more
interesting than loudly-dressed, loud people like Ravers. Most goths
would happily join the house nation as long as people will leave them
alone every once in a while so they can crank up the Faith and Disease
and read. Oh, and as long as they don't have to go outside in
daylight, of course....

From sfraves-owner  Wed Apr 13 07:58:39 1994

	id AA25423; Wed, 13 Apr 94 07:58:29 PDT
Received: (laura@localhost) by soda.berkeley.edu (8.6.8/PHILMAIL-1.10) id HAA11167; Wed, 13 Apr 1994 07:58:26 -0700
Message-Id: <199404131458.HAA11167@soda.berkeley.edu>
From: laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Wed, 13 Apr 1994 07:58:24 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: Courtney Love-Cobain  <payn@chaph.usc.edu>, sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: Little Red Raver Girl fairy tale!!
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


I don't know how people can make such horrid generalizations based
on what type of dance music subculture you happen to follow.

"Goths are more introspective."  "Ravers are loud."

This is such bull malarky.  I know loud and obnoxious goths (well,
except when they are on the dance floor) and I know shy ravers 
(well, except when they are on the dance floor).  My point is that
someone's dance floor behaviour may not necessiarly correspond to
anything, it's just how they are reacting to their surroudings and
the music.

Maybe it's more a case of that old lemmingism-I-have-to-fit-in.  Maybe
some people who like goth music etc behave the way the do so they can
fit in.  Ditto for some people who like house/techno.  I've found that
most of all people just want a place in some sort of society that they
can belong in, so a goth would wear black and a crucifix and a raver
would wear orange and a glowstick but it's really all the same thing
now isn't it?

I thought the story was really cute . . . but then I'm neither a goth
or a raver.  Don't take yourselves so seriously folks.

Laura

Previously, jpp@markv.com said:

>   It is harder in real life.  It is hard to transform your self from
> goth to house.  It is hard to accept goth (or any other "not-with-it
> folks") into your house.  But still we try, grow and learn, all ways
> trying to honor, love, and respect others, to live in peace, and of
> course, dance our asses right off!

The transition is easier if  you like industrial/goth -> hard trance/acid.
I think my new goal is to find records to best mix into industrial ->hard 
trance. I went to The House of Usher and those people cannot mix. (So I 
am picky about mixing these days, but I understand they try). The point 
that the transition of goth to house is difficult, because of the style 
of the beats - happy, hip-hoppy, wailing diva, disco groove. 

All of this shouldn't matter since music in all cultures have the same 
effect on people - it brings them together. Some might eventually 
crossover into a completely genre of music and maintain a balance between 
the two. Not to flame you, but it's not "your house," it can be anyone's,
as long as people are open minded to new things and people. It would be 
nice if people didn't have to label others - goth, raver, hippie, geek, etc.
It associates the idea of those characteristics portrayed by the media. 
However I am glad the people on this list see beyond all of that hype.

Cindy makes a comment about how the transistion musically from goth
to house is difficult because of the styles.

Well, there are other forms of music played at raves . . . the dark
trancey acid that I like seems to be a good place to start.  When
I was at the Eighth House two weeks ago playing things like Seefeel's
"Plainsong" and Bio-Dreams' "White Sands" there were people who dressed
like the goth stereotype and people who dress like the raver stereotype
both getting deep into the trance.

Someone on alt.rave has already suggested that deep trance (in the techno
vein they meant) could be a good musical bridge between the two subcultures.

I was talking to someone at a party last Friday who was telling me that
trance does get played at traditionally goth clubs and they also said
that the Eighth house was promoted to the goth, rave, and art
communities.  If the sounds system had been better it would have gone
over a lot better, but you've all heard that line on this before.

(I can't back up because of my editor but yes Cindy, I know you know
there are other forms of music, I was being rehtorical.  And, since
I'm adding disclaimers and stuff, I do fully understand that "Courtney
Love-Cobain's" posts were humorous, I actually agree with where he/shie
(I mean she) is coming from, I was just in general criticizing those
people who actually BELIEVE those stereotypes and try to keep 
propagating them by being offended by the whole thing.)

See you all later,

Laura

Subject: gothrave
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU

Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

So says laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa):
> I don't know how people can make such horrid generalizations based
> on what type of dance music subculture you happen to follow.
>
> "Goths are more introspective."  "Ravers are loud."
>
> This is such bull malarky.  I know loud and obnoxious goths (well,
> except when they are on the dance floor) and I know shy ravers
> (well, except when they are on the dance floor).  My point is that
> omeone's dance floor behaviour may not necessiarly correspond to
> anything, it's just how they are reacting to their surroudings and
> the music.

When I first read this last night, I responded (privately, I think) that 
my letter was meant as a joke, and left it at that (although I suspect
that she recognized that I was joking and meant something else that I
missed, it being late on a boring night and all). Then I went to sleep, 
and suddenly I awakened in the middle of the night (aka 9:30am) and 
realized that I actually wanted to answer her seriously. Don't ask why.

There really is more to being a goth than just clothes and music. In fact, 
the clothes and the music really aren't nearly as important as the 
mindset. By definition, a goth is _gothic_, which means that she (I use 
the word "she" here as the generic pronoun just to balance out all the 
times "he" is used the same way) has romantic and introspective tendencies, 
that she can recognize the beauty in the dark and gloomy. Naturally, 
there are other tendencies that go along with this--the pretentiousness 
(although every goth I know recognizes that she's being pretentious and 
enjoys it all the more because it's such a conscious, maybe even 
self-conscious, form of pretention), the aristocratic mindset, the quiet 
self-absorption, and so forth.

Of course the truth is, everyone has this side, and the goths may not be 
on average any more gloomy or introspective than anyone else. The 
difference is, this is the side of themselves that they enjoy expressing, 
and therefore choose to express.

Similarly, there's more to being a raver than the clothes and the music. 
Everyone at some point in her life feels infectiously happy, feels like 
she can change th world through the sheer force of her joy. This is a 
wonderful feeling. The central difference between ravers and other people 
is that this is the side that ravers enjoy expressing, and therefore 
choose to express. Sure, the clothes are a fashion statement, and they 
look cool, but when it comes down to it, the real reason these clothes 
are raver clothes in the first place is that they're fun and expressive.

Of course these two expressions are't necessarily contradictory (at 
least I hope not--I personally can and do fit in somewhat with either 
group, so either they fit together pretty well or I'm just a 
schizophrenic). But despite the similarities between the raver and goth 
subcultures, the differences are more fundamental. All the more reason, 
of course, to seek unity. To use Marx's (no, not Gary Marx of the Sisters 
of Mercy, don't be silly) ideas in a way which would probably annoy him, 
if the gleefully post-borgeous ravers are the antithesis of the 
artistocratic goths, there has to be a synthesis. And it ought to be fun 
getting there....

And all this explains why, as I mentioned earlier, goths can and do smile.

To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: if you ever go East
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I often get requests from people for rave info for the east coast.
I'm always happy to help, but please give me as much lead time as
possible so I can track down the ne-raves calendar.  I don't always
save it every week since I don't get to go to NYC very often now that I
live out here in SF.

Generally, I get the calendar sometime during the day on Wednesday.

If you have enough lead time before your trip you can also hop on the
ne-raves calendar list briefly before you go.  That way you'll
get the calendar automatically dumped in your mailbox on Wednesdays.

To sub to it, send a message to majordomo@techno.stanford.edu and put

        subs*ribe ne-raves-cal

in the body of the message (but use a c instead of the * in my example).

Otherwise, you can just drop me a line and I'll send you the calendar as soon
as I get it myself, but please be patient as it only comes out once a week.

Laura

On Wed, 13 Apr 1994, Don Labutay wrote:

> -> What ever happened to those XDZebra reviews that were posted by 
> -> Pete Ashdown periodically on sfraves?
> -> 
> Also, what ever happened to Pete Ashdown?  That last time I heard about him, he was
> selling techno cds on the Internet rec.music.marketplace newsgroup. 
> 
Well, actually Pete moved to New York and is currently in a common-law 
marriage with Lydia Lunch who both collaborate with the Orb (Alex, 
Thrash, Frank Sinatra, Stan Kenton and 2 of the Shirelles) part-time. 
Look for his (quite popular) pen-name -RICH^H^HARD JAMES /qBL00DY HELL- 
on the new 5LP/4cd Orb double-gatefold release "Big Fluffy Clouds live 
remixed remixes 94." I think Pete plays the accordion on track 32. I don't 
have the track name though as they are only identified by scratch-n-sniff 
panels in the booklet. I think it smells like a burnt chocolate used gym 
sneaker, but then again so does tracks 48, 2, 13, 22, 14, and 50 (Bingo!)

As for XDZebra, a certain animal rights group felt the name was a slight 
to certain species and thus after a drawn out legal battle, the name was 
changed to XDAnimalswithstripesofblackandwhite to be more correct. You 
can find it in the XDFTP site FTP12/klxwty,megafoo:12:3:Pinto in the 
directory :

/top/next-to-top/still-alittle-lower/watchyourhead/almost-there/reviews 

Oh, I forgot to mention this is only accesible to users on the FishNET 
network connecting both machines in Antarctica. All files are compressed 
with Mu-zip (pronounced myoo-zeep') so don't forget to pick up the 
shareware decompressor De-load on your way out. Of course, the reviews 
mainly cover the growing number of artists composing with samples from 
Electronic greeting cards, but they're still well written (8/10).

But seriously, he was just on idm today (wasn't he?) I haven't tried 
digging up any XDZebra's lately, but Pete seems to post quite a bit, so 
he's definitely around. In fact by the time I get around to finishing 
this message, he will have probably answered your question. Jeez. I gotta 
get out of the house more...

Just 400IUs of JMRTNKO supplies you with 1333% of the US RDA!

From sfraves-owner  Wed Apr 13 17:21:17 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA17920; Wed, 13 Apr 94 17:21:17 PDT
Received: from lightning.berkeley.edu by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA17622; Wed, 13 Apr 94 17:20:17 PDT
Received: by lightning.berkeley.edu (5.65c/CHAOS)
	id AA09122; Wed, 13 Apr 1994 17:20:11 -0700
Date: Wed, 13 Apr 1994 17:19:57 -0700 (PDT)
From: Franklin Shotwell <shotwell@ocf.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: Earth House Hold
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9404131601.A8720-0100000@lightning.berkeley.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


	Thanks to those of you who showed up at Earth House on Saturday.
This was my first flyered gig, spinning, and I had a blast!  It was kind 
of bizarre having such glossy flyers for such a low-budget party.  Noah, 
the promoter, grabbed a corner of someone else's print run for cheap.
	So we set up at the Albany landfill spot, around eleven, and 
found out that the power 'switch' (an infernally and unnecessarily 
complex mechanism) on one of the turntables was busted.  As Noah and I 
were pulling out to go get another table, Albany's finest pulls in for a 
bust.  Too bad I didn't have my trading cop cards handy to get some 
autographs.  
	So we moved it across the bay, and got started at 24th & 
Illinois.  Noah was distressed at this point, with the fact that none of 
the dj's were anywhere to be found.  I wasn't.  It just meant I could 
spin a 3 1/2 hour set.  I opened up with the D St. Herbie Hancock Megamix --
a style I must confess I lifted off of John D (thanks for the tip), and 
worked electro breakbeats in and out of the next couple hours of mixing.
	Gary Nurriso showed up around 4:30 and took it off for real.  
He's got a breathtaking progressive house style -- mixed seamlessly, with 
just enough vocals for the crowd, and just enough acid to keep it 
interesting. 
	I was psyched to finally meet John Draper, dancing as furiously 
as ever, and Bryce and Pat out on the street by their car, laying down 
their own chill space, in an Ultraworld manner.  As much as I lurk on the 
list, I still don't know many of you.  Hope to remedy that over the 
course of this upcoming summer o' luv, and I'll fill you in on the next 
Earth House.

		...minor...

X-Signed: PGP-Detached-2-3,

   ba0w/WxXOQpWdgk/LuJiP5PLel7eXRs+KwGOIBKPT006tTwIv3qN2vGx
Date: Wed, 13 Apr 94 20:04:19 PDT
From: jpp@markv.com
Message-Id:  <9404132004.aa24468@hermix.markv.com>
Source-Info:  From (or Sender) name not authenticated.
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

> From: Sea of Sin <kawakami@noc.usfca.edu>
> Date: Wed, 13 Apr 1994 08:05:06 -0800 (PST)
> 
> Previously, jpp@markv.com said:
> 
> >   It is harder in real life.  It is hard to transform your self from
> 
> The transition is easier if  you like industrial/goth -> hard trance/acid.

  Actually I was talking about the transformation of my inner
landscape, not preference in music (or clothes, etc.).  I expect
others may have a similarly hard time.  But, I don't know this for a
fact.  I think the music, and fashion transformation is trivial by
comparison.

> Not to flame you, but it's not "your house," it can be anyone's,
> as long as people are open minded to new things and people.

  Not a flame at all!  Exactly my sentiment.  It isn't "my house" or
"The Wicked Posse's house".  But I, or "The Wicked Posse" can act to
either welcome other folks, or drive them away.  When you drive folks
away you are burning down the house, and damping the vibe.  When you
are accepting, open and welcoming, then you are building a house with
those around you, you are energizing the vibe.

> It would be nice if people didn't have to label others - goth,
> raver, hippie, geek, etc.  It associates the idea of those
> characteristics portrayed by the media.

  I agree.  Labels are dangerous to assign to people.  But labels are
nice for a hint about what kind of music to expect at a club.  When I
pay $20 for one thing, and hear another, I can be very disapointed.
BagPipe, Tin Whistle, and Fiddle music is nice...._sometimes_ =).

  And in my many years being a 'death rocker' I certainly encountered
a large variety of people who all claimed the 'death rocker' label.
Homogeneous they were not.  I would never say 'all goths are unhappy'
or that 'all ravers are happy'.  But there is a difference between the
philosophy that seems common to house and that which seems common to
gothic.  At least to me.  My psychology is affected by what I see and
here, and what I choose to see and here is affected by my psychology.
I loved _Temple_of_Love_, and that says something.  Think about it.

> However I am glad the people on this list see beyond all of that hype.

  Me too.

j'

> From: jpp@markv.com

> [...]  It is hard to accept goth (or any other "not-with-it
> folks") into your house.  [...]

  Wait... _I_ said that??  I thought I spent entierly too much time
thinking out what I had to say... but I missed that...  Sigh...

  If someone didn't know me well they might think that I felt 'goths'
weren't with-it.  I don't.

  I have met some 'housers' who think 'goths' are not-with-it,
and some 'goths' who think 'housers' are not-with-it.  I think that
this kind of attitude is easy to develop, and hard to avoid.  And
most importantly, I endeavor to avoid this kind of attitude myself.

Respect, when I am aware enough, and apologies when I am not,

j'

 This time I'll be bringing a CD/cassette/AM/FM portable ,
so bring some music media with you . Looking out my window, I see 
blue sky and little fluffy clouds ... see you there! 
				Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com
------------------------------------------------------------------
Just a quick reminder to let everyone know about
today's SFR South Bay Lunch ...

When: Thursday  
Time: 12.00 noon
Where: Greer Park, Palo Alto

Directions:

* From 101 (South or North) take the Oregon Expressway Exit
  Northbound: Past San Antonio Road 
  Southbound: Past University Avenue 

* Left at the first signal - W. Bayshore
  (it's a frontage road that takes you south again)

* Follow this road approx. 1/4 mile (pass apartment complexes on right)
  
* You will see the park on your right hand side. Turn into the first 
  driveway on your right.

* We'll meet on the grassy knoll , behind the round baseball fence.
  Next to the restrooms and ball courts.

Bring lunch, toys, yourselves!

From: Sun Kim <sunkim@sfsuvax1.sfsu.edu>
Subject: Position Paper
To: SF Raves <sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9404141311.A15969-0100000@sfsuvax1.sfsu.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I will be writing a position paper on the 'rave' scene, specifically
whether the scene enhances or detracts from leisure expression /
participation (creativity, optimism, love, playfullness, curiosity, simple
joyfullness, resilience, explorativeness, eagerness, imagination,
frinedship, sensitivity, trust).  I'm having a really hard time trying to
find references for my paper.  Can anyone tell me of any references that I
could use? 


From sfraves-owner  Thu Apr 14 13:14:23 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA29892; Thu, 14 Apr 94 13:14:23 PDT
Received: from sfsuvax1.sfsu.edu by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA29883; Thu, 14 Apr 94 13:14:12 PDT
Received: by sfsuvax1.sfsu.edu (5.57/Ultrix2.4-C)
	id AA17830; Thu, 14 Apr 94 13:13:56 -0700
Date: Thu, 14 Apr 1994 13:13:55 -0700 (PDT)
From: Kendall Griggs <kgriggs@sfsuvax1.sfsu.edu>
Subject: need RIDE to Anything Box/ slowdive
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
In-Reply-To: <199404141348.GAA11560@netcom9.netcom.com>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9404141318.B14292-0100000@sfsuvax1.sfsu.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I apologize if I completely shift subjects here, but here's one synth 
band with lots of energy that'll make you want to dance your ass off!  
Remember ANYTHING BOX? In 1990, they were radio/club semi-demi-gods with 
such hits as "Living in oblivion", "Jubilation (This Thing Called Life)", 
and "Soul on Fire".  Believe it or not, I have yet to find a 12" lying 
around of "Living in Oblivion."  I have been a fan since 1990's album 
_Peace_.  Now they have released a NEW album in '93 called _Hope_, which 
is fabulous.  Yet, it has virtually been IGNORED by the so-called 
"alternative" radio station, Live 105.  Just because they are on a new 
indie label (from LA) does NOT mean they should be avoided.  They NEED 
support to gain back the status they had while they were on Epic.  Epic 
tried to commercialize them and turn them into a rock band; instead of 
using synth/techno energy.  The vocals are mesmerizing, and their dance 
versions are PUMPED up.  I wish DJ's would play them more.  Check them 
out, it's "worth" it.

For the matter at hand, they are PLAYING down in Santa Monica at:
		Fair City
		2020 Wilshire Blvd.
		Santa Monica, CA

		Date: 4/28/94  (Thursday)
		Time: 7:30.

I NEED a RIDE there, and will be GENEROUS with gas $$$$.  If ANYONE from 
up here is going down there, PLEASE let me know and we'll work something 
out. I am considering other options, so the sooner I know, the better.

ps.  Slowdive kinda induced a trance.  Or I may have inhaled something. 
Rachel was more mesmerizing this time around...they NEED to do "waves" 
through. 

that's my .02

Subject: This Week's SF Rave Guide!
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU (SFRaves)
Date: Thu, 14 Apr 94 13:38:31 PDT

Another interesting weekend with lots of choices; practically everything
looks intriguing.  The low-budget weekend would be Basics, the Organic
Golden Gate Park party, and Good Housekeeping on Sunday.  But the others
look quite reasonable too...

I've also heard about something tonight at Art Deco (510 Larkin) and
another free party Saturday night, but I don't have details.  If
anyone knows more, post it!

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------- UPCOMING RAVES IN THE SF/BAY AREA ---------------------
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Thursday, April 14th - Pure Space
        jeno, spun & ernie
        375 11th St at Harrison St, 21+  415.267.0640
        [will be weekly]

Thursday, April 14th - Illusion
        DJs Garth  Eric Hill  Liquid
        + Caliban in the ambient room
        18+, 364 S Market St, San Jose.

Friday, April 15th - ZenDada
        Djs Jeno and Taj
        1015 Folsom Basement, $5, 21+.  12am-7am

Friday, April 15th - Basics
        Tony  Doran  Josh & others
        Free, bring a smile :)  415.905.9629

Friday, April 15th - DJs Wool and others in a Santa Cruz underground
        415.292.3289

Saturday, April 16th - Organic party in the Golden Gate Park Bandshell
        Jeno  Graeme  DJ Dan  Digit  Neon Leon
        11am-6pm   415.266.8215   415.267.6129

Saturday, April 16th - House
        Chicago Style - Freddy Bain  Lil' John  Orlando
        SF Style - Tommy Rogers
        415.677.7952

Saturday, April 16th - Close Encounters
        DJ Alex  Jonah  Zero  Ethan  Julio See  & special guests
        $7 before 11pm, $10 after.  415.708.5697  415.560.3275

Saturday, April 16th - Dig!
        an evening of metaphysical jazz stylings and underground funk vibes
        featuring the Broun Fellinis with the African Identity
        and DJs Mark Farina, Charlotte & Dani
        doors at 10, band at 11.  $5, 21+.
        Kennel Club, 648 Divisadero @ Grove, SF.

Sunday, April 17th - San Jose Women's Collective outdoor party
        in the La Raza picnic area in Hellyer Park
        free!

Friday, April 22nd - Earth Day Wicked
        415.512.5713

Saturday, April 23rd - Organic
        Jeno  Tony  Graeme  DJ Dan  Simon  Markie
        18+  415.266.8215   415.267.6129

Saturday, April 23rd - Contact
        DJ Jan Cooley
        9:30p - ? (free before 10:30p)
        2721 Broadway, Sacramento   916.484.5661 

Sunday, April 24th - Afternoon Vibe
        djs Dave Andersen/Tony D./Thomas
        4:00p-11:00p, 2721 Broadway, Sacramento.  916.484.5661

Saturday, April 30th - Anthem of the Sun
        Jeno  Thomas  Simon  Spun  Markie  Carlos  Rick Preston 
         Dutch  Tony  Ernie Munson  Chris Lum  Ghost  
        415-979-3005

Saturday, April 30th - possible Basics
        415.905.9629

Saturday, May 7th/Sunday, May 8th - Beltane Wicked
        415.512.5713

Saturday, May 14th - Fundamental
        Spun  Josh  DJ Dan  Ernie Munson  Rick Preston
        Visuals by Donovan, Pure, Ken Stone
        $10, 18+ w/id.  415.487.4339  415.486.9400

Saturday, May 14th - possible Vision
        415.267.4800

Saturday, May 28th - SFRaves presents - In The Light
        Laura, Markie, and guests
        12-6pm, Golden Gate Park at the Bandshell

Here are some weeklies, in the house/techno/acid jazz/etc vein.  Some
of them may have ended - let me know when that happens...

---------------------------- T h u r s d a y --------------------------------

Your Sisters' House - 9pm discussion - 10pm-4am funkygrooves - 415-435-7575
Universal Groove - $5. 415.281.5913  510.869.2727
Ajax - Acid Jazz w/Julius Papp (San Jose)
Lift - Digit, EFX, David Harness & guests - 55 Natoma, SF - 415.267.5984
Inspirations - 610 Coleman Ave, San Jose.  9pm-2am, 18+.
        408.236.2102  415.267.6974

------------------------------ F r i d a y ----------------------------------

Corduroy City  - $5 - call for DJs and location - 415.974.9715
Life/Twirl - Sound Factory - 525 Harrison @ 1st, SF    415.543.1300   21+
	DJs include Doc Martin, Aaron O, Pete Avila
Deep - Nikki Rivera, Jason Hayes, Lewis. 6th & Harrison (the End-Up)
Raw - Neon Leon, Jan Cooley, David Harness & guests - 540 Howard - 415.243.8181
Ooga Booga - 2600 Watt Ave (upstairs @ country club lanes) - 916.484.4006

---------------------------- S a t u r d a y --------------------------------

Dorothy's Tribe - Neon Leon, Rick Preston, Tommy Rogers & guests
	6am-2pm at the EndUp, 401 6th @ Harrison.  $2.  415.979.4515
Funky Buddha - presented by Spundae - 435 Broadway, 9pm til late.
        Head on House DJs: Simon, Henrik, Ernie, Jay-J, Mic, Eric Lacy, Josh.
        House of Funk & Killa Grooves: Bam Bam, Miquel, Melvin J, John Howard
        21+, $8 before midnite.  415.764.2922
Dig! - DJs George and Charlotte. the Kennel Club, Divisadero & Grove.
Contact! - various guest DJs. $5, 18+, 2721 Broadway, Sacramento.  916.484.5661

------------------------------ S u n d a y ----------------------------------

Groove Morning - 6am-3pm, 18+, $5.  Mission Rock, China Basin.  415.905.6441
Sunday School - Tommy Roger, Aaron O, Swing Kid, Smile-E.  6am-midnight.
        free before 2, $2 after.  the EndUp (6th & Harrison).  415.543.7700
Signs of Life - 375 11th @ Harrison (DNA).  $3, 6am-3pm, 21+
Good Housekeeping - presented by Flavor - w/sound technicians Alfie, James,
        Markie, Harry Who & live guests.  7am-4pm, $4, 21+.  
        spuds & stuff @ 9.  1190 Folsom St, SF.   415.928.2710
     [4/17 - Josh, Charlotte, Harry Who, Swing Kid, Alfie, James & no cover!]
Light-n Up - 1015 Folsom, 21+, 9am-5pm.  415.267.7615
Sunset - 2pm-sunset. Free! - 415.985.5264

Bulletproof boat party - 5-9pm pier 40 (usually last Sunday of each month) 
        Tickets at Bulletproof 629 Haight (255.7168)
Ameba Ambient Tofu BBQ + films - BBQ lit at 5pm; bring BBQables, blankets,
        records.  1732 Haight.
Spundae - various guest DJs - 9pm-5am, 21+, $5 b4 12 - 55 Natoma. 415.974.9389
I-Beam Tea Dance - Neon Leon & others - 5pm-1am. 1748 Haight.
Zuvuya - DJs Josh, Charlotte & guests - 10pm-4am, 1015 Folsom - 415.281.8494

------------------------------ M o n d a y ----------------------------------

Mushroom Jazz (Jazid Up)- acid jazz w/Mark Farina, Thomas, Ammon, Is,
	Alex, Kevin, Bob Taylor and/or Julius Papp.
	$4, 10pm-4am.  1190 Folsom St, 21+. 415-905-8811
FreeLife - every other Monday at 551 W.Julian (@ Montgomery) in San Jose.
Pepper - various djs - 510 larkin @ turk  (Art Deco), 21+

----------------------------- T u e s d a y ---------------------------------

Together/Happiness - 21+, $5, 1015 Folsom - 10pm-3:30am - 415-979-8825
Check - rare grooves & house - Alfie, James & guests - 
        the I-Beam, 1748 Haight @ Cole.  21+, $2.  415.668.6006
Body and Soul - Larry Blakes, Berkeley 10pm-2am, acid jazz and funk $3

--------------------------- W e d n e s d a y -------------------------------

Motion - 400 S 1st St, SJ (side entrance of F/X). 21+.  
Fixx - Jan Cooley, Phillip, Aaron, Neon Leon.  Cocktails, 9th & Howard.
Stone Groove - acid jazz n' cosmic funk.  presented by Bulletproof.
        $3, 21+, 9pm-2am.  Miss Pearl's, 601 Eddy @ Larkin.  415.255.7168.
        [April DJs - Mark Farina, Gavan, Dani, Alex, Kevin, Gerry V, Kirk,
                     Andrew (Groove Merchant), Harry Who]
SPAZ (Semi-Permanent Autonomous Zone), 2 sound systems, new DJs and live
        performances each week.  $3, 60 Sixth Street.  info 415.sols666 
Recycle - every other Weds w/Carlos, Dutch, Christophe & guests. 415.599.3750
Pacific - 683 Clementina @ 8th (between Folsom & Howard) - 
        Starts at 10pm, $5.  415.985.5264
Gemini - josh, spun, donald glaude, la paix, rick preston, dj dan,
        carlos & dutch.  415.979.4915

------------------------------- Info Lines ----------------------------------

Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087.  Usually has 5-10 listings, updated daily.
Elmo - 415-884-ABCD

------------------------------ Radio Shows ----------------------------------
Sunday mornings 1-3:30am - Minor Minor KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
Sunday evening 6:30-9pm - Mescalina, KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
Sunday evening 9-11pm - Universal radio at 89.1 FM.  Trance dance
        and power house.  Guest DJs weekly (SF & East Bay)
Sunday night 10pm-2am - Ambience w/Michael Hayes & David X  KWOD 106.5 (Sac)
Mondays 10pm - Belladonna, KFJC 89.7, Foothill College (Los Altos Hills)
Tuesdays noon-3pm - "London Jamaica" w/Unknown KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
weeknights ~9pm - the Modern Mix w/Steve Masters KITS 105.3 (SF)

If anyone has info on any other events, submit them! I can't possibly hope
to get all the info every week.

At  1:16 PM 4/8/94 you warmly wrote:

[...]

>On a related note, I happened to be watching, "rescue 911" at a friend's house
>a while back and there was this story about a guy who was hanging out of a
>window of a highrise apartment that was on fire.  Smoke was pouring out from
>behind him and it wasn't clear if he would be forced to jump to his death.
>Two firepeople with scuba tanks and facial masks and the whole outfit
>roped down from the roof into an adjacent window, broke the
>window and entered through it.  It was obvious that they were risking their
>lives.  Well they rescued the guy and later they interviewed him.  He was
>basically saying  that he was so surprised that two humans who didn't even
>know him would actually put their own lives at risk to save his.  And he was
>crying and he just couldn't believe their kindness.  And I was crying too.
>And it gave me the warm fuzzies all over.
>
>All right so it wasn't related to raving but I just wanted to relate that
>story.  Hey, the warm fuzzies is a great feeling too.  Acts of human kindness
>and compassion make my day.

Shows like that and sometimes COPS, do that to me a lot.  It shows there
isn't enough human kindness in the world, especially when we hear shit
coming from Bosnia and Rwanda.  And then when we see things like that on a
show, it catches our emotions off-guard.  Thanks for sharing...

- Steve
>
>ex-fractal surfer who wanders all over the place (topic-wise)
>Space

I read in the calendar about the SJ Women's collective party happening
on Sunday....now, I talked to someone in that collective and she said that
there wasn't going to be a party.  But I talked to Harry last night and

> Call me stoopid;  Call me clueless;  But, who are these Goth Girls???
> and what is the music they listen to???
How 'bout if I call you Steve?

> - Steve (hopelessly out of date :)
Oh, good, it's your name anyway....

OK, goths are people who dress gothic, listen to gothic music, and think
like goths. Real helpful, right? Basically, the clothing is black, often
covering either as much of the body as possibly (sometimes down to veils 
and gloves) or as little as possible, most often just a simple long black
dress. The accessories are steel and silver jewelry, usually with mythical
(including Christian or otherwise) significance, and sometimes (thanks to
Andrew Eldritch of the Sisters of Mercy, the gothest guy around) dark
sunglasses and leather jackets, despite the fact that they don't really
fit the look. Most goths are pale with black hair (not always natural,
of course). Some wear makeup designed to make them look more corpselike,
but this is not as common as it was in the days when Fad Gadget made fun
of his followers for it. Gothic music is an interesting genre, better
defined by the tone of the music and lyrics than by the sound (it's hard
to imagine where the common ground is between Siouxsie and the Banshees,
Christian Death, Sisters of Mercy, and the Cult, in purely musical terms).
Other important bands, besides those four, are Fields of the Nephilim,
Joy Division, Bauhaus, and the various splinter groups and precursors of 
all of the above (except for New Order, of course). Goths also often
listen to industrial bands like Skinny Puppy and sometimes to ambient
and atmospheric music.

Speaking of hopelessly out of date, there are those who say the goths 
are hopelessly out of date. In one sense, this is certainly true--they
celebrate romanticism, aristocratic and--well--gothic myths (like, oh,
I don't know, vampires), and so forth. Of course the Sisters of Mercy
seem to be more cyberpunk than vampiric, actually, and their videos are
full of large metal structure, factory machinery, lasers, black leather,
sunglasses... but still, the prevailing ideas in gothdom are romantic.
In the other sense, this is somewhat true. The real heyday of gothic
music died out in the mid-1980s, when some of the bands that the goths
held close to their hearts suddenly became mainstream alternative bands
(the Cure, Siouxsie), others broke up (in particular, the Sisters of 
Mercy--of course Andrew just formed a new band, as he is wont to do,
but there's only been one album since 1987's Floodland, and that one
album really kind of sucks), and for various other reasons (in LA, for
example, The Crypt shut down), many goths just stopped being goths. Of 
course the most dedicated continued on, driving farther to find clubs
or just being gothic at home. Recently, for no good reason as far as I
can see, there was a new explosion of gothic music, and cities like
Sydney, Melbourne, London, Los Angeles, and even Salt Lake City suddenly
have thriving gothic scenes, mostly made up of newcomers of course. It
is to these, who most outsiders see as trendy copycats (and maybe they
are, but the old goths certainly don't mind them), who are usually
called out of date, for celebrating what's essentially seen as a retro
scene (tell that to the Neph or Rosetta Stone, though) as if it were new.

If you want more info, I've e-mailed a FAQ from the alt.gothic newsgroup
to Steve, and I'll be happy to send it to the list if anyone wants it,
but to avoid wasting bandwidth, I won't send it unless someone asks. You
can also FTP it from ftp.maths.tcd.ie in /pub/music/gothic/gothic-faq,
or if you have Web access, you can find it in http format at
http://gothic.acs.csulb.edu:8080/~vamp/Gothic/Text/gothic-faw.html,
or ask me for it.

------- Forwarded Message

To: interesting-people@eff.org (interesting-people mailing list)

From: Tony Rutkowski <amr@isoc.org>

The NSF-NIS NSFNet statistics were released today.  A couple of developments
of some strategic significance:


A new traffic record was reached in the Internet world. Traffic on the NSF
backbone grew by a stunning 20.7 percent - nearly 2 terabytes - during the
month of March, for a new total of 11.226 Terabytes per month.  This is the
largest single jump in the history of the Internet.

The browsing services continue to grow at remarkable rates.  Gopher traffic
grew by 17.6 percent and http (WWW) grew by 32.9 percent to a new total of
one-half terabyte per month.  Indeed, http traffic grew by a total of 0.7
percent of total NSFNet traffic, and is now 5th in service rank after
ftp, telnet, netnews, and smtp mail.


The new statistics are embodied in the latest Internet Society
powerpoint graphs:

ftp://ftp.isoc.org/isoc/charts/internet.ppt and browsing.ppt

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
 Anthony M. Rutkowski
 Executive Director
 Internet Society

 12020 Sunrise Valley Dr, Suite 270
 Reston VA  22091

 fax: +1 703 648 9887

Here are some excerpts from today's Chronicle article:

"Mathew Fox the avant-garde priest defrocked by the Vatican for his 
free-spirited theology, will become an Episcopal priest and begin a
high-tech, high-decibal 'Rave Mass' this year in the basement of Grace
Cathedral.

"Fox got the idea for the rock and roll liturgy after visiting a band of
unorthodox young Anglicans in England - where the "Rave in the Nave
features loud music, women dancing in bikinis and vieo monitors flashing
messages such as "Eat God".

[...snip..]

"During Fox's visit to England, the Mass was held in the basement of a
sports complex and included 42 television sets flashing images of
galaxies, dancing atoms, DNA, lunar eclipses and male-femal archetypes

[...snip..]

"Episcopal Bishop William Swing said he has talked to Fox about his
theological ideas and has determined that 'his understanding of Jesus
Christ is both orthodox and biblical.'

[...snip..]

"Fox acknowledged that designer psychedelic drugs such as 'Ecstasy' are
popular in the Rave culture in both the United States and England.

'That's exactly what they (the sponsors of the Rave Masses in England)
are trying to combat', he said. 'The Rave culture did not begin with drugs.  
You can go drugs, or you can go religion, go transcendence, go for the
spiritual power of community and ritual.'"

[...snip..]

I don't think "Christian Rave" is any more of an oxymoron than "Pagan Rave"
There are people who go to parties for basically religious (or spiritual)
reasons (like me :) and I must say that  as far as I'm concerned, the 
ultimate goal (at a good party) is to reach some sort of state of trancendance,
so I applude his actions.  I think if anybody actually read and thought about
the things that Jesus said (or stuff that people said that he said), it in 
itself is not a bad thing.  I think if you read the words and decide the meaning
for yourself that is good, this is my experience of a good party, there isn't
someone up there telling you "how to rave" or how to feel or anything like that
but yet a lot of people who go to parties are having a group experience of
"communitas" as it was called in the early church.

 anybody know how I can get in touch with him?


			G

i am really shocked that any church could/would want to do this...and i
bet this guy fox has never been to a "real" rave (i love when they 
talk about that loud rock n roll at raves...and i bet they will 
have no problem getting permitts for sites..ahhhrrg!)...susie (:  from the 
San Francisco Chronicle April 15, 94

     'RAVE MASS' PLANNED FOR GRACE CATHEDRAL

by Don Lattin

     Matthew Fox, the avant-guarde priest defrocked by the Vatican for his
free-spirited theology, will become an Episcopal priest and begin a
high-tech, high-decibel "Rave Mass" this year in the basement of Grace
Cathedral. 

     Fox got the idea for the rock and roll liturgy after visting a band
of unorthodox young Anglicans in England--where the "Rave in the Nave" 
features loud music, women dancing in bikinis and video monitors flashing
messages such as "Eat God." 

     "I'm grateful it's in the basement," said the Rev. Alan Jones, dean
of Grace Cathedral, the seat of the Episcopal Diocese of California. 

     Rave Masses are all part of a high-risk, high-energy attempt by Fox,
53, and the local Episcopal church to get the attentin of the young
Americans bored by traditional Christian worship. 

     During Fox's visit to England the Mass was held in the basement of a
sports complex and included 42 television sets flashing images of
galaxies, dancing atoms, DNA, lunar eclipses and male-female archetypes. 

     Fox--whose blend of Christianity, eco_mysticism and liberal politics
led to a 10-year-old batle with Vatican authorities--now describe himself
as "a post-denominational priest." 

     "We don't have a lot of time to fiddle around with whether we're in
this demomination or that one," Fox said.  "I challenge you to find any
20-year-old cho can tell the difference between a Presbyterian, aLutheran,
a Methodist, an Episcopalian and a Roman Cathlic.  An who cares?" 

     Under Vatican pressure, the Dominican order dismissed Fox last year
after he refused his supervisor's order to leave his Institue for Culture
and Creation Spirituality, based in Oakland, and return to Chicago. 

     Fox, an internationally known author and lecturer, was accepted into
the Episcopal Church as a lay person earlier this year in a quite ceremony
at Grace Cathedral.  He is now being tutored in Anglican studies and is
scheduled to be ordained as an Episcopal priest in December. 

     He hopes to celebrate the first Rave Mass in October. 

     Episcopal Bishop William swing said he has talked to Fox about his
theological ideas andhas determined that "his undrstanding of Jesus Christ
is both orthodox and bibical." 

     "What makes him so controversial is that he attempts to translate the
central revelation of Christianity in a vocabulary that is not easyly
recognized in traditional circles," Swing said. 

     "He attempts to be a conduit for allowing a new generation to come to
terms with creation and the primary human need to worship God." 

     In a statement he plans to read at a press conference this moring at
Grace Cathedral, Fox laments that the Roman Catholic Church "is losing the
spirits and adventurous energies of the young." 

     "The Roman Cathlic Church is this archdiocese alone is busy selling a
dozen of its churches rather than asking the obvious quetion: Why do
people no longer want to attend church?" his statement reads. 

     Officials at Holy Names College in Oakland, the Catholic school that
has housed Fox's Institute for Culture and Creation Spirituality for the
past decade, said that they are "saddened" by Fox's decision to join the
Episcopal Church but that Fox will continiue to be associated with the
ecumenical institute. 

     Fox, whose mother was an Episcopalian, said in the interview that
"there is more elbow room" in the Episcopal Church today. 

     "Look what they've done about ordaining women, about maintaining a
balance of lay and clerical decision-making," he said.  "On issues of
birth control or married priests, they have not hid their heads in the
sand." 

     Fox acknowledged that designer psychadelic drugs such as "Ecstasy" 
are popular in the Rave culture in both the United States and England. 

     "That's exactly what they (the sponsers of the Rave Masses in
England) are trying to combat," he said.  "The Rave culture did not begin
with drugs.  You can go drugs, or you can go religion, go transcendence,
go for the spiritual power of community and ritual." 

     Jones, a native Briton who has met the Anglican priest who started
Rave Masses in England, said he has mised feeling about Fox's move from
the Catholic Church. 

     "He's a brilliant communicator and reaches a generation in a ver
exciting way," he said.  "But I am sad for the Roman church.  It's a
failure for the whole church when someone can't be at home in his won
tradition." 

     Jones also has some misgivings about Rave Masses. 

     "It sounded horrendous until i thought about my 17-year-old-son," he
said.  "We need to rish more to communicat the good news to young people. 
If it doesn't work, we'll try something else." 

     Fox is scheduled to preach at Grace Cathedral at 11 a.m. April 24.

To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Fri, 15 Apr 94 15:28:27 EDT
Subject: Jesus raves?
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I have a serious problem with any organization trying to use the 'rave' 
enviroment.  It takes a lot of personal effort for many just to be open, 
friendly, and have fun.  Renegade parties are an escape from the power
structure that most nightclubs are a willing and integral part of.  It is not
easy to let yourself become succeptible and theological  or politcal head
trips can bring fear and paranoia--just the playful use of some of its
imagery by the visul artists can really bug you out. I'd be seriously UNHAPPY
if it was 'for real.'  No message needs to be conveyed--the event speaks for
itself.  The use of heavy-handed, mass media style communication (how many
TVs did they have?) to try and channel the energy is a blatant attempt to
steal something that they lost long ago.  The good part is this means that
they acknowledge the fact they we got it like that!  Keep it goin.
BTW, I do agree that most of the Jesus stuff is, in of itself, a pretty
positive message but I don't think it can be separated from all that is 
associated with it at this point in time.

phuture

Matthew Fox is a Very New Age kind of person. Many New Agers have a set of
religious preferences which are taken from traditional religion of one 
kind or another. I think raving is part of new age culture.
Terrence mckenna/esalen/space time. Ghandi said he would be happy if the 
west was more christian. Its that Global village with pluralist, 
multi-cultural perspective that New Agers advocate. When I used to shelve 
books I used to have a hard time determining whether to put him in 
religion or new age sections. Ultimately he ended up in religion with the 
other christ-ey stuff. I too got queezy when confronted with the "died so 
you could live again" thing. The mental flips required to erase my bad
time at the Salvation Army are too great. There is room under the new age 
umbrella for rev. Fox but my predjudices and marketing skills got in the way.

salutations, allen@ameba

have lost the meaning of true spirituality.

The pushers of Christianity (an addictive drug, like all organized 
religions) often try to excuse themselves by the same tired argument
Matthew Fox has used, that "Well, a lot of people who _call_ themselves
Christian do bad things, but _real_ Christianity is a good thing."

You can't separate the two.  What Christianity is is determined by the
people that practice it, and that has been an overwhelmingly shameful
legacy of corruption, oppression, hatred, and destruction.

Besides, the Bible is very clear on how one must be intolerant to be
Christian, even to the point of killing those who don't practice its
arcane rituals of daily life.

All the reasonable people I've met who call themselves Christian actually
talk and act more like Buddhists than Christians.

I believe that if we want to build a community based on love, trust, and
transcendence through trance (not to mention indulgence), we ought not
to handicap ourselves by starting from a belief that is based on fear of
eternal punishment and dependence on misogynist authority.

// g

Here's another twist to the Rave Mass story. The San Jose Mercury News
also had an article about Matthew Fox , and while most of the same 
information was covered, there were some interesting new data:

Quote Source: San Jose Mercury News , April 15 , 1994
Writer: Richard Scheinin , Mercury News Religion and Ethics Writer
Title:"A Catholic moved by a new spirit: Maverick priest, theologian 
turns Episcopalian"

 After 27 years as a Roman Catholic priest and a decade of engaging in 
public brinkmanship with the Vatican, Matthew Fox is moving to the 
Episcopal church. 

 Characteristically, the Oakland-based theologian and author, whose 
writings were once denounced as "deviant and dangerous" by Rome and 
whose international audience keeps growing among many who are 
disgruntled with the Vatican and other religious institutions is making 
the move with a splash . 

 Today he will announce his new association with San Francisco's Grace 
Cathedral, which will sponsor him as a candidate for the Episcopal 
priesthood and provide a forum for his work in "creation spirituality."
And, true to form, the man who once placed a witch on the faculty of his 
Institute of Culture and Creation Spirituality at Holy Names College in 
Oakland will announce his "solidarity" with a group of blue-collar, 
Anglican youths from England who are "reinventing rituals" with rave 
dancing, electronic media and techno art. A contingent of these radical, 
electronic Christians will soon come to San Francisco to establish an 
independent "base community" with the prospect that Grace will help them 
find a home for their Masses in the Bay Area.   

[text removed]

 He expects the Episcopal Church, whose relatively liberal policies 
support the ordination of women as priests, to be more accepting of his 
"revisioning" of Christianity and his conception of a "Cosmic Christ" who 
infuses and transcends all creation. From his new home, Fox will pursue  
his latest project: working with the young Britons from a depressed 
industrial town outside Manchester, England. Each Sunday, 600 of them meet 
for Mass in the darkened basement of a sports complex.  

 "They have 42 television sets and a dozen video screens with images of 
DNA dancing and galaxies and atoms ... flitering on all sides of the 
altar," said Fox, who visited in November and February. "It's dark and 
mysterious. The only light comes from these electronic sources - but it's 
a MASS.... Ten of these young people are coming here this summer to show  
us that you can pour this youth culture, this cutting-edge art, into  
the spiritual tradition of the West and turn everyone on by creating  
these rituals .
 
[text removed]

 ... he has often said creation spirituality is concerned with 
returning spiritual power from institutions to individuals and communities.
Why then is Fox now aligning himself with a new institution, albeit an 
Episcopal one? 

 "Because I'm not New Age," he said, "and because I believe in tradition. 
And the Anglican tradition is very close to the Roman Catholic. Half my 
books are about the medieval mystical tradition in Christianity. To teach, 
you have to be connected with a tradition. 

[text removed]
[ end of article ]

---------------------------

 So , who are these British blue-collar Anglican radical electronic
Christians?????

	Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

From rkrouse@octel.com Fri Apr 15 21:36:51 1994
