GS> This is about a Book....

Date  _____________
Copied: March-31-1994
>From  : LIBOR SPACEK
To    : ALL
System: XBN
Conf. : 0080 - C:NEW_AGE2

From: spacl@essex.ac.uk (Libor Spacek)

In the rain forests of Peru, an ancient manuscript has been discovered.
Within its pages are 9 key insights into life itself - insights each
human being is predicted to grasp sequentially, as we move toward a
completely spiritual culture on Earth.

1. Nothing happens "by accident". (Everything carries personal meaning).

2. Our thinking is shaped and limited by the time we live in but we
   can gain broader perspective.

3. Everything is made of pure Energy that can be directly experienced.
   Evolution is seen as an increase of the Energy (frequency). Human beings
   have a lot of this Energy.

4. All human interactions have been motivated by trying to obtain this 
   Energy from other people (mostly unconsciously).

5. The Energy can be gained directly from the Source by mystical experience
   thus putting human interactions on the right footing.

6. The Energy is taken from others by controlling them through one (or more)
   of the following set behaviours: intimidation (inducing fear), 
   interrogation (finding fault), aloofness (begging attention), "poor me" 
   (inducing guilt). There are set patterns of interactions that get passed
   from parents to children. If we recognise these patterns in our own life,
   we can become aware of our true life purpose (strategy).

7. We get immediate (tactical) guidance at all times from (all) people we
   meet, from our dreams and from "daydreaming". Cf. (1). The skill is to
   formulate the right questions - the answers will come. In future, we will
   naturally reward people for the way they touched us, rather than for
   their material goods.

8. We can stop other's "control dramas" by recognising and naming them.
   The energy can be given and freely exchanged (cf. 5), rather than taken.
   In loving relationships this happens at first, later often degenerating
   into the usual energy competition. If energy (full loving attention)
   is consciously given out within a group to one person at a time,
   everyone is energised = evolved much more. 

9. On the level of a society, this can set up a "positive feedback loop"
   whereby whole groups of people (such as the Mayans who had left us the
   Manuscript) will be so energised as to turn into light, ie. become
   invisible and Ascend. Fear is the only way to stop/drain this energy.

You're sure quick to respond to anti-christian gobbley gook, finding some
easy target to vent your frustrations on.  Do you think _all_ Christians
blindly listen to the bable of the first reverend that comes along and then
go out and kill the neighbor Planned Parenthood doctor?

I'm rather sick of all this garbage about love, peace, & harmony from many
of the raver community myself.  Why?  Because they're so unapproachable.
How many times I have ran into many of them at parties, having already
introduced myself at a previous party, then to have to remind them of who I
am;  Again!

So, you want to talk about love, then you can start by doing the hardest
thing first;  Love a Christian!

- Steve (who goes to church, then to light-n-up)
>
>// g

> Hey check out this month's wired the cover has a supposed "zippie"
> on it and an article about the new cultural phenomenon in the UK called
> zippies... funny, they still look like ravers to me :)

It seems to me that the SF rave scene has already accepted the hippies
in a way that the ravers in most other cities haven't. In particular, in
England, the "crusties" used to be despised by just about every group
of alternatives, from punks to grebos to ravers. So when British ravers
decided to hang out with the crusties and see what they could learn, it
was pretty open-minded of them.

In other words, the zippies are about as "advanced" (or whatever word
you want to use) as ravers from SF (in that they're interested in what
deadheads have to teach them, for example).

Anyway, having said that, the article was definitely overhyped silliness
to some extent. However, the big Evolution rave at the Grand Canyon in
August sounds quite cool. Not only do you get the ultimate outdoor 6-day
rave, you can meet these zippies and see what the hype is all about (if 
anything). 

I've written for info (to England), but if anyone else knows anything
substantive, go ahead and tell us. 
  ___________ ______________________________________________________________

/ scf.usc.edu /                         --Hilt                              /
\____________/_____________________________________________________________/

Joel Slayton and his Do-What-Do multi - media hightech madness
will be in front of the Palo Alto City Hall tonight, sat 16th.

He created a multi-media drive in on top of a sanjose parking garage
last year. This one will be like a cyber lawrence welk. Starts at 8pm.

The Budget is huge, The Technology is abundant.

Joel Slayton is a MIT artist castaway from the abandoned MIT project
which combined artists and engineers to develop new media. Many of the 
creative people left in the early eighties to join the silicon frontier
out here in the bay area. He is now a professer at SJSU and is my 
favorite working artist and a great guy.

salutations, allen@ameba

From: Raul Gilbert MinaMora <tow@well.sf.ca.us>

Subject: Re: Rave Masses at Grace Cathedral
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

from Geoff White:
>I don't think "Christian Rave" is any more of an oxymoron than "Pagan Rave"
>There are people who go to parties for basically religious (or spiritual)
>reasons (like me :) and I must say that  as far as I'm concerned, the 
>ultimate goal (at a good party) is to reach some sort of state of
trancendance,
>so I applude his actions.  I think if anybody actually read and thought
about
>the things that Jesus said (or stuff that people said that he said), it in 
>itself is not a bad thing.  I think if you read the words and decide the
meaning
>for yourself that is good, this is my experience of a good party, there
isn't
>someone up there telling you "how to rave" or how to feel or anything like
that
>but yet a lot of people who go to parties are having a group experience of
>"communitas" as it was called in the early church.

 anybody know how I can get in touch with him?


			>G

 Well spirtuality and religion are two different things,
and as soon as you attach any religious moniker to rave it brings
with it at least its core beliefs if not all the dogma. So if you
don't share thier beliefs you are excluded in a very fundamental
way, your denied the very wellspring of your own spirituality,
wherever it may come from or whatever it might be. One of the 
wonderful things about raves is that they can be a spiritual
event for individual and group without as you point to "someone up
there telling you "how to rave" or how to feel or anything like that"
and I'd like them to stay that way. In the same scence "pagen" as defined
these days as "not christian or not judeo/christian" (from the dictionary
I have at hand) would also be an oxymoron because it denies the Jewish
and the Christian thier wellspring. Though when I see it on a flier it 
rings as more of an empty phrase.
 At any rate like I said I have no qualms with christians, independants,
wickians (sp?), artists, frog worshipers or people who just want to throw
a daaaang good party putting together a rave. Its when its used to codify
spiritualy in the framework of a particular belief system and used to
support that particular belief system and when its used to bring people
into the fold of that particular belief system that you lose me. From 
whats been posted out of the articals from the two newspapers these
things are clearly intended by the priest named Fox. Why else call them
"Rave Masses". To the priests credit he recognises that raves have a 
spiritual aspect and doesn't deny it. Its one of the strengths of the 
house community. But what binds us as a community (at the very least) is 
our enjoyment of dancing together in an event where people consiciously
try and create a benevolent vibe. We are able to do it quite well with
out a shared belief system and good for us I say.

Gil

To: SFRaves@techno.Stanford.EDU, datherton@ea.com, saeedi@netcom.com
Subject: Sound Factory shooting
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

In reference to the questions re: the shooting, I'll pass on what a 
couple of rival club owners said occurred.  

Apparently, a customer got into an argument with a bartender over 
"something to do with *ice*" (the cold, wet kind) and was expelled from 
the club, shouting threats and curses throughout the ordeal.  The guy 
stood out front making threats of violence for awhile afterward.  The 
police were not involved at that time according to most sources.   I'm 
told that the club management later said they *had* called by this point.
Anyway, there were no police present until well after the guy had gotten 
into a pickup, driven around the club several times, hazing staff and 
pedestrians, and finally pulling a pistol from under the seat and firing 
six rounds into the entrance before speeding off.  An otherwise uninvolved 
girl was hit and hospitalized.  I have heard every possible option 
regarding her condition, so maybe someone else can help you there.

Hope that helps.  Like I said, it's all heresay, but is probably as close to
the truth as we're liable to get.   Take care, Kerry

	The Budget is huge, The Technology is abundant.
	
	Joel Slayton is a MIT artist castaway from the abandoned MIT project
	which combined artists and engineers to develop new media. Many of the 
	creative people left in the early eighties to join the silicon frontier
	out here in the bay area. He is now a professer at SJSU and is my 
	favorite working artist and a great guy.
	
	salutations, allen@ameba
	
	


From sfraves-owner  Sat Apr 16 20:53:59 1994

	id AA25841; Sat, 16 Apr 94 20:53:54 PDT
Received: from localhost by mail.netcom.com (8.6.4/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id UAA11265; Sat, 16 Apr 1994 20:55:07 -0700
From: chinacat@netcom.com (J. Petersen)
Message-Id: <199404170355.UAA11265@mail.netcom.com>
Subject: Re: This Months WiReD
To: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White)
Date: Sat, 16 Apr 1994 20:55:06 -0700 (PDT)
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
In-Reply-To: <199404161608.JAA03502@nexsys.nexsys.net> from "Geoff White" at Apr 16, 94 09:08:11 am
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 1860      
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

> 
> > 
> > I've written for info (to England), but if anyone else knows anything
> > substantive, go ahead and tell us. 
> 
> From what I can assertain, this Grand Canyon Evolution thing is none other than
> the Godd Ol' 'merican RAINBOW GATHERING of which the zippies have invited
> themselves too.
> 
> 

Except that, according to alt.gathering.rainbow, the prospective
locations for the National Rainbow Gathering don't include
the Grand Canyon. Besides, I can't see them choosing such
a public place to HOLD a Rainbow Gathering...

My guess is that the zippies are trying to associate themselves
with something they read about in Rolling Stone magazine, and
aren't really 100% aware of what the Rainbow Gathering is all
about.  I can't see how a mass of generators playing amplified
techno music is going to fit into a Rainbow Gathering without
being a major disruption. If they have their own camp, out on
the peripheral of the main Rainbow camp, that might work.

It would be great to get the ravers together with the Rainbows,
but I would feel terrible if it in any way detracted from the
Rainbow experience. I am afraid of the prospect of tons of
ravers descending on a Rainbow Gathering without first being
fully informed what the Rainbows believe in and what they
are looking for out of their Gathering.

Just as you wouldn't want a bunch of Rainbows to come over
to your rave and unplug all the machines, it's not fair for
Ravers to go to a Rainbow Gathering and plug IN all kinds
of machines.

Hopefully there will be some forethought and some planning
about all of this.

If it happens, it will be quite an experience!  :-)



D

Jim Petersen                              Argue for your limitations...
chinacat@netcom.com                            And they are yours


From sfraves-owner  Sun Apr 17 03:18:15 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA29117; Sun, 17 Apr 94 03:18:15 PDT
Received: from mail.netcom.com (netcom4.netcom.com) by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA29110; Sun, 17 Apr 94 03:18:08 PDT
Received: from localhost by mail.netcom.com (8.6.4/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id DAA16359; Sun, 17 Apr 1994 03:19:24 -0700
Date: Sun, 17 Apr 1994 00:59:57 -0700 (PDT)
From: JMRTNKO DSGN ETC SFCA <martinko@netcom.com>
Subject: Respect for the Living (was Sound Factory...)
To: ezzevvravess <sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU>
In-Reply-To: <2DB017E1@pcsmtp.ea.com>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.85.9404170057.A5724-0100000@netcom4>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


Well, what are you gonna do? At the risk of sounding cynical, all the 
raves in the world won't stop senseless violence. And even if it could, 
it can't stop death. Life is a fragile thing and nobody gave you a 
guarrantee that it would be either long or good (the two not necessarily 
going hand-in-hand). Heartless? I don't think so. I can't do anything for 
the woman killed or any of the other people I hear about. I *can* do 
something for myself and the people I love to make sure that if these 
lives do (regrettably) turn out to be short, that they were at least *good*.

My grandmother died last month and they guy who was in all the papers a 
couple weeks ago after he was stabbed to death in the Haight was Carmen's 
friend Justin who spent his last afternoon on my couch before heading 
back up there. So, sorry to be selfish, but I've had my share of death 
this month. I don't want sympathies, nor does Carmen. Long or short, they 
both had good lives mostly due to the people around them, and that's what 
we want. Good people and good friends, because that's what matters and 
what should be remembered, not an obituary.

As far as preventing violence, I'll pat everyone's back and say we've 
already done more than a herd of legislators, lawyers and cops. For 
whatever reason, we bring together hundreds, sometimes thousands of
people of all kinds weekly without incident. How many events or 
activities can you say that about? Our goals seem simple enough: to use 
our individual talents and desire to celebrate this little piece of life 
we have and to share it with and connect it to others. Instead of dwelling  
on the past and 'what might have been' we learn and look forward to 'what 
might be.' Sure this is the pure gristle for cheesy rave-luv-unity flyers 
and such, but there *is* an amount of simple truth to it. This truth takes 
a while to sink in as it is certainly not the prescribed norm of 'consumer 
dissatisfaction,' but for many of us it has. And as the number of people 
around us grows, there are bound to be folks who don't fully share this 
ideal yet, but given time, it'll sink into them as well. Wherever techno 
or house or rave or trance or whatever unimportant musical style is hot 
at the time, hopefully we'll all still remember that simple ideal.

As I said, death is inevitable, and we've not been without our share. 
Though nobody here may specifically say anything, I suspect noone giggles 
when they hear about a death. I personally consider it disrespectful to 
remember someone only in death, thus unless I can comment on their life, 
I choose to remain silent, so that others who can are able to do so. My 
sympathies go out to the Chocolate Factory people for their loss, but 
what's really important is support for all the people who remain. Life 
isn't the same after someone dies, but life does go on, and if anything 
is learned, it gets stronger.

When I came back to SF after my Grandmother's funeral in Detroit, I can 
say that having people come by the bbq, just to stop by, and when seeing 
people at Eigth House, the simple kindness of them remembering my name 
and saying hello meant a lot more than the biggest truckload of sympathy 
cards. Because it's a reminder that no matter what happens, there's still 
a lot more life to live. And that respect and kindness paid to someone 
while they are living means a lot more than when they're gone.

We may not have a global solution to the problem, and I don't think there 
is any, but if my story says anything, you're all doing a great job one 
person at a time. Sorry this was so long. The topic came up and I guess I 
just needed to write this. Thanks. John.

------

On Sat, 16 Apr 1994, Atherton, Darren wrote:

> has come up on this line.. people have not said much of anything-instead they 
> go on about admission prices and smoked out locations+ i think we need to 
> start thinking about what is goin on in this culture of ours and talk more 
> about how we can keep violence and hate away from the raving experience 
> because it has been creeping it's way in like almost every where else in this 
> state/country..

>  To which Steve Saeedi said: 
> > ....  If you
> > want to talk about love, why is it that when I posted about someone getting
> > shot in front of Sound Factory last week, no one gave a rat's ass about it,
> > but talked about their favourite homebrew party instead?......

> ravers have been killed , and there has always been some mourning here
> on SFRaves. Obviously , if the shooting actually occured , and if someone
> had actually been hurt or killed at the Sound Factory , it seems that  
> nobody on this list knows the person or even if the tragedy occured.

> It would be great to get the ravers together with the Rainbows,
> but I would feel terrible if it in any way detracted from the
> Rainbow experience. I am afraid of the prospect of tons of
> ravers descending on a Rainbow Gathering without first being
> fully informed what the Rainbows believe in and what they
> are looking for out of their Gathering.

Well, the whole point of the zippie movement, supposedly, is
uniting the ravers and the "crusties." If they've worked out
something with the Rainbows and explained to them the benefits
(both to the ravers and the Rainbows, presumably) of having a 
bunch of ravers come over with high-tech gizmos and loud music,
then they're thinking the same way as you are. Hopefully, a
group made up of wandering post-hippies as well as ravers will
know how to handle this all properly.

> If it happens, it will be quite an experience!  :-)

I agree.

Well for one thing if you are a promoter you could think twice about where 
you are going to throw a party. Don't get wrong i know that their is no real 
way of predicting a safe location but you could think twice about throwing a 
party at let's say locations like Hunters point. Yep all the raves in the 
world won't stop humans so called unstopable need to C:/hate/kill/control 
one another. 

But hay some of our closest musical cousins like - hip-hop- 
share similarities to us like the way they dress and as of recently the 
places they go. Listen and look closely at what hip hop is saying to the 
world i know it has its good points too but most of it is pure anger.. Do you 
feel that what we have been apart of could in some way have an impact on 
that generation of kids? All you have to do is pick up mags like URB and you 
can see the anger in the eyes in the hip hop ads right next to reviews of 
parties of smileing ravers. 

i don't know what i am going to do change 
anythang other then remain open and free of hostility. But it is O.K. to 
chat about life/death here. Your right we all face it in its many forms. And 
i think in some way it helps others on this line to realize that there is 
more to this then drugs and flashing laser beams.

raves in the world won't stop senseless violence. And even if it could,

From sfraves-owner  Sun Apr 17 11:23:14 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA03692; Sun, 17 Apr 94 11:23:14 PDT
Received: from mercury (mercury.sfsu.edu) by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA03685; Sun, 17 Apr 94 11:23:06 PDT
Received: by mercury (5.0/SMI-SVR4)
	id AA01408; Sun, 17 Apr 1994 11:18:58 +0800
Date: Sun, 17 Apr 1994 11:18:57 -0700 (PDT)
From: Sun Kim <sunkim@mercury.sfsu.edu>
Subject: Re: Christian Raves?
To: SF Raves <sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU>
Cc: saeedi@netcom.com
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9404171106.A1111-0100000@mercury>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Length: 1380
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Steve Saeedi said:

>I'm rather sick of all this garbage about love, peace, & harmony from many
>of the raver community myself.  Why?  Because they're so unapproachable.
>How many times I have ran into many of them at parties, having already
>introduced myself at a previous party, then to have to remind them of 
>who I am;  Again!

Why are you equating someone forgetting your name with "this garbage 
about love, peace, & harmony."  I have met plenty of people that I forget 
their names but that doesn't mean I appreciate them being there.  
Yesterday when I went to the Organic party at GG Park I met a lot of 
people from the last Full Moon that I did not remember their names for.  
I remember most faces but you meet so many people and/or high that it's 
very difficult to remember all the names.  

The names I tend to remember are the people who have a deep personal 
meaning to me.  I met someone at Organic named Casper that I will not 
forget because she was so kind to me.  A random act of kindness that just 
bewildered me and made me so happy that a stranger could be so nice. 

I know that not everyone that goes to a rave has the ideal of "love, 
peace, and harmony."  It's a personal meaning for each person that 
attends.  I know some people just go for the drugs or for the music.  
It's up to the individual to decide if want to be open and giving.  

Sun.

***** "It ain't over yet muthaf*ckas!" - Ice Cube *****

Good Housekeeping was, if nothing else, a chance to make a change...with
that said I wanna thank the following for making GH (Good Housekeeping)
everything we wanted to be, and more:

Alfie, James, Harry Who, Kyla, Jason (Sacramento OG Posse), The Doug
Ellington Quintet (yeah, the grand nephew of Duke Ellington...), Loren,
Charlotte, Josh, Swing Kid (Larry),Neon Leon, Mark Farina, Ron Ciron, Toph,
Brad, Geoff White (my MAN), Moni (monicat - > I like Moni better, much more
*flavor*), Tom, Larry C., Jeff, Lisa, Preston, Julianna, Barbara, Gina,
Aida, Tammy, Erin, Tony, Roy, Zoe, Sharon (Fremont), Lee Fogel, Adrian,
Andrea, Rob, Ron, Mike, Kari, Tommy, Marina, Tony, Kelly G., Kelly (Tasti
Box), Na Na & Sig Other, Capn. Crunch, Joe Harp, Michelle Harp, Tunni,
Traci B. Fierce,  and anyone else I forgot to mention...Thanks for making
Good Housekeeping all THAT.

Onto FLAVOR!!!!

Audi 5,
John

P.S.  I talked with an SFR today who is a lurker.  I forgot your name, but
enjoyed our conversation.  Please contact me via e-mail.  You are fucking
right on!!!!

P.S.S.  I really enjoyed doing GH.  And although we did not get the numbers
we wished we had gotten, we did have the vibe goin' on....and THAT is THE
most important thing.  I cannot thank all those who attended, enough for
stopping by and saying Hello.  This year has just begun, and some day the
*TRUTH* will be told, but that time is not now.  For now however there are
bigger mountains to conquer, and a bigger vibe to achieve.  The next few
weeks will be my time off.  The weeks after that will be my time on.  The
next level cannot be stopped.  Mediocrity will be confronted, challenged,
and defeated.  All people who front will be outed, so keep the shit real!
Anything less is a waste!!!!

Peace and keep everything *REAL*.
All Love,
John

"It ain't over yet...."

                 Ain't no future in your frontin'

On Apr 16,  8:49am, Larry asked:
}  As far as I remember , there was still a matter of wether the incident
} had actually occured or not. Weren't we waiting for someone to confirm
} the shooting? Looking at my old mail , it seems that no one confirmed it.

I'll confirm that it had happened - I was working late at Wired (on
2nd street near Bryant) and as I was leaving I heard sirens, so I
decided to see what was going on.  There were 3 fire engines and
4 squad cars outside of the club, that whole block of Harrison was
closed off, and everyone was outside.  The crowd looked like the
typical Sound Factory crowd, not Wicked which I thought might be there 
that night.  Anyways, as I turned around I asked someone on the street
what had happened and they said there had been a shooting, but that's
all I heard of it.

	Brian


From sfraves-owner  Sun Apr 17 21:11:15 1994

Subject: Religion, respect, and "the scene"
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Sun, 17 Apr 1994 21:10:33 -0700 (PDT)
In-Reply-To: <199404161059.DAA14337@mail.netcom.com> from "Steve Saeedi" at Apr 16, 94 03:57:43 am
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL21]

> >What Christianity is is determined by the
> >people that practice it, and that has been an overwhelmingly shameful
> >legacy of corruption, oppression, hatred, and destruction.
> 
> Unlike Islam, Judaism, Hindu, Buddism, ...

All organized religions are structures whose purpose is to maintain
themselves by controlling the behavior of others.  The easiest way is
to view anyone not part of your cult as inferior.  From there, it is
easy to justify harming or killing them, because you are better than them
and are justified in deciding their fate.  This is an explicit tenet
of the major messianic religions (Islam, Christianity), and is an
easy step that has often been taken from other religions (Confucianism,
Hinduism, the Sikhs).

Someone brought up the difference between religion and spirituality,
which is important.  Religion is a power structure, spirituality an
individual experience.  Religion purposely confuses the two in an
effort to ensnare people who have experienced spirituality outside its
confines.  ("Don't you see, that was the Lord telling you to quit
shooting up.  And He also says...")

> >Besides, the Bible is very clear on how one must be intolerant to be
> >Christian, even to the point of killing those who don't practice its
> >arcane rituals of daily life.
> 
> Which Bible are you referring to?  Can you cite a source?

Um, all of Leviticus, to start?  "Thou shalt not suffer a witch to
live," etc.?

I've heard some people say that those were directions to the Jews way
back in BC and don't apply now, but they're still used to justify
hatred and oppression -- which is my point.

> >I believe that if we want to build a community based on love, trust, and
> >transcendence through trance (not to mention indulgence), we ought not
> >to handicap ourselves by starting from a belief that is based on fear of
> >eternal punishment and dependence on misogynist authority.
> 
> I certainly don't want to live my life transcending through trance.

I only go out about once a month, but it's still important to me.  If
it's not important at all to you, why rave?  I'm not sure I understand
you here.

> If you
> want to talk about love, why is it that when I posted about someone getting
> shot in front of Sound Factory last week, no one gave a rat's ass about it,
> but talked about their favourite homebrew party instead?  Didn't _you_ care
> enough to respond?  What happened?

Mourning for the dead achieves nothing, as JMAR so eloquently stated.
The past is the past, and cannot be erased.  What we can do is to build
a mobile community of TAZs within which we can keep BS like that from
happening -- and we have.  I can remember two deaths that occurred during
actual raves in the past year or so, and in each case, we've learned 
more about how to keep ourselves safe.  What's the SF homicide rate in
the neighborhoods most of us rave in between midnight and 7 AM?  Damn
high -- and of the two deaths I remember, one was in Santa Cruz and the
other in Santa Clara.

If people can be made to feel guilt over something they had nothing to
do with and could not have prevented, they can be simultaneously
controlled by those instilling the guilt and distracted from the
actual solution.  "Jesus died for your sins."

> You're sure quick to respond to anti-christian gobbley gook, finding some
> easy target to vent your frustrations on.  Do you think _all_ Christians
> blindly listen to the bable of the first reverend that comes along and then
> go out and kill the neighbor Planned Parenthood doctor?

No, I do not.  I don't judge you based on the actions of others.  What
I am saying is that, to me, a belief system that causes most people
(hundreds of millions!) to become willfully ignorant and hate-filled is
not worth salvaging or supporting, even implicitly, no matter what
some people might tell me it "really" means.

This is why I'm an anarchist -- government seems to always end up
screwing over the people (for instance, me) despite the best
intentions of its founders -- but that's another topic for another
time.

> I'm rather sick of all this garbage about love, peace, & harmony from many
> of the raver community myself.  Why?  Because they're so unapproachable.
> How many times I have ran into many of them at parties, having already
> introduced myself at a previous party, then to have to remind them of who I
> am;  Again!

I remember faces but I'm terrible at names.  I don't think I've met you,
though.

I agree that people can still be unapproachable, especially at
massives.  This is why I enjoy the UG parties net.people have thrown,
because the community is small enough that I can meet, remember, and
talk to people.  We have a long way to go before we live up to
its ideals, but at least the ideals are good, and progress is
happening.

> So, you want to talk about love, then you can start by doing the hardest
> thing first;  Love a Christian!

When I meet people, I start with respect, which can descend to tolerance
(or worse), or ascend to love.  Your group identification doesn't matter
to me except as it affects your actions.

// g

From sfraves-owner  Mon Apr 18 01:02:50 1994

From: deaks@netcom.com (Ernie Deakyne)
Message-Id: <199404180804.BAA14859@netcom8.netcom.com>
Subject: Big Sur 'Natives'
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Mon, 18 Apr 1994 01:04:02 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 2128      
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

  Unfortunatley for me, it's a two hour commute to check out any parties 
up in the city, however I have had the chance to experience the Big Sur 
Natives....

  On Saturday night me and some friends all went to a party, hung out for 
a while until someone suggested we go to the Natives.  We all live in 
Monterey so Big Sur is only a 30 min trip.  Anyways, I was stoked to go 
but a bit tweaked. ;)

  Anyways, we get there around 11:30.  My friend informs me it's "Just 
like a rave."  But it was much more of a tribal gathering then a rave.  
Lots of people I know are milling around an open fire while the drummers 
are going crazy inside.  I notice the inside of the River Inn is packed 
with people so I go on in and begin to dance.  

  It was jammin.  Ive seen some guys play bongos at raves before, but 
this was intense, four drummers and various other people with different 
percussion instruments.  Each person was in a trance but somehow the 
music flowed of their hands like magic.  I took the whole image into my 
head and began to smile BIG :)  Infact, I didn't stop smiling for the 
rest of show, which unfortunatley ended at 12.  Of course, we got in free 
for being late, but I would of had no problem paying $10+ (It's only three)

  Anyways, this was a very inspirational show for me.  I woke up the next 
morning not fealing like left over chinese food, but rather energized.  
I ended up jogging 12 miles around Carmel and Monterey basking in the sun.
The vibe from the 100 or so people there was great, everyone was having a 
great time and smiling at each other.  

  This was my first trip to see the Big Sur Natives, and I think I am 
going to start making it a regular occourance.  It happens every two 
weeks at the River Inn (Just take Highway One, You'll see it) But it's 
happening next week too, so I don't know the exact schedule :| 

Btw, this is my first post to SFraves.  Been reading messages for a 
couple months but since I'm just on the edge of the scene, I dont get to 
participate in much.  Oh well, I'll be going to USF next year, then 
things will be different :)

-=*DJ Deaks*=-



From sfraves-owner  Mon Apr 18 02:36:03 1994

I guess this is the age old argument- what ideal religion has turned 
into.  I don't think it's going to be solved...
But there are a few fundamental things everyone is overlooking, that i 
think need to be expressed.  As a Christain i can only speak 
confidently about Christianity, but i think all relegions experience the 
same lack of justice. 
I'm confident that Christ should be the center of a "Christain's" faith 
and life.  If that's the case then Christianity should be something 
different than what the 'church' presents it as.  Christ was truly an 
anarchist of sorts, who rebelled and opposed the power structure of the 
Jewish law.  He claimed to be the provider of Life.  But that Life he 
preached was not any external power structure, it was and is a spiritual 
experience- and a personal one.  One needs to separate what Christ 
taught with what the Church presents, because the Church is human and 
humans distort.  No matter what anyone says- Christainity is only about 
Christ- nothing else.  He provides a personal experience with God, and 
that experience is separate from any one or anything else!  Perhaps 
religion does purposefully confuse spirituality with sick power 
structure- indeed, that's what Ceasar did when he forced Christainity as 
a national religion...  but Christ is still Christ, and despite human 
actions, his purpose to provide us with a new spiritual life remains...

Christianity should be equated with Jesus and his actions, his life, not 
with the modern church.  He loved completely, he was in perfect 
harmony...  he should be the image one sees when one thinks of  
Christainity, but unfortunately he's not.

I guess one just has to just quit judging others, and start to judge 
themselves.

There's the same mixture of love and selfishness in raves as there is 
in the rest of reality... 

so be it.

--hans

Well, Basics marks I think my fourth attempt in a row to go dancing over 
the past few weeks (others have been 21+, busted, or unfindable).

Made the trek from Berkeley to Bonny Doon, noticing ONE cop car while 
passing the small group of parked cars.  Kept going, turned at the next 
street, only to find Martin and a small group of others waiting with the 
sound system still in the van.  They said they were waiting for the cops 
to leave before they set anything up.  By this time it was about 1:30.  
Passing the parked cars on the way back, there were close to 10 (TEN!) 
cop cars flashing pretty blue and red lights.  

Went to a friend's place in Santa Cruz to wait, called the info line 
about 45 minutes later, and it said the party was busted, maybe would be 
moving to San Fran.  

After the trek DOWN from San Fran, we weren't about to go back up there 
to hunt for a wharehouse.  So what happened?  DID it happen?

-Seth

Institutionalized religion and personal spirituality is not the same.  I 
happen to find the Bible as I interpret it a meaningful and important 
part of my faith experience.  
The difficulty rises when one attacks the tenets of the faith rather than 
those who pervert, distort it to their advantage.  Lets face it, 
institutions, in general, are corrupt.  Our government has succeeded in 
turning the Constitution into a means of controlling the masses.  TV 
evangelists have succeeded in turning the Bible into a method of sucking 
the money and life out of little old ladies.  UNC at Chapel Hill has 
succeeded in turning an academic atmosphere into an athletic fanatisism 
where sports players have no financial ceiling and receive absurd amounts 
of money, facilities, etc for their use.  However, in and of itself, the 
Constitution is an innocent, if not beneficial, doctrine.  In and of 
itself, the Bible is a positive book, and in and of itself, UNC Chapel 
Hill has a very good academic program.
Please don't scrutinize me because I happen to believe in our 
Constitution, in and of itself, because I find value in the Bible, in and 
of itself, and because I support academic environments, in and of themselves.
Tanya

"fear of eternal punishment" which has deep personal meaning.

spirituality.  I trust that others will respect me.

I don't recall hearing that the Sound Factory shooting occurred at a
rave. Did it?

I have a friend who is all twisted up inside because she hears about
all the killings and the pollution and corruption and the myriad of
bad things that happen in the world. Just about everything she hears
affects her personally. It makes her very unhappy and her anxiety is
killing her.

So where does one draw the line? What things may we see as unrelated
to us, and what things must make us experience angst?  What things
must make us angry? How related to us must something be before we're
obligated to get involved?

Personally I think a lot of tolerance is in order. I know a lot of
people for whom every little bit of happiness is a thing to be
cherished. Many of my friends are struggling to get their own life in
order, much less save the world.

How does that saying go? "Spend a day in their shoes."

Sean

Subject: Bonny Doomed 2 (complete Text)
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Basics Busted or Bonny Doomed

The raver kid in the "Rolling Stone" said "The cops can't do anything because
it's on private property. They just give tickets,...........it's the best
party in Northern California." Well, the last thing Santa Cruz wants is to
become a Rave Mecca. It's already the city "that time forgot," meaning it
became the Sun City for every aging 60's hippie still living in America.
'

So much for pissing off the police, and throwing down the gauntlet. I'm sure
the article reached members of the police and city government of Santa Cruz.
Since it has gone "public" they no longer have the option of looking the
other way while the ravers play.

As we drove up to Basics, from a distance I saw the red lights flashing.
There must have been 15 police cars (Highway Patrol) not city police.  People
were being pulled over, flashlights in their eyes. I can only guess that
people were arrested for drug or alcohol possession.

Being older, I felt strangely alien, or protected as I walked around amid the
police cars along the road. I thought about the British Rave Police, and
realized that raving is a counter-cultural revolution, and as such, the
police and city governments, will rightfully interpret it as a threat. Can
you envision the day in sunny California, when you get 2-5 years for putting
on, or attending a rave? The English posse, Garth, Jeno, Thomas,etc. left
England to find a safe haven to Rave, (which the club scene provides)
however, I think we're just beginning to see the kind of police tactics they
were trying to escape.       Robertj..........MRP

From sfraves-owner  Mon Apr 18 12:17:49 1994

From: robertj308@aol.com

Message-Id: <9404181515.tn04727@aol.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Mon, 18 Apr 94 15:15:10 EDT
Subject: "House"-Chicago Style Stiffed (review)
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Chicago Style Stiffed--

Alright, so I'm a tiny bit prejudiced, being from Chicago. But, I think SF
missed another extraordinary opportunity to experience Chicago House music. A
few months back, Luciana (the promoter) put  "La Pleisure de Vivre." She flew
3 Chicago  Dj's out here to spin. (Remember that the Rolling Stone article
cited Europe's almost religious appreciation for Chicago House music.)  The
party was attended by approximately 700 people, and someone from Sfraves
reviewed it. 

Unfortunately, only about 100 people showed up. not to say it wasn't a great
party, and I did get to meet "Ahmeet," (msp?) from sfraves. It was  the 174
King street, without the crowd, and without the smoke. Plenty of room to
dance. And the music..........great music!!!

Chicago House,  is often distinguished by it's black female  rhythm and blues
vocals, or it's more rhymic jazz baselines and drums instead of a "thud,
thud, thud." It is also driven a bit more by piano and organ instrumentals,
than synthesized techno computer stuff.  The Aretha Franklin "Deeper Love,"
falls into this category.

Anyway, Luciana said she printed 8,000 flyers, and had hoped to build on the
700 peole who attended the previous party. So why didn't they come? Were
people at other parties? Bad Promotion? Bad Promoter? Bad Location?
Snobbishness?  "E" all of the above?

I thought Luciana was a wonderful person, who in addition to the thought of
making money, honestly wanted to bring music she loved to SF. I never saw
someone having  so much fun, while they were losing so much money!!!

For all the past complaining I've heard on the Net about the "same dj's,"it
was a shame more people did not avail themselves of something different. I
don't know if there will be another  Chicago Style party soon, but judging
from Saturdays turnout, I suspect NOT. Which is too bad, IMHO. Robertj....MRP

From sfraves-owner  Mon Apr 18 12:32:51 1994

	id AA24209; Mon, 18 Apr 94 12:32:38 PDT
Message-Id: <9404181932.AA24209@groovy.us.oracle.com>
Date: Mon, 18 Apr 94 12:32:38 PDT
From: Bob Ramstad <rramstad@us.oracle.com>
To: robertj308@aol.com, acid23@uclink.berkeley.edu
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: "This will stop"
Reply-To: boccibob%groovy@us.oracle.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


To make a long story short, I saw cops on the way in, but they seemed
to just be ticketing cars in the main lot.  There was only one cop car
on the way in.  While down on the beach, at around 1 AM, the cops came
around to each group of people, shining flashlights and told us that
the beach was closed and that we would have to leave.  There were also
cop cars up on the tops of the cliffs, shining bright spotlights down
on the beach.  Walking out I saw four or five cop cars in the main
lot.  Ethan and I ran into Tony on the way back to my car.  We talked
to him for a minute and started up Bonny Doon Road.  A cop drove up,
leaned out the window, and asked Tony what was in the box.  He said
records, and the cop said "please stand over there, I want to talk to
you".

We (around eight of us) decided to hang out and see what went down.
Again to cut to the chase, after establishing that the records were
his and that he had no official connection with the group throwing the
event, the cop asked us if we were with Tony.  We said yes, and the
cop said "well, then, gather around, you might as well all hear this".

I can't recall precisely what all was said, but here were some of the
high points.

This will stop.  The next step for us is to set up sobriety
checkpoints on both sides of Highway 1 and stop all cars coming in or
out.  If we need to, we can cite each individual on the beach after 10
PM for trespassing at $250 apiece.  The residents here have been
tolerating these parties for a long time and they can't happen here
any more.  Find a new place for them.  The board of supervisors has
told the sheriff that this can't continue.  Even liberals support
stopping these parties, if you had seen the beach after the last
party that was here, you'd understand why.  Not to mention that
someone ripped up a fence in Davenport for firewood during the last
party.  10% of the people cause 100% of the problem.

I could go on, but if you could have seen the resolve in the face of
the cop, you'd understand exactly what he was saying.  There will be
no more parties at night at Bonny Doon.

Now, I did ask him point blank if daytime no alcohol public free
parties would be OK, and he said if it was small, that wouldn't be a
big deal.  "300 or 400 people, you'd probably want to check with park
& rec, and call the sheriff and let them know so they could come out
and make sure that people weren't bringing alcohol or glass out on to
the beach."

I think it might be the right time to have a daytime party there,
don't flyer, have SFR do it, bring lots of garbage bags, have everyone
who comes fill up one bag of garbage and clean the place up.  It's
still fairly cool there even when it's clear and sunny.

Bob

Yes it seems like the days of Full Moon Massives at Bonnie Doone are
over but I still think we can have _small_ (50 - 200) person _underground_
parties there.  Unfortunately I don't think there will be any Full Moons
there for a long time. But maybe this is good, the last FMM at Bonnie Doon
had over 3000 people and the beach was left in a mess, I think it's better
to stop them and keep the beach beautiful then to continue them and
totally trash the place.

What do you think?  Should we write an anonymous letter to the SCPD
explaining the situation and thanking [sic] them for the tolerance
that they have shown for the past 2 years?  It might go a long way to
mending some fences that the Rolling Stone article have splintered.

From: winston@lurnix.COM (Mark Guthrie)

To: grigsby@agames.com, uunet!chip.ucdavis.edu!ez040308@uunet.UU.NET
Subject: Re: Religion, respect, and "the scene"
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU

I guess this is the age old argument- what ideal religion has turned
into.  I don't think it's going to be solved...
But there are a few fundamental things everyone is overlooking, that i
think need to be expressed.  As a Christain i can only speak
confidently about Christianity, but i think all relegions experience the
same lack of justice.
I'm confident that Christ should be the center of a "Christain's" faith
and life.  If that's the case then Christianity should be something
different than what the 'church' presents it as.  Christ was truly an
anarchist of sorts, who rebelled and opposed the power structure of the
Jewish law.  He claimed to be the provider of Life.  But that Life he
preached was not any external power structure, it was and is a spiritual
experience- and a personal one.  One needs to separate what Christ
taught with what the Church presents, because the Church is human and
humans distort.  No matter what anyone says- Christainity is only about
Christ- nothing else.  He provides a personal experience with God, and
that experience is separate from any one or anything else!  Perhaps
religion does purposefully confuse spirituality with sick power
structure- indeed, that's what Ceasar did when he forced Christainity as
a national religion...  but Christ is still Christ, and despite human
actions, his purpose to provide us with a new spiritual life remains...
Christianity should be equated with Jesus and his actions, his life, not
with the modern church.  He loved completely, he was in perfect
harmony...  he should be the image one sees when one thinks of
Christainity, but unfortunately he's not.
I guess one just has to just quit judging others, and start to judge
themselves.

There's the same mixture of love and selfishness in raves as there is
in the rest of reality...

so be it.

--hans
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
But how do you know what christ said if "humans distort" because the bible
is bunch of different and often conflicting human accounts that were then
considered for truth and accuracy by a bunch of humans (who werent impartial
as they were all christians) and some accounts were even discarded such as
that of mary and other people.

-Winston (the man with a thousand names)

U know what that is true.. when ever stuff about violence in our community
has come up on this line.. people have not said much of anything-instead they
go on about admission prices and smoked out locations+ i think we need to
start thinking about what is goin on in this culture of ours and talk more
about how we can keep violence and hate away from the raving experience
because it has been creeping it's way in like almost every where else in this
state/country..
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
I don't think anyone is avoiding reality here on this list.  What else can
you say?  Oh someone got shot - just like the other couple hundred that
happend somewhere in the country.  Oh, I feel bad for that persons family
and friends.  Oh, it happened at a party, it coulda been me or someone I
care for.  None of this helps.  What helps is taking an individual 
responsability to making sure not to do something like this yourself and
to try to make sure your friends and children don't.  I would bet everyone
on this list already does that.  Anything else is preaching to the converted.

-Winston

Now please before you get all bent out of shape maybe you SHOULD read
the article first.  

According to Tamara it was written by someone who writes for Urb who
has been involved with raving for like two years or so now.

I read the article and it was quite positive and honest and well-written
and for once didn't go on and on about drug use in the scene.

It's not Rolling Stone's fault the cops found the Bonny Doon party. 
It was a combination of using the location SO many times for so many HUGE
parties and of the mess the beach was reportedly left in after the last
party there (before Basics tried it).

Face it:  you can't easily hide 700 cars and 3000 people.  It had to
give sometime.

Laura

Subject: Re: Bonny Doomed

On Apr 18,  1:45pm, Geoff proclaimed:
} Yes it seems like the days of Full Moon Massives at Bonnie Doone are
} over but I still think we can have _small_ (50 - 200) person _underground_
} parties there.  Unfortunately I don't think there will be any Full Moons
} there for a long time. But maybe this is good, the last FMM at Bonnie Doon
} had over 3000 people and the beach was left in a mess, I think it's better
} to stop them and keep the beach beautiful then to continue them and
} totally trash the place.
} 
} What do you think?  Should we write an anonymous letter to the SCPD
} explaining the situation and thanking [sic] them for the tolerance
} that they have shown for the past 2 years?  It might go a long way to
} mending some fences that the Rolling Stone article have splintered.

The Rolling Stone article didn't do nearly as much damage it seems as 
leaving the beach trashed did.  I can't believe that the beach was left
like that after the last one.  Didn't the last people to leave feel any
obligation to leave the place as clean if not cleaner than when the 
group arrived?  Maybe they shouldn't be there - or ANYwhere else - 
if people can't control the amount of trash they leave behind.  That and
things like breaking fences for firewood... god, no wonder I haven't been
to a full moon in ages.  This group needs to do a LOT of internal
housecleaning before anything else happens.

I'd support a daytime party down there, but I don't think it'll have
much of an effect.  The damage is done.  A letter might help, but 
it takes more than words to mend fences (literally, in this case).

Sorry if I sound angry in this letter, but I am, as I and a couple
others here worked hard when parties were first being held there to
establish some sort of unwritten unspoken contract with the locals.
They held out their end of the deal, which was to do their job but not
bother us over the hill, and we failed ours, which was to hold
peaceful, nondestructive gatherings.  Look back over posts made here
during that time and this becomes abundantly clear.  At this point,
I'm on the cops' side.  Sad thing is, I think the beach could have
survived the publicity from Rolling Stone had people done enough to
act responsibly (and it wouldn't have even needed to be a majority
who acted responsibly, either.)  

End of an era.

	Brian



From sfraves-owner  Mon Apr 18 14:24:39 1994

From: laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Mon, 18 Apr 1994 14:24:26 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: dead full moon sites
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


Palo Alto Wetlands -- according to Brian they now station a ranger there
	at night because the rangers were so mad at how trashed the wetlands
	were after the one party that was held there.  I think in this
	case what was meant by "trashed" was that the ground was all
	torn up.

Berkeley Marina -- noise from incoming party-goers and worn-out grass
	from dancing got to the point where cops are stationed there
	to prevent parties.

Albany (??) landfill -- cops busted the last party there, not sure why.

Bonny Doon -- large amounts of trash and broken fences become the straw
	that breaks the camel's back.

So, the Bonny Doon thing wasn't exactly an isolated incident.  I know
I'm speaking to the converted here:  the vast bulk of the net-ravers
are quite contientious, but we're not the only people out there partying,
but at the same time are we required to babysit the irresponsible 
practicies of everyone?  It's good to help out but there's a limit to
how much of your brother's keeper you can be.  The Liquid Air parties
always look spotless afterwards, so I *know* that the net-ravers know
what to do with their trash and when to do it, and I'm always happy
to see it.

Even though it might not do much good in the long run a cleanup down
at Bonny Doon is still a good idea, if for no other reason than the fact
that it's the right thing to do.  The cops and the locals might not ever
forgive the ravers, but at least the birds and other animals won't have
to suffer for it.

Laura

Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU

Subject: pank floyd
Reply-To: boccibob%groovy@us.oracle.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


the floyd shows are incredibly oversold due to massive amounts of
ticket speculation.  the sj mercury news has over 70 classified ads
for floyd tickets.  prices vary from face value to $400 each.

do not pay more than face value plus BASS fees for your ticket(s).

if no one pays outrageous ticket prices, the organized ticket
speculators (read: scalpers) will ease off, and the fans will be able
to get better seats more easily direct from BASS.

to give you an idea of the situation, the who, led zepplin, rolling
stones, even U2 --- none of them have ever even tried to play three
shows in a row at oakland stadium.  3 * 60,000 is a lot of tickets to
sell.  my personal guess is that there'll be people selling tickets
below face value in the parking lot (especially wed/thurs).

note that i also generally do not pay less than face value for a
ticket, unless it's clear that i'm buying from a scalper, in which
case he can eat the loss for all i care.  scalping hurts everyone who
has ever had an extra ticket for a show only to discover that because
of ticket speculation, massive numbers of tickets are being sold below
face, and so the ticket is worth less and sometimes worthless.

example: David Bowie, Foxboro MA, summer 1990 tickets through
Ticketron were $30.  day of show at the venue there were scalpers
offering "buy one at face, get four free".  my extra ticket was
effectively worthless.  this after the show had sold out in 20 minutes
when tickets originally went on sale.

off soapbox,
Bob

tidbit: i'll be ushering at the floyd show wednesday, actually.

  This is my first post to this group after lurking for several months but
  I wanted to comment on a couple of observations:

  I just read how few people attended Chicago. I went to Close Encounters
  at the Haze. Except for reading past posts about how bad the Haze was
  I wouldn't have known it. This was my second time there and I had a great
  time - just gotta love the music. I did notice the small turnout however.
  If both Chicago & Close Encounters were low turnout - where was 
  everyone ?

  I did enjoy the Haze event and there were no noticable problems other
  than security confiscating pipes etc. if used in an obvious way but I
  did notice at least 2 distinct groups did I not ? ( I'm new remember )
  Group 1 are presumed Ravers (TM) dancing mid floor all smiles etc.
  Group 2 are presumed Gangers (??) mostly Hispanic, mostly stern, didn't
    seem to like the music, certainly didn't dance.
  The non mixing of these two groups seemed like potential trouble to me
  but before I get paranoid...
  Why would the group 2 gang types even bother coming to an event where
  they didn't even like the music ?  What would happen if the ravers 
  attempted to communicate with these folks and perhaps enticed more of
  them to take part and dance? These questions were just on my mind.

  Finally, I have been an electronic musician for years and was brought
  up on really spacey European electronic music T. Dream, Schulze , 
  Kraftwerk are those more commonly cited. I wondered where tastey  
  electronic music went to then I discovered house - the Orb, Orbital,
  Aphex Twin etc. and I'm home again... I'll be about and my partner and
  I are investigating the possibilities of playing live within the rave
  community.. P.S. I'm another "old guy" at 42 but most people would
  not recognize me as that age either inside or out..

  Last question : Was that an SFraver with the light stick swinging away
  at close encounters? 

  Mike

Mike asks:

  >I
  >did notice at least 2 distinct groups did I not ? ( I'm new remember )
  >Group 1 are presumed Ravers (TM) dancing mid floor all smiles etc.
  >Group 2 are presumed Gangers (??) mostly Hispanic, mostly stern, didn't
  >  seem to like the music, certainly didn't dance.
  >The non mixing of these two groups seemed like potential trouble to me
  >but before I get paranoid...
  >Why would the group 2 gang types even bother coming to an event where
  >they didn't even like the music ?  

I had it explained to me like this when I was at a party two weekends
ago at the Haze, and it made perfect sense:

Those non-rave kids are mostly under 21 and, due to the stupid caberet
laws in San Francisco, really have no place to go out.  So, they
keep going to the Haze no matter WHAT is going on there because at
least they CAN go there.  They don't really care about the music or
who's DJing or whatever, it's just a place where they are allowed
entry so they can hang out, see their friends and aquaintences, and just
BE rather than sitting on a street corner where they'll get in trouble
for having no place to go.

Laura

It may just be a fact of life that when more than a certain number of
people go to a site they're going to trash it. The question is: How do
you fine tune a party like that so it doesn't get too big or stay too
small?

There was a lot of garbage on the ground after the Organic GG park
party. I cleaned up some, and noticed Bob doing the same. 
I did it for the promoters, because they spent their money and their
effort to throw that party. I did _not_ do it for the "good of rave";
people should clean up their own mess, or, like me, not make one in
the first place!

I wonder if people would act responsively if there were a _lot_ of
garbage cans around? Ideas?

Sean

Ok, ok, I cannot keep my fingers from not typing anymore.  Now I was at the 
last  Bonny Doon Full Moon and I stayed there till about 3pm.  Before leaving,
I helped clean the beach - the southern half.  There were many garbage bags
piled full of trash neatly piled near the main enterance.  When I left, the
beach did NOT look trashed!  That was my interpretation.  I not only looked 
for large obvious pieces of trash but picked up every cigarette butt I could
find, some which were obviously weathered so much that they didn't come from
that night.  

There was no organized concerted effort to clean the beach but several others
also started picking up trash after the music stopped.  I stopped by the
beach again at 5pm to look at it again and viewed it from the cliff in front
of the railroad tracks and from that distance, the beach looked CLEAN.  I 
know it was from a distance but I couldn't pick out any obvious large pieces
of trash in my view.

Now please somebody who actuallly inspected the beach at say 4 or 5pm please
speak up and say if the beach was trashed then or not.

According to mine eyes and some effort on my part the beach was not trashed.

Space

Let me clear up what I actually DID say: she is not involved with Urb at all.
She is the music editor of LA Weekly. What I did say is that she wrote a very
informed article on the LA scene about three years ago. I had not read the
Rolling Stone article so I couldn't comment on its contents but I wanted to 
point out that she had at least been writing about this subject for a few 
years and wasn't just some writer who just stumbled upon and infiltrated the
scene.

Since my post I have had occasion to read the Rolling Stone article. I felt
it was somewhat irresponsible journalism and basically nothing new from what
was covered in the mainstream press within the last two years.

From: Luke Youngblood <LUKEY@wordperfect.com>

Subject:  Close Encounters, Chicago & -Reply

	First of all, I apologize for making this broad generalization, but
I've found that while "ravers" (TM) :) generally go to a party to
dance, enjoy the music, and have a great time, group 2, the
"gangstas" that I've seen at parties seem to be more interested in 2
things: 
1. scoping out any females in the crowd and attempting to victimize
them.
2. making a profit by selling drugs.
	I'll be the first to admit that not all gang members are like this,
but when I say "gangstas", I'm referring to the people that you can
always tell are like this because you see them stand in the middle of
a party in a circle and project negative energy and attitude in all
directions around them.  They don't come to a party to contribute to
the vibe, or to show love for any other person; their goals seem to
be more selfishly driven.  Maybe it's wrong for me to make a
generalization like this, but those are the only reasons I can see
for that type of people to come to a party.

>>> Michael E. Clay <meclay@netcom.com>  4/18/94, 03:26pm >>>

I did notice at least 2 distinct groups did I not ? ( I'm new
remember )
  Group 1 are presumed Ravers (TM) dancing mid floor all smiles etc.
  Group 2 are presumed Gangers (??) mostly Hispanic, mostly stern,
didn't
    seem to like the music, certainly didn't dance.
  The non mixing of these two groups seemed like potential trouble to
me
  but before I get paranoid...
  Why would the group 2 gang types even bother coming to an event
where
  they didn't even like the music ?

Subject: Bonnie doon
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU

X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL5]

I lived in santa cruz for most of the 80's and there have always been 
drug parties at bonnie doon, especially during spring and summer.
They began cracking down every summer and virtually shut down 
every beach North of Santa Cruz using massive amounts of manpower to
achieve the total curfew after dark. 

We cant party there in the summer because it appeals to to many people
who don't care about anything other than getting high and fucking shit up.

I bet when the weather gets cold and wet this winter we can use the spot
with discretion.

This problem has existed for as long as I can remember in Santa Cruz.
And it probably is a social reality of kabalistic proportion.

salutations, allen@ameba

From sfraves-owner  Mon Apr 18 15:26:58 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA28007; Mon, 18 Apr 94 15:26:58 PDT
Received: from pilot.njin.net by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA27998; Mon, 18 Apr 94 15:26:48 PDT
Received: by pilot.njin.net (5.59/SMI4.0/RU1.5/3.08) 
	id AA19898; Mon, 18 Apr 94 18:26:24 EDT
Date: Mon, 18 Apr 94 18:26:24 EDT
From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9404182226.AA19898@pilot.njin.net>
To: meclay@netcom.com (Michael E. Clay)
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Close Encounters, Chicago&  (response & review)
In-Reply-To: <199404182126.OAA05548@mail.netcom.com>
References: <199404182126.OAA05548@mail.netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

The one with the light stick was either me or Greg Mosheh. Greg has a
buzz-cut with a ponytail. I have med-length straight brown hair & was
wearing a white T-shirt and jeans. I gave him the light-stick after a
while cause he was having so much fun with it :).

Close Encounters rocked. Alex played a wonderful techno-trance set and
Synthesis played some great _techno_!! 

The crowd was into it at first, then dispersed during Alex's set. I
agree pretty much with Mike's assessment. Most of the crowd seemed to
just be there, not even realizing what kind of music was to be played.
I went specifically because of the music, and was completely aurally
satisfied :).

They did a good job of dispersing the Haze Curse and turning it into a
decent rave space. The security, as usual, were hassling everyone. I
saw them bust into the bathroom stall and tell a guy he had to hand
over his drugs or be ejected. (Hmmm I wonder what hapens to the
drugs?)  Does anyone have any idea why they look so hard for drugs?
Hell, I've seen cops do security at events and not be that intrusive.

They shut it down at 4am when there were about 6 people left.
Synthesis looked pretty pissed. He wanted to keep spinning! Look out
for this guy. He can _really_ spin techno!

We rescued a couple of tripped out people and took them to a safe
place :). Lesson learned: If you see someone who you think might be
having a bad time, _ask_them_. I should have talked to this guy much
earlier, but I was afraid of interrupting him. It turned out he was
having a _really_ bad trip and desperately needed help. We could have
rescued him 2 hours earlier. Don't wait: ask.

I think the Haze can work. It needs good visuals, a friendly promoter
touch, more real ravers, and a bit less harassment from the security.
The latter really needs to be addressed because sooner or later
someone is going to react to it violently.

The sound was pretty decent, too. The trick, I think, is to not put
too much sound in there. At first, it was too lound and boomy. Ethan
had them turn it down a bit, and tweaked things for a while (it was
not his system), and then it sounded _good_. Better than most events.

Well, that wraps it up. Best of luck to the promoters -- I thought
they put on a good event.

Sean

From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)
Message-Id: <199404182241.PAA13249@mail.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Rave report
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

SF Rave report
==============

  This weekend promised to be more outdoors raving with the free Basics
gig this friday,  which turned out to be a big bust.    Bonny Doon was
the selected place for Basics this Friday,  but with extra publicity
and focus on Bonny Doon because of the Rolling Stone article,  the cops
were there waiting.    We get there just after 2:45 AM and as we left
Lancaster on the last 2 mile stretch of hiway 1,  we notice an unusual
amount of cop cars and other "Piggish" activities in the area,  so we
just drove on a while until we came up to a group of cars and found
out that the pary was busted.   Arghh!!    

   Instead,  I visited a friends place in Santa Cruz and we fired up some
old Jeno tapes,  cranked up the volume and had our OWN rave until about
11 am,  then headed back to SF where I had to attend a SRL meeting. (Survival
Research Lab - those crazy people who build monster machines that spit
out fire and fight each other).   After the meeting,  I head out to
Golden gate park for the Band Shell rave that was hoppin.   DJ Dan was
spinning some really good funkey tunes until they had to shut down.

  Sat evening we had.....  XYZ at Richmon Civic center (A $20 commercial
thingie) which none of us self respecting SFRavers wanted to patronize due
to the high cost.    We also had some Chicago origional DJ's spinning at
174 King St and at 16th and Harrison for only $7 (Before 11 am) we had
some true European and British style Acid Trace (which I liked the best),
so I had to put up with the 16th and Harrison (Hayes Theator) goons again
(Arghhh!),  and they sure lived up to their reputation.

  This rave was called Close Encounters,  and featured Alex from Gia Montra
records,  Ethan,  and Jonah.    I think Jonah was spinning when we got there
(About 12:30),  and I sure was happy to dance to the faster paced european
acid trance.    And BOY was I tranced out that evening!!  :-)

  The attendance factor wasn't that good,  especially when the faster paced
misic was being spun,  but I dug the shit out of it,  and was as happy as
"Pig in shit" hopping around an almost empty dance floor.   I guess the
California weenies cannot handle this stuff,  but I don't think that explained
why it was so poorly attended.    

   As the evening wore on,   Sean and me noticed this dude standing by the speakers
totally fried out staring at the cieling.   Sean commented... "I'm sure what he is
seeing is quite a bit different than what we see...".    Unfortunately,  by 3 am
the place was practically deserted and shut down early,  but I was totally 
incapable of driving anywhere, so thanx to Sean and his friends,  we made plans 
to hang out together and go somewhere to chill out.    Just as we were leaving,  
that dude that was staring up quietly said...  "Please help me!!",  so I sat 
him down,  summoned Sean over and this guy was totally hosed.   We found out later 
on,  that he had overdosed on speed.    We head out to the IHOP on Lombard St 
for some coffee and food.    Our spaced out friend wa staying in Lafeyette 
(About 35 miles east of SF),  and he begged me to stay with him until he 
recovered from his high.    Sean drives us over there, and I say with this 
dude and his friend trying to talk him out of doing more speed and comforted 
him as he was going through the last stages of the effects of the speed.  

   Eventually,  I head back to SF on BART,  pick up my car,  and
headed over to Light-n-up.   I didn't get much dancing in this weekend,
(only 6 hours),  so after Light-n-up I head over to the End-Up and went
insane,  dancing my ass off to make up for all the raving time I missed.

   While at the End-up,  this girl comes up and asks me how old I was,
then she commented.... "You are one awsome stud"...   We talked for a while
and made plans to get together next weekend.   That incident with the girl
brightened up my day,  that's for sure... Normally, by the time I get
to the End-up,  I'll have been dancing almost 20+ hours,  but because of the
Bonny Doon bust,  helping out a fellow raver on speed,   I had lots more
energy left and wanted to literally burn it up....   Eventually,  I had to
get back early to get ready to leave town on Monday,  so I (sigh) had to
leave.    The End-up was especially crowded,   but the outside porch
provided me plenty of room (and cooler environment). along with a beautiful
sunney day,   more than made up for all the hassles I had in my attempts
to go out raving this weekend.

Cheers...
Cap'n Crunch

Robert,
	These were my sentiment _exactly_!
	Earlier in the day, wile I was at the GG park party I ran into
	a well know orange-haired rave queen who asked me where I was going
	that night, I told her I was going to House, she kinda squinted,
	SShe said "Who's spinning" I said these fantastic DJ from Chicago,
	Lil John, Orlando and "Freddie", when they were here last they
	_fucked_ it up! She gets this sorta doubtful look on her face
	and then asked "Well, who's party is it?" I say to her, "Who the
	fuck cares? It _should_ be about the MUSIC not who's party or
	what DJ's are spinning!" And this weekend, this point was driven
	home to me in a very sad way at "House".  Here were three GREAT DJs
	people like lil john could give even the likes of Jeno a serious run
	for his money (he did just that at La P de V).  They played stuff that
	SF DJ's like Jeno and Markie all have in their crates and play to
	estactic crowds, but on saturday this "House" was near empty.

	These three did something neat that I though SF should really see,
	rather then each playing one 2 hours set a piece the each took 20 - 40
	minute turns, and co-operated to make the product a more communal
	group effort.

	It's a shame that the Scene is becomming so clickish and factionalized
	but I guess it is inevitable.

If I remember correctly, the first "La Pleisure de Vivre" suffered from its
*deservedly* bad association with one "jalim" (haleem? whatever) of local
infamy. I don't care *who* he brings out here to play, you will not find me
at one of his parties. Too, I remember someone I know getting stiffed by
him/them that night. So it is no big surprise, to me, that their second
effort was met with little enthusiasm. If Luciana is as cool as you say I
wish her luck in the future.

ObChicago House: one set's worth of wailing divas almost put me in the
loony bin at the one rhythm I attended. Jan Cooley had a similar effect on
me recently. I can't imagine being able to survive a whole night of it.
Occasionally a morning set of it can be a nice way to start the day
however.

One problem I have with wailing divas and more generally vocals is that
they imply lyrics which imply meaning. This is a very limiting factor; I
prefer to just entirely disengage the lyric>decode>meaning>insight part of
my brain. If I want meaning from words I'll read faulkner. What I want from
a rave is a deep trance unhindered by "deeper loves","brighter days" or
other such "insights".

roll the deep techno trance
ethan

                                _______ 
 ethan miller                     nrg                            pgp me   
_________________________ 'one unbroken whole' _________________________   
                         
                (: positive energy can save the world :)
               __________________________________________

for all the good times some of us have had there.

going to spend a day cleaning up the beach and maybe ask for some support
from the sanitation/parks dept.  It might show that at least _some_ ravers
care about such things.  It might be a good way to initiate some dialog
with the cops so that _small_ parties won't be hassled.

convinced the cops to let us have the very first "rave" on that site, I think
we should be the ones to write a letter, and maybe even sign it.
are you interested in helping me draft a letter?

Tanya, I totally relate to what you are saying.  And it pisses me off 
when people scrutinize me or the Bible because they believe otherwise.  
People often say that all Christians do is condemn others because of 
what they believe or don't believe.  What I find to hold true is that being a 
Christian is not necesssarily tolerating others but accepting others for 
who they are.  Maybe I don't agree with a person's views but I do have 
profound repect for them, just as they should for me.  And it pisses me 
off when people, who call themselves Christians, condemn others because a 
difference in beliefs, Jesus loved and cared about EVERYONE regardless of 
who they were. And if we are going about carelessly calling ourselves 
Christians while we fling accusations then we are no better than who we 
scorn.  If I sound a bit preachy its because I have friends who are gay, 
straight, white, black, brown (me :), friends that have various assorted 
hair colors;  and maybe being a pit preachy will make some people realize 
that respect is a major part of this scene and when it gets a bit hard, 
its just a test of how strong we are as individuals and as one group.  
Well, there's what I think.  I hope that I have at least made some people 
think of what its *supposed* to be like to be a Christian.
-Brian

In general, I don't like deep house or Chicago house, no matter how
well it's played. It's like country to me; I just gotta be in that
rare mood. I acknowledge the brilliance of Mark Farina and others,
it's just that the entire genre puts me to sleep most of the time.

What I'd like to hear more of is hard trance, high-energy house and
progressive house, and some hard dark dark dark claws coming out of
the speakers 150+ bpm black as night bad trip techno.

:)

Sean

I don't think its the end of an era;  at least I hope its not.  I think 
that the recent exposure of bonny doon is just a temporary "fad".  Since 
rolling stone thinks its cool, you know, it must be.  But the way fads, 
fashions, styles and other mindless crap the exudes from the corporate 
hole of Rolling Stone, it will be just another back issue that we will 
want to forget about and continue on with the reality of the scene.  
Bonny Doon was my first fmr and it was the time of my life.  I never felt 
such warmth from total strangers.  And I would hate to see it get tossed 
away labled as another overused site.  I just hope that the people that 
really care about what's going on can keep on dancing and forget the 
mainstream. I know I'd like to forget about them.
Brian

On Apr 18,  3:59pm, you proclaimed:
} I think I'll write a letter to the SC authorities and tell them that we are 
} going to spend a day cleaning up the beach and maybe ask for some support
} from the sanitation/parks dept.  It might show that at least _some_ ravers
} care about such things.  It might be a good way to initiate some dialog
} with the cops so that _small_ parties won't be hassled.
} Brian B. since you were the person who "found" (with proper props
} to caliban :) the site as far as raves are concerned and I was the one who
} convinced the cops to let us have the very first "rave" on that site, I think
} we should be the ones to write a letter, and maybe even sign it.
} are you interested in helping me draft a letter?

Yes, Geoff, I'll help with this.  If anyone else has memes they would like
to help us weave into this, send them to me or Geoff.  Let's get a draft
together by Friday.  Here are some ideas in my head:



We believe it *is* possible to hold large events there, if we take
the right precautions.  "In the old days" this meant people parking
cars, on-site medical volunteers, people making sure others came down
the cliffs the right way, etc.  This was perhaps lost on others who
have used the beach since, but it can be relearned.

Mention that there is little lateral communication in our scene (I feel
this is true, despite SFRaves) and that means sometimes abuse of social
contracts can take place.  This is what happened here, and we need to
learn from it.

There is lots more but you know what I mean.  This letter shouldn't be
meant as an attempt to reconcile or find a solution to the problem or
be an apology.  It should be an attempt to let them hear the other
side of things, in a situation other than at the beach at 2am.  They are
smarter than we might think, and recognizing that is important.

Additionally, it would really help if there were Santa Cruz residents,
particularly older Santa Cruz residents, who could speak to or 
communicate with the community about this as well.

	Brian
