Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Mime-Version: 1.0
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

One thing Sean mentioned about Ethan getting them to turn down the
sound . . . one thing I'm realizing is how important the concept
of "enough" is to sound reinforcement.  Enough meaning, sometimes tere
is too much and you have to turn it down.  This was a problem again
this week in Portland at the event Jeno spun at, in a concrete warehouse
where the mid-bass is just packed solid and gets overly percussive with
just a *little* too much drive.  They had it EQed down but it was still
too loud.  My view of it is when I'm in the sound sweet spot (they had
this set up as a quad), I shouldn't need earplugs.  And I needed plugs
pretty much all night.

If all you want is THUD BOOM, fine, breaks are for you.  If you want
more musicality, demand better sound!  I *know* it can be loud and good,
that was the lesson of the legendary 1992 Troc sound system.

Bravo!  I would suggest adding that as the initial instigators, if you
will, of using Bonny Doon for raves that you were always aware of the
carrying capacity of the area and did what you could to help keep
traffic organized and so forth.  

I think many of us can testify to the spiritual aspects of the place.
So thank you Santa Cruz County and especially the earth that made us
for letting us have this kind of experience even now in these drive-
fast-cars-drop-cigarette-butts-and-empty-beer-cans era.

Nothing could beat thrashing through the surf in the morning sun while
Garth was playing the remix of Eddy Grant's 'Walking on Sunshine.'  Nothing!

phred

From sfraves-owner  Mon Apr 18 18:31:30 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA02531; Mon, 18 Apr 94 18:31:30 PDT
Received: from duckmail.uoregon.edu by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA02522; Mon, 18 Apr 94 18:31:14 PDT
Received: from [128.223.116.100] (lanrover1-4.uoregon.edu [128.223.116.100]) by duckmail.uoregon.edu (8.6.5.Beta11/8.6.5.Beta7) with SMTP id SAA15961 for <sfraves@sfraves.stanford.edu>; Mon, 18 Apr 1994 18:31:15 -0700
Date: Mon, 18 Apr 1994 18:31:15 -0700
Message-Id: <199404190131.SAA15961@duckmail.uoregon.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
From: drenalin@duckmail.uoregon.edu (Adrenalin)
Subject: rolling stone article (long)
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

     Here is some of the article why doesn't someone else keep typing where
I left off,  hint, hint.. anyway it's long and this is the main part about
SF and the FMM.  I'm thinking of sending one with many comments, because
I'm not very fond of the article but this is unadulterated version.  Enjoy!
:)

----------------
         Along a deserted strecth of highway north of Santa Cruz, Ca., and
a few miles south of the San Andreas fault, the shoulder of the road
suddenly turns into a parking lot, with 600 cars jammed tightly on either
side.  Three police officers frantically write tickets.  "What's going on
here tonight?" one of them asks a group of people getting out of a truck.
They give a vague answer and hurry across the asphalt, disappearing over
the bluff toward the distant heartbeat of a sound system.  The Southern
Pacificcoastal railway runs along the west side of the highway.  Acoross
the tracks, a ridge descends to an exquisite beach secluded within a cove,
a setting so pristine it wouls suit a travel brochure.  Roughly 2,000
people are gathered, dancing in the sand, sitting around fires or walking
along the surf.  Some have pitched tents, and a circle of men sit on the
ground with drums, pounding a rhythmic counterpoint to the throb from the
speakersand the random hiss of a nitrous oxide tank.  The ocean carries the
palpable buzz of psychedlics.  Some people pass joints, and a few hold
bottles wrapped in brown paper.  The tribal scene would remind a baby
boomer of Woodstock.
        Threre's no bandstand tonight; instead, dancers press up around two
turntables on a stand planted in the middle of the beach.  The makeshift DJ
booth is lit by a portable generatorthat also fuels two massive speaker
stacks decorated with columns of balloons.  DJ Garth, one of the stars of
the bay Area rave scene, has just pulled Tranquility Bass' "Cantamilla"
into a pulsating, meditative mix of techno and house.  The record booms
against the cliffs, which form a natural echo chamber, and the full moon
glows over the ocean, bathing the landscape in dim blue light.
        Tonight's crowd is an even blend of college kids, club poeple,
Santa Cruz hippies and ravers.  Predominantly white, but also Asian, Latin
and black, they've come from all over Northern California and as far away
as Los Angeles and San Diego.  Assembled without promotion except for word
of mouth spread earlier this evening, they are here for the free party that
in the last two years has become a Bay Area Ritual: the Full Moon Massive
rave.  tThe trunout is especially large because the full moon is rising on
a Friday night and the weather is fine.
        Over the last few months, 20 year-old Shawn O'Docaharty, a
pierced-and-tatooed student at Cabrillo College, near Santa Cruz, has
become a regular at Full Moon.  At a perch high on the enbankment, he sits,
enjoying the view of the beach and the crisp air off of the water.  "It's
the best rave in Northern California," he says.  "The cops can't do
anything, because it's a private beach, and ther's too many people here for
them to break it up.  A $20 parking ticket split between a car of four or
five people is still a bargain for most ravers.  They'd pay $20 each
somewhere else."
        At 6am, the moon still hangs in the sky, and the first rays of
morning illuminaste the terra-cota and purple layers of the cliffs.  Nearly
500 people remain, dancing or sharing blankets around fires.  "The last
party lasted until 4 in the afternoon," says O'Docharty.  "By that time,
things get pretty communal: 'I've got food food, you've got water, he's got
a bowl.'  There's kind of a family value to it."

-----------
Thanks for smiling, please come again!

The Cloud Factory
Our People Make the Difference

	The bible is the bible.  Next your gonna tell us that such and such
	was in the writings of Paul so "i don't belive you can back these words
	text from Peter"  The christian line is that the bible (which ever one
	you choose) is the word of god and the collection of writings were written
	and put together through divine intervention and that they stand %100 correct
	as a whole because it is of and from god (funny how Gutenberg's first run
	had a bunch of typos in it though).  Anyway, what differnce does it make
	if "suffer not a witch to live" is in the biblical chapter of Liviticus
	or Mathew?  Except maybe your gonna say because it would be before or afte
	Jesus.  But the old an new testament represent the same god.
	
	-Winston (changing my name yet again to match my login)
	
	this is bullshit, winston.  i was raised and confirmed a
	catholic, and though i pretty much have abandoned their
	scene altogether, i still remember it all.  the new 
	testament and the old testament are seperate entities in
	many ways.  the new testament is a revision, and in many 
	ways, a renunciation of the old ways.   the old ways are
	what killed christ, so the story goes, who was there to
	teach a new life to everyone.  

	how can you say that christianity advocates killing of
	non-believers (and that the bible *supports* this, which 
	is the main point you made) when the first and foremost
	*prime directive* of the new testament is "thou shall
	not kill"?  think about this for a moment.  now read on.

	i am in no way denying the slaughter of thousands upon
	thousands of people at the hands of christians, christians
	who believed they were doing gods work.  fuckin-a, people
	died horrible tortuous deaths because of the inquisition
	alone.  factoids like this are what made me abandon the
	christian life very shortly after i was confirmed.  but
	nonetheless, i hold my ground that the new testament says
	*nothing* to support this sort of terror, or any killing
	at all.  it preaches love above all, really, and i think
	it is a good book.  unfortunately, throughout the ages 
	and including this age, people have been interpreting the
	bible in a vast variety of ways, to the point of making 
	the words fit exactly their philosophy and desires.  it
	is going on right now with homosexuality and with the
	exclusion of women, mainly.

>Mike asks:
>
>  >I
>  >did notice at least 2 distinct groups did I not ? ( I'm new remember )
>  >Group 1 are presumed Ravers (TM) dancing mid floor all smiles etc.
>  >Group 2 are presumed Gangers (??) mostly Hispanic, mostly stern, didn't
>  >  seem to like the music, certainly didn't dance.

What the *FUCK* is this shit?  Let me get this straight:

Group 1 MUST be mostly white, peaceful beings with all love in mind.
Group 2 MUST be the others, bangers, whatever...

And to boot Laura, you did not call him on it.  Well I will...This streak
of racism that has been going around in very masked terms sickens me.  That
is not what this scene is about, that is not what the music is about, and
it is not what life is about.

Classifying people by their looks is stupid, moronic, and rather
old-fashioned.  Not what I have come to expect from people who consider
themselves enlightened.
I also find it TRAGIC that everyone let this shit slide by with some brief
elucidation about what's what and hows what at the Haze.  Weak.

Here let me clue some of you in...that term "Gangster" seems to be applied
to people who are of the browner persuasion.  It has always, at least here
on the list as well as the fucked up media, been applied to African
Americans & Latino/Hispanics. Why is that?  The only gansters I know of are
the few thugs (most of whom do NOT fit the above sickening stereotype [i.e.
they are WHITE]) who have caused fights at clubs, been so high as to fight
the cops, try to beat up dj's, etc.  So far, I have found NO bangers do
such shit.  And if you wanna spot me the few incidents of voilence I can
site several more where no minority was involved.

Stop the classification, stop the racist bullshit, stop the codewords.
It's plain as day what you mean, and even moreso when people let the shit
slide.

Late,
John

From sfraves-owner  Tue Apr 19 07:01:29 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA11478; Tue, 19 Apr 94 07:01:29 PDT
Received: from mail.netcom.com (netcom6.netcom.com) by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA11454; Tue, 19 Apr 94 07:01:08 PDT
Received: from DialupEudora by mail.netcom.com (8.6.4/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id HAA09261; Tue, 19 Apr 1994 07:02:24 -0700
Date: Tue, 19 Apr 1994 07:02:24 -0700
Message-Id: <199404191402.HAA09261@mail.netcom.com>
X-Sender: jsl@localhost (Unverified)
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Subject: I just don't get it, AT ALL!
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Bonnie Doon - I for one am *GLAD* that it may not be used again.  Poor
planning, and just stepping onto ground where no arrangements were made
beforehand, only begs the question, "Were they asking to be shut down?".
Yes, IMHO.  The second thing about Bonnie Doon (in general terms) and
outdoor shit in general is that people really could give a fuck.  It's free
so they go.  Yes, many of us who respect the scene and respect what
djs/promoters/ravers-partiers do to make it real, but what we have lost
sight of is that there are MANY who are not clued into the big picture
(thus the term, for lack of a beeter one, clueless).  It's not that they
are not tied in or know the right person, but they are really not informed
of the etiqutte involved with being at a party.  I would venture to say
that the majority of us were introduced to the "scene" by people who were
in it, had gone to a few, and were versed as to the goings on.  Like any
"trip" a good guide can tell you whats to be expected, as well as what is
expected of you.  What we fail to understand is many, and I would say the
majority, have not had such kind intro's into our community.  The result,
3000 cracker-jacks: 200-400 that have gone out before, 2600-2800 new folx
just there for the big show == taking things for granted == mess at the
beach.

To further this nonsense it has been the community at large (many here on
the list), who have volunteered their time, and thinking of ways to correct
a problem that they have taken as their own.  That is very human, and very
good.  However, where in the FUCK is Allan, Trish & the Boyz when it comes
to this catastrophe?  What, if anything, have any of them done to try to
clear up this mess, and make things right with the SC police.  They should
be the focus of the effort (it was their efforts that made it possible),
and they should take the high road and do something about it.  They should
be held JUST as responsible for the mess as every person who dropped
rubbish on that beach.  It would really be nice if I can eat my words, but
knowing what's up, I know I am not far off in my assesment of their lack of
response in this area (and it would NOT be the first time things were
foisted onto the community due to actions of a very, very few ;(  ).

Although I do not go out to outdoor parties (due to the mess humans leave,
and the general respect I have for nature), I do hope that this will not be
the last one for those who enjoy such events.  Good luck in the repair of
Bonnie Doon. I wish there were more people like those who have the
initiative to take such action, in the general public; it would be a better
place to live.

Urrgh Music Wars/Possification of SF - I am glad I am stepping away for a
few weeks from the innards of the rave/club scene.  It seems every time I
get involved with it, I find the new high points of the people who are in
it, as well as thier lows.  But I ain't about slingin mud here, just wanna
chat about what I see as the strong opinions truning into stone realities.
Let's take music for instance...."House" @ 174 King St.  shoulda gotten
more support.  Great DJ's great music.  The reason they did not do well is
simple, there were a bunch of unknowns on the flyer.  Unknowns don't play
here real well (unless they play here often enough to get a rep).  This
sucks.  People are starting to form their own little camps of music posses.
You know, where it's the DJ you like, or the Promoter, or the "style" of
music.  The result, posses and super-posses.  Wicked is a classic example.
Yeah, I've defended the party most recently, but it *IS* a huge posse of
people who love to hear the boyz.  Most of them wanna hear *ONLY* the boyz.
The same can be said of many parties.  Either it's "I hate lyrics..." to
"I hate 150+ bpm..." to "...too many gays..." to "...too many gangsters..."
to "...too much of this..." and "...too little of that...".  I can't wait
for the day people open their heads again and give other things a try.  I
used to HATE screaming diva stuff.  I would BAG on any DJ who played it,
and any promoter who allowed such garbage to be played at his/her party.  I
have found that some lyrics in some songs are really cool, even when that
screaming goes on it can be fun.  Yeah, I know some is preachy, but MOST is
not!  I have learned to appreciate it for what it is, and have realized
that the alchemist (dj) who's tellin that tale is the real force behind the
story being told.  It's beyond just lyrics and vocal tricks.

The same can be said of "hardcore".  I personally don't like it.  Why?
I've listened to that stuff for the past 4 years that's why (to me it's
played out, heard it at Halim's, heard it at Toon Town, heard it in LA;
I've heard it, grew up on it). IMHO it has not evolved to the extend of
other genres of house.  However, I have quite a few "hardcore" trance
techno CD's that I've taken to work recently, and listento at home.  I have
found I have a great time listenting to it, given the right circumstance.
I even , omigod, booked a hardcore DJ for a Vortex a while back.  He
slammed it, and I had a GREAT time with his set.  Even though I was not
"into" it personally , I could hear the story, and got off on it!  It's all
about keeping that open mind and giving things a chance.  That's what it's
about.  Isn't it?

All of these tastes turn into posses when people take it to the next level
of discrimination (and you should be discrimitating at times IMHO).  You
know what I'm talkin about:  "I/We only go to Wicked..." or "I/We only go
to YSH..." or "I/We only go to anypartyname/anypartytype...".  This ensures
this scenes demise.  And if such selectivity continues, I will be VERY
happy to see the whole thing end.  Nature abhors a vaccum and it abhors the
specialist.  Only through many offerings/many tastes can this scene thrive.
Diversity is strength so diversify every now and then.  When out of town
DJ's come in for a spin, take a listen to 'em (esp. if it's cheap).  Try
out parties you would not normaly attend, just for kicks (and keep a good
'tude.  Just go for the fun of it! Hell, it's just a party :) ).  Support
the good parties, and give the new promoters/dj's/etc. a chance to prove
themselves (The majority of the folx here on the list do this last item
pretty well, but I had to say it nonetheless).  And if possible do
something yourself, or with a collective.  Keep it goin' !

Peace,
John

                 Ain't no future in your frontin'

other : John_Lee.DPI@notes.worldcom.com

From sfraves-owner  Tue Apr 19 08:54:54 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)

Received: from lizard.srv.PacBell.COM by pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA07370; Tue, 19 Apr 94 08:36:14 PDT
Date: Tue, 19 Apr 94 08:36:14 PDT
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9404191536.AA07370@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Our scene In The Light
Cc: sfraves-planners@techno.Stanford.EDU, jlf3@mofo.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I think Geoff's idea of a letter to local Santa Cruz officials is a good 
one, and in a way, underscores the main problem that's happening with our 
scene.  What has been sorely missing from the scene is COMMUNICATION.

Let's face it, FMRs lost their full moon ritualistic nature focus a long
time ago, and there has been no attempt at all to communicate *anything*
worthwhile to the party-goers.  And what was that free Basics party all
about?  "Let's stop fucking around" and go invade the Bonnie Doon
neighborhood again?  If the scene is just about the music and partying, 
even free ones aren't going to "keep it alive".  Parties like Kindness 
and Your Sisters' House have the right idea because they attempt to 
communcate something beyond the mainly hedonistic aspects of raving.  At 
all the other major parties I go to, I rarely see info sheets about 
*anything* anymore, just flyers for other parties.  Have you all seen
the flyer for "Apocalypse" with the nuclear mushroom cloud?  Now there's
a nice image for ya. 

In case no one noticed, we're supposed to be putting on a party on May 
28th, the Saturday of Memorial Day weekend.  This could be a chance to get 
a positive message out to people in the scene who are not online, 
including some of the none-raver public.

But first, I have a confession to make.  After the success of CONNECTION
EARTH last October, it was clear that another SFRaves party in the park
would be a good thing.  So I went ahead and made the arrangements, and
lined up May 28th, for us.  With the help of a couple of others, all the 
basic elements are in place: permits, DJs, sound system, U-haul, generator,
flyers... but something is missing here, and in the last couple of days,
it's been eating at me - and I think the Bonnie Doon bust has been my wake
up call.

I think I've been overlooking the fact the IN THE LIGHT is supposed to be
an SFRaves party.  Because I wanted it to happen so badly, I've pretty much
forged ahead with the arrangements, just assuming that the list was behind
me.  Well, this isn't supposed to be about *me* at all.  Even though I've
already put my personal signature on it, if this doesn't become *our* 
party, I'm going to have to cancel it.  And I'm *not* talking about the 
money.

I want to hear from people.  Do we really want to do this?  What's the 
point?   Would it make sense to bring Geoff & Brian's letter to the party 
and get signatures?  Should we have handouts that talk about how important
it is for ravers to respect the environment?  Can we get more signatures 
for the Hemp Initiative?  Can we, as a group do something worthwhil, or is
the scene really dying?  With your help, I think we can get a good turnout 
and make a positive impact.  But I just don't know if the enthusiasm is 
there.  There's no point in having a party for the sake of a party.

I want to thank my wife, Janie, for helping me understand what it was I
was forgetting about.  It's just like what a lot of people in the scene are forgetting about - raving is not about personal accomplishment or egos,
or getting off on helping people have fun.  It's about all of us, together, 
connected, communicating the things we believe in, trying to make our world
a little better for *everyone*.  What should we do?
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com
____________________________________________________________________________

>One thing Sean mentioned about Ethan getting them to turn down the
>sound . . . one thing I'm realizing is how important the concept
>of "enough" is to sound reinforcement.  Enough meaning, sometimes tere

I'm really glad this got picked up as a thread cos it's an essential issue
at this point in time. 

Close Encounters as a party was *destroyed* by the sound system. Alex's set
which should have been great (certainly his music was) was unbearably
painful at the volumes at which it occurred. It drove bryce and I screaming
from the room. So I did not ask them to turn it down, I went and found the
amps and turned it *way the fuck down*, 50% at the amps. At those levels it
was still insanely loud but free of distortion, basically listenable. 5
minute later the promoter came and harassed alex for turning down 'his'
system. My ears rang for a day. Vivid suffered from the same probelm,
Kindness, Townsend, Groove Kitchens at King Street, Basics at trocadero,
etc. Thank god most of Martin's big parties (Gathering, Vision et al)
employ the famed Mark Wayne and is Meyer Sound gear which while not
altogether Hi-fi is nonethless plenty powerful and very well managed.

Compounding this problem is that djs don't know what a good sound system
sounds like. I'm sure you'll disagree Geoff but I've heard Garth do it and
I've heard Jeno do it; I've heard Spun, Josh, and Evil Eddie do it. DJs
invariably want to know *what it sounds like out there*, that very deep
urge to actually hear the set you're playing. A well poistioned DJ booth
(or table etc.) should disallow this; DJs should be behind the main system
with excellent monitors. Somtimes they are in which case the DJ turns it up
until the whole room resonates. They think they're hearing *it* what
they're actually hearing is the compressors in the amp rack compressing the
distortion they're forcing out of the mixer. Those red lights on the LEDs?
THEY'RE RED FOR A REASON! So that big DJ sound? Compressed, badly
reverberant distortion. 

Promoters and djs take note:

>>>>>>  Bad audio will kill this scene. <<<<<<

The door to trance is thru sound. If the sound system drives you out of the
room, the party's over.

Repeat after me: 
I love my eardrums. I love my eardrums. I love my eardrums. 
I love my eardrums. I love my eardrums. I love my eardrums. 
I love my eardrums. I love my eardrums. I love my eardrums. 
I love my eardrums. I love my eardrums. I love my eardrums. 
I love my eardrums. I love my eardrums. I love my eardrums. 
I love my eardrums. I love my eardrums. I love my eardrums. 
I love my eardrums. I love my eardrums. I love my eardrums. 
I love my eardrums. I love my eardrums. I love my eardrums. 
I love my eardrums. I love my eardrums. I love my eardrums. 

take it easy
ethan

On Tue, 19 Apr 1994, ethan miller wrote:

> >One thing Sean mentioned about Ethan getting them to turn down the
> >sound . . . one thing I'm realizing is how important the concept
> >of "enough" is to sound reinforcement. . .


  You Go, Ethan!!!   No-one is more <painfully> aware of the problems with 
Djs <who *may* play good tunes but have no listening for their environ> 
than those of us who must work in the same small, painfully loud, booth 
with them!   I do have a bit of a different view as to cause and effect, 
though:  I think the monitors are the enemy. 

I was a very successful club dj from 1975 thru the late 80's, working 
mostly in Texas, but also in NYC and SF, and was actually the original dj 
*and* light operator at 1015 when Ira got it in '86. Now I find I'm not 
as consumed by the need to be the one who introduces the music, so I try to 
work the space and support the DJs, the scene, and the music visually.
Somehow I kept 20/20 hearing while playing four to five night per week
in large clubs. I believe it is because I would not work in a space that 
required me to guess what the crowd was hearing while being locked away 
in a remote closet with a totally different sound system.  Trying to dj 
in the most booths in SF is sorta like trying to compete in the Indy 500, 
while driving by remote control from the press box.  You just don't have 
the same feel for the road and thus the ability to finesse the machinery 
to the same degree.

I've recently been told by my doctor that my left eardrum (the side 
towards the dj) is noticeably more inflamed at every checkup for the past 
year.  He says to expect that to evolve into a significant hearing loss.  
Now consider this:  I'm a good 8 feet or more from the monitors in the 
booth while the dj is INCHES away.  It's not hard to figure what's 
causing the poor sound quality in the clubs if you check out what the 
jocks are doing to their own ears!  I'd be willing to make a wager that 
very few if any will be hearing accurately <if at all> before we know 
it.  And who wants to listen to a deaf dj?   Roll over Beethoven!  

From sfraves-owner  Tue Apr 19 11:40:16 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)

From: phuture@aol.com
X-Mailer: America Online Mailer
Message-Id: <9404191437.tn43691@aol.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Tue, 19 Apr 94 14:37:36 EDT
Subject: Re: Hispanic Gangstas
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I just got through this thread and tend to agree with John, since race was
mentioned(Hispanic nonetheless) and this white boy got the same vibe.  I
recently had the chance to work on a recording project with some Chicano
rappers(who fit the description previously given) and I made some good
friends and learned a lot.  Here are some things I came away with. First,
Chicano is preferable to mexican which is preferable to latino which is
prefeable to hispanic.  There are large cultural differences among these
groups.  Chicanos have a distinctive culture here in California and
rightfully don't like to see it always lumped in with the diverse group of
cultures encompassed by a term like hispanic.  Second, these guys have had a
happening dance/party scene for a LONG time--decades with multiple
generations partying together.  There is a lot of history here with respect
to DJing and dancing.  Techno is very popular with a lot of the younger
generation.  OK, the hard, cool , macho thing can be a barrier--but that's
what it is.  Defensiveness is a way of life growing up in the enviroment they
did.  I have been to several parties, where the vibe got so huge that no one
could resist and the contribtution when this group opened up and expressed
was massive energy(not negative)--the party slammed!  Its about feeling
comfortable and that can be much harder for people who come from violent,
tough 'hoods.  Hip-hop(Chicano or regular flavor) is much abused and often
blamed for violence, but there is a lot of really positive music, art,
clothes and the rave scene has certainly benefitted from this cultural
crossover so far.  With so many questions about our scene's possible death
maybe the answers lie in this 'other' culture that many don't yet understand
or appreciate.
phuture

From sfraves-owner  Tue Apr 19 12:59:24 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA16987; Tue, 19 Apr 94 12:59:24 PDT
Received: from mail.netcom.com (netcom4.netcom.com) by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA16980; Tue, 19 Apr 94 12:59:13 PDT
Received: from localhost by mail.netcom.com (8.6.4/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id NAA13089; Tue, 19 Apr 1994 13:00:23 -0700
From: brycer@netcom.com (Bryce Ryan)
Message-Id: <199404192000.NAA13089@mail.netcom.com>
Subject: Re: >>>Big sound etc...
To: kgoto@artsci.wustl.edu (Keigo Goto)
Date: Tue, 19 Apr 1994 13:00:23 -0700 (PDT)
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.89.9404191450.B21867-0100000@banana> from "Keigo Goto" at Apr 19, 94 02:21:05 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 4058      
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

My mailer says that Keigo Goto said:
> 
> 	I agree with having to much sound is going to kill us.  My 
> suggestion is turn down the treble and mid-range sounds and let the bass 
> do the trick.  From my experience loud bass doesn't make your ears ring 
> only piercing treble does...
> 
I heartily concur.  There are several issues in addition to the psycho-
acoustics: overal volume, equalization, room acoustics, and efficiency.
It is almost always the case that the mid-high and high frequency 
speakers are *lots* more efficient than the bass frequency drivers.
this is largely due to the fact that the power needed to move woofers
is substantially larger than tweeters: the magnets weigh more, and
they have to move a *lot* more air.  The room acoustics, if not taken
into account, can wreak havoc, since an improperly or unequalized
room will accentuate certain frequencies, attenuate others, and in
general turn the best system into mush.  If you can hear a room
resonate (sounds like you're inside a drum) at low frequencies (with
the bass beat), then the high frequencies are also going to resonate
(that is, be accentuated) potentially at very high power levels (perhaps
as much as 4 times the rated output power of the system---and that's
an incredible volume level).  

There is also a critical power level below which the room will be
predominated by *direct* sound, rather than *resonant* sound.  The
system at the Haze is a classic example of too much power for the
room.  Rooms sound much better if you keep the power below this
level, because when the room resonates, the music starts to sound
like mush.  This is because it takes *time* to build up that much 
energy, and *time* to dissipate that much energy. meanwhile, the 
program material (the record) may be a beat or two or even more, past
the sound that started it all--mush.

Folks familiar with acoustics: i'm taking some liberties with the terms
here. Bear with me, please.

So, another secret to good sound is the keep the volume below the
above-mentioned critical power level.  Finally, it is *necessary*
to equalize the sound system for the room.  This is because room
acoustics have an amazing effect at such high power levels. And
also because of the above-mentioned differences in efficiency between
the drivers.

Some of the ways that DJs can mess up the best laid plans of the sound
people are: turning the levels up at the mixer (results in distortion
being pushed through the system), messing substatially with the
equalizer on the mixer (kills the best tuning and results in that
painful high frequency ring), and not evening out the levels between
records. 

one of the problems that i personally have with certain kinds of music
is the predominance of high frequencies (at irregular intervals). rarely
are the systems tuned for worst case: usually just for average.  so, if
the material goes from being full frequencied to being very high level
high frequency material, the sound system exceeds the threshhold of pain
on that high frequency stuff, and blammo: Permanent Hearing Loss.

Badly tuned systems, over-powered systems, and the like do just that:
they CAUSE permanent hearing loss.  If your ears ring the day after
an event, you have been subjected to too much sound power. if you
hear distortion (especially at high frequencies), or your head kind
of hurts, you are being subjected to too much power. My suggestion
to anyone experiencing discomfort at a party because the sound is
too loud for you:  if you can find the promoter or a staff person,
demand they turn down the system.  if you can't find a responsible
person, leave and demand your money back.  Don't suffer.  No single
party is worth the possibility of permanent damage to your body. And
promoters should have the health and well-being of fellow-partiers
at heart.  if they don't, avoid supporting them if you can.

<stepping down from soapbox>
-- 
Bryce Ryan ------- AMBIANCE ----------- brycer@netcom.com-----
"We have a problem. Too many of you know who we are."  AMI
Semiconductor ad copy

** Long message ... skip to ObSFrave if tech stuff bores you **

	With a good mixing board, a DJ can eliminate monitors all together
and mix inside headphones alone.  All that's required is a cueing
system that lets you hear the mix through one ear and the track
you're mixing in through the other.  The only problem is that it's
then harder to set the master levels properly, because you're
isolated (same as in a booth) and can't hear what it sounds like on
the main sound system.  You can't just rely on LEDs alone...  As far
as I can see, the only way to keep the sound quality good is to
constantly monitor what it sounds like on the dance floor.  This has
to be done either by the DJ or the sound people.  A good sound person
can do a great job, just by constantly eqing and adjusting various
levels.  Of course, clipping caused by the DJ overdriving the levels
will always be a problem, but that's why it helps if the sound guy
and the DJ can work together, and the DJ can drop his mixer levels,
so the sound guy can turn it up out on the floor.

ObSFrave:	What I think most promoters don't realize is that you
can't just set an amp stack over in the corner, run cable to the
speakers, turn the amps up to full volume and let it go...  A good
sound system takes lots of tuning, and precision placement of the
speakers.  Even though some promoters are starting to realize this,
there's still a lot that don't and it's kind of sad.  I hate events
where you feel as if the sound system is _physically_ damaging you. 
I've heard good sound enough that I know it can be loud, and bassy,
the kind of bass you feel, without hurting your ears.

>>> Kerry Jaggers <jaggedge@well.sf.ca.us>  4/19/94, 12:28pm >>>

> >One thing Sean mentioned about Ethan getting them to turn down the
> >sound . . . one thing I'm realizing is how important the concept
> >of "enough" is to sound reinforcement. . .


  You Go, Ethan!!!   No-one is more <painfully> aware of the problems
with  Djs <who *may* play good tunes but have no listening for their
environ>  than those of us who must work in the same small, painfully
loud, booth  with them!   I do have a bit of a different view as to
cause and effect,  though:  I think the monitors are the enemy. 

I was a very successful club dj from 1975 thru the late 80's, working
 mostly in Texas, but also in NYC and SF, and was actually the
original dj  *and* light operator at 1015 when Ira got it in '86. Now
I find I'm not  as consumed by the need to be the one who introduces
the music, so I try to  work the space and support the DJs, the
scene, and the music visually.
Somehow I kept 20/20 hearing while playing four to five night per
week in large clubs. I believe it is because I would not work in a
space that  required me to guess what the crowd was hearing while
being locked away  in a remote closet with a totally different sound
system.  Trying to dj  in the most booths in SF is sorta like trying
to compete in the Indy 500,  while driving by remote control from the
press box.  You just don't have  the same feel for the road and thus
the ability to finesse the machinery  to the same degree.

I've recently been told by my doctor that my left eardrum (the side 
towards the dj) is noticeably more inflamed at every checkup for the
past  year.  He says to expect that to evolve into a significant
hearing loss.   Now consider this:  I'm a good 8 feet or more from
the monitors in the  booth while the dj is INCHES away.  It's not
hard to figure what's  causing the poor sound quality in the clubs if
you check out what the  jocks are doing to their own ears!  I'd be
willing to make a wager that  very few if any will be hearing
accurately <if at all> before we know  it.  And who wants to listen
to a deaf dj?   Roll over Beethoven!

You know what would be really cool is to get one of the AKG or Neumann dummy
head microphone systems and hang it or mount it out above the crowd.  The DJ
would then have a true binaural stereo monitor source--he'd literally have a
head in the crowd.  The voulume issue wouldn't be automatically resolved, but
the DJ (or soundperson) would then have a much more accurate idea of what the
system sounds like out on the floor.
phuture

What really bugs me is how many DJs just jam the knobs all the way up.
They were doing this at Wicked in 174 King St. I remember seeing it in
the back room at the Gathering in Richmond Civic Center. All the red
LEDs were on all the time. And both systems sounded like shit, because
mixing decks introduce distortion when you push them into the red.
Even if one has a compressor-limiter between the board and the amp so
it _can't_ be turned up too loud, all that distortion is still there.

It's really a shame, because I bet most DJs just don't know how shitty
those records--the ones they sweated blood finding--sound to the
crowd.

And as far as stuff being too loud... I bet OSHA would have a word or
two to say about it. Anyone filed a workman's comp yet? :)

Sean

John S. Lee writes:
 > >  >I
 > >  >did notice at least 2 distinct groups did I not ? ( I'm new remember )
 > >  >Group 1 are presumed Ravers (TM) dancing mid floor all smiles etc.
 > >  >Group 2 are presumed Gangers (??) mostly Hispanic, mostly stern, didn't
 > >  >  seem to like the music, certainly didn't dance.
 > 
 > What the *FUCK* is this shit?  Let me get this straight:
 > 
 > Group 1 MUST be mostly white, peaceful beings with all love in mind.
 > Group 2 MUST be the others, bangers, whatever...

I was there, and Mike's assessment of it was correct. From Mike's
statements, the following conclusions are NOT supported:

Group 1 was caucasion. They may have been mostly black, indian, asian,
or of mixed races. They were in fact of mixed races.

Hispanics are gangsters. Group 2 was mostly hispanic, but that does
not imply the opposite is true.

All of the asshole security guards were wearing yellow jackets. Not
all the security guards were assholes. Not everyone wearing a yellow
jacket was an asshole, and it would be foolish to assume so.

Mike was making an observation without judgement, and me having been
there to confirm it, it was an accurate one. I don't think an angry
response is justified. If Mike doesn't like the gangster look and
attitude, then that's a differerent issue to be taken up.

Personally, I don't like being around the "angry testosterone" vibe,
though I respect people's right to be and feel however they like. I
just choose to not be around them. I've had enough anger and hate for
three lifetimes. I wish to embrace something else. And that is _my_
choice.

Sean

Keep it goin' your*self*, John S. Lee.  

Great postings the last couple of days.  

As for me, I keep going where the music is interesting and the people are
good, and see no end to either of those situations, so therefore no chanc
of the scene 'dying'.  Changing, yes.  Take it from one who's been living
on the front lines of the record bins for the last six months -- we are
in a golden era for the music, when *every* style from club disco to
the fastest gabber has great tracks coming out all the time.  (You
didn't catch me saying the good ones are *easy* to find, they never are!)
What seems to be changing most is the taste of the audience, broadly
considered, for all this kind of music.  The intense convergence of
1991-92 is over, and a thousand flowers and considerable confusion are
blooming.  

On the commercial tip, the word in the biz is 'get commercial'.  This is
the theme throughout the trade rags I get.  One representative example -
the main wheel at ZYX Records, a Brooklyn label with a German operation
that covers a fairly broad range of music but focuses on club releases,
says "no more dub tracks," that is, no more non-vocal remixes from their
label, in an effort to develop "identifiable" artists (a la M People,
2 Unlimited, others of greater or lesser merit).  On the other end of
the spectrum are the hardcore and jungle labels which seem determined to
drive as much as possible into harder-and-faster territory no matter who
they leave behind.  In some ways I don't mind either trend, but underneath
it is an air of exclusivity about the desired target audience that I really
don't like, instead of an attitude of adherence to quality music and
educating rather than satiating the audience.  

But we've seen this pattern before, for example the 1979-81 era where
punk and new wave severed their fragile alliance and headed off in their
own directions.  But that opens up fresh territory for new approaches,
like the American-jangly-guitar bands of the mid-1980s exemplified by
REM or Husker Du who really weren't directly from either tradition.

I expect clubs to get clubbier, the underground to go more under, and
some openings for those adept at finding the fertile spaces in between.

So jslee, you GO!!

*Some* people get off on bass thumps that practically boil your blood.
I am *not* one of those people.  When the bass *permeates* you and
helps get you energized and you can still hear every point on the audio
spectrum with excellent clarity. . . then you *got* me!

Of COURSE we want May 28 to be an inclusive one, Lee.  Which is why
I'm planning to be there if I can possibly manage it.

I'm all for providing a way for people to distribute messages, do voter
reg, whatever, at In the Light.  But as many of you have heard me rant
about to the point of boredom or worse, the biggest contribution I think
we can make is to have really great events that make a reality of the
underlying principles we talk about as important to us and which keep
drawing us toward public gatherings involving music and interaction and
all that good stuff.  Anything less, as jslee keeps putting it, is
frontin' pure and simple.  We gotta walk it like we talk it.

Long before I had a sound system or thought of being a dj I used to go out
to parties every week and bring a table, a blacklight and neon body paints.
I never met a promoter that wouldn't let me in free. I'd set up the paints,
hang out while it was still early, meet people, talk, joke, help out etc.
After a while I'd leave the paints and go dance. Every once and a while I'd
come back and clean up a little, refill the paint saucers and then go dance
some more. People loved the paints. I remember at the first Imagination at
Townsend/King St. I came back at 6am and these two people who were just
*lit* had been sitting there for hours painting each other. They both had
full-body, neon tribal work of astonishing complexity. Wow.

I remember knowing then, quite clearly, that my *active* particapatory
positive energy was an absolutely essential ingredient in any party I
happened to be at, that a good party was something we all had to build
together, that *any* party could be a great one if everyone there took
responsibility for making it one. Nobody dances until someone dances. Faces
are mail reflectors; smile and the world smiles with you.

I think I'm only recently realising that I got bored of 'consuming' raves a
long time ago. I think I started throwing parties, doing sound, dj-ing,
etc. because it *ensured*, for me, a particpatory experience. And, in
truth, I have the best times at the small (often *very* small;) parties
that we do together.

sfraves is something very, very special. I won't try and define it. We all
love it for our very own and exactly the same reasons. It is a community,
it gives meaning.

In The Light is yet another chance for us to do it our way, to make it mean
something. May 28th lets get *together* and put a sonic dent in the fucking
universe. 

(That's the cool thing about sound you know, it just keeps on goin.)

:)

take it easy
ethan


                                _______ 
 ethan miller                     nrg                            pgp me   
_________________________ 'one unbroken whole' _________________________   
                         
                (: positive energy can save the world :)
               __________________________________________

Oversensitive me...

I guess you just have to walk on eggshells when posting on the list, lest
JSL jump all over your ass....UNTRUE.

C'mon people let's face it.  As much as many would HATE to admit it, CA is
as racist as racist can be.  The Bay Area is certainly no exception to this
rule.  And CA in general is pretty bad.

In Miami we do not have skinners (or didn't when I left years back;  if
they're there now, they are most likely dead).  Sure got 'em here tho!  The
west coast is home to these creeps.  SF was a bastion for these pigs for
the longest time.  Ask certain...forget it.

KKK?  Yeah sure, but not as many as CA (in 1950 the LARGEST KKK contingent
was in Anaheim CA. >40000  The city council was chock full of 'em.  Home of
DIsney == Home of the KKK.  Real California dreamin').

Guys like Metzger were so underground in Miami cuz' you got every non-white
type in FL. Most Metzger types had to escape North & West to get some
acceptance.  It seems they found fertile ground in Az., Texas, all the way
to the hotbed of fermentable thought, CA.  Numbers do bear me out on this.

So what's up?  What's with me getting all chip-on-the-shoulderish with the
simple term, gangsta?  Hey, he (Mike) was only talkin about:

Clothes/fashion.
A small group who was not necessarily minority.
A group of folx not into the vibe.

And *I* am the racist because:
He never said the first group was white, *I* did.

The trend:
There has been so much gangsta talk.  Either it's gangsta-moll, or gangsta
type.  I have seen post, after post from a few on the list, using this
reference.  And I and *SOME* others of color have begun to ask:

Who are they talking about?
What are they talking about?
What are they seeing that we're not?

I have noticed that the term is used primarily to denote those of
non-european ancestry (i.e. non-white for the sake of converstaion).  And
it is most often used to distinguish the real "loving" ravers, from those
who supposedly do not belong.  I guess it is coincidental that whenever
there is a greater presence of latino/chicano/hispanics or blacks/af. am.s
that this term is used more often.
Ok it's a coincidence, I am being oversensitive (why else would I be so
observant as to notice how/why/when it's used ) ;).

I have also noticed that when a party does not have many of the, er group
2's  ;), that the term disappears.  I guess it's a coincidence, and I am
being oversensitive.

I have also noticed that the news always shows blacks and latinos getting
arrested when it comes to gang activity, or drugs (even though the
consumers are for the most part white; as well as the kingpins [bka US
Govt.]).  But I guess I should never believe the news, or even watch it.
It may sensitize me.

On the other hand I have to ask: Why are these classifications being used,
in a community that prides itself on breaking down barriers?  Why classify,
and allow classification based upon appearance rather than deed?  Is the
concept of measuring a person by his/her deeds and character gone to the
wayside while appearance, once again has taken the forefront?  Is judging
by character now considered PC?

A gangsta would, from *my* experience:
Kick your ass for looking at him/her for 1/4 sec.
Call you out, and kick your ass for stepping in his/her space.
Kick your ass because you're there and he/she's there.
Steeping into territory where you do not belong.
Shoot your ass on a good day.

Dress is unimportant.  There are certain styles of dress, but it varies
from group to group.  There is susally a signal of some sorts that is done
before things are done, and afterward.  Soemtimes there are even colors.

There is a west coast style, as well as an east coast style.  In both
dress, and deed.

By the time you notice them, it's too late.


Now I ask AGAIN, what gangsters has anyone seen at a party?
What gang was it?
What colors?
Where is their territory?
Do they go to BASICS?  Wicked?  Etc.

Why would they SPEND money to get into a place, when they would do just as
well to bum rush it?  Especially if it costs $20 to get in?

I submit that the term has been used as a classification of certain groups
of people based along race lines.  That's why I blew up.

I know I'm not oversensitive because:
I went to an industrial show a while back, saw many bald headed white guys,
in all black, army boots, white tee shirts.  I never assumed they were
skinners.  I assumed they are a bunch of dudes with bald heads.  I was
re-assured when one of the guys black/latina girlfriend gave him a whopping
kiss.  He even said, "What's up bra'" as we were all leaving.  This was in
Strong Beach , CA. (long beach)  Bald headed, yes.  Skinhead however would
be a stretch....my mediocrity was defeated and I then knew my calling ;)

And that's what I'm sayin....There are two type of mutha's born in this
world, some would say three:  Good, Bad, & Ugly.  All are IMHO determined
by their actions, not what the fuck they wear, not what the fuck color they
are, only through someone's deed or LACK of it can a determination be made
as to a person's worth.  Anything less is weakness.  And anyone not
attacking such weakness is, in my little corner of the world, a traitor to
humanity at best.
I just wish people would see thru the bullshit and get to what's under the
skin, cuz that is REAL.

*** John S. Lee, it is written, then takes the staff of G-d, spreads it
over the SF Bay and parts the water.  He then looks over his shoulder to
see that Mediocrites, struck in awe of the power of G-d, stop, allowing the
masses to cross the now parted bay.  With rubber boots on, the Partyites
cross the bay, to seek refuge in the land of milk, honey, E (fruit and
veggies for those on a strict no-dose diet), SoundVision, and Hella DJ's
spinning that is called, er uh, The Land of Milk and Honey.  Somewhere
north of Telegraph (SF is paved over ). It is written, it is done. ***

Audi 5,
John

mean, do they come from Concord?  BlackHawk?  Where do these gangsters come

nonsense should stop, if we are to move on as a community.  This scene as
far as I am concerned, needs an injection of diversity if it's gonna last.

tell all.  Time for new ways of thinking.  Time to call a human a human and
leave it at that.  Time to know the good thru the deed, and the bad thru
the greed.  Let's get real.

Race, and the concpet of race does not "just exist".  It is one of the MANY

each others throats.  Just another way to point out THEM from US.  The
second you stop seeing THEM the US becomes stronger.  And that's what I'm
pissed about.  Too much THEM/US.  Epsecially along racial lines.  So
regressive, so stupid, so old.

>It is sad that no longer can one make simple

You are DAMN right.  There are social codes we all have to follow.  You
break them, you face certain consequences, that is your right as well.  The
social code is quite clear, if you wanna follow it then cool, if not then
deal with the consequences.  You can't go around calling people racial
epithets, without at some time someone crackin your skull.  And if you want
to engage in classification based upon something as benign and
old-fashioned as race, then you can enjoy the 21st century quite alone.

As for simple observations:  Tell me what a gangster is and how many YOU
have seen at parties.

What did they look like and *HOW* did you know they were gangsters?
What *does* a gangster look like?

>Please don't assume that everyone on this list is white, etc, etc.  I'm

Hello?!?!?!?  Did I say that everyone was white?  Where did you get THAT

is that it is a rainbow of sorts.  Some colors of it are more abundant than
others, but a rainbow nonetheless.  Please don't assume that I assume
anything about this list.  I do however deplore racist statements, and
deplore people who ignore them; whether they be white, black, yellow,
brown, red, I could give a damn.  Racist rubbish is a blight.

people that i have EVER meet in my life.  good soild people.  after
staying and talking to them for close to two weeks found something out.
they were discusing there biz (guest house owners) and very matter a
factly told us that of course they don't allow arabs to stay there.  in
that way that suprises you: "of course you agree there is no question
about it right".  this kind of racism always bothers me the most.  it is
deeply accepted as a resonable and correct pt-o-vw.

people will defend there pt-o-vw if called on it (as a non-racist i've
nvr heard a good arguement but.. ).  rather then just deeply beliving
that people should not allow to be.

Hello Folks!

 In case anyone was wondering which day the South Bay lunch is going to be 
be this week , I decided not to "officially" announce one , since I'm still
receiving opinions about the location and time. However , I'll be there 
at Greer Park today at 12:30 , just to get my weekly dose of sunshine
and fresh air - I'll bring the "boom-box" too.

	Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com
 ( poll results to follow ... ) 
----------------------------------------------------------------------
today's "unofficial" SFR South Bay Lunch ...

When: Wednesday  
Time: 12.30 PM 
Where: Greer Park, Palo Alto

Directions:

* From 101 (South or North) take the Oregon Expressway Exit
  Northbound: Past San Antonio Road 
  Southbound: Past University Avenue 

* Left at the first signal - W. Bayshore
  (it's a frontage road that takes you south again)

* Follow this road approx. 1/4 mile (pass apartment complexes on right)
  
* You will see the park on your right hand side. Turn into the first 
  driveway on your right.

* We'll meet on the grassy knoll , behind the round baseball fence.
  Next to the restrooms and ball courts.

Bring lunch, toys, yourselves!
------------------------------------------------------------------

RE: New day/time/site for the South Bay Lunch 
 Results So Far: It seems that most of the folks who responded can make
  it Wednesday at 12:30 . Menlo Park seems like the absolute northern
  most location , as the work-to-park-and-back distance would be too
  far for some folks - even Menlo Park was bad for one person.

below:

>  but #1 choice).

>  Addison near Scott St. (no bathrooms)
>- A grassy area w/ benches on Lytton across from the Gatehouse.

>parking so good luck in finding a spot.

a lot of time out from my lunch schedule, and looking for parking would
be worst. Maybe a weekend? ....

On Apr 19,  9:23pm, Jay Ess Ell Double-E said:
(quoting Sean)
} >Personally, I don't like being around the "angry testosterone" vibe,
} >though I respect people's right to be and feel however they like. I
} >just choose to not be around them. I've had enough anger and hate for
} >three lifetimes. I wish to embrace something else. And that is _my_
} >choice.
} 
} Agreed.  But when you talk about gangsters, *who* are you talking about?  I
} mean, do they come from Concord?  BlackHawk?  Where do these gangsters come
} from?  Where do they live?  Has there been ANY gang activity in our scene?
} Where?  How did you *KNOW* they were gangsta's, if you knew at all?

I wasn't there so I'm not going to defend the classification, I'll only
say that the "gangsta" "look" doesn't have to be qualified by whether or
not someone's really in a hardcore gang or not.  My dad could sport over-
size jeans, a plaid shirt buttons at the top button, and a red bandana,
and a scowl across his face, and some would say he's sporting a "gangsta
look".  Whether or not it strikes YOU as a racist classification, John,
to most of us it simply classifies a look and perhaps lifestyle, and
I've seen all shades of skin color sporting that look.  

} I despise the "angry testosterone" vibe (one of the many reasons I stay
} away from "hardcore" parties ;) ).  But really, this classification
} nonsense should stop, if we are to move on as a community. 

Whoa whoa whoa... why do we have to lose our sense of subjectivity in
order to act as a community?  We should always have the right to call a
spade a spade, and in the case that started this whole thing, the
"gansta look" wasn't what distinguished that group of people as being
a problem, it was that "angry testosterone" vibe that accompanied it.
The two are not synonymous, and no one was suggesting they were.  I've
seen people with the "gangsta look" wiggling their behinds at lots of
parties.  

And good thing you put that smiley in there, or we'd really think you
really meant to associate "angry testosterone" with "hardcore" parties.

} This scene as
} far as I am concerned, needs an injection of diversity if it's gonna last.
} All the classification, and re-classification is killing it; the numbers
} tell all.  Time for new ways of thinking.  Time to call a human a human and
} leave it at that.  Time to know the good thru the deed, and the bad thru
} the greed.  Let's get real.

	Diversity we need, yes.  But let's be clear: we need to
destory the cliqueishness going on in the scene, not "classification",
Classification agreed is a tool people use to define their clique at
times, but as long as it isn't based on an unfair basis like race or
creed or income level or "you don't ususally go to these parties, what
are you doing here?", what's the problem?

	Brian

Randy Tinkerman writes:
 > brian's freudian slip:
 > 	>We should always have the right to call a
 > 	>spade a spade...
 > 
 > next we'll be calling a hoe, ho.  ?-)  

For the record, there are a lot of uses and phrases associated with
the term "spade". Only one of them is considered offensive and is not
very commonly used. "Calling a spade a spade" is not a racist term.

1spade \'spa^-d\ n
[ME, fr. OE spadu; akin to Gk spathe^- blade of a sword or oar, OHG
     spa^-n chip of wood -- more at SPOON]
(bef. 12c)
1: a digging implement adapted for being pushed into the ground with
     the foot
2: a spade-shaped instrument
-- spade-ful \-,fu-l\ n 
-- call a spade a spade
1: to call a thing by its right name however coarse
2: to speak frankly 

2spade vb  spad-ed; spad-ing vt
(1647)
:to dig up or out or shape with or as if with a spade
~ vi: to use a spade
-- spad-er n 

3spade n
[It spada or Sp espada broad sword; both fr. L spatha, fr. Gk spathe^-
     blade]
(1598)
1a: a black figure that resembles a stylized spearhead on each playing
     card of one of the four suits; also: a card marked with this
     figure
1b pl but sing or pl in constr: the suit comprising cards marked with
     a spade
2: NEGRO -- usu. taken to be offensive
-- in spades: to an unusually great degree: in the extreme 
============
Concise Oxford Dictionary, 8th Ed., Copyright 1991 Oxford Univ. Press

/spade/1 <<speId>> n. & v. 

n. 
1. a tool used for digging or cutting the ground etc., with a sharp-edged
   metal blade and a long handle.
2. a tool of a similar shape for various purposes, e.g. for removing the
   blubber from a whale.
3. anything resembling a spade.

v.tr. dig over (ground) with a spade. 

"call a spade a spade" speak plainly or bluntly.

"spade beard" an oblong-shaped beard.

"spade foot" a square spadelike enlargement at the end of a chair-leg.

/spadeful/ n. (pl. /-fuls/). 

OE spadu, spada 

/spade/2 <<speId>> n. 
1. 
   a. a playing-card of a suit denoted by black inverted heart-shaped
      figures with small stalks.
   b. (in "pl.") this suit.
2. [sl.] [offens.] a Black.

"in spades" [sl.] to a high degree, with great force.

"spade guinea" [hist.] a guinea of George III's reign with a spade-shaped
shield on the reverse.

It. spade pl. of spada sword f. L spatha f. Gk spath&emac., rel. to
/spade/1: assoc. with the shape of a pointed spade 
============

WRONG!  This isn't worth arguing as I'm sure nobody belies it, not even you
John.



The trend:
There has been so much gangsta talk.  Either it's gangsta-moll, or gangsta
type.  I have seen post, after post from a few on the list, using this
reference.  And I and *SOME* others of color have begun to ask:

Who are they talking about?
What are they talking about?
What are they seeing that we're not?

I have noticed that the term is used primarily to denote those of
non-european ancestry (i.e. non-white for the sake of converstaion).  And
it is most often used to distinguish the real "loving" ravers, from those
who supposedly do not belong.  I guess it is coincidental that whenever
there is a greater presence of latino/chicano/hispanics or blacks/af. am.s
that this term is used more often.
Ok it's a coincidence, I am being oversensitive (why else would I be so
observant as to notice how/why/when it's used ) ;).
--------------------------------------------------------------------------

Well because of the input I've recieved from "gangstas" themselves, I and
it seems others thought that a "gangsta" was different from a gangster and
that "gangsta" didn't mena you had to be part of a gang just a hard tough-
guy/girl that dresses gangsterish and emits "hard" vibes.  And no John, it's
not just you and others of color who have begun to ask what they are talking
about we all did and I thought that I had it figured out with the above
definition.  And you haven't "noticed that the term is used primarily
to denote those of non-european ancestry" because it wasn't in the posts, 
your assuming it.


I have also noticed that the news always shows blacks and latinos getting
arrested when it comes to gang activity, or drugs (even though the
consumers are for the most part white; as well as the kingpins [bka US
Govt.]).  But I guess I should never believe the news, or even watch it.
It may sensitize me.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------

The news is skewed and racist because they focus on this stuff but blacks
and latinos do comprise most of the street gangs and that drug consumers
are mostly white is bull shit.  Especialy if you mean crack.  It was a 
popular un-fact for a while that white people were the primary crack 
consumers but then the facts came out.  As a generality, blacs deal and
consume crack, whites deal and consume powder and the laws are indeed
racist because there are harsher penalites for crack by weight.


On the other hand I have to ask: Why are these classifications being used,
in a community that prides itself on breaking down barriers?  Why classify,
and allow classification based upon appearance rather than deed?  Is the
concept of measuring a person by his/her deeds and character gone to the
wayside while appearance, once again has taken the forefront?  Is judging
by character now considered PC?
--------------------------------------------------------------------

I have been anoyed for quite a while when people start complaining about
classifications because although we should always no a person is deeper
than the outside shows, for the most part classifications are self-imposed.
When someone dresses like a raver they wanna be seen that way.
When someone dresses like a goth they wanna be seen that way.
When someone dresses like a hippy they wanna be seen that way.
When someone dresses like a gangsta they wanna be seen that way.

-Winston

Received: from localhost (dmi@localhost) by holonet.net (David M. Ilstrup)
	id NAA20699; Wed, 20 Apr 1994 13:35:11 -0700
Message-Id: <199404202035.NAA20699@holonet.net>
Subject: Race, Sex, Drugs, $$$, Scene
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Wed, 20 Apr 94 13:35:08 PDT
From: "David M. Ilstrup" <dmi@holonet.net>
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


Hi Kidz, so here's my $0.02 regarding this discussion of race, gangsta's etc.

Not every guy in a T-Shirt standing around with his arms crossed is a 'gangsta'.
Not every phunkily attired 'raver' is full of love and happiness.
Not every white guy with a shaved head is a skinhead nazi.
Not every 'goth' is full of gloom and wants to drink your blood.
Not every person in a biznis suit and tie wants nothing but money.
	-etc.-, but you know that already really...

Com'on people. If this scene is supposed to be about 'acceptance' then it is
going to take some work. Most of the 'scenes' I know about or take part in
are about identification. There is something that everyone has in common that
draws them in. Maybe this is obvious, but I feel it needs to be said because.

	Acceptance does not equal identification

Some scenes are mixed racially, like many Jazz clubs.
Some scenes are mixed economically, like many bars in the City.
Some scenes are very polarized by race and age, like parts of the punk scene.

The point is that the demographics vary wildly, but each social environment
has a focal point (maybe a fuzzy one) of interest. Please call me on it if
I'm wrong, but raving to me as it stands is just a psychedelic dance party,
with a few extra flavors thrown in. Don't get me wrong, I *love* psychedelic
dance parties, that's why I go. And like any party, it can go off or it can 
sputter and die. But if you keep the definition at that, then you leave room 
for everyone that seems to show up. Then it is OK to, trance out, just dance,
check people out, flirt, stand around, listen to music, trip on the visuals,
dose, etc.

More than a few female friends have commented that these guys standing around
with their arms crossed are a real turn on. Do you think you are going to get
someone to stop doing something that works for them to attract people?

People are at these parties for different reasons, and if acceptance really
is the emphasis, then everyone is going to have to live with the increased
friction that can happen when people are misreading each other's signals.

For instance, if you are spiffily attired in layers of too nifty clothing and
are well rested and dosed and beaming, you are going to feel prickly to someone
that could barely afford the door and is burnt anyways from working all day at
some shit job. I'm not saying people *must* modify their behavior in 
consideration of this fact, but it would be *kind* to do so. For example, I and
some friends who are probably reading this were at U.Groove and having, uh,
nutritional supplements in a very indiscrete fashion and the kids at the booth
next to us were pissed and threw the stuff on their table on the floor to
'express' their anger. Stupid but not unexpected and not the end of the world. 
We could have been more discrete. Maybe I'm just projecting, but that's where
I was and how I felt when I was just getting started in the Bay Area.

Anyway, I could keep babbling but let me just say that I don't think there
is anything wrong with this scene. It has alot more variety in terms of
music and people than just about anything else around.

-Dave

>The news is skewed and racist because they focus on this stuff but blacks

drugs in the U.S. in a proportional way (something like per capita) that
the result s would be different than we all think.??

>  Especialy if you mean crack.  It was a
>popular un-fact for a while that white people were the primary crack

>consume crack, whites deal and consume powder and the laws are indeed
>racist because there are harsher penalites for crack by weight.
At my high school my janitor was dealing crack (not to students) and got
busted, I got busted also because someone had narced on me for getting dope
from him.  If I would've gotten busted for the acid I had at the time I
probably would've gotten off light becuase I was only 17.8 yrs old.  A
couple of more months and I might've faced going to jail for ten years!!
My janitor is out on probation and only faced a max of 15 yrs in prison.
Years were added because he had sold crack on a school campus to officers
who had come onto campus...this is quite skewed if you ask me.

Here are comments that I had threatened to put in and was actually
requested.  Just some questions I had thought of and comments, I thought it
was subpar article .  My comments are in parentheses.


>         Along a deserted strecth of highway north of Santa Cruz, Ca., and a
>few miles south of the San Andreas fault, the shoulder of the road suddenly
>turns into a parking lot, with 600 cars jammed tightly on either side.  Three
>police officers frantically write tickets.  "What's going on here tonight?"
>one of them asks a group of people getting out of a truck.  They give a vague
>answer and hurry across the asphalt, disappearing over the bluff toward the
>distant heartbeat of a sound system.  The Southern Pacific coastal railway
>runs along the west side of the highway.  Acoross the tracks, a ridge descends
>to an exquisite beach secluded within a cove, a setting so pristine it would
>suit a travel brochure.  Roughly 2,000 people are gathered, dancing in the
>sand, sitting around fires or walking along the surf.  Some have pitched
>tents, and a circle of men sit on the ground with drums, pounding a rhythmic
>counterpoint to the throb from the speakersand the random hiss of a nitrous
>oxide tank.  The ocean carries the palpable buzz of psychedelics

 (what is the' palpable' buzz of psychedelics? something I've never heard
of before).

Some people pass joints, and a few hold bottles wrapped in brown paper.
The tribal scene would remind a baby boomer of Woodstock.

 (another stupid association with the past, I have much respect for past
movements and such but why do we always have to be equated to something in
the past)

>        Threre's no bandstand tonight; instead, dancers press up around two
>turntables on a stand planted in the middle of the beach.  The makeshift DJ
>booth is lit by a portable generator that also fuels two massive speaker
>stacks decorated with columns of balloons.  DJ Garth, one of the stars of the
>bay Area rave scene,

(one of the stars? maybe this is from Nevada :) I'm going out with a girl
from Carson City and her friends call any 'ravers', 'ravestars', this kind
of threw me off!)

 has just pulled Tranquility Bass' "Cantamilla" into a pulsating,
meditative mix of techno and
house.

(what is a mix of meditative TECHNO and HOUSE? does this happen often at
the Full Moon?)
I've never heard it? sorry if I'm being to sarcastic here :))

 The record booms against the cliffs, which form a natural echo chamber,
and the full moon glows over the ocean, bathing the landscape in dim blue
light.
>        Tonight's crowd is an even blend of college kids, club poeple, Santa
>Cruz hippies and ravers.

(labels that don't need to be worried about in my opinion)

 Predominantly white, but also Asian, Latin and black, they've come from
all over Northern California and as far away as Los Angeles and San Diego.
Assembled without promotion except for word of mouth spread earlier this
evening, they are here for the free party that in the last two years has
become a Bay Area Ritual: the Full Moon Massive rave.  The trunout is
especially large because the full moon is rising on a Friday night and the
weather is fine.
>        Over the last few months, 20 year-old Shawn O'Docaharty, a
>pierced-and-tatooed >student at Cabrillo College, near Santa Cruz, has become
>a regular at Full Moon.  At a perch high on the enbankment, he sits, enjoying
>the view of the beach and the crisp air off of the >water.  "It's the best
>rave in Northern California," he says.  "The cops can't do anything, because
>it's a private beach, and ther's too many people here for them to break it up.
>A $20 >parking ticket split between a car of four or five people is still a
>bargain for most ravers.  >They'd pay $20 each somewhere else."

(I wouldn't pay $20 dollars for a rave that's cold, starts late and now
doesn't have enough sound to reach past the people dancing?!)

>        At 6am, the moon still hangs in the sky, and the first rays of morning
>illuminate the >terra-cota and purple layers of the cliffs.

(I don't ever remember the cliffs being all that spectacular where have I
been :))

> Nearly 500 people remain, dancing or sharing blankets around fires.  "The
>last party lasted >until 4 in the afternoon," says O'Docharty.  "By that time,
>things get pretty communal: 'I've >got food food, you've got water, he's got a
>bowl.'  There's kind of a family value to it."

(Why doesn't this happen earlier Shawn?  Do we need to wait until we have
something that we can barter with until we become communal?  If anyone on
this list ever experienced QMart (free water donuts and rolls at the FM's
last summer) I hope you know what I'm talking about!)

I really have enjoyed the FM's I've been to but at the last one when I
measured 1.2 miles of cars along Highway 1 alone I knew that things were a
little out of hand (that doesn't include Bonnie Doon Road).  The FM's I
first went to were more intimate and special.  I personally think that
there shouldn't be a "Full Moon" that is always by Wicked people.  Liquid
Air was a Full Moon Rave in my opinion more people should be willing to
throw other Full moon's and not feel obligated to go THEE Full Moon.  When
the feeling of intimacy was lost for me some of the magic definitely went
with it.  To find people you know you shouldn't have to go to the Lost and
Found booth :)

Look for some other Full Moon's this summer, I'll try to throw one!

The Cloud Factory

From sfraves-owner  Wed Apr 20 16:33:26 1994

Received: from mailgate.prod.aol.net by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA20353; Wed, 20 Apr 94 16:33:17 PDT

	(1.37.109.4/16.2) id AA09713; Wed, 20 Apr 94 19:30:50 -0400
From: robertj308@aol.com
X-Mailer: America Online Mailer
Message-Id: <9404201930.tn96048@aol.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Wed, 20 Apr 94 19:30:24 EDT
Subject: The Grey Gangsta or Flame Follies (long)
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Well, Bob was able to "bald" to avoid the slings and arrows of outrageous PC
persecution. However, what  can this grey-haired gangsta do? Oh well, I'm in
such a minority here that no one even wants  or bothers to flame me. I'm
offended that when I reviewed by Organic party at Little Caesar's a while
back, and felt fearful of the "gangsta crowd," and that I got more "what are
you doing here vibes"  there than at any other party I've been to, nobody
scorched me in the slightest. Should I feel discriminated against by this
group? Or simply venerated? Just asking?

Another perspective here, from the philosopher Wittenstein said that the mind
thinks by making distinctions; from seeing differences(black,white, hispanic,
gangsta) by seeing "what is, by what is not." i.e., you can't see a ball
unless you see everything that is not ball.  In the case of "seeing"
differences in race, the mind will do that automatically. The danger is in
the thinking, or the meaning we attach to those differences; good, bad, etc.
Further, The problem is that the mind will also attach pre-conceived, or
previous meaning to the same or like circumstances; the "pre-judiced" or
prejudgements based on earlier-similiar experience. The trick is to live in
the moment, and not in the past, or prejudice. It is not far flung for John
to have attached negative, or fearful associations to the "gangsta-look."
However, where we diminish people, or discrimiate against people, is when we
attach prejudice to all people, and are not responsible for our
pre-judgements. We also diminish ourselves in the sense that we do not allow
people to be more than we think they are. Lastly, I try to remember
Augustine's admonition: " Hate the Sin. but Love the Sinner." In this case,
we may hate gangs, violence, etc. but our only hope is to come from love
regarding people. In particular, I began studying martial arts, so as not to
live in fear of many of the gangsta kids I teach, so I can keep my heart
open. But, I'm not perfect, I wouldn't come to rave with my friend for over a
year, because I "knew" I hated electronic   music. It ain't easy keeping your
mind open (in the present) when you're young, and it's harder when you're
old. However, you may discover that in a flame-war, both sides are probably
wrong, because neither side is on the side of love. 

 From a politically grey-haired incorrect minority of one.   
Robertj.........MRP
