>C'mon people let's face it.  As much as many would HATE to admit it, CA is
>as racist as racist can be.  The Bay Area is certainly no exception to this
>rule.  And CA in general is pretty bad.
>-------------------------------------------------------------------------
>
>WRONG!  This isn't worth arguing as I'm sure nobody belies it, not even you
>John.


Double wrong on you sir.  Things in CA, in general, are no better, and
offten times WORSE than the South (I am from the south, have people there,
and visit there often enough, and am black enough to know <- sorry but RACE
has everything to do with the type and strength of discrimination you get
from society.  Observing is fine; living it is a different matter).  Rodney
King did not happen in the South for example.  In any case the type of
discrimination here is very subtle.  People here smile in your face, then
stick it in when you're turned.  There are hella codewords here like: "Bad
area", "High crime", etc.  Everyone knows what's meant when they are said.
In the South, and the Northeast, things are much more honest and open.  You
know somebody donesn't like you it's hardly hidden.  CA is much more
covert,  but just as bad.
>
>
>
>The trend:
>There has been so much gangsta talk.  Either it's gangsta-moll, or gangsta
>type.  I have seen post, after post from a few on the list, using this
>reference.  And I and *SOME* others of color have begun to ask:
>
>Who are they talking about?
>What are they talking about?
>What are they seeing that we're not?
>
>I have noticed that the term is used primarily to denote those of
>non-european ancestry (i.e. non-white for the sake of converstaion).  And
>it is most often used to distinguish the real "loving" ravers, from those
>who supposedly do not belong.  I guess it is coincidental that whenever
>there is a greater presence of latino/chicano/hispanics or blacks/af. am.s
>that this term is used more often.
>Ok it's a coincidence, I am being oversensitive (why else would I be so
>observant as to notice how/why/when it's used ) ;).
>--------------------------------------------------------------------------
>
>Well because of the input I've recieved from "gangstas" themselves, I and
>it seems others thought that a "gangsta" was different from a gangster and
>that "gangsta" didn't mena you had to be part of a gang just a hard tough-
>guy/girl that dresses gangsterish and emits "hard" vibes.  And no John, it's
>not just you and others of color who have begun to ask what they are talking
>about we all did and I thought that I had it figured out with the above
>definition.  And you haven't "noticed that the term is used primarily
>to denote those of non-european ancestry" because it wasn't in the posts,
>your assuming it.

Let's just say this:  I know what parties people attend, and I know when
the term is used.  It may be coincidental that for the parties where things
are a bit less "colorful" the term is hardly used.  But when we start to
get that brown goin, it is a different matter.  Comments on BASICS are
classic examples.  Yeah, the party for the most part escaped the gangsta
comment when there was a majority white.  But when you started to get the
influx of the brown, who at times, danced in the huge cirlces, the comments
started to pour out.  It was not as if the "style" of clothes had all of a
sudden change (I've seen plenty of people from Concord wearing gangsta
style, if I may call it that), it was that the parties constituents had
changed.  I have noticed this trend in regards to reviews given.  That's
all I'm saying.  The wonderfully perverse thing about codewords is that
they can be said with relative impunity.  Impunity until the person who
it's targeted at notices the transgression.

>
>
>I have also noticed that the news always shows blacks and latinos getting
>arrested when it comes to gang activity, or drugs (even though the
>consumers are for the most part white; as well as the kingpins [bka US
>Govt.]).  But I guess I should never believe the news, or even watch it.
>It may sensitize me.
>--------------------------------------------------------------------------
>
>The news is skewed and racist because they focus on this stuff but blacks
>and latinos do comprise most of the street gangs and that drug consumers
>are mostly white is bull shit.


I see that YOU may have been watching too much news, and you need to take a
look at the HVP (Hayes Valley Projects), or PoHill (Potrero Hill).  I see
more whites venturing in that area than I do see blacks.  You do see the
crackheads outside with their shriveled bodies.  But what you fail to
notice is the stream of cars that pour through these areas for purchases.
The FACT is the projects do not have the economic resources to keep crack
flowing, so there must be another source outside of the community that is
the main supply line for not only the money but the drugs.  As for crack
usage, yes, it does tend to concentrate itslef in lower-socioeconomic rungs
(hows that for a codeword).  But cocaine is still flowing freely, in it's
powdered state, all over middle/uppermiddle/upper class white
neighborhoods.  The stats from the DEA, ATF, & CIA do bear me out on this
one.

>Especialy if you mean crack.

crack==coke+baking soda

I mean coke.

>It was a
>popular un-fact for a while that white people were the primary crack
>consumers but then the facts came out.

They do consume the majority of cocoaine in this country.  Crack is just a
small component of sales.  And if you wanna see strung out, I would still
have to say that there are more whites on crack than blacks/others.  It's
just that they tend to have the support mechanisms avaialbe to get help,
and thus make the problem seem less than it is.  I can give you some stats
if you wish.


>As a generality, blacs deal and
>consume crack, whites deal and consume powder and the laws are indeed
>racist because there are harsher penalites for crack by weight.
>

Another stereotype...give me stats, and where you got this information.
For a quick look, go to lower haight at about 3-4 in the morning.  Amongst
the black crack dealers you will see PLENTY of whites getting that rock.
Skinny women getting out of brand new Samurai's in one of the toughest
parts of SF, all to get that rock.  And just look in the rehab programs.
It sure as fuck ain't filled with black folks.  And I would say the
majority of them sure as hell ain't on the horse either.

>
>On the other hand I have to ask: Why are these classifications being used,
>in a community that prides itself on breaking down barriers?  Why classify,
>and allow classification based upon appearance rather than deed?  Is the
>concept of measuring a person by his/her deeds and character gone to the
>wayside while appearance, once again has taken the forefront?  Is judging
>by character now considered PC?
>--------------------------------------------------------------------
>
>I have been anoyed for quite a while when people start complaining about
>classifications because although we should always no a person is deeper
>than the outside shows, for the most part classifications are self-imposed.
>When someone dresses like a raver they wanna be seen that way.
>When someone dresses like a goth they wanna be seen that way.
>When someone dresses like a hippy they wanna be seen that way.
>When someone dresses like a gangsta they wanna be seen that way.
>
>-Winston


I get annoyed at insensitivity.  And the oversimplification of
classifications belies a real problem with communication.  Blacks/Af. Am.'s
surely did not classify themselves as Nigra's/Niggers/Colored.  Please
Winston...a little historical perpective on American History surely taught
you better...

In any case,
John

I really don't know about you all, but i am uncomfortable at events that are 
ultra white or ultra homogenous. I have been in a very mixed element all of
my life, and I really get a nervous feeling if I happen to find myself at these
subtly segregated events - if this whole scene, movement, whatever you want to
call it is supposed to be a diversion from the ugliness of what's really out
there, the fact that there aren't many events that have a peaceful and positive
balance of people is a real commentary.

Comments? This is very interesting to me.

upcoming for Good Housekeeping. I have something neat to share with you.

Tamara

Perhaps this would be a good time to mention that there is a new list set up
for the discussion of gangs...

gangtm-request@dhvx20.csudh.edu

The list owner is a very well intentioned prof from Cal State Dominguez Hills,
and he envisions this list as someday being a link for high school kids or
younger with gang or former gang members. It sounds lofty, and without a lot
of money and manna from heaven, it probably won't happen. I am trying to get
UCLA faculty interested to at least propel the discussion into more than
the direction in which it is headed right now, namely a bunch of people who
don't seem to know much about gangs and just have bad things to say. I don't
know much myself beyond 
a few books that I have read and I just think that more people with more resources need to be a part of the discussion.  I dunno...

I am sorry this isn't rave related and I am perpetuating non rave threads
on the list. SO...if anyone has got a copy of the record by The Mephisto
Odyssey (Jon, didn't you say you had an extra copy???), PLEASE mail me...!!!



It's on Orpheus Records outta The City.

From: rox@netcom.com (Roxanna Stieber)

It does seem like the parties have gotten alot more homogenous and
younger than they used to be. At the earlier Toontowns there was a mix
of all ages from teens to 70's, outrageously dressed transvestites,
gays, Af/Americans, asians, hippies, computer geeks, suburbanites,
goths and some punk dressed types. I prefer to be in a mix like this,
cuz there's so much energy. Also I didn't mind the people dancing in
circles at the Basics at the Armory. I enjoyed seeing people having fun.
One of the reasons I started partying in The City even though I lived 
in Santa Cruz at the time is because I liked the diversity of the people
at the various parties/clubs/etc. I also liked the diversity of the
music available here. I like to dance to more than house or techno at
times. I like reggae/dancehall/dub, Industrial body music, and the more 
melodic hip-hop as opposed to "gansta". I really wouldn't mind that style 
either if it weren't so misogynistic and racist. I too am uncomfortable
at events that are too "white bread" because I don't feel like I fit in.

Rox 

---------------------------------------------------------------------------
I really don't know about you all, but i am uncomfortable at events that are 
ultra white or ultra homogenous. I have been in a very mixed element all of
my life, and I really get a nervous feeling if I happen to find myself at these
subtly segregated events - if this whole scene, movement, whatever you want to
call it is supposed to be a diversion from the ugliness of what's really out
there, the fact that there aren't many events that have a peaceful and positive
balance of people is a real commentary.

Tamara

Ok, fellow keyboard tappers,

here's a simple and easy experiment you can all do:  in the next month or so
if you happen to be watching bay area TV news or "world" news or commercials 
on channels 2,4,5, or
7 and they are doing a report on the "war against drugs" or a commercial type
"keep our children from drugs" or a commercial or news story on violent
crime look closely at the race of the actors who play the drug pushers and
even the actors who play the drug addicts in the anti-drug commercials or
in the videos of convicts.  Not of specific convicts, just when they show
a video clipping to go along with a report on generalized violent crime.
You may learn something, if you haven't noticed it already.  It's pretty
fascinating.

Space

From sfraves-owner  Thu Apr 21 09:52:17 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA04764; Thu, 21 Apr 94 09:52:17 PDT
Received: from mailgate.prod.aol.net by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA04757; Thu, 21 Apr 94 09:52:11 PDT
Received: by mailgate.prod.aol.net
	(1.37.109.4/16.2) id AA23591; Thu, 21 Apr 94 12:49:40 -0400
From: mauzi@aol.com
X-Mailer: America Online Mailer
Message-Id: <9404211249.tn08851@aol.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Thu, 21 Apr 94 12:49:09 EDT
Subject: Matthew Fox's 'Rave in the Nave'
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

To:  SFRaves
From:  Cliff

Greetings!

Pardon my breach of protocol for posting so early after I joined the mailing
list, but I may have something to offer to a discussion I understand is
underway among many subscribers. The topic is Matthew Fox and the Chronicle
and San Jose Mercury-News articles of April 15.

I work with Matthew Fox, currently as director of new projects for his
non-profit organization.  I have been working with him for more than a year,
helping to develop new ways of getting his work into the culture.  I traveled
with him to England in November to visit the community that inspired his
decision to show solidarity with young people who are using technology to
reinvent ritual.  He ended his latest book, The Reinvention of Work, with a
section on ritual, saying that ritual is the new work of our species, that it
is the shortcut to awaken the energy we desperately need to reinvent the
ageist, patriarchal, human-centered, consumption-addicted culture that is
effectively destroying the life systems of the earth.

Matt was so moved by both the English community and their "rave mass" that he
returned to teach the group for three weeks.  He said someone there told him,
"We are the first generation to understand your work."  As someone under 30
myself, I think they are absolutely right.

We'll understand Matt's work because we're the first postmodern generation. 
We operate in a new frame of mind understood by only a few people who were
radical in the 60s.  We know that the modern ways of doing government,
economics, education, religion and business have proven to be manifest
failures in the face of ecological crisis.  While global fisheries are fished
to extinction, frogs disappear worldwide, and agri-business washes away the
remaining topsoil, government has prostituted itself to lobbyists, business
continues its agenda of promoting increasing consumption of diminishing
nonrenewable resouces, and the pope says it's a sin to masturbate.  It's time
somebody woke up around here, and it looks like it's going to have to be us.

Doing things in a postmodern way demands a choice.  Postmodernism can lead
either to deconstruction or to restructuring.  Choose deconstruction, and you
might as well check out, there's no reason to live.  Choose restructuring,
and you've got hope.  In this mindset, you realize that your reality is what
you choose it to be.  So, you look at what's out there, pick what you choose
to go along with, and move on.

That's where Matt's work in creation spirituality comes in.  To make choices,
you've got to have some sort of spiritual grounding.  Which spirituality do
you choose?  Certainly not what most churches have to offer now.  They're
stuck in a theology called theism - the idea of god as some bearded white man
in the sky.  This thinking says that god is outside you, and you are
originally sinful and cursed, so you have to go to some man-made institution
to make it to a puffy cloud with your name on it. That's the bad news.  But,
Matt says, the good news is that you don't have to buy that crap.  That's not
the only way of looking at things.  Matt proves that there's an even older
way of looking at things - called panentheism.  This says that god is in all
things, and all things are in god.  Since god is within you, you must be
originally blessed.  So, things start with praise for creation, for the
fireball that exploded 16 billion years ago and gave birth to the photons
that are in every cell of your body and your computer. This mindset is
praise-based, not guilt-based.  It's about reclaiming your own responsibility
to get a spiritual life, about expressing yourself through your creativity,
about paying back the gift of life you have been given by doing something for
the people and the environment around you.  

Unlike "all is light" New Age, though, this tradition recognizes pain, the
pain of letting go, the death that gives way to new life, the bottoming out
that hollows the soul and allows it to hold more life.  Unlike those who use
drugs and mushrooms to reach a mystical state, this tradition uses
non-chemical ways of getting high and celebrating beauty, including
electronic ritual, art and making love within committed relationship.  This
tradition helps to put things in perspective, requiring those who have
discovered mysticism to pour their new energy into healing the hurting people
and planet around them.  It's about engaging and interfering directly in the
culture, not opting out into some cynical, self-pitying stupor.  It's about
the evolution of the culture, not the enlightenment of the individual.  It's
about learning more about science to find out more about god, not allowing
science to be used to kill more people or sell more things.  It's about the
living organism of base communities, not the cold isolation of nuclear
family. It's about clearing the way so the Cosmic Christ can emanate from
within each person and meet itself in its fullness.

The great thing about this whole schtick is that it's been around a long
time.  Matt didn't invent it; he's just teaching what was taught by Hildegard
of Bingen, Meister Eckhart, Nicholas of Cusa, Julian of Norwich, Rainer Maria
Rilke, Abraham Heschel, Gregory Bateson, Albert Einstein, and the Celts and
the aboriginal peoples.

Matt's written 15 books in case you want to read more about it.  There's an
article on-line from last year in Mercury Center.  He did a dialogue Tuesday
night with scientist Brian Swimme at Herbst Theater, and will speak at Grace
Cathedral at 11 a.m. April 24.  He's working on two books with British
biologist Rupert Sheldrake (author of a hot new book in England called
something like "Seven Experiments You Can Do At Home to Disprove the
Scientific Establishment.")

If you would like any more information about what Matt's doing, or would like
to pass on a message to him, please let me know.  He says he would like to
know more about the work you're doing and would love to be invited to a San
Francisco rave...

keep in touch
cliff

Not flaming, just curious:

> I feel _really_ weird when sometimes I go to an event and notice there
> are few, if any, black people. 

Is that not simply another form of discrimination (ie realizing that 
there are not "enough"--what constitutes "enough"--people who look a 
certain way, and wishing there were more because, since all people who 
look like that act basically the same, they will add another dimension 
to this party)?  Again, not flaming.  That is just how I interpreted the 
excerpted statement above.

> This happens a lot at YSH, and I've often wondered why. I have seen 
> many other non-caucasians there, but black seem to be particularily 
> under-represented. 

Under-represented?  I am confused again.  I thought the point of clubbing 
is to go out and dance.  Representation implies a common interest or 
ideology in an attempt to achieve certain goals.  Applying the term 
"representation" to people trying to have fun seems to be bringing all 
of these people in question down to some basic stereotype...which is 
racism, IMHO.

*Again*, not flaming.  Sean, if I'm wrong, can you clarify?

Sami

one of the biggest discussions amongst ecumenical groups of all the
  various christian religions is whether jesus actually said he was
    the son of god.  actually, there still is no single statement
      attributable to him in which he made that assertion.  he did
        refer to the "son of man" on several occasions, but it is
          possible that the original translation from hebrew to greek
            somehow munged that statement. 
  yerz truly is NOT a religious scholar, but i do have a passing interest
    in christianity...

  furthermore, any supposed religious "scholar" you may see on TV or 
    whatever who doesn't read hebrew isn't worth his weight in
      communion crackers...

Cc: mauzi@aol.com

Hi Cliff and Welcome!

It's nice to get some of these ideas nearly straight from the source,
however, as I think you'll soon notice, your entre will most likely
generate a flurry (to say the least) of empassioned and very pointed
discussion so let's get Matt on-line with us and get right down to it.  :)

In general, I have few problems with Matt's schtick as you present it. I
must however take issue with at least two points.

  o Christ on the Cross has little if no meaning to anyone I know. Rather,
    it seems a growingly inappropriate anachronism heavily burdened with
    2000 years of questionable cultural/mythological baggage. I shudder to
    think at the volumes of blood let in Christ's name. As a myth *or as a
    factual event* it has simply outlived it's usefulness if, in fact, it
    ever had any. So Cosmic Christ still puts me off.

  o I was more than a little dismayed at your barely masked contention
    that "use of drugs or mushrooms to reach a mystical state" implies 
    "opting out into some cynical, self-pitying stupor," especially given
    that you cite aboriginal (indigenous?) peoples as one of his/your
    models, many of whom have/had shamanic traditions of which naturally
    occurring plant psychoactives are an integral part. 

    God and the cumulative psychic manifestations of life may easily be
    present in dimensions reachable by a simple chemical. Organisms are,
    after all, not only spiritual beings, but also bio*chemical* systems.
    Why then this chemical alienation? Does it make it too easy? Does one
    have to be *worthy* of god (like we've been hearing for 10000 years?)
    I sure hope not. 
   
    People find god in their own way. The conscious use of psychoactives
    towards these or other like goals is an entirely valid and historically
    verified approach. 

    However I would go further and add that a truly recreational,
    psychoactive induced reality shift *for it's own sake*: fun
    is something I think everyone on this planet could use. That this is
    available with relatively low overhead in terms of dogma or ideology 
    is a proverbial *good thing*.

Let The Good Times Roll!

peace always, and please forward this to Matt.

take it easy
ethan


                                _______ 
 ethan miller                     nrg                            pgp me   
_________________________ 'one unbroken whole' _________________________   
                         
                (: positive energy can save the world :)
               __________________________________________

  I notice that you all seem to comment on the 'race' of the people in
the drug comercials.  I think being aware of this 'programming' is
good, and I encorage you to keep your eyes open.

  I don't watch TV at all, so I don't know for sure, but I wonder
about the gender.  I'll bet you the 'criminal' vendor is depicted as
male, and the 'victim' consumer as female or a child.  Just my
(sexist?) guess.  It is also different from my personal experience.

  For a while, I used to hang out near a particular corner just west
of down town LA.  At that corner, a lot of crack was bought, sold, and
used.

  The folks I met who used crack (and who seemed to live on the
street) left me with the impresion that the consumers were about 75%
men, but formed a fairly representative sample of 'races'.  (I expect
that living on the street biases the sample towards men, but I don't
know for sure.)

  My impression was that the vendors were about 75% male, but I didn't
run around with a clip board counting heads, and asking to see
genitillia.  (Although that kind of crack was also available at this
particular street corner, with female vendors predominating.)  The
vendors were (almost 100%) 'chicano'.  Actually they were all 18th
st. gang members near as I could tell.  I suspect that the gang was
racist. (Goodnews though, I hear that trend is passing away here in
LA.  Most gangs are (voluntarily -- no government mandate!)
integrating.)

  ObRave: The house at that corner was lived in by many ravers, and
rave organizers.  Infact, the guy who introduced me to raving lived
there.  It was a really cool, funky, victorian house (much rarer in LA
than SF), and had some really nice spaces inside.

j'

Let's just say this:  I doubt that anyone on this list or even in this scene is
"racist".  I doubt that they anyone gets uncomfortable when there are too many
black or any other type of people at a party, John.  I do think that when there
are people at a party who dress "gansta" and give hard looks it makes people 
nervous and wonder why people like that would come to a party and this thought
may be in part due to ignorance but you can't realy blame people when there 
have been incidences of "gangstas" being violent at parties or elsewhere, a
stereotype yes but self preservation has a way of causing that.  If you were
swiming in the ocean and you saw a shark it would be considered wise to get
out of the water.  Yet, we all know that there are very few man-eating varieties
and of those they rarely attack.  But, we all know that this situation has as
much a probability of becomng an attack as any other and the fact that it could
be you is all you need to know and nobody can realy blame you for being affraid.
Besides, a lot of the complaint is that these people stand around not dancing
and detracting from the vibe just like the occaisional gawking suits or suave
"hey baby" don Juans.  I'm sure you have a keen eye for racism John, but somtimes
I think you might be miss-analysing some situations and I'd caution you to try to
consider other possibilities or reasons for things instead of always assuming
everybody is a racist.

I realy don't have the time, energy, or inclination to go into it, Tanya
wore me out on this a couple months ago ;-) but seriously, I find that
christians realy beleive strongly with there heart and can answer any
point I make with a biblical answer that they believe to be accurate,
even when were arguing about the legitamacy of the bible itself!  But,
let me assure you I'm not just some "heathen" who know not what he speaks,
I'm a "heathen" that does know what he speaks |-) I was raised going to
church, reading the bible, and even went to church school in 7th grade.

Just for a taste though, how did you know that Moses was raised under the
Tamarian (Tamaria - ancient north-African name for Egypt) Education
System, living in the pharoa's palace and all and was given an extensive
education about this religion/belief system.  Funny then, how the ten
comandments were a subset of the 40 commandments of the Tamarian system,
word for word, yet he said Jehova (who didn't exist before this) gave them
to him on the mountain top.  It is also true that this Tamarian system may
be as old as 10,000 years B.C., before there were any Hebrew or Jewish
people as a race, but oops I forgot the common theological view is that
the earth and human race is younger than 10,000 years B.C.  There are
also some other direct pleagerisms in Moses' books of the bible from
well known scholars and leaders of Moses' history books.  The whole
christian spiel, including the concept of heaven and hell, the judgement
of the soul, the virgin birth are all taken from the Tamarian system, that
predates christianity, and is common folklore in other cultures.

Or how about the story of Sodom and Gamora?  God destroys it because it's 
evil and the whole town "turned" gay!  Except for Lot and his family who
happend to be the only straits in town.  So they were warned to leave,
left, Lots wife looks back after being told not to, turns into pillar of
salt.  That night in order to re-populate, Lots daughters get him drunk 
and screw him (sheesh this is gettin like a soap opera).  Moral of the
story:  Homosexuality bad, incest O.K.?

Though shal not kill - fist commandment
Suffer not a witch to live - text in Leviticus 

David, one of the godliest biblical men, infact a favorite of god,
also one of the most warlike, some also say homosexual.

Most of you, unless your a seventh day baptist, seventh day adventist, branch
davidian, Jewish, or a few others, don't even go to church on the day god 
supposedly told you to with the commandment that says 6 days shall though
labour but rest and worship on the seventh day.  The calendar starts with
Sunday as the first day and Saturday is the 7th.  The church changed this to
convert the sun (sunday) worshiping pagans.  Why would god care?  I 
don't know but "He" supposedly made it a commandment and why would god want
religious dogma and to be worshiped.  I feel intelectualy superior at my level
to not want beings to gravel and worship me if I could create them.

Noah was actualy able to build a boat big enough and house two of every species
of every earth animal and the whold world flooded despite no archeological
evidence of such a cotastrophe.  Amazing!

Political parable of the swine taken by christians as a case of demon expulsion
when it was a political alegory about Roman occupation.

Multiple differing accounts of the last days of christ by his disciples, 
including whold conversations and his last words.  (The) church still trying
to sort it out.

Most or all of the saints and miracle stories are Anthro-cataloged folk stories,
often lifted from pagan god or goddesses, look 'em up yourself.  Same with all
the holidays and there symbolisms.  Easter (Eostra, a saxon goddes of the dawn,
associated with springtime), Christmas tree - pagan christmas evergreen, easter
eggs, young chicks, bunnies -  common pagan symbols of fertility and life,
St. Johns day - Summer solstice,  St. Valentine's day - pagan fertility and lovers
holiday roots,  Christmas - close to winter solstice for a reason, etc.


and the list goes on...

but I find it particularly enlighening to trace the roots of the cristian 
belief system to find that it like other CULTURAL phenomena borrows heavily
from other system even when it claims to be origional or the first.  There's
nothin new under the sun.

Sami Khoury writes:
 > Not flaming, just curious:
 >

 > > are few, if any, black people. 
 > 
 > Is that not simply another form of discrimination (ie realizing that 
 > there are not "enough"--what constitutes "enough"--people who look a 

Of course I don't think there should be a quota. It just makes me
wonder what the cultural differences are when a race that represents a
substantial part of the population is hardly evident at a gathering.

*RANT ON*

[This is not directed at you Sami, it just needs to be said.]

I don't discriminate. For that matter, I was savagely ostracized
growing up in W.Va and Ky for NOT discriminating, for not being
prejudiced, for not being misogynist, and for criticizing those who
perpetuate hate and belittlement of other people.  I've spent most of
my adult life trying to fix that damage, and it really bothers me when
someone suggests I am being prejudiced. I have worked too hard and
paid too high a price for my ideals to have to put up with that.

And to those who are victims of discrimination: Don't hate. Don't find
the least excuse to scream "Racism!" and accuse and spread more hate. 
I have no sympathy for people who do that, because they are *just* as
bad as those they accuse. You want to save the world? Stop the cycle
of hate.

The bottom line is, I'm not going to be PC for anybody. If you're
going to be offended, then be offended. It's your energy you're
wasting; I won't let you waste mine. Everything I say will offend
someone. I can either follow everybody's instructions on what to say,
or nobody's. I can't follow everybody's.

*RANT OFF*

Sean

Mark Guthrie sez:

> Most or all of the saints and miracle stories are Anthro-cataloged folk stories,
> often lifted from pagan god or goddesses, look 'em up yourself.  Same with all
> the holidays and there symbolisms.  Easter (Eostra, a saxon goddes of the dawn,
> associated with springtime), Christmas tree - pagan christmas evergreen, easter
> eggs, young chicks, bunnies -  common pagan symbols of fertility and life,
> St. Johns day - Summer solstice,  St. Valentine's day - pagan fertility and lovers
> holiday roots,  Christmas - close to winter solstice for a reason, etc.

This is the part of all of this Fox stuff that worries me.  Christians
have an extensive history of going into another culture adopting their 
symbols changing, diluting, or completely dissolving the original meaning
while they say "look, we're with you".  Easter Eggs, a symbol of fertility
have nothing to do with the resurection of Christ.  And (what is now
called) the Christmas Wreath has again nothing to do with Christ but
was displayed during Winter Solstice to welcome the sun back from its
rest.  So now we've got this Fox guy coming into the rave world and saying,
"look, I'm with you".  I won't buy it.  I wish he'd just go away.


Take care,

he engaged in cultural appropriation, or is it the other way round?

chompin Greeks.  Bacchus, a pale drunken caricature of the entrancing

To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU (SFRaves)
Date: Thu, 21 Apr 94 15:53:46 PDT
Cc: sfraves-calendar@techno.Stanford.EDU (SFR Calendar)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL0]
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU



The Organic Golden Gate Park party last weekend was quite nice,
good turnout from SFR and the rest of the scene.  I also had
a chance to check out the tail end of Dig that night - it
turned out to be more rap-oriented, with Mark Farina, Dani
and Charlotte tag-teaming - pretty good stuff overall.  Last
Thursday, I also caught Mark Farina and Dani at Flower (@ Deco),
nice space with a mellow crowd of mostly old-skoolers.  This week,
I might check out Wicked, the Launch Pad party, Mushroom Jazz or
Pepper, Together, and/or Light-n Up.  See ya there! :)


-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

        415.512.5713

Friday, April 22nd - Free Boat Party   415.765.7666

        (next to Thunder Bay) ---  daytime

        This Is Acid Jazz record release & giveaway what not
        Djs Is  Kevin  Thomas  Bob  and special guest Greyboy
        1190 Folsom St, SF.  10pm-4am.  21+  415.905.8811

        Spun  Jeno  Garth  Suiki  Rick Preston  Dedan  Thomas
        Julius Papp  Christophe  John Howard  Jan Cooley  
        Visuals by Donovan
        10 PM - 8 PM, 18+ After 2 A.M.

Here are some weeklies, in the house/techno/acid jazz/etc vein.  Some
of them may have ended - let me know when that happens...

---------------------------- T h u r s d a y --------------------------------

Your Sisters' House - 9pm discussion - 10pm-4am funkygrooves - 415-435-7575
Universal Groove - $5. 415.281.5913  510.869.2727
Ajax Lounge - Acid Jazz w/Julius Papp (San Jose)
Lift - Digit, EFX, David Harness & guests - 55 Natoma, SF - 415.267.5984
Inspirations - 610 Coleman Ave, San Jose.  9pm-2am, 18+.
        408.236.2102  415.267.6974

------------------------------ F r i d a y ----------------------------------

Corduroy City  - $5 - call for DJs and location - 415.974.9715
Life/Twirl - Sound Factory - 525 Harrison @ 1st, SF    415.543.1300   21+
	DJs include Doc Martin, Aaron O, Pete Avila
Deep - Nikki Rivera, Jason Hayes, Lewis. 6th & Harrison (the End-Up)
Raw - Neon Leon, Jan Cooley, David Harness & guests - 540 Howard - 415.243.8181
Ooga Booga - 2600 Watt Ave (upstairs @ country club lanes) - 916.484.4006
Apocalypse - 16th & Harrison, $7, all ages - 415.979.8411
        [04.22 - Demigod,DRC,Buck,Frank Nitty,Richie,Binnie,Ben,
                 Galen,Kwashi,Maxx,Gary,Spinner,Dice,Mars + RON D CORE]
        [04.29 - Demigod,DRC,Binnie,Ben,Galen,Kwashi,Frank Nitty,
                 Christophe, Gary Maxx, Chris Lum, R A W]

---------------------------- S a t u r d a y --------------------------------

Dorothy's Tribe - Neon Leon, Rick Preston, Tommy Rogers & guests
	6am-2pm at the EndUp, 401 6th @ Harrison.  $2.  415.979.4515
Funky Buddha - presented by Spundae - 435 Broadway, 9pm til late.
        Head on House DJs: Simon, Henrik, Ernie, Jay-J, Mic, Eric Lacy, Josh.
        House of Funk & Killa Grooves: Bam Bam, Miquel, Melvin J, John Howard
        21+, $8 before midnite.  415.764.2922
Dig! - DJs George and Charlotte. the Kennel Club, Divisadero & Grove.
        [next one April 30th]
Contact! - various guest DJs. $5, 18+, 2721 Broadway, Sacramento.  916.484.5661

------------------------------ S u n d a y ----------------------------------

Groove Morning - 6am-3pm, 18+, $5.  Mission Rock, China Basin.  415.905.6441
Sunday School - Tommy Roger, Aaron O, Swing Kid, Smile-E.  6am-midnight.
        free before 2, $2 after.  the EndUp (6th & Harrison).  415.543.7700
Signs of Life - 375 11th @ Harrison (DNA).  $3, 6am-3pm, 21+
Good Housekeeping - presented by Flavor - w/sound technicians Alfie, James,
        Markie, Harry Who & live guests.  7am-4pm, $4, 21+.  
        spuds & stuff @ 9.  1190 Folsom St, SF.   415.928.2710
Light-n Up - 1015 Folsom, 21+, 9am-5pm.  415.267.7615
Sunset - 2pm-sunset. Free! - 415.985.5264

Bulletproof boat party - 5-9pm pier 40 (usually last Sunday of each month) 
        Tickets at Bulletproof 629 Haight (255.7168)
Ameba Ambient Tofu BBQ + films - BBQ lit at 5pm; bring BBQables, blankets,
        records.  1732 Haight.
Spundae - various guest DJs - 9pm-5am, 21+, $5 b4 12 - 55 Natoma. 415.974.9389
I-Beam Tea Dance - Neon Leon & others - 5pm-1am. 1748 Haight.

------------------------------ M o n d a y ----------------------------------

Mushroom Jazz (Jazid Up)- acid jazz w/Mark Farina, Thomas, Ammon, Is,
	Alex, Kevin, Bob Taylor and/or Julius Papp.
	$4, 10pm-4am.  1190 Folsom St, 21+. 415-905-8811
FreeLife - every other Monday at 551 W.Julian (@ Montgomery) in San Jose.
Pepper - various djs - 510 larkin @ turk  (Deco), 21+

----------------------------- T u e s d a y ---------------------------------

Together/Happiness - 21+, $5, 1015 Folsom - 10pm-3:30am - 415-979-8825
Check - rare grooves & house - Alfie, James & guests - 
        the I-Beam, 1748 Haight @ Cole.  21+, $2.  415.668.6006
Body and Soul - Larry Blakes, Berkeley 10pm-2am, acid jazz and funk $3

--------------------------- W e d n e s d a y -------------------------------

Motion - 400 S 1st St, SJ (side entrance of F/X). 21+.  408-236-3732
Fixx - Jan Cooley, Phillip, Aaron, Neon Leon.  Cocktails, 9th & Howard.
Stone Groove - acid jazz n' cosmic funk.  presented by Bulletproof.
        $3, 21+, 9pm-2am.  Miss Pearl's, 601 Eddy @ Larkin.  415.255.7168.
        [April DJs - Mark Farina, Gavan, Dani, Alex, Kevin, Gerry V, Kirk,
                     Andrew (Groove Merchant), Harry Who]
SPAZ (Semi-Permanent Autonomous Zone), 2 sound systems, new DJs and live
        performances each week.  $3, 60 Sixth Street.  info 415.sols666 
        [4/27 - Captain Bastard mans the moongarden > court is being held
         by Sir Sensual > DJ Sunflrfish and the disco balls >>>]
Recycle - every other Weds w/Carlos, Dutch, Christophe & guests. 415.599.3750
Pacific - 683 Clementina @ 8th (between Folsom & Howard) - 
        Starts at 10pm, $5.  415.985.5264
Gemini - josh, spun, donald glaude, la paix, rick preston, dj dan,
        carlos & dutch.  415.979.4915

------------------------------- Info Lines ----------------------------------

Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087.  Usually has 5-10 listings, updated daily.
Elmo - 415-884-ABCD

------------------------------ Radio Shows ----------------------------------
Sunday mornings 1-3:30am - Minor Minor KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
Sunday evening 6:30-9pm - Mescalina, KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
Sunday evening 9-11pm - Universal radio at 89.1 FM.  Trance dance
        and power house.  Guest DJs weekly (SF & East Bay)
Sunday night 10pm-2am - Ambience w/Michael Hayes & David X  KWOD 106.5 (Sac)
Mondays 10pm - Belladonna, KFJC 89.7, Foothill College (Los Altos Hills)
Tuesdays noon-3pm - "London Jamaica" w/Unknown KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
weeknights ~9pm - the Modern Mix w/Steve Masters KITS 105.3 (SF)

If anyone has info on any other events, submit them! I can't possibly hope
to get all the info every week. 

Brian Behlendorf, bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu, and
Derek Chung, dhchung@us.oracle.com, 415-506-6195

majordomo@sfraves.stanford.edu with either the line

s*bscribe sfraves-calendar   or
uns*bscribe sfraves-calendar   

(type 'u' in place of the '*' - i've taken out the 'u' so this message
 passes thru majordomo's filter)

nrg sez:
>
>  o Christ on the Cross has little if no meaning to anyone I know. Rather,
>    it seems a growingly inappropriate anachronism heavily burdened with
>    2000 years of questionable cultural/mythological baggage. I shudder to
>    think at the volumes of blood let in Christ's name. As a myth *or as a
>    factual event* it has simply outlived it's usefulness if, in fact, it
>    ever had any. So Cosmic Christ still puts me off.
>
    did me too, i dont understand the preoccupation with christ.  its sorta
    like those elvis sightings.  people, the guy is dead.  yeah, he was cool
    and all that, he taught some heavy shit, but lets address the now.

>  o I was more than a little dismayed at your barely masked contention
>    that "use of drugs or mushrooms to reach a mystical state" implies 
>    "opting out into some cynical, self-pitying stupor," especially given
>    that you cite aboriginal (indigenous?) peoples as one of his/your
>    models, many of whom have/had shamanic traditions of which naturally
>    occurring plant psychoactives are an integral part. 
>
    say it brother!!!

>    God and the cumulative psychic manifestations of life may easily be
>    present in dimensions reachable by a simple chemical. Organisms are,
>    after all, not only spiritual beings, but also bio*chemical* systems.
>    Why then this chemical alienation? Does it make it too easy? Does one
>    have to be *worthy* of god (like we've been hearing for 10000 years?)
>    I sure hope not. 
>   
>    People find god in their own way. The conscious use of psychoactives
>    towards these or other like goals is an entirely valid and historically
>    verified approach. 
>
    yeah, until this fox guy or anyone else for that matter has the courage
    to acknowlege these points.  i'll save my spiritual endeavors to going
    to raves.

    barry

Greetings Friends & Co-Conspirators!

Following numerous proddings both internal and external, we (you, me,
bryce, us: we :) have decided to try and unleash the first full-blown,
*free*, outdoor, all ages, sfraves renegade rave and general bru-ha-ha of
the spring season. Yippee!

We've selected a beautiful and centrally located sf spot of great renegade
tradition and no little infamy--jsl once decribed this spot as weak (with a
little w) so you know it's great ;-). Said spot has a glorious view of the
bay, large warehouse walls (for projecting on) and has been recently
renovated, now sporting a *very wide* swath of asphalt for your dancing
comfort and convenience. 

SoundVision will be in full effect so bring your ears ;) On the wheels of
steel will be:

  Meme
  Lee An
  Ethan
  Laura
  Buck

Yes, that's right, Buck. He's psyched, we're psyched. Some other guest djs
may join us as well.

What You Can Do:
Bring yourself, bring your friends (lots), bring your absolutely positive
energy, food, drink, duraflame logs, blankets, pillows, toys, lights
doohickeys and other enhancements. I know one of you (but I forget who) has
a video projector so please bring it and twist our minds :)

I've printed up little fliers (we thought we'd call it Launch Pad, cos of
the tarmac :) so if you're in sf tonite or tommorrow gimme a call, come get
some and give em to all your friends and cohorts. Or, you/they can call:
415.487.8497 for up-to-date information.

Remember this is *your scene*--we're just facilitating--this party can be
anything you want it to be, so please, set aside the night and come help us
blast this one off! 

take it easy
ethan


                                _______ 
 ethan miller                     nrg                            pgp me   
_________________________ 'one unbroken whole' _________________________   
                         
                (: positive energy can save the world :)
               __________________________________________

From sfraves-owner  Thu Apr 21 18:47:18 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA15037; Thu, 21 Apr 94 18:47:18 PDT
Received: from mail.netcom.com (netcom4.netcom.com) by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)

Received: from localhost by mail.netcom.com (8.6.4/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id SAA04516; Thu, 21 Apr 1994 18:48:31 -0700
From: meclay@netcom.com (Michael E. Clay)
Message-Id: <199404220148.SAA04516@mail.netcom.com>
Subject: Audium Review
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Thu, 21 Apr 1994 18:48:29 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 1649      
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

>Subject: Audium


>A while back there was a thread concerning this place.  Anybody ever go?  
>Critiques?

>Sami

  Great little theatre of sound run by Stanley Shift (sp?) who controls
  the performances of multichannel music that he composes. Everyone 
  should try it at least once but make sure to take some friends to
  insure a performance. If only 2 people show up he may or may not run
  the show and crowds are not to be found at a space that has been going
  for more than a decade. Check pink sheet for times etc.

  The music is not beat oriented but rather inspired by a process more
  like lucid dreaming - music concrete, ambience constiting of children,
  parades etc. are swept around, above and under you as you sit in total
  darkness in a room resembling a planetarium but filled with 100+ 
  speakers (talk about cross-overs!) Large woofers in the subfloor often
  vibrate the entire area etc. Sounds swirl and pass through you... close
  your eyes or open them doesn't matter all that much.. disorienting to
  some, fascinating to some, boring to others - opinions vary. 

  I last attended with a group of four friends and another couple showed
  up so the performance was on. After the show our group was completely
  thumbs up. Outside I noticed Jennifer crying - she said it was because
  she experienced her birth during the show.(She was unaltered by chemicals
  except those produced internally). Her response while not typical is
  well within the range of reported reactions. You should note that Stanley
  said his wife is bored by his compositions so there is quite a range.

  So definitely go try it and see ... 

From sfraves-owner  Thu Apr 21 19:24:12 1994

	id AA15586; Thu, 21 Apr 94 19:24:12 PDT

	id AA15579; Thu, 21 Apr 94 19:24:04 PDT
Received: (from rmt@localhost) by well.sf.ca.us (8.6.8/8.6.6) id TAA06426; Thu, 21 Apr 1994 19:24:06 -0700
Date: Thu, 21 Apr 1994 19:24:06 -0700
From: Randy Tinkerman <rmt@well.sf.ca.us>
Message-Id: <199404220224.TAA06426@well.sf.ca.us>
To: mauzi@aol.com, sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re:  Matthew Fox's 'Rave in the Nave'
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

My initial freeflow response to cliff's posting about Matthew Fox follows,
with the caveat that it is an instantaneous online respone, with no editing
or months of refined generation of ideas.

I'm glad Fox recognizes that this post-modern generation has the tools to
make grand spiritual and social changes.  Cliff's version of his thoughts
indicate that he's forgotten that every generation is the first post-modern
generation from the previous one.  That technology and other variables seem
to be exploding exponentially is a given, but I can attest that many people
in the 60's recognized the same, even to the point of noticing that we were
the "first" postmodern generation.

If there was a break with the past, that break was absolutely related to the
widespread use of sacramental substances, both chemical and organic, which
allowed the individual to experience alternate realities that differed from
the socially imprinted norm.  To disallow, or put down, the validity of
these experiences, and its social effect both then and now, misses the key
nature of those experiences.  Let's not forget that path of sacramental
substances may well have deeper roots than any mystical tradition, but goes
back before recorded history.

In fact, those substances may even be necessary to break down socially
imposed conditioning or imprinting. The rave community did not spring solely
from technological experiments with computing, lasers and midimedia.  Its
roots are firmly in the tradition of ritual substance communally shared.
To make statements putting down the validity of this tradition violates what
is happening here.  Further, the right to explore one's own mind may be the
most basic right of all, and any action that does not further the cause of
obtaining those rights is a disservice.

That he recognizes the validity of ancient ways of spirituality is fine,
especially that he rcognizes what does not even need to be spoken of in
aboriginal cultures.  So God is in everything, so what's new. In my life
that's a given to the depth of my being. But even the native tradition of
the creator may not give true picture of some high-level heterarchical
self-organizing quantum principle that underlies the universe.

So making love is OK in a committed relationship?  Thanks alot. Non-corecive
good-hearted fucking in the streets may be just as good.  Are we seeing the
new rules of *scripture* being formed, updating the old sins to post-modern
level?  In some aboriginal cultures, ritual fucking was essential to the
spritual health of the community.  Young people were encouraged to split off
into the woods.  Dream desires were fulfilled by authority of the community.
Don't tell me what the acceptable social norm should be.  Just do what's
good for *you.*

Certainly, Fox's approach moves strongly in the desired direction.  Just
don't put down something other's do that doesn't fit your own choices.

In the long run, though the outward death wish of present society may be
mitigated by a move in Fox's direction, and a better world fostered by him,
the true mysticism will always remain underground.

Skennah Kowa.  Hiro Kone.
alpha-10

From com-priv-forw@lists.psi.com Thu Apr 21 17:57:46 1994
Message-Id: <2976040329.0.p00997@psilink.com>
Date: Thu, 21 Apr 94 14:57:10 -0400
To: "com-priv" <com-priv@psi.com>
From: "David Rothman" <rothman@netcom.com>
Reply-To: rothman@netcom.com
Sender: p00997@psilink.com
Subject: CompuGov Deal Goes Through
X-Mailer: PSILink-DOS (3.6.1)

WASHINGTON-The federal government was sold today to CompuGov, a
high-tech consortium that includes IBM, Microsoft, AT&T, Northern
Telecom, Sony and several other corporate giants in Europe and Japan.

"It's the ultimate vindication of the Free Market philosophy," said a
high-ranking Administration official. "This deal is the logical
extension of lessons from the computer and telecommunications 
industries. What's government but the processing and transmission of
information?"

Effective immediately, the popular vote was ended at the federal level.
Instead Americans will be able to buy Stakeholder Shares. Those with
sufficient numbers of Shares may attend CompuGov board meetings in
Tokyo. Members of Congress each received 10,000 Stakeholder Shares and
Golden Parachute protection--in addition to extra Shares reflecting the
sizes of past campaign donations from Political Action Committees run by
CompuGov members.

CompuGov announced the spin-off of most nondefense assets and the
dismissal of 75 percent of the federal workforce. Tennessee entrepreneur
Chris Whittle will buy the Department of Education, for example, while
Humana will purchase the Department of Health and Human Services.

"We regret the need for downsizing," a CompuGov spokesperson said, "but
education and health have been lacking as profit centers. "They just are
not part of our corporate mission. Our role is simply to protect our
customers against force and fraud."

Asked about the pending spin-off of the Securities and Exchange
Commission to New York businessman John Gotti, the spokesperson said:
"We must always be open to the wisdom of the Free Market. If Mr. Gotti
can make the SEC more responsive to the needs of business, I see no
reason why we could not also sell him the Justice Department."

Final negotiations are continuing between CompuGov and the individual
states, with deals expected shortly. Only Massachusetts is balking.

"The consensus is that the Free Enterprise system is best," said the
CompuGov spokesperson. "America's big mistake was in simply trying to
get government out of the economy. The best solution is to get
government out of government." 

                              - 30 -

[Hey, it's still April.]

          with unnecessary restrictions on the flow of knowledge!

>
>A while back there was a thread concerning this place.  Anybody ever go?  
>Critiques?

i went expecting to hear some funky 3-d stereophonic sensaround 
waves of tangerine dream weaving all around me, and i was rather
disappointed.  the arrangement and acoustics are incredible -- 132
speakers -- but the show itself seemed somewhat dated, like maybe
mid-to-late 70's.  a lot of old synthesizer sounds, running up and
down the scales and such.  there were definitely some neat effects,
though -- like a drop of water that seems to splash through the
whole room, and a train that runs through everything.  if you've
got nothing else to do on a friday or saturday night and you've
got eight bucks to spend, it's something to consider ...

andy

Message-Id: <9404221417.AA01480@gaia.internex.net>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU, lwyatt@ocf.berkeley.edu
Subject: About Race (Was Re: Culture Communicationn
X-Sun-Charset: US-ASCII
Content-Length: 6612
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


> From SFRaves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU Fri Apr 22 00:37 PDT 1994
> Date: Fri, 22 Apr 1994 00:35:19 -0700
> From: Lisa M. Wyatt <lwyatt@ocf.berkeley.edu>
> To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
> Subject: Culture Communication
> 
> 
> True...there HAVE been a high number of messages on the various
> groups at parties, on racism, on prejudice...etc. But please realize
> these are HUGE issues, issues that continually affect all aof us, 
> and communication is VITAL if we ever want to solve the difficulties
> brought on by them. And this, if I'm not mistaken, is a communication
> zone, eh? If more needs to be said, it seems very appropriate and
> necessary that it should be.
> 
> Enjoy your days!
> Lisa.
> 

I agree, this is VERY relevant to the Scene (at least here in SF)
and I think that we can make alot of head way in this group where a lot
of different people know each other (at least virtually :)
Just make sure that as you post and reply you honor and respect the opinions
and feelings of those around you.

In fact the opportunity that is before the rave scene is to ADDRESS and
go through these issues once and for all.  It has been my observation
that we have to chance to go beyond political correctness.  Affirmative
Action is no longer needed when people of other backgrounds get
together socially.  I worked at a _very_ progressive computer
networking organization a few years ago, and people would always say to
me, "we need to get more people of color in here" my response to them
was "well, how many people of color do YOU know personally?" Most
people hire or refer other people that they know socially!  If young
people party with diversity, they will build a society that IS diverse,
from the ground up.  Equality will not have to be legislated (which
AA/EEOG is, it's a _last resort_, it should not have to be this way.)
The Scene (except for it's deplorable performance with regards to women
DJs) has been pretty good in this arena, the problems that have been
there and that have been aired (often starting on this forum), I have
seen efforts made to address these issues.  As far as racism and code
words, well of course they exist,  and I have seen them used on this
and other list,we have to guard against stereotyping of all sorts.
I don't mean the ocasional joke about "Black people having more rhythym"
or "Patriarcial White Males" it is important for us to make jokes BUT realize
that these type of things are stereotypes and that they can be very dangerous
if believed.  Stereotypes come in both good and bad flavors, both are damaging
to the believer and to the person that is the target.  My friend Jack who is
chineese says that when he would pal around with a black friend of his (who
also goes to stanford) when people would find out that they both went there
they would ask Jack what his major was and his friend what sport did he play :)
I'm sure these people didn't think that they were being racist, but their
questions originated in stereotypes that have very racial overtones.

As I have said before, I have no problems with "Oaktown Hommies" comming
to ANY party as long as they respect the people around them.  Unfortunately
I have often heard remarks about said group along with talk about "ganstas"
and the like.  This saddens me because eventhough some of these folks could
cause trouble at parties, except for one incident (Candlestick park), I don't
know of any overwhelming occurance of trouble by any of these groups.
I also never hear people being afraid of the "Concord Cowboys" who IMHO
have as much stereotypic potential for perpetuating violence and abuse
at a party as any "darker" posse.  Let's face it, fear and prejudice go
hand in hand.  I must say I'm more afraid to be alone in Concord at night
(where black men have been lynched at BART stations in RECENT history) then
in Emeryville or Oakland, but it doesn't stop me from going to martin's parties
when they turn up there.  The rule is not to be stupid but we must all realize
that racism IS A DISEASE of our culture, it is a strong meme and WE ALL HAVE
IT to some degree.  Raving, in proper doses administed with love has proven to 
be a _very_ effective treatment against this disease which is why I will be 
on the dance-floor tonight, and future nights.  This is why I also tend to go to
parties where the racial makeup is more diverse (WICKED, GATHERING, SPUNDAE)
It's nice to bask in a cocoon of safety and love and be around people that all
look and think and act like you, it is rejuvinating and re-energizing, and there
is nothing wrong with it.  But that is NOT why I go to parties.  I go to 
parties to _radiate_ love, respect and consciousness.  The Oaktown Homies
and the Concorde Cowboys both need to learn this lesson badly, what better place
than at a rave?  As some of you know, I'm a rather large :) guy.  This often
gives me a sense of (and actually !) security that many other people can't 
have.  I try to use this not in an intimidating way but in a positive way.
I go up to the gangsta and the cowboys and talk to them, tell them I'm glad they
made the party, answer their questions, etc.  Let me ask you, if you don't
do this who will?  As many of you know, I often wind up talking to the police
at renegades and the like, some people say I have a "way" with them, but what 
you may not know is how hard this is for me to do.  I grew up in an 
environment where  THE POLICE WERE NOT YOU FRIEND!  When I was 
young in Brooklyn, folks would call the neighborhood black panthers during
a domestic squabble before they would call the police.  My inner automatic
feelings about police border on out and out hatred but I also have learned
to realize that underneath that uniform is a human being, no matter what
an asshole he/she is being, they were a little baby once, who came into
this world with fear and wonder and all that other bullshit is just (as my
man jsl would say) frontin'.  What all this leads up to is you have to 
look BEYOND the enemy.  What you might see are your own fears and prejudices.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

From sfraves-owner  Fri Apr 22 07:31:08 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA24285; Fri, 22 Apr 94 07:31:08 PDT
Received: from mail.netcom.com (netcom4.netcom.com) by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA24278; Fri, 22 Apr 94 07:31:02 PDT
Received: from DialupEudora by mail.netcom.com (8.6.4/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id HAA16902; Fri, 22 Apr 1994 07:32:21 -0700
Date: Fri, 22 Apr 1994 07:32:21 -0700
Message-Id: <199404221432.HAA16902@mail.netcom.com>
X-Sender: jsl@localhost
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Subject: Non-Rave Posts...
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Oh no, not another hard line....

Yes, there have been some interesting threads about:  religion, race,
politix, and a host of other subjects.

I have found that most of these topics started out as rave related
conversation.  And they end up as rave realted conversation.  And end as
rave realted as well.  There is no such thing IMO as a pure rave post.
Unless all anyone wants is where the party is, who threw it, how good/bad
it was.  To me this seems pretty boring.

Also, given the fact that the number of parties have shrunk (yes, the scene
has become less larger than life) to just a FEW promoters, and even fewer
DJ's people are willing to give a listen to, it becomes inevitable that we
dig a little deeper to find out why we go/don't go to parties, why there
are so few people out, why the number of people throwing parties has
shrunk.  These topics answer some of these questions, even though, on the
surface, it may seem a bit trivial and nit-picky.  The underlying feelings
as to why people do not go out, it seems are numerous, but based in the
realities of life:  money, culture, classification (this is an
oversimplification, but for brevity's sake...).

Just look at what has happened:  People only go out becuase of certain
cliques that may be around.  People go only to hear DJ x,y, or Z.  People
only go out if the party is done by a certain promoter, certain music,
certain classification.  And Whaddaya get?  England ALL OVER AGAIN.  Posses
and more posses.  Gang wars due to party alliances.  The list goes on.  The
same thing is happening here (the rave community US stylee) and it's sad.
The real issue here is that people have rally not noticed it at all.  And
these little prejudices have crept into eevery aspect of what we call rave.

There was a time that if you threw a gig, and did things even half way
decent, you would get a certain number of people.  Now the hardest thing is
getting people to let go of their preconceptions and try something new.
This is especially true of old-skoolers, who still carry hella weight when
it comes to goin' out.  It's all become a business, a way to pay the rent,
a way to get a bit higher in the economic climate, and a way to shut others
down. A way to make sure that people attend only certain events by playing
certain ways/things at some people's parties while playing the best at your
own (so fucking unfair).  A way to make sure you don't get certain
"elements" by having it in certain areas, inviting only certain groups of
people, etc.

So race has everything to do with rave these days (at one time it didn't
the number of people of color going out is rebounding, but for the past two
years it has shrunk to nothing.  The numbers bear me out, and it was NOT
always this way.  Something happened.). Culture has everything to do with
rave (WHO can drive some 60 miles out to a gig, and WHO has the resources
to scramble some resource to get that goal done.  And when you get there
WHO is dancing).  And MONEY has to do with everything!!!! :( :( :( :(
:(!!!!! (YES,  there are PLENTY of RENT RAVES going on.  Plenty of people
getting stiffed due to cash.  People trying to ensure that they get theirs.
Promoters still being greedy.  DJ's still being greedy.  Everyone
wonderin' when they're gonna get theirs.  What bullshit!).

So as I see it, people have begun to analyze how/what they think.  More
importantly we have started to talk about what we see as problems in a very
open way.  This IMHO is a very good thing.  No, the time for brushing shit
under the rug, and saying "well, we know it's unresolvable, so let's just
get back to the subject of rave....", is over.  The fact that we have begun
to talk about it gives least a possibility of resolution.  To me it's
getting real about something we all treasure in one way or another (i.e
rave).  And even though a certain thread may die, it sparks some
conciousness on everyone's part.  Just gives that extra something to think
about when we go out.  You know, remeber what used to THINK about when in a
mass of 2000+ people.  How this many people, from soo many backgrounds, can
put away their shit, and dance, TOGETHER.  Where everyone is there for the
dance.   Where the music guides you into the inner realm (sometimes it
didn't even matter WHAT the DJ was spinning, as long as it was done well.
99% of the time it WAS).  A week later you would see a fellow cracker-jack
along the street, and you two exchange glances that meant "I know where you
were last weekend, and what you looked like with that big smile plastered
across that face of yours!".  Nothing more neede to be said, all done with
a look.

I think these discussions will eventaully take us back to these essential
roots of the rave culture.  One good time crackin-on with your friends, in
a sea of cracker-jacks, everyone there for the music, everyone there for
the dance.

Coolness.

Audi 5,
John

P.S.  So I guess I think the discussions of late have been MORE than
relevant to our scene.  It's all about that communication.  Tellin' that
story, and having others tell theirs.  Right on!

=================================================================
                 Ain't no future in your frontin'
=================================================================
             --PGP Public key available upon request--
Best  : jsl@netcom.com
other : John_Lee.DPI@notes.worldcom.com

CyberTribe-5).  I thought I would share it with all of you,
I have removed the name to respect the person's privacy.

----------------------------------------

To: umt@nexsys.net
From: 
Date: 24 Jan 94 10:02:54
Subject: re:CyberTribe rising
Priority: normal
X-Mailer: Pegasus Mail v2.3 (R5).
Content-Length: 3819

I read your piece entitled CyberTribe rising when it was posted on
the activl listserv (is that the right word?) anyway, it was
interesting to hear that people call themselves ravers in parts of
the world other than here and that huge raves are still happening
elsewhere if not in the country of their origin. One aspect that had
me a tad worried was the prominence given to the role drugs play in
the rave culture and the assumption that the rave culture was some
kind of unifying world family. I've been living in and arround the
rave 'scene' for a good many years now and have come to the
conclusion that it and the drugs that define it are very much a
part/symptom of the dominant 'control' culture that sructures our
governments etc. Apart from having watched a number of people i love
die or go insane from drugs, i have also observed that at the times
when things look especially promising for any kind of breakthrough in
favour of the creation of more TAZs or PAZs the quantities of drugs
miraculously increase to guarantee that as many people as possible
are too lost to the world to do anything consciously positive. This
may sound a lot like a far fetched conspiracy theory but time and
again I and many others have noticed that in the summer when the
weather and the mood calls for parties and festivals it is suddenly
easier to buy smack than anything else.
  Drugs and the culture they have evolved from/into provide an escape
from the 'real world' in all its grimness but due to the fact that as
a reaction against that world they are still part of it and due to
the fact they are manifestly predudicial to life I do not feel like
celebrating them, neither do I feel like part of a 'family'.
  I am what is called here in Britain a 'New Age Traveller', this is
not what i call myself believing that labels of all kinds are
restrictive bullshit, but what it does mean is that as part of a
group of people that has been conclusively shat on by our government
i do feel i have a lot of personal experience of sub/counter-culture.
The rave thing grew out of the festival scene which was very much
Traveller territory for many years before the ravers arrived. What I
mean by that is that Travellers organised them (if the semi-
miraculous accumulation of random people in one place at one time can
be called organisation) Travellers provided food, entertainment and
of course cheap soft drugs in copious quantities and so we bumbled on
happy and relatively un-noticed (except for events like the battle of
the beenfield in '85) till rave happened.  Then thousands of peole
descended on festivals for the weekend with no idea of how to behave,
left their excrement lying around took lots of hard drugs, left
enough rubish lying on the ground to totally cover the grass, left
broken glass where our children and animals trod on it and caused
enough trouble to motivate the government to draw up legislation
aimed at us specifically in order to outlaw our way of life.
  I don't of course believe that the ravers acted in malice but in
ignorance, nonetheless the damage is done. The driving desire of
thousands of people to forget their lives for a while by dancing and
taking what were then thought to be harmless drugs has destryoed our
small attempt to build a permanent autonomous zone in this country. I
feel sad and angry about this and very sceptical of any kind of
concept of world family and love and harmony based on the party ethic
because it is essentially escapist, short-sighted and self-
destructive.

  As for cyber-space I have only recently discovered it and I'm very
excited about its possibilities. I was intrigued and puzled at your
linking that with the rave scene, but maybe rave means something
different on your side of the atlantic!

Keep cheerful,

From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)

To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Pure space....  A new experience
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


   I attended the 2nd "Pure Space" happening this Thursday evening
at the DNA Lounge on 11th St.    For those that missed it,  I would
venture to say you missed ONE HOPPIN party.....  The vibe was what
really made that party something I'll remember for a long time.

   I would say about 60 - 100 people showed up,  and the music was
just killer,  some of the trancies acid stuff I've heard in a long 
time.    When I got there,  Josh was spinning,  and I've heard some 
really great new stuff.    Initially,  he had trouble keeping up the 
beat,   but once he warmed up,  the place was one hoppin party.    
As usual,  I went  totally insane,  trancing out,  digging the shit 
out of the great music.

   About 2 pm,  just before the bar closed,   I talked to Marky Mark
and said "give me a good dance workout",  and he lived up to my 
expectations by laying down one of the longest most continious sets of 
NEW MUSIC!! and stuff I haven't heard before.   For all I know,  it 
could have been some really old stuff,  but in the state my head was 
in,  I hardly cared.... They were Loooong sets....

   So,  in conclusion, check out Pure Space as an alternate to Your
Sisters House.... You Won't be dissapointed....

John D.

From sfraves-owner  Fri Apr 22 12:37:54 1994

From: laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Fri, 22 Apr 1994 12:37:11 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: mtnraves@xmission.com, ne-raves@umdd.umd.edu, sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU,
        vrave@gnu.ai.mit.edu
Subject: Grand Canyon Festival
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Wired Magazine reported that Megatripolis from the UK was going to join up 
with the Rainbow Gathering to do a big event in the Grand Canyon.

I started reading alt.gathering.rainbow and found out some interesting things:

(1)  The Rainbow Gathering isn't going to be in the Grand Canyon this year.

(2)  Even if it were, the on-line Rainbow people aren't in to the idea of a 
	rave invading their space (ravers are welcome, so long as they leave 
	their generators and loud music at home).

(3) There *is* something happening in the Grand Canyon, it's just
        not quite as it was alluded to in Wired:

>Article 1457 of alt.gathering.rainbow:
>Subject: RE: Rainbow in Wired
>Date: 22 APR 94 19:05:03 GMT
>
>The Gathering which I know about in August at the Grand Canyon is called the
>"World Unity festival and conference" and it's officially from Aug.22-28.
>I saw an add for it in "Threshold", the magazine of the Student Environmental
>Action Coalition (SEAC). It's described as a gathering of world artists,
>musicians, and organizations, and sounds amazing. There's places for camping
>and hotel accomadations, there're $20 concerts and free festivals, and it
>sounded like something for people from all walks of life. It's produced by
>Quetzacoatl Productions (I probably spelled that wrong) based in San Francisco
>(I think). I don't have the address but they'd probably know at seac@igc.org.
>I'm planning on going so see you there.
>             Peace -Andy

Just thought you all would be interested before you pack up your tents and 
drive cross-country.

If I happen across any other useful information I will post it.

Laura

From sfraves-owner  Fri Apr 22 12:43:46 1994

	id AA29114; Fri, 22 Apr 94 12:43:46 PDT

	id AA28715; Fri, 22 Apr 94 12:26:26 PDT
Received: from DialupEudora by mail.netcom.com (8.6.4/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id MAA17163; Fri, 22 Apr 1994 12:27:29 -0700
Message-Id: <199404221927.MAA17163@mail.netcom.com>
X-Sender: nrg@localhost
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Fri, 22 Apr 1994 12:30:50 -0800
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
From: nrg@netcom.com (ethan miller)
Subject: Matthew Fox Meeting
Cc: sfraves-planners@techno.Stanford.EDU
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Greetings Friends!

Sometime last week two local newspapers ran a story on Matthew Fox and the
"Rave Mass" he is planning. As I'm sure you noticed, the concept generated
a lively debate on the list covering ground from: how raving and
spirituality interact, to the potential ill effects of organized religion
on our culture, to the similarities between raving and established
religious practice--the gospel experience for example.

I was very intrigued by the idea. For me it was the third event in a three
pronged synchronicity that I experienced surrounding people discussing the
relation of raving to the more classically defined transcendant religious
experience. 

So I attempted to contact Matthew Fox to get a better grip on exactly what
he had in mind. One of his associates, Cliff Atkinson, contacted me. We
talked and he sketched for me a brief outline of both Matthew's ideas in
general and as they related to the "Rave Mass". My curiousity remained
piqued.

I asked him if he was aware of sfraves and that there was a lively
discussion underway regarding these ideas, suggesting that perhaps he
subscribe to the list and enter into the fray. Which he promptly did,
yesterday morning.

Since then many of us have responded vigorously, both publicly and
privately, to the points he made. Clearly the issues under discusion run
very deep.

Matthew and Cliff were, I think, very surprised and pleased by the volume
and the depth of the mail they received and would like the opportunity to
get together with us to meet each other, respond to our questions,
criticisms etc., and just generally hang out and exchange ideas. They have
asked me to coordinate a meeting for this Sunday afternoon, which I am
happy to do.

I think it's important to stop and state at this point that I neither
support nor dis-support what they have in mind. I don't know what they have
in mind. It's not an it yet. And, from what I understand, what 'it' becomes
will be the result of whatever common ground they and the bay area
house/raver community can find. But I'm going too far. Come and find out
for yourself.

Let me just add this one point: clearly they, like us, have realised that
music, dancing, the active particpatory celebration of life and relation
creates a transcendant experience and that community often falls out of
groups of people that share in the creation of transcendant experiences.
Make no mistake, I for one will *never* contribute to the cooption,
dogmatization, distortion or other such degradation of our scene, but from
what I can gather, they are here seeking our similarities rather than our
differences, as people in community we should do no less. 

So I urge you to take advantage of this remarkable opportunity to get
together and talk. And please, bring your absolutely positive energy; this,
like everything else, can you be anything you want it to be.

Please rsvp me by private email or call me at home (I go off-line on
weekends): 415.826.6137

take it easy
ethan


                                _______ 
 ethan miller                     nrg                            pgp me   
_________________________ 'one unbroken whole' _________________________   
                         
                (: positive energy can save the world :)
               __________________________________________

Received: from hulk.sfsu.edu by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA29843; Fri, 22 Apr 94 13:22:47 PDT
