	id NAA05733; Fri, 22 Apr 1994 13:16:00 -0700
From: pandora@hulk.sfsu.edu (Candice)
Message-Id: <199404222016.NAA05733@hulk.sfsu.edu>
Subject: Splinter groups
To: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee), sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU (sfraves)
Date: Fri, 22 Apr 1994 13:15:59 -40962758 (PDT)
In-Reply-To: <199404221432.HAA16902@mail.netcom.com> from "John S. Lee" at Apr 22, 94 07:32:21 am
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23alpha]
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 2800      
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

John S. Lee sez:
> 
> Just look at what has happened:  People only go out becuase of certain
> cliques that may be around.  People go only to hear DJ x,y, or Z.  People
> only go out if the party is done by a certain promoter, certain music,
> certain classification.  And Whaddaya get?  England ALL OVER AGAIN.  Posses
> and more posses.  Gang wars due to party alliances.  The list goes on.  The
> same thing is happening here (the rave community US stylee) and it's sad.
> The real issue here is that people have rally not noticed it at all.  And
> these little prejudices have crept into eevery aspect of what we call rave.
> 
I'm glad that this was brought up again.  I have a different outlook on the
issue though.  I don't feel that people are in general closing their minds 
down and becoming unwilling to try new things (although this of course does
happen) it seems to me that people are becoming more discriminating.
That through trying out different things they have found what it is
that makes them happy.  If I go to a restaurant and order something 
that I really like I'll go back for that particular item again or to try
something else believing that the restaurant is capable of making good food.
But if I go to eat someplace and have a bad experience with one menu
item I'll be hesitant to go back there for anything at all.  It really is
just a simple learning process.  Experiences of people that I know and
trust have an impact on my decisions also.  The cleaners really messed
up my friends clothes so now I won't take my clothes there.  I'm sure
that my analogy between rave and consumerism is not pleasing to
everyone but I think there is some truth here.  If a person has a great
experience with a DJ they will go to other events where this Dj will
be, etc.  It seems more like a decision making process than a clique.
If people are being exclusive that's a clique.  I really can't say
that I've experienced this too much (not saying that it's not happening,
just that it hasn't personally affected me).

These splinter groups may also just be part of an evolutionary process.
People always said "rave won't die it will just evolve"  Maybe that is
exactly what is happening.  The rave sub-culture is now breaking off into
new and different sub-cultures.  This may not be something to mourn, but
rather to celebrate and keep on moving forward.  Change is the only
constant.  Also, diversity doesn't necessarily mean a bunch of different
types of people doing the same thing.  It can also mean different types of
people doing different things with acceptance and respect for each others
tastes and prefferences.

Just a couple different perspectives...

Take care,
CC
-- 
Candice			pandora@hulk.sfsu.edu


    I'm nothing now, but I'm something compared to what I used to be.

Laura wrote:
>Wired Magazine reported that Megatripolis from the UK was going to join up
>with the Rainbow Gathering to do a big event in the Grand Canyon.

I just got off the phone with one of the Megatripolis DJs, Darius.  He read
the article and says that while they are thinking about coming to the US,
the idea of hooking up with the Rainbow family was conjecture and was never
something definite due to lack of funds.  I was one of the fortunate people
who actually made it to the grand reopening of Megatripolis last October in
England.  Believe it when they say it's as good as it is!  I'm friends with
some of the DJs and organizers and plain ole partygoers who are involved
with Megatripolis.  Before I left England in November, they told me they
were coming to San Francisco in April to hook up with old time friends
Jeno, Garth and Markie who were part of the original "Tonka" replaced by
"SLACK," and now they're talking about possibly New York later this year.
Go figure.

>(1)  The Rainbow Gathering isn't going to be in the Grand Canyon this year.

Correct, the family are having their grand reunion in Wyoming this year.
Supposedly the Megatripolis people know it's not taking place there and
think that Wyoming is 60 miles away from the Grand Canyon.  *chuckle*
However "the turtles" also have a separate but small yearly gathering.
They are a splinter group who broke off from the family because basically
they wanted alcohol included in the festivities while the majority don't
etc.  This group I hear is more radical and their politics don't sound very
wholesome but this is all heresay anyway.  Judge for yourself.  I don't
know where they are meeting but I don't think it's in the Grand Canyon
either.

>(2)  Even if it were, the on-line Rainbow people aren't in to the idea of a
>        rave invading their space (ravers are welcome, so long as they leave
>        their generators and loud music at home).

Correct again, the family doesn't appreciate amplified music of any sort.
I don't know if "the turtles" would either so don't get your hopes up.  I
made this clear to my friend who didn't realize that the family are more
traditional hippies that don't embrace technology like they do.

and in reference to the article from alt.gathering.rainbow:
>>The Gathering which I know about in August at the Grand Canyon is called the
>>"World Unity festival and conference" and it's officially from Aug.22-28.

I don't think the Megatripolis people even know about this.  And this still
doesn't agree with the dates in the Wired article which several times
states August 1-15 as the dates.  It seems as this article has a bit of
disinformation.  I've never even heard the term "zippie" and I've been
friends with people that fit the definition off and on since 1990.

From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9404230021.AA25729@pilot.njin.net>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: 1015 Folsom in the news: "SF Nightclub Wins Restraining Order"
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

	A federal judge in San Francisco has issued a temporary order 
blocking San Francisco police from requiring a large gay night club 
south of Market Street  to close by 3:30 a.m.
	The owner of the club, 1015 Folsom, filed a federal civil rights 
suit against the city this week claiming that attempts to close the 
cabaret early violated First Amendment guarantees.
	Owner Ira Sandler claims he holds a city permit that allows him to 
keep the dance bar open until 6 a.m., like a dozen other after-hours 
clubs south of Market.  
	But in February, police ordered him to close by 3:30 a.m., citing 
permit conditions that Sandler claims he had removed after he took 
over the property in 1990.
	U.S. District Judge Eugene Lynch on Thursday granted Sandler's 
request for a temporary restraining order.
	But Deputy City Attorney Thomas Owen said the city will resist any 
attempt to make the order permanent.
	Owen said Sandler's permit still contains the 3:30 a.m. operating 
limit.
	According to Owen, police want to restrict the club's hours due to  
``significant problems with noise.''   

From sfraves-owner  Fri Apr 22 20:15:34 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA04548; Fri, 22 Apr 94 20:15:34 PDT
Received: from mvax.Sonoma.EDU by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA04541; Fri, 22 Apr 94 20:15:27 PDT
Received: from SSUVAX.DECnet MAIL11D_V3 by mvax.Sonoma.EDU (5.57/Ultrix2.4-C)
	id AA21231; Fri, 22 Apr 94 20:10:04 -0700
Date: Fri, 22 Apr 94 20:10:03 -0700
Message-Id: <9404230310.AA21231@mvax.Sonoma.EDU>
From: buehring@Sonoma.EDU
To: "sfraves@techno.stanford.edu"%MAILER.dnet@mvax.Sonoma.EDU
Subject: Re: Launch Pad/Spiral Jive
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

(sorry about that blank post)

>
>You know, something I'd like to see sometime is some tag-team DJing.
>Never seen it, but it sounds like fun (and sounds like fun to do,
>too).
>
>Sean

I saw Digs & Whoosh (from the DIY renegades in the UK) here in SF
a while back.  They tag-teamed it, each took a turntable and took
turns mixing in songs.  I saw them spin an excellent set at a FMR
last year.  Their set was pumping and they got into a thick
groove.  It was cool, one could cover and help the other if needed;
they seemed to be more relaxed and less presured than playing
alone.  
At another party (channeling i think) I saw whoosh pull off
the sketchiest save manuever.  Digs was attempting to match up his
next song and was having trouble due to poor monitors.  He must of
been stoned or something cause he didn't notice the record was about
to run out.  Whoosh was watching him and when the record was just about
over he reached over and picked up the needle (on beat) and dropped
it back in the middle of the record and somehow it landed on beat- 
and just sounded like a transform!  (This was pretty sketchy to do
over a such a large PA system).  Actually digs was so spaced out
he didn't even notice it and continued to match... the record was
about to run out again and whoosh picked up the needle and dropped
back again... this time it came down off beat and digs hadn't
noticed and he had just started to come in with his song- which
created a massive train wreck. so things can be tricky with two
people at the wheels!

Seeing digs & whoosh was inspiring.  A friend and I used to try
and tag-team it at parties in santa cruz.  Its a lot of fun, and
definitely takes some of the pressure off.  It can be hard though
to get into a coherent, deep groove.  You really have to follow each
other or the set can get very scattered.  But If you work together well,  
you can create a blazing set with variety.  Also it helps to play
with someone who has a similar style.

So I'm all for tag-teaming djs.  Hopefully we'll see some more soon.



James from santa cruz


hope to meet you all at Launch Pad sat :) !

	id VAA22437; Fri, 22 Apr 1994 21:05:44 -0700
Date: Fri, 22 Apr 1994 21:05:43 -0700 (PDT)
From: Robin Roseanne Penfield <rrose@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Re: dead full moon sites
To: Sean Casey <csc@pilot.njin.net>
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
In-Reply-To: <9404182202.AA19212@pilot.njin.net>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9404222027.A20778-0100000@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU



On Mon, 18 Apr 1994, Sean Casey wrote:

> It may just be a fact of life that when more than a certain number of
> people go to a site they're going to trash it. The question is: How do
> you fine tune a party like that so it doesn't get too big or stay too
> small?
> 
> There was a lot of garbage on the ground after the Organic GG park
> party. I cleaned up some, and noticed Bob doing the same. 
> I did it for the promoters, because they spent their money and their
> effort to throw that party. I did _not_ do it for the "good of rave";
> people should clean up their own mess, or, like me, not make one in
> the first place!
> 
> I wonder if people would act responsively if there were a _lot_ of
> garbage cans around? Ideas?
> 
> Sean

This is a good question Sean.  Although the fact that some raves leave a 
mess is not adequate excuse for the cops to bust them at will or simply 
prohibit them from ever taking place at a certain venue, clearly there is 
ample room for improvement on our side as well.

I think your suggestion of having garbage cans available is a good one.  
I also think you can accomplish wonders by giving people an incentive.  The 
WOMAD palooza/fest/schmorgasbord last summer in Golden Gate Park was attended 
by around 100,000 people who littered left and right, yet as I followed 
the crowd off the polo field at the end of the day the area was 
remarkably clean, thanks to an offer by Ben & Jerry's ice cream for a 
free treat coupon in exchange for a bag of trash on the way out (bags 
were provided on site).  Another way we can improve cleanup is by urging 
promoters to mention this on their voicemail messages for outdoor 
parties, and/or print it on the fliers.

Promoters can also communicate with ravers at the events to let them know 
this is a concern.  If people are made to feel it is their party also, 
they will generally care enough to not want to leave a mess.  

This is my first message to sfraves, and it seemed appropriate for Earth 
Day.  Happy Earth Day & Love & Smooches to Everyone!

                              *** Starchild ***

In my opinion, this proposed letter to the cops/Santa Cruz authorities 
should include a reference to how much money they made off us ravers by 
giving out parking tickets.

In effect, you can almost say that the cops were the "promoters" of the 
large events that took place there.  They didn't put out fliers or line 
up DJs, and they *definitely* didn't do anything to help make the parties 
go down well, but they sure took in a nice cover charge, didn't they?

People may have parked illegally, but more to the point, were they in 
anyone's way, or engaged in reckless activity of any kind?  Maybe someone 
has more knowledge on the local angle on this.  Laws should have a 
purpose aside from raising more money for the government machine at our 
expense, and we should not be conceding this in my opinion.

Rave On,                  =)   *** Starchild ***

--- Forwarded mail from Sheri Hendrickson <sherih@kitchen.mcad.edu>

>From sherih@kitchen.mcad.edu Thu Apr 14 14:01:42 1994
From: Sheri Hendrickson <sherih@kitchen.mcad.edu>
Date: Thu, 14 Apr 94 16:05:01 -0500
Received: by NeXT.Mailer (1.87.1.RR)
Received: by NeXT Mailer (1.87.1.RR)
To: Sun Kim <sunkim@sfsuvax1.sfsu.edu>, sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: Position Paper
Cc: sherih@kitchen.mcad.edu
Status: OR

Sun Kim asks,
"I will be writing a position paper on the 'rave' scene.... I'm  
having a really hard time trying to find references for my paper.   
Can anyone tell me of any references that I could use?"

	Okay, I am usually quiet on the sfraves net since I live the  
Midwest but here I go. Books will be obsolute on this new and  
underground subject matter. Here are some better sources.

1. MAGAZINE ARTICLES. Look in the periodicals in the library for the  
subjects of "techno" and "raves." I guarantee you'll find something.  
As you know, the current Rolling Stones did an article on the Bay  
area's scene. Some other mags that had a couple of pages on the "rave  
scene" are Newsweek, Time, Sassy, and etc. But these articles are  
sort of cheezy and candy-coated. Nothing really in depth except a  
report on a bunch of kids dancing to a special kind of music.

2. RAVE ZINES. Big zines like Urb, Slurp, and Reactor are a start. I  
know I can hook you up with some really underground Midwest zines. (I  
happen to do one myself). There are a ton of them here. One zine,  
Massive, is a compilation of zines. * One thing about Reactor, it  
hypes about what a super ravey scene Chicago has. It's sort of dead  
there. Most of the Chicago ravers go to Minneapolis or Wisconsin for  
the parties. Also, Reactor did an interview with cheezy Hi-NRG band,  
Pyskosonik, of Minneapolis. (I'm so embarrassed that these pretty  
pin-up boys live in the same town as I do). Reactor was suppose to  
interview Drop Bass Recording artist, DJ ESP Woody McBride (Earthworm  
Sings, Amplification '94, There's No Such Thing as Bad Acid, etc)  
instead of those Pyskos. Woody is a better representation and more  
respectable music maker and dj of Minneapolis.

3. INTERVIEWS. (You're best option.) Talk to promoters, djs, zines,  
and ravers themselves. They can fill you in a lot of info. However,  
promoters might be cautious on talking to you unless you them  
personally. They might think you are a narc. Just reassure them you  
aren't. Call up a promoter's voicemail to set-up an appointment to  
talk to them. (At their own party when they are running around to see  
if everything is going okay, is a bad time).

I hope this can help you.


Sincerely,
HKK
expositor 


--- End of forwarded message from Sheri Hendrickson <sherih@kitchen.mcad.edu>

Hi, I'm from England and I remember this happening about a year ago, or maybe it
was longer. Anyway, in the UK we all decided it was another pathetic attempt by
the established church to reach the next generation seeing as they already have
almost complete control of the last generation.

Personaly I don't think anyone should go to a Rave which is held by anyyone from
the church, as has already been said Christian and Rave don't go together, they
never have and they never will. The truth is that if Rave has to be associated 
with any religion it would be Shamanism. And if Christianity is further away
from any religion it would be Shamanism.

Me, I am mostly against all religions which limit a person or tries to control
society. I believe in the power of my mind and that a human being can do
anything if he knows how to use his/her mind. That's why I believe in the power
of the Rave as not just a place where people dance and do drugs but as a whole
ideal, even a religion in its own right.

Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU

From: modE@alpha2.csd.uwm.edu

Sami Khoury III writes:

:A while back there was a thread concerning this place.  Anybody ever go?  
:Critiques?

i was there. i wasnt very impressed, however the old man that runs the
place (it was his idea) is very nice. you walk down this dark hall turning
a bunch of corners and enter a circular room with 20 or so chairs. the 
parameter of the room is lined with lights that slowly fade to complete
blackness. the music starts (analogue beeps and tones, no samples, NOT
digital) and persists for something like 2 hours with a break. it was a tape
recording including lots of hiss. i think he was actually playing and
overlaping tape loops live. there were 300 some speakers in the room, around,
under and above you. dont expect the sounds to moving all over the place
(this was disappointing). he got some federal grant to construct the thing.
he wants to create a digital version of the audium, but he cant get the
funding.

dan.

modE@csd4.csd.uwm.edu

	After considering the long spiel containing some of Matthew Fox's
beliefs, I found the source of my discontent in cognitive dissonance.

	Fox's message is contradictory at best and deceitful at worst.
Either he doesn't believe at all in Christianity and is trying to
reach a wider audience by calling himself a priest of their cult, or
he's trying to bring those rebellious young'uns back into the fold
through gradual indoctrination, or possibly both.

	Anyone seduced by his images will eventually be confronted by
a basic dilemma, to wit: "If we are all God, then what makes Christ
special?  Why would he die for the sins of those equal to he?
Furthermore, why should I, as God, give a shit anyway?  For if I am
God, there can be none sitting in judgement above me, and I should
fear no judgement but my own."

	At some point, we all have to make a choice: do you believe in
the Cosmic Patriarchy, or do you believe in being a master without slaves?
Do you act according to the rules of the Cosmic Patriarchy in hopes of
getting a gold sticker by your name in the Book of Life, or do you make
your own decisions and accept the joy (and pain) of their consequences?
Is your life based on the fear of reprisal or the joy of existence?

"Give up on life after birth
 for life after death?
 It's a hard choice.
 Don't blow it."
		-Sperry

"The fence is not a comfortable seat." -me

// g

Well the attempt to go to Organic was ill-fated. What ever happened to nice
cheap events at the Troc?  I didn't think that the Organic crew would 
charge more than $10 for a rave. I was wrong. The price was $20. That is 
way too much for me these days. I don't think it is worth it attend these 
events. I understand it is to cover costs and all, but still i see it as 
a capitalistic ploy to suck the money out of young people (there were a 
lot of young people there) who want to have a good time. Commercialism +
Capitalism = means for profit. People could of had a better time  for 
free at Sprial Jive in the park. Even though it was cold, and 
there wasnt any big name DJs, it was nice. (yes, it was VERY cold :)).
Underground small parties are the only way to go these days. 

I am not completely ripping on the Organic people, I know they have good 
intentions and they also do free events, just they should consider other 
optional costs of an entrance fee. I know that if the group I was with 
(5 people) went in they would have made a hundred dollars, instead they 
lost it. c'est la vie.

RE:  Organic

Just because promoters do "free" events doesn't mean they're free to the
people who go to the commercial events.  If someone charges $20 for a $15
event (to cover the expenses of their "free" party) then the party is only
free for those who don't show up at the paid event, while the paying
regulars pay for the free party.  It's called getting you audience to pay
for your advertising.

Parties should be judged on the quality of sound, lights and space per
dollar, w/ a nod to quality fo DJs.   ?-)   maybe there should be a vibe
fadctor as well  ?-)

peach

Subject: "Rave" Not an Effective (or Meaningful) Counter-Culture Movement

This statement was posted to the anarchy-list
(anarchy-list@cwi.nl) in response to my response
on his list of "Youth Movements over the last 100
years".  I sited "The Acid House Movement" as the 
latest version in this tradition which includes

the Dadaist in Germany, 
the beat movement and the
hippie "movement.  
This person sites punk as the 
phase culminating in the riot grrrls.

I sent him a copy of "CyberTribe Rising" and told him
this was my view a year ago and it has changed somewhat
since then.

Here is his replay,
if you want to correspond with me off-line thats OK 
(I know some people would like to talk about the
quality of parties then this heave stuff) but if you don't
want to discuss this on the main list, it OK with me.

I am composing a response to this and intend to publish it on May 1
(The anaversary of the last one :).  The last umt communication
was a collaboration of 3 people (including myself).  I would
welcome dialog and feedback from anyone who has comments on the 
political nature of the Scene (if any) or the previous documents
or what-ever.  I will be setting up a WWW home page to make
this a little easier, stay tuned.






----- Begin Included Message -----

>From jamal@gnu.ai.mit.edu Sun Apr 24 10:00:03 1994
Return-Path: <jamal@gnu.ai.mit.edu>
From: jamal@gnu.ai.mit.edu (Jamal Hannah)
Subject: "Rave" Not an Effective (or Meaningful) Counter-Culture Movement
To: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White)
Date: Sun, 24 Apr 94 12:59:17 WET DST
Cc: anarchy-list@cwi.nl (Anarchy List)
Organization: Planet Earth
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Content-Length: 3356
X-Lines: 59
Status: RO

Well, I read over the Rave response, and the "Cybertribe" essay.
I cant say that, from this perspective, "Rave" has much to
do with counterculture, at least effectivly,
because it's primarily hedonistic in nature.. youre also relying on
technology that's been created by a system that was oppresive to begin with.
Granted, you can use it as you wish, but being dependant on it, but not
the _owner_ of it's means of production (the computer companies,
the record label companies, etc), means basicly relying too much
on something one is fighting against.   Hakim Bey's "Temporary Autonomous
Zone" was a cute way to make what a bunch of well-to-do college kids
had the ability to do anyway (chat with computers, go to rave
parties, etc) and made it seem somehow political.
But a "rave" culture is far to dependant on the very forces that
caused the problems they are fighting against.

All of the other countercultures I mentioned, with the exception of
the Riot Grrrls, seriously consider the role of the working class
vs. the ruling class.  And Riot Grrrls at least realize that the one
with the power over them they are fighting against is the _male_.

Going to a "Rave", dressing up wild, and taking drugs is a way to
have fun for some, perhaps.. but the notion that because everyone is
dancing together means some fundimental racial or class barriers have been
broken all over the world, is just plain wrong.  It's just another party,
really.  If the event encourages people, through some form of propaganda,
to do activism which encourages and stimulates people to commit themselves
to actions and organization which effect real _change_ instead of simply
hanging out together in one's own "autonomous zone", it could be
dewscribed as political, but the "rave" or "house party" in itself
is not what is progressive, or specificly "counter" to a system of
oppression.

Since a "Rave" party is intended to be as intense and flashy as possible,
it's easy enough for some rich entripeneur to throw the party themselves,
and reap the profits, by possesing a huge, flashy technological setup
that will "blow peoples minds".

Dancing in a rave is like masterbation:  ok, so you liberated yourself
from your own inhibitions against doing it, fine.. but, does it really change
the dominating relationship of Capitalists towards working people?  Hardly!
If anything, the system simply re-adjusts, and opens "official" rave-party
locations.

Rave does not put a progressive philosophy first and formost, as it's
central structure.  You couldnt be closely associated with the other
movements without being political yourself.   The real Hippies
were not the peopel who dressed up in bellbottoms, etc. Thsoe wernt the
peopel I was talking about.  The people who _activly sought_ ways to
undermine or abandon Capitalism and Industrialization altogether were
the real hippies, but at the time of intense crisis, they seemed
Godlike in their ability to stand up for what was right, which made them
"hip" and popular, and widely imitatable.

I know it seems like a big "killjoy" to say that youre just not being
revolutionary when you're partying... sorry.  No one is going to stop you
from doing it, but is it gonna help feed the starving?  Fight oppression?
Stop people from being exploted by corporations in Columbia?  Nope.

 - Jamal Hannah  <jamal@gnu.ai.mit.edu>


----- End Included Message -----




----- End Included Message -----

	$20 allows you to manufacture 10 compact discs w/
	jewel cases.

	$20 gets two people a meal at the Felafel place on
	16th/Valencia.

	$20 gets you an import CD of music you like that you'll have
	forever.

	I was floored to have someone at a nightclub tell me that
	it costs $20 come inside. I just couldn't believe it. It reminded
	me of when someone asked me for the same amount of money to see
	X play in 1987 or so. 

	The Aphex Twin/Orbital/Vaporspace show wasn't $20 and these
	guys came from far away to play here and their lights and sound
	were amazing.

	I don't care if they have free parties in the park. SFraves puts
	on parties at the park and never charges a dime for anything.

	Owning a soundsystem for use outdoors is expensive but completely
	obtainable and there is no reason to try and justify one act
	with charging $20 at a NIGHTCLUB.

	The guy at the door said "its $20. Its Organic".

	So we went to Spiral Jive in the park and it was awesome.
	Gorgeous weather. Great sound/music. And some guy brought a 
	gorgeous Great Dane that I got to play with.

From sfraves-owner  Sun Apr 24 17:01:30 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA05472; Sun, 24 Apr 94 17:01:30 PDT
Received: from hamlet.ucdavis.edu by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA05465; Sun, 24 Apr 94 17:01:24 PDT
Received: by hamlet.ucdavis.edu (8.6.8/UCD2.50)
	id QAA00921; Sun, 24 Apr 1994 16:50:07 -0700
Date: Sun, 24 Apr 1994 16:50:05 -0700 (PDT)
From: THE Mike <ez040312@hamlet.ucdavis.edu>
Subject: My first...?
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9404241656.A29708-0100000@hamlet.ucdavis.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


This may be long, I don't know right now, so you might want to save this 
for later.

I don't know, but have the people in the "scene" changed? I went to 
Contact in Sac. last night and it was fun and all, but there were not 
many people dancing for any amount of time.  There seemed to be people 
from the Mexican Mafia (no, not really, but just the stereotypical look 
of that particular group of people--don't flame me, this isn't racist, 
I'm Mexican too.) 

It's really hard to go out and dance when you're a big guy like me when 
almost everyone else is sitting/standing around looking at you. Maybe the 
Sacramento scene isn't as close and friendly as it was back in SLO. I 
don't know, except that Contact was my first technoey/housey club that 
I've gone to since I moved here in August, LAST YEAR!

Now,  enough of the griping.  Contact was held in a small cafe type 
place. The dance floor was good enough for the amount of people that were 
there. One thing though, the visual stand (or whatever it's called) sort 
of was just there in the middle and it chopped about 1/3 of the dance 
floor off.  It was difficult to dance around it too because I'm very 
conscious of other people's stuff and I didn't want to hit it or 
anything, causing things to break.

The visuals were cool. That's about as much as I can say about it. They 
had projections of hindu god sculptures and people running after a car, 
all the time with different color gels sweeping across them.  

The music was really good. Some of it I'd even heard before. (I love 
singing along with the music--especially when others can't hear me above 
the speakers.) The house music got a little old with the 
thump-thump-thump always being around the same bpm.

As for the security and such, they were very nice about some things. In's 
and out's were allowed, they didn't check my backpack (although that 
could be dangerous around Oak Park and such--if the rumors are true of 
what I've heard about it, including some stories from a resident that I'm 
friends with.)  You could bring in your own water, and I had brought in 
some Gatoraid, which got warm, and the bartender even put ice in it for 
me! He really was a nice guy. Water was free, but I think that it should 
have been served in plastic cups instead of glass. Glass can be pretty 
dangerous you know? :)  They had beer and such for the 21+ crowd--the 
crowd that I'm not a member of yet....They had candy sales: blow pops, 
and others, I thought that was pretty groovin'.

Alll in all, I think that with some more variety in the music styles and 
more promotion, that place can go off pretty well, considering Sacramento 
has it in them.

Check it out, if you can.

Mike	<masolis@hamlet.ucdavis.edu>    >thE musiC oF choicE<
	<hula@deeptht.armory.com>       >iS iN thE voicE<

On Tue, 19 Apr 1994, ethan miller wrote:

> Long before I had a sound system or thought of being a dj I used to go out
> to parties every week and bring a table, a blacklight and neon body paints.
> I never met a promoter that wouldn't let me in free. I'd set up the paints,
> hang out while it was still early, meet people, talk, joke, help out etc.
> After a while I'd leave the paints and go dance. Every once and a while I'd
> come back and clean up a little, refill the paint saucers and then go dance
> some more. People loved the paints. I remember at the first Imagination at
> Townsend/King St. I came back at 6am and these two people who were just
> *lit* had been sitting there for hours painting each other. They both had
> full-body, neon tribal work of astonishing complexity. Wow.
> 
> I remember knowing then, quite clearly, that my *active* particapatory
> positive energy was an absolutely essential ingredient in any party I
> happened to be at, that a good party was something we all had to build
> together, that *any* party could be a great one if everyone there took
> responsibility for making it one. Nobody dances until someone dances. Faces
> are mail reflectors; smile and the world smiles with you.
> 
> I think I'm only recently realising that I got bored of 'consuming' raves a
> long time ago. I think I started throwing parties, doing sound, dj-ing,
> etc. because it *ensured*, for me, a particpatory experience. And, in
> truth, I have the best times at the small (often *very* small;) parties
> that we do together.
> 
> sfraves is something very, very special. I won't try and define it. We all
> love it for our very own and exactly the same reasons. It is a community,
> it gives meaning.
> 
> In The Light is yet another chance for us to do it our way, to make it mean
> something. May 28th lets get *together* and put a sonic dent in the fucking
> universe. 
> 
> (That's the cool thing about sound you know, it just keeps on goin.)

Dear sfravefriends,
     Ethan's message is so right-on!  I'm replying here partly so 
everyone who maybe skimmed over it will get a chance to take a second 
look and really think about what he's saying...
     I'm sure everyone has heard this before, but building positive 
energy is what it's all about, and it is frighteningly easy to lapse back 
into a mode of being where we are not truly spreading joy at parties, 
where we are inhibited and afraid to be too nonconformist, reluctant to 
let go and be as happy as we can be.
     Whatever talents you have, whatever you can bring to the raves you 
attend, do it!  Don't be inhibited by others lack of creativity -- your 
efforts will inspire them, and build a better scene for us all.
     Peace, Love & Strawberry Lollipops,
 
                            *** Starchild! ***

re "christian ravers" ... AKA the "jesus army" ?  Come on, we all know what 
the score is, regurgitated religion already. I mean 2000 years of 
oppressive mentalies ain`t enough for you, so now you got to `infiltrate` 
dance music and the cultute it spawns? Yes I do say "infiltrate", because 
thats exactly what it is, classic tactics though, subdue the anarchist 
pagan earth cults by adopting their customs dressed down for the 
spiritually illiterate and then claim all those nasty ravers are spoiling 
it for the rest of us by taking drugs, playing to loud, having parties 
without `proper authorisation`, acting heathen already...pretty soon we 
all be dancing to the tune of that patriarchal capatilist bullshit, you 
know the "love your father, cause if you don`t  he`ll whomp you with his 
mighty sword already" (and as people living in the post fruedian age we 
can all take a stab as to what `sword` symbolically represents. We need 
christian ravers like Rodney King needs police protection.  The whole 
point of taking drugs (and, yes therein potentially fucking our heads 
up), dancing all night (yes it is so short term, but I gotta wake up to 
the sanitised denatured husk of an environment thats been left to us by 
the concept of "man" as gods "central" creation) and listening to devil 
mucic real loud, and then maybe I can obliterate the conditioned me that 
has been brought up to think that I have to be thankful for my existance 
to those who claim they have the ear and the voice of god.  Christian 
beebop...pah. > > 

               THREE (Club Dog UK)

On Sat, 23 Apr 1994, JUMP IN THE FIRE wrote:

> Date: Sat, 23 Apr 1994 19:43:06 -0700 (PDT)
> From: JUMP IN THE FIRE <grigsby@agames.com>
> To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
> Subject: Raving or Naving: a choice?
> 
> 
> 	After considering the long spiel containing some of Matthew Fox's
> beliefs, I found the source of my discontent in cognitive dissonance.
> 
> 	Fox's message is contradictory at best and deceitful at worst.
> Either he doesn't believe at all in Christianity and is trying to
> reach a wider audience by calling himself a priest of their cult, or
> he's trying to bring those rebellious young'uns back into the fold
> through gradual indoctrination, or possibly both.
> 
> 	Anyone seduced by his images will eventually be confronted by
> a basic dilemma, to wit: "If we are all God, then what makes Christ
> special?  Why would he die for the sins of those equal to he?
> Furthermore, why should I, as God, give a shit anyway?  For if I am
> God, there can be none sitting in judgement above me, and I should
> fear no judgement but my own."

Although I don't endorse Matthew Fox's theology--there is something about 
him and it that doesn't sit right with me, call it intuition--his 
apparent statement that "we are all God" is not necessarily irreconcilable 
with the statement that Christ is the son of God.  According to the 
Bible, once someone is born again he or she is instilled with the Holy 
Spirit.  This spirit is part of the trinity--God in man, as opposed to 
Jesus, who was God as man.  Consequently, we are a part of God, but we 
are not God per se.


> 
> 	At some point, we all have to make a choice: do you believe in
> the Cosmic Patriarchy, or do you believe in being a master without slaves?
> Do you act according to the rules of the Cosmic Patriarchy in hopes of
> getting a gold sticker by your name in the Book of Life, or do you make
> your own decisions and accept the joy (and pain) of their consequences?
> Is your life based on the fear of reprisal or the joy of existence?
> 
> "Give up on life after birth
>  for life after death?
>  It's a hard choice.
>  Don't blow it."
> 		-Sperry
> 
> "The fence is not a comfortable seat." -me
> 
> // g
>

from my first posting on many different areas from the NET.  Sooo.  I suppose
I may make this a habit if interest keeps up.  Good habit I think! He!

about happenings here in the Midwest lemme know, especially ST. Louis,
Chicago, Milwaukie, and Detroit.
Heres my update:

_________________________________________________
Dallas - April 23rd - Hazy Daze & Groove Kitchen (SF) with DJs Ernie Munson -
John Howard - Darkhorse (SF) - Robert Taylor - Cle - and Rob Vaughan
INFO 214-522-4674 or 214-682-9022

outside of Dallas.  The sound was great, and Ernie Munsen (SF) John Howard
(SF) kicked hard.  Wow!  First time to hear them and it won't be the last. 
These boys have gotta come back!

definately kick! He!)

JaJo from St. Louis. Outside at the CompleX 10-10 (no earlier! but maybe
later!)  Film and Video will be MORE than abundant by myself, ZERO, and

From sfraves-owner  Mon Apr 25 10:07:04 1994

Received: from nexsys.nexsys.net by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA18449; Mon, 25 Apr 94 10:06:54 PDT
Received: from localhost by nexsys.nexsys.net (8.6.5/SM-8.6.4)
	id KAA17891; Mon, 25 Apr 1994 10:04:59 -0700
Date: Mon, 25 Apr 1994 10:04:59 -0700
From: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White)
Message-Id: <199404251704.KAA17891@nexsys.nexsys.net>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: No rest for the Wicked
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU



The party was going to be at 1015? Really? But isn`t Martini's
happening there? Yes and yes, I was told.  When I got there with my
friend, Ali, there was already a line out of the side door, it seemed
that WICKED was to go on in the basement while Martini's would carry on
up stairs.  Strange but it seemed to work, Martini's is, as someone
posted a while back, "all about scammin" and the energy was thick,
still alot of the regular Martini party goers became curious about this
"seperate party" (which they couldn't go to unless they got a stamp,
which I'm sure they had to pay extra for). People always want something
even more if you tell them they can't have it.  The WICKED party was
your standard sweaty e-pit type WICKED, in the basement, hot,
smokey,steamy, sexy and killer music.  When I got there at about 1:00,
Bones was going off on the decks, warming the crowd up (as if it needed
it).  I ran into jsl and complained to him about the temperature in the
basement, he made a very prophetic statement when he said something
like "It don't matter, the true believers will all be down there before
the night is over" Markie took control around 3:00, and proceeded to
slam it.  It was hot and smokey which seriously interfears with my
ability to dance, but I went for it anyway, as I looked around, I saw a
lot of "old-skool" in the house, people I haven't seen in months, some
of the Martini's crowd would filter in, most couldn't stand the heat
and left but a few remained... to have their minds blown open.  I must
say that the smile factor was high but the craker-jack factor was even
higher (can I get a witness jsl? )  Markie had muthafuckers jumpin and
screamin and carrying on in 100 deg. heat.  I would periodically go
upstairs to get air, you know I have a great idea, instead of selling
hits of nitrous at these hot basement wickeds, why not sell hits of
oxygen?  I know I'd buy a balloon :) Anyway by 4:30 am the place was
"out of control" when I saw Jeno push through the crown and open his
crates, jsl and I looked at each other, we both knew what was about to
happen, I said "Aw shit, here we go", Jeno was _relentless_ it is
definitely the best set I've heard him play all summer, (I hear he's
been practicing and it shows) I had a feeling that he would have to
bust it open _way_ past Markie and I'm glad Markie set the marker way
up high so he really had to go for it, and go for it he did! Even in
the heat, "old-skool" was in the back tranced out, doing flips, twirls,
summersaults,and floor dives :) It was so intense that some folks
couldn't take it any more and had to take their asses home :) (Can I
get another witness jsl? :).  But in the end John you were right the
true believers did wind up in that basement in the morning.

Oh I forgot about my episode with Sgt.Buchard, the one man raver hating
task force.  This guy has been hassling south of market clubs for the
last year or so, he really has it in for WICKED, I'm upstairs at the moment
trying to deal with a kid that has taken one hit too many and is screaming
"help me, sombody help me" at the top of his lungs.  I had to move him out of
the stimulus of the basement (which was a trip in it's self) almost getting
in a fight with a "gangsta" (I guess my overwhelming size _is_ an asset,
this guy pushes the dosed raver real hard as I'm trying to get him through the
crowd, I kinda loose my kool and tell him to get out of the way, "gangsta"
stands there being kool, then the Brooklyn blood wells up in me and I yell
"Step the FUCK back, NOW!" Gangsta says "fuck you" but he gets out of my way.
We sit the guy down in the hall way, he is still screaming, finally I give
him some rescue remedy (a bach flower remedy, sorta like a homeopathic 
remedy) and he begins to calm down, just then Buchard comes through the door,
I say OH shit, the last thing WICKED needs is for this asshole cop to find a
kid out of him mind dosed, so I bust-myself of any contra-band that I might have
been carrying and step to him.  He engauges me immediately (which is what I 
wanted) and starts asking me my name, I tell him John :) "John what"
"John Waters", OK where do you live John, "Why do you want to know? Are you 
gonna come visit me big boy? (Straight cops _hate_ gay male energy, it makes 
them uncomfortable, and when they are uncomfortable, YOU have the upperhand,
(I don't mind being queen for a day :).  "Well what's your phone number"
I say "I don't have to tell you that, we haven't even met yet, , What's your 
name?" He says "Sgt. Buchard, let me ask you, why did you come here tonight?
Do you work here?" I say "No, I'm a patron, I've come to dance and have a good
time, why did you come here?" He says " I'm here to make sure that these people
have their permits in order and.." I cut in "OH I heard about that, but didn't
a federal judge put a restraining order on the city of san francisco? Something
about civil rights violations?" He says "Yeah, well I gotta go John" and out the
door he goes. Shit, a very psychicly draining experience.  It totally blew
my high and it took the best part of Jeno's set to restore my vibe factor,
still mission accomplished I guess.  As I said, thanks Sean for posting that
tid bit of info, it really came in handy.

From sfraves-owner  Mon Apr 25 10:34:09 1994

From: alves@bethe.ucdavis.edu (David Alves)
Message-Id: <9404251734.AA19855@bethe.ucdavis.edu>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: Raving or Naving ...
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


Well, to the dismay of everyone sick of the bible-raving thread I
am inclined to comment again.  Let me preface this with the following:
there have been only a few posts expressing discomfort or disatisfaction
with Mathew Fox's proposed rave mass.  I share this discomfort.
I believe it is part anti-drug crusading and partly a move to embrace 
young, hip, christian kids (i.e. give them "cooler" church dances).

( the words of //g )
> ... I found the source of my discontent in cognitive dissonance.
> ...  he's trying to bring those rebellious young'uns back into the fold
> through gradual indoctrination, or possibly both.

He is preaching to the converted - let him be.  If he starts sending
out missionaries to other raves who are spreading "the word" then
I would be concerned.  This type of behavior could easily cause some
people to feel guilty or angry and could trigger "bad trips".

> "If we are all God, then what makes Christ special ...

Here is my interpretation.  Christ is an ideal.  He is an abstraction.
A model of perfection provided to those who want such a model to guide
them in their lives.  Like in a dog show - the dogs don't compete
against each other but against the Kennel Association's description of
the perfect dog.  It seems to work for some people.

>	At some point, we all have to make a choice ...
> Is your life based on the fear of reprisal or the joy of existence?

Although words like "fear of reprisal" seem crazy to many of us.  We
have to hope and trust that it is not the same literal fear that motivates
the KKK and other hate mongers.  I still think that there are decent
Christians who believe deeply in those words in a way that I don't
understand or care to.  I try and be happy for their happiness.  Period.

Please keep any reponses rave-related and short or else send it just
to me.  Thanks.

Dave

THE HACKER TEST - Version 1.0
 
Preface:  06.16.89
 
This test was conceived and written by Felix Lee, John Hayes and Angela
Thomas at the end of the spring semester, 1989.  It has gone through
many revisions prior to this initial release, and will undoubtedly go
through many more.
 
 
(Herewith a compendium of fact and folklore about computer hackerdom,
cunningly disguised as a test.)
 
 
Scoring - Count 1 for each item that you have done, or each
question that you can answer correctly.
 
 
If you score is between:                    You are
 
0x000 and 0x010       ->         Computer Illiterate
0x011 and 0x040       ->         a User
0x041 and 0x080       ->         an Operator
0x081 and 0x0C0       ->         a Nerd
0x0C1 and 0x100       ->         a Hacker
0x101 and 0x180       ->         a Guru
0x181 and 0x200       ->         a Wizard
 
Note: If you don't understand the scoring, stop here.
 
 
And now for the questions...
 
 
0001 Have you ever used a computer?
0002 ... for more than 4 hours continuously?
0003 ... more than 8 hours?
0004 ... more than 16 hours?
0005 ... more than 32 hours?
 
0006 Have you ever patched paper tape?
 
0007 Have you ever missed a class while programming?
0008 ... Missed an examination?
0009 ... Missed a wedding?
0010 ... Missed your own wedding?
 
0011 Have you ever programmed while intoxicated?
0012 ... Did it make sense the next day?
 
0013 Have you ever written a flight simulator?
 
0014 Have you ever voided the warranty on your equipment?
 
0015 Ever change the value of 4?
0016 ... Unintentionally?
0017 ... In a language other than Fortran?
 
0018 Do you use DWIM to make life interesting?
 
0019 Have you named a computer?
 
0020 Do you complain when a "feature" you use gets fixed?
 
0021 Do you eat slime-molds?
 
0022 Do you know how many days old you are?
 
0023 Have you ever wanted to download pizza?
 
0024 Have you ever invented a computer joke?
0025 ... Did someone not 'get' it?
 
0026 Can you recite Jabberwocky?
0027 ... Backwards?
 
0028 Have you seen "Donald Duck in Mathemagic Land"?
 
0029 Have you seen "Tron"?
 
0030 Have you seen "Wargames"?
 
0031 Do you know what ASCII stands for?
0032 ... EBCDIC?
 
0033 Can you read and write ASCII in hex or octal?
0034 Do you know the names of all the ASCII control codes?
 
0035 Can you read and write EBCDIC in hex?
 
0036 Can you convert from EBCDIC to ASCII and vice versa?
 
0037 Do you know what characters are the same in both ASCII and EBCDIC?
 
0038 Do you know maxint on your system?
 
0039 Ever define your own numerical type to get better precision?
 
0040 Can you name powers of two up to 2**16 in arbitrary order?
0041 ... up to 2**32?
0042 ... up to 2**64?
 
0043 Can you read a punched card, looking at the holes?
0044 ... feeling the holes?
 
0045 Have you ever patched binary code?
0046 ... While the program was running?
 
0047 Have you ever used program overlays?
 
0048 Have you met any IBM vice-president?
0049 Do you know Dennis, Bill, or Ken?
 
0050 Have you ever taken a picture of a CRT?
0051 Have you ever played a videotape on your CRT?
 
0052 Have you ever digitized a picture?
 
0053 Did you ever forget to mount a scratch monkey?
 
0054 Have you ever optimized an idle loop?
 
0055 Did you ever optimize a bubble sort?
 
0056 Does your terminal/computer talk to you?
 
0057 Have you ever talked into an acoustic modem?
0058 ... Did it answer?
 
0059 Can you whistle 300 baud?
0060 ... 1200 baud?
 
0061 Can you whistle a telephone number?
 
0062 Have you witnessed a disk crash?
0063 Have you made a disk drive "walk"?
 
0064 Can you build a puffer train?
0065 ... Do you know what it is?
 
0066 Can you play music on your line printer?
0067 ... Your disk drive?
0068 ... Your tape drive?
 
0069 Do you have a Snoopy calendar?
0070 ... Is it out-of-date?
 
0071 Do you have a line printer picture of...
0072 ... the Mona Lisa?
0073 ... the Enterprise?
0074 ... Einstein?
0075 ... Oliver?
0076 Have you ever made a line printer picture?
 
0077 Do you know what the following stand for?
0078 ... DASD
0079 ... Emacs
0080 ... ITS
0081 ... RSTS/E
0082 ... SNA
0083 ... Spool
0084 ... TCP/IP
 
Have you ever used
0085 ... TPU?
0086 ... TECO?
0087 ... Emacs?
0088 ... ed?
0089 ... vi?
0090 ... Xedit (in VM/CMS)?
0091 ... SOS?
0092 ... EDT?
0093 ... Wordstar?
 
0094 Have you ever written a CLIST?
 
Have you ever programmed in
0095 ... the X windowing system?
0096 ... CICS?
 
0097 Have you ever received a Fax or a photocopy of a floppy?
 
0098 Have you ever shown a novice the "any" key?
0099 ... Was it the power switch?
 
Have you ever attended
0100 ... Usenix?
0101 ... DECUS?
0102 ... SHARE?
0103 ... SIGGRAPH?
0104 ... NetCon?
 
0105 Have you ever participated in a standards group?
 
0106 Have you ever debugged machine code over the telephone?
 
0107 Have you ever seen voice mail?
0108 ... Can you read it?
 
0109 Do you solve word puzzles with an on-line dictionary?
 
0110 Have you ever taken a Turing test?
0111 ... Did you fail?
 
0112 Ever drop a card deck?
0113 ... Did you successfully put it back together?
0114 ... Without looking?
 
0115 Have you ever used IPCS?
 
0116 Have you ever received a case of beer with your computer?
 
0117 Does your computer come in 'designer' colors?
 
0118 Ever interrupted a UPS?
 
0119 Ever mask an NMI?
 
0120 Have you ever set off a Halon system?
0121 ... Intentionally?
0122 ... Do you still work there?
 
0123 Have you ever hit the emergency power switch?
0124 ... Intentionally?
 
0125 Do you have any defunct documentation?
0126 ... Do you still read it?
 
0127 Ever reverse-engineer or decompile a program?
0128 ... Did you find bugs in it?
 
0129 Ever help the person behind the counter with their terminal/computer?
 
0130 Ever tried rack mounting your telephone?
 
0131 Ever thrown a computer from more than two stories high?
 
0132 Ever patched a bug the vendor does not acknowledge?
 
0133 Ever fix a hardware problem in software?
0134 ... Vice versa?
 
0135 Ever belong to a user/support group?
 
0136 Ever been mentioned in Computer Recreations?
 
0137 Ever had your activities mentioned in the newspaper?
0138 ... Did you get away with it?
 
0139 Ever engage a drum brake while the drum was spinning?
 
0140 Ever write comments in a non-native language?
 
0141 Ever physically destroy equipment from software?
 
0142 Ever tried to improve your score on the Hacker Test?
 
0143 Do you take listings with you to lunch?
0144 ... To bed?
 
0145 Ever patch a microcode bug?
0146 ... around a microcode bug?
 
0147 Can you program a Turing machine?
 
0148 Can you convert postfix to prefix in your head?
 
0149 Can you convert hex to octal in your head?
 
0150 Do you know how to use a Kleene star?
 
0151 Have you ever starved while dining with philosophers?
 
0152 Have you solved the halting problem?
0153 ... Correctly?
 
0154 Ever deadlock trying eating spaghetti?
 
0155 Ever written a self-reproducing program?
 
0156 Ever swapped out the swapper?
 
0157 Can you read a state diagram?
0158 ... Do you need one?
 
0159 Ever create an unkillable program?
0160 ... Intentionally?
 
0161 Ever been asked for a cookie?
 
0162 Ever speed up a system by removing a jumper?
 
* Do you know...
 
0163 Do you know who wrote Rogue?

0166 Do you know what HCF means?
0167 ... Ever use it?
0168 ... Intentionally?
 
0169 Do you know what a lace card is?
0170 ... Ever make one?

0172 ... Have you celebrated the end of an epoch?
0173 ... Did you have to rewrite code?

0176 ... Can you wire a connector without looking?
 
* Do you have...

0206 ... Is it legal?

0210 Do you use more than 16 megabytes of disk space?
0211 ... 256 megabytes?
0212 ... 1 gigabyte?
0213 ... 16 gigabytes?
0214 ... 256 gigabytes?
0215 ... 1 terabyte?
 
0216 Do you have an optical disk/disk drive?
 
0217 Do you have a personal magnetic tape library?
0218 ... Is it unlabelled?
 
0219 Do you own more than 16 floppy disks?
0220 ... 64 floppy disks?
0221 ... 256 floppy disks?
0222 ... 1024 floppy disks?
 
0223 Do you have any 8-inch disks?
 
0224 Do you have an internal stack?
 
0225 Do you have a clock interrupt?
 
0226 Do you own volumes 1 to 3 of _The Art of Computer Programming_?
0227 ... Have you done all the exercises?
0228 ... Do you have a MIX simulator?
0229 ... Can you name the unwritten volumes?

0231 ... Did you participate in the OS/360 project?

0233 Do you have printouts more than three years old?
 
* Career

0462 Have you ever written self-modifying code?
0463 ... Are you proud of it?
 
0464 Did you ever write a program that ran correctly the first time?
0465 ... Was it longer than 20 lines?
0466 ... 100 lines?
0467 ... Was it in assembly language?
0468 ... Did it work the second time?
 
0469 Can you solve the Towers of Hanoi recursively?
0470 ... Non-recursively?
0471 ... Using the Troff text formatter?
 
0472 Ever submit an entry to the Obfuscated C code contest?
0473 ... Did it win?
0474 ... Did your entry inspire a new rule?
 
0475 Do you know Duff's device?
 
0476 Do you know Jensen's device?
 
0477 Ever spend ten minutes trying to find a single-character error?
0478 ... More than an hour?
0479 ... More than a day?
0480 ... More than a week?
0481 ... Did the first person you show it to find it immediately?
 
* Unix
 
0482 Can you use Berkeley Unix?
0483 .. Non-Berkeley Unix?
 
0484 Can you distinguish between sections 4 and 5 of the Unix manual?
 
0485 Can you find TERMIO in the System V release 2 documentation?
 
0486 Have you ever mounted a tape as a Unix file system?
 
0487 Have you ever built Minix?
 
0488 Can you answer "quiz function ed-command" correctly?
0489 ... How about "quiz ed-command function"?
 
* Usenet
 
0490 Do you read news?
0491 ... More than 32 newsgroups?
0492 ... More than 256 newsgroups?
0493 ... All the newsgroups?
 
0494 Have you ever posted an article?
0495 ... Do you post regularly?
 
0496 Have you ever posted a flame?
0497 ... Ever flame a cross-posting?
0498 ... Ever flame a flame?
0499 ... Do you flame regularly?
 
0500 Ever have your program posted to a source newsgroup?
 
0501 Ever forge a posting?
0502 Ever form a new newsgroup?
0503 ... Does it still exist?
 
0504 Do you remember
0505 ... mod.ber?
0506 ... the Stupid People's Court?
0507 ... Bandy-grams?
 
* Phreaking
 
0508 Have you ever built a black box?
 
0509 Can you name all of the 'colors' of boxes?
0510 ... and their associated functions?
 
0511 Does your touch tone phone have 16 DTMF buttons on it?
 
0512 Did the breakup of MaBell create more opportunities for you?

Actually, events have been $20 at the Troc since I can remember.  When they
had the best club sound system I've *ever* heard, 15 months ago, it almost
seemed worth it.  I bet Organic had to pay an enormous rental for the place.
The lack of medium-sized indoor spaces is beginning to constrict the scene
severely.  Not a single new one seems to have become reliably available
in the last year in the Bay Area, at least that I know of.

Date: Mon, 25 Apr 1994 11:33:33 -0700
In-Reply-To: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White)
        ""Rave" Not an Effective (or Meaningful) Counter-Culture Movement" (Apr 24, 11:45am)
References: <199404241845.LAA16616@nexsys.nexsys.net>
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.0.0 15dec93)
To: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White), sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: "Rave" Not an Effective (or Meaningful) Counter-Culture Movement
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Mime-Version: 1.0
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Jamal Hannah's opinion that raving is not 'progressive' because it relies
on technology produced by the same system that oppresses us is the same
old tired academic-left argument which misunderstands what Marx wrote
about the relationship between technology and capital.  Consider that
the computer he -- and we -- use to write and read these messages are
far more closely allied with the post-World War II technologies of
nuclear weapons, guidance systems, COMINT and all the other military
and commercial electronic technology that is in use, than the turntables,
loudspeakers and vinyl-cutting and pressing machines that are the 
technological backbone of musical events.  Contradictions, contradictions :)

Hakim Bey had some very canny things to say about the technology/capital
relationship, and I wish Hannah had taken them into account.  But even his
radical critique of social relations mediated by technology, and the
counter-efforts to subvert/transform those relations -- for example, by
redirecting their intent and use in the T.A.Z. -- is hardly a new thought.

Emma Goldman said it best (and many remember this quote even though they
know little of her own efforts otherwise):

If I can't dance, I won't be part of your revolution!

From sfraves-owner  Mon Apr 25 11:47:40 1994

	id AA20356; Mon, 25 Apr 94 11:47:40 PDT

From: brycer@netcom.com (Bryce Ryan)

Subject: A (Long) Weekend
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Mon, 25 Apr 1994 11:48:58 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]

Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Greetings, Ravers!

Sorry for the disappointment of no Launch Pad.  We've decided to take
a rain check <groan> to Saturday, May 21st.  In preparation for Launch
Pad, I got to go out and promote at a number of different parties
from Thursday through Sunday, so I thought I would share my impressions.

On thursday night, i stopped in to Pure Space at the DNA. $5, and a party
put on by Donovan.  Spinning were Spun, Josh, and Markie.  I heard
the tail end of Jason's set, and the first 2/3 of Josh' set, which
were both quite good.  The sound system is a little peculiar at DNA,
and completely lacked any focus, but there _was_ sound everywhere,
since there were speakers everywhere (it seemed).  Lots of old and
familiar faces there.  A fine party that seems to have a bright
future.

Friday, I visited Apocalypse at the Haze, to visit with DRC.  Unfortunately,
I had my ears blown out again, and so I'm going to swear off the Haze
for a while, or always take earplugs, or both. Sigh.  I wandered over
to 1015 to check out Wicked.  I always hang out outside at 1015 to check
the vibe before I go in.  This time, I decided *not* to go in, since
two people who i know well (and who know me) completely ignored my
screaming in their ears.  Plus, i got to witness several people being
abused and ignored at the line for the plebians.  Sigh. just another party
at 1015.

Saturday, after much sturm und drang over Launch Pad, i eventually popped
out to Spiral Jive.  These folks have a good sound system (phuq all loud
enough), are good DJs, and have a fine location.  I got to visit with
some friends and hear some fine tunes, well mixed, and get my renegade
fix that i had been jonesing for.  Check out this party some time.

Sunday, at phred's recommendation, and my own desire to visit the Tofu
BBQ and Ambient Party, i stopped in to Ameba's.  This is a fine get-
together hosted by Allen.  I highly recommend stopping in to visit with
Allen and the crew for a tofu burger, barbequed garlic, a yam perhaps,
and some fine tunes, all in the outdoors.  i spun a bit of ambient,
got to listen to Adam from SD as well as Galen and phred.  love this
party, and loved the energy.  Brycer says: check it out.

Well, that's that.  See you all soon, i hope!
-- 
Bryce Ryan ------- AMBIANCE ----------- brycer@netcom.com-----
"We have a problem. Too many of you know who we are."  AMI
Semiconductor ad copy

From sfraves-owner  Mon Apr 25 12:04:47 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA20821; Mon, 25 Apr 94 12:04:47 PDT
Received: from netcom.com (netcom3.netcom.com) by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA20812; Mon, 25 Apr 94 12:04:39 PDT
Received: from DialupEudora by netcom.com (8.6.8.1/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id MAA06645; Mon, 25 Apr 1994 12:05:53 -0700
Message-Id: <199404251905.MAA06645@netcom.com>
X-Sender: nrg@localhost
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Mon, 25 Apr 1994 12:09:23 -0800
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
From: nrg@netcom.com (ethan miller)
Subject: Recent Thoughts
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Greetings Friends!

Well, I've got a lot of ground to cover so get a cup of coffee and 
settle in :)

First off Launch Pad:
Really sorry this one didn't happen as planned (a first for us!) but my
take on the situation (and others, though not all involved) was that rain
was an easy possibility in addition to which the wind was positively
howling and the air temp was the coldest I've felt since winter proper.
I've been at this site (for our parties) numerous times when it was
brutally cold. The usual scenario is that all our friends and often others
show up to support us, get driven away by the cold around 2ish, and ten or
so of us dance as hard as possible for the rest of the night to keep from
dying;) I'm still concinced that, as much as I love playing to/with my
friends (especially on my system ;) parties need people. In retrospect I
think the correct decision was made. Most of you that I've talked to since
concurr. However let me add this: this party would have gone *off*. I
bumped into people on the street that were planning on going, I know lots
of you were planning on going, people I barely know--that I have know idea
how they found out--were calling me, etc. I think 100-150 is a very
accurate estimate of the nights potential. So anyway, weather permitting,
(!-!) we *will* do this party on Saturday May 21, so mark your calendar and
save up that good energy!

Spiral Jive:
Allright I'm gonna put this right on the table, and allen I'm sorry, but
you're the one that made it a *public* issue. It really pissed me off that
allen raised the issue of joining parties publicly instead of asking us how
we felt about it first. Obviously everyone would think it was a good idea
so in truth he was forcing us to accomodate SJ lest we look like dicks
which, as you can see, I feel would have been a very unfair assesment. For
at least this reason: In trying to set up a schedule for djs that would
give them at least enough time to find some kind of a groove, we
necessarily said yes to some and no to other very close friends (and sfr
djs) of ours. Why should we say no to them (who've worked with us and
supported us for a long time now, asked for slots, etc., etc.) and then
suddenly accomodate some other folks who just happened to be throwing a
party that night as well, especially considering the fact that they've been
doing parties almost every week. On any night, especially this summer,
there's gonna be lots of parties. What would've happened if we'd called
Organic and said: Hey, we're doin a party too, why don't you give our djs a
couple of slots and we'll join forces?
Which brings me to my next point.

Organic:
When allen said he was concerned about LP 'going up against' Organic (and
SJ) I basically replied (about organic): Fuck those scum sucking, plastic
palm tree, commerical $20 shitheads; they're almost the whole reason for
doing a renegade! And in indeed that reaction is one I tend towards easily.

Us and *Them* (generally, as opposed to organic or SJ):
After we decided to cancel LP I fell into a very dark mood. I started
wondering if by voting no on the party I was getting weak in my old age ;)
if I was getting jaded, lazy, complacent; if I had let you, and bryce, and
everybody else that was planning on coming down. As the rain resumed
falling and it got colder I grew a little more comfortable with that
decision but I also found myself bothered by my own awareness of the
emotional severity of my reaction to both Organic and the SJ collaborative
issue. So after some thought, I decided that, like it or not, I'd fallen
prey to the exact cliquishness, posseishness, us/them-ness that is really
chopping this scene up. More often than not it's easy to dress this up and
rationalize it, saying for instance; they're killing this scene by throwing
$20 parties, by only ever playing *their* djs, by always using the same
stupid nightclub, blah, blah, blah. There's a fine line between being an
astute consumer and applying the only leverage consumers have: not
consuming and--content in the knowledge that, 'only *we* know how to do it
right'--giving up on everything else cos 'it all sucks.' 

So I decided to just go out and give organic a chance. Ronan came over, we
played some records, went to Organic, got absolutely twisted and had a
really excellent time. I still feel that $20 is outrageous for any party at
the Trocadero but then again seing any band at the coliseum (yucchh!) would
cost ya $30+ for a three hour show so....In any event, all the djs were
excellent. Jeno went totally mad, playing *yes, it's true* very deep techno
trancy stuff, some nice hard acid and even a couple of my favorite choons
from my crate, Robert Armani stuff for instance. Unfortunately half the
sound system died during his set (for about an hour), which totally pissed
him off, but otherwise was the best big sound I've heard in a while. Tony
was brilliant, Graeme was great, DJ Dan impressed me and Markie went deep
on a *very experimental* tip early in the morning. I think he was playing
new material blind cos he was train wrecking all over the place, but the
music itself was just weird and twisted, right up my alley. He finally
settled down a bit and we ended the party with daylight filling the place,
little groups of people sitting, talking, tons of room on the dancefloor
with like twenty people just going mad! Jumping up and down, bouncing off
the walls, jogging leaping, cartwheeling. Best pure out dance release I've
had in a while. Viusally lots of hype and glitz. Big light show, dayglow
dancers prancing and dancing all night. Pink, green, purple, glow in the
dark, blobby "Organic" custom dj booth, and the ever amazing Make Mattel
banners. His banners are going down in history, he's an absolute genius.
I'm sure they'll be worth million some day. 

So if you feel like paying a premium for production values there's always
Organic. So how do I feel about that? Well, yesterday while talking with
Matt Fox (I'm gonna let that settle for a while before I post) we were all
kinda railing agaisnt the specifics of christianity and Bob Jesse asked the
question (and I paraphrase here): Religions are like lifeforms evolving
thru time, christianity is one of these. Do we really want it gone, dead,
extinct or, despite the fact the some of us detest it, does it nonetheless
have some value to the world? I would ask the same about Organic or any of
the 'biggies'. The economies of scale and associated risk seem to determine
that massives will remain in the $15-$20 range. So, is it over? Do we just
want small posse-related renegades? When I first got into this there were 4
$20 parties with lasers every weekend. I went, though I didn't often pay,
and more often than not I found what I wanted there: smiles, warmth,
massive sound, nifty visuals, release. People, maybe not us of late, are
still finding these things at raves. Do we want them gone? I don't know.

Sometimes it's awfully lonely being right.

peace always
ethan


                                _______ 
 ethan miller                     nrg                            pgp me   
_________________________ 'one unbroken whole' _________________________   
                         
                (: positive energy can save the world :)
               __________________________________________

Subject: Re: Radio Show
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Geoff comments in reference to Adam Curry's post about bringing a European
techno show to US radio markets:

>Uh-oh, here we go folks...

And what do you mean by that?  I happened to have talked to Adam about
this last night.  His aim is to bring techno/trance/progressive (as
in progressive house) music to radio in the US.  

Right now the best we have on "alternative" commercial radio is Steve 
Master's TACKY mix show on Live 105.  Masters plays bad tracks (i.e. 
Messiah's latest, "Thunderdome") the WORST mixes of tracks (i.e. the 
butchered breaky/diva mix of "Kinetic"), and plays stuff that is at 
least a year old (he finally played "Gravitational Arch of 10" three 
weeks ago, and I first bought it over a year ago.)

Sure, college stations often have good shows but I can't get any of
the good stations at my house or in my car.

So, if Curry's thing works, that would be good!  It's bound to be
better than the "Modern Mix" on Friday nights.  And if it doesn't work, 
then it certainly won't hurt us.

By the way, Adam also told us (we were on vrave at the time) that he
has quit his job at MTV, and is in the process of changing his 
machine at mtv.com to a new name.  So if you were really groaning
about the MTV aspect of it then never fear.

A friend of mine and I were talking the other day about how techno
is so locked into the rave scene.  I welcome the chance to hear it
in a new non-rave context.

Laura

Just a quick post--

I hadn't gone to a wicked in a long time; I had read all the posts about
the vibe and all that and I just didn't know if I wanted to go to a
"club" type party---

well, fuck that.  Wicked was absolutely kicking.  And, I must say, I met
more people at that party than any other this year.  Easily.  It was
hot, and it was awesome.  It was crowded and it was fantastic.  People
were there to dance and scream and shout and go OFF.  Everyone shared
water and smiles were abundant.  I introduced myself to a lot of people,
because I was tired of "people not meeting each other" and people
were into it.  It was a fantastic party, and Markie was fucking brilliant.

Brilliant party.  Gives me hope.  If you haven't checked out a Wicked for 
awhile, do try to check out the Bassment jams.  They are great.

Thanks for the good time!

m

Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


From: geoffw@internex.net (Geoff White)
> As I have said before, I have no problems with "Oaktown Hommies" comming
> to ANY party as long as they respect the people around them.  Unfortunately
> I have often heard remarks about said group along with talk about "ganstas"
> and the like.  This saddens me because even though some of these folks could
> cause trouble at parties, except for one incident (Candlestick park), I don't
> know of any overwhelming occurance of trouble by any of these groups.

Well, there was this "Rave Called Sharon" Free-Party at the beach below the
stables in Daly City. Some A.A. gangsta types with a large/mean Rottweiler
got the dog to start attacking ravers. A fight ensued, but no
injuries. Eventually the rave got going again, but it pretty much killed
the vibe for an hour or so. As the gangstas were retreating, ravers shouted
stuff like "you would have been welcome at our party but instead you had to
come ruin everybody's fun". I also heard mention that the fatal shooting at
that warehouse rave in santa cruz was mexican gang related.

However, in general, when I refer to "gangsta types" (and I have in the
past), I am not necessarily thinking about any particular race group, and
in the Bay Area there are Vietnamese, Mexican, Afro-American, Chinese
Samoan, Hawaiian, "redneck", and geek gangstas (we carry cellular Apple
Newtons, instead of pagers). A gangsta for every color of the rainbow.

But my brain hasn't melted down to the point that I'm so morally
relativistic to think that gangstas should be tolerated, exalted, or made
into a fashion statement. And if you think about it, that's what many of
the gangstas are -- fashion poseurs. And some of that 'tude is nothing but
a front that might be changed or grown out of.

This isn't a race thing, you should understand -- it's just a matter of not
accepting violence, domination, agression, and groupthink as a way to live.
On the other hand, isn't it kinda "imperialistic" of us to be asserting our
'tude on them? Why do we feel the need to prosletise and assimilate? And is
their 'tude and pose perhaps nothing more than their need to prosletise and
assimilate and fit in.

--------------------

Speaking of poseurs, a strange cultural event ensued yesterday while
walking off Jeno's Sunday afternoon trance @ 1015 Folsom (L.U.). There was
this huge line of people, many dressed in "gangsta wear" but basically too
young and innocent (and female :-) to look like it would pose much
danger. And besides, their parents, parked nearby in Voyagers and Vanagons,
would yank their allowance for a week if they got unruly. 

Turned out to be the line for that night's appearance of "NEW KIDS ON THE
BLOCK" at the Trocadero. Hoo boy. So I and a few other people that happened
to find themselves at Hotel Utah having an afternoon brew went outside to
watch the ebulluient, effervescent, unbridled innocence of youth. There
was a line of NKOTB fans, and a line across the street of over 21-year old
gawkers. We could also see the comings and goings of personnel in the New
Kids on the Block Tour bus. We were hoping to either see whether there was
blatant groupie activity going on, and secretly hoping that we'd see a
Beatlesque stampede on the tourbus -- Police tearing just-pubescent girlz's
grip's from band-member's legs and all that.

Eventually, due to the fact that the expectations of our overactive
imaginations weren't being met by the dull goings-on, we found ourselves
cackling insanely while we joked "Ohmigod!  Donny's Wearing a HUGE
strap-on!". And wondering aloud "what's that glass pipe he's smoking from?"

We figured we could run back to the Hotel Utah if we got attacked, since
the whole NKOTB line wasn't of age....

I guess the moral of this story is that it's damn hard not to be an asshole
to some other group; no matter how innocent the laughter, the laugher, or the
laughee. As someone said, "we're not laughing at them, we're not laughing
with them, we're laughing through them!"...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==           Niels Mayer -- netcom!mayer -- mayer@netcom.com               ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

....flashback...October..1993...from.the.sfraves.archives...................
 
"Every now and then, when I think that the Scene is really bad, when I 
think that it is dead, it's over, fucked.  A party will come along that 
helps me remember why we are all here and connected.  This was the party 
that did that for me this summer, It was a most fitting way to bring in 
fall and say farewell to the warm weather and regular outdoor parties. My 
hat goes off to all the SFRAVERS who  helped to put this party on."

"The vibe was strong and I really got a good groove fix."

"...and *so* many sfravers in attendance!  i think many of us got our views 
of the scene pleasantly refreshed.  thank you so much."

"Sunday in the park was major FUN stuff.  BIG Thanks to everyone
who made it go off ...   I just love losing my head w/SFravers.  :)"

"Well gang, the park party was fantastic.  Great to see everyone.  I think 
we need to throw another one just to thank the crew that put up this first 
one! "

"i also tryly enjoyed connection earth... i even had my picture taken by 
some ravergurlz."

"Then we went to the GG Park rave. It was killer!  It was just a 
fantastic time from beginning to (Alas!) end."

"Ditto on the kudos, boyo! That was a great party!"

"The other reviews were right on. It was a good vibe all day with people
dancing and hanging out and just being family.  It's truly a privilege to 
have all of you around as you spread such a good vibe and so many good
feelings. That's what it's all about :)."

"I hope everyone who went to the GG Park rave had as much fun as I did. 
Good dj-ing, communal sharing of stuff to eat and drink, dancing  Praises 
and applause for all the people who made it happen.  Let's do it again."
..........................................................................

Out from the darkness and away from our terminals, the varied talents of
SFRavers will mix and merge to send a message to the Bay Area House scene 
and to the crazy city of San Francisco: 

Organized by technology and motivated by the love of music & dance, 
SFRaves will present on May 28th, the Saturday of Memorial Day Weekend:

		       	IN THE LIGHT

A Celebration of Positive Intent, the Respect for Diversity, 
And the Ability to Transcend our Limits in Harmony with the World with a 
Ritual of Fun:
			
		->Get Infected by Meme -> 
		->Trance out with Laura ->
		->Take an Acid House Bath with Markie->

	      Audio by SoundVision - Three Turntables

	   Noon to 6PM at the Bandshell in Golden Gate Park
