i agree with laura about hearing techno music in places other that rave 
related. if techno were played in other places, and it's as good as we 
know it is, more people will like it. that will mean more possibilities 
for 'ravers' to have fun with the rest of society. 

while i sort of like the fact that most of the music i listen to, most 
people i know have never heard of and will never hear, it would be nice 
to be able to buy music at a store in the same town i live in and not 
have to mail order everything. it would be nice to go to the park with 
friends and bring a boom box and play some music that my friends have 
heard of before and like. it would be nice to go more events with the 
rest of my friends who have not been introduced to 'rave music' and not 
have it be at a rave. 

a lot of my friends don't live the same scedule and aren't willing to stay
up all night. i'd still like for them to get a chance to listen to good
music. 

i know there are also some drawbacks to rave music becoming more popular, 
like exploitation of the scene and capitolism ruining some aspects. 
aren't we strong enough to overcome that though? 

actually, i'm not certain what the outcome will be when rave and rave 
associated music reaches more mainstream bandwiths. i think it is bound 
to happen though, and we should think about it so that we can hopefully 
guide it and let it grow in to something good. can we change the world 
with music? that seems to be a reacurring cycling philosophy with 
sub-cultures around the world. maybe this is it? maybe it can happen? 
we'll see. i know i'm gonna try my hardest.

Wicked was hot sweaty and fun! I got there pretty late, ~3:30 or so, just
as they closed the upstairs and ushered everyone down to the bassment.
Great Vibe, except for this one asshole that kept coming up and just
standing in my dance space. So close to really cut into my style. I kept
moving to different parts of the room to escape him and finally I did. Also
he was smoking cigarette after cigarette which I just can't handle when I'm
exercizing. The music was the best I've heard in a long time. I couldn't
stop dancing! 
I wanted to check out Lighten-up  on Sunday but just couldn't get motived
to go out. Oh well, another time.

From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9404252153.AA02727@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: more light on IN THE LIGHT
Cc: sfraves-planners@techno.Stanford.EDU
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

After putting everything on hold for week to assess the overall picture
concerning our scene, the attitudes on SFRaves, and my own convictions, 
it has become clear that not only do people want _In The Light_ to happen, 
but it may be more important *than ever* that we unite for parties that 
that come from the heart and speak to the ideals that transcend the 
differences among us and among the various factions of the Bay Area House 
Music scene.  This is *not* to say the Organic and Wicked don't have
heart, because they do.  Every party has its own flavor but some of us
prefer certain flavors over others... 
 
The flavor for _In The Light_ has the potential to be very special - all 
ages, outdoors, free (or a donation), in harmony with the public,
and the participation of SFRavers who come from a broad crossection of
tastes and "loyalties".  This will be a party of Unity, with the vibe
in full view, on stage...Liquid Air meets Your Sisters' House meets
Wicked meets the Dead Sea scrolls at the De Young Museum... Spiritualists,
Wiccans, Christains, goths, gangsta types, smokers, nudists... all will 
be welcome (not necessarily in any particular order :-).

Planning: As some of you know, there's a separate planners list
in existance.  It was created long ago to plan parties like Connections
that did not have a legal site and required a lot more secrecy and coor-
dination.  
 
The situation for _In The Light_ is a little different. The fundamentals
are all in place, though there is still some coordination that has to take
place.  But this is a party where everyone can voluntarily participate in a 
number of ways - ie. lot's of easy little things that do not require formal
planning - so unless there are major objections, I'm gonna keep SFRaves
completely in the loop.  More on those things in the coming weeks.
 
I want to thank everyone who contacted me and helped *me* see the light
and realize that there is never a wrong time for us to do what we feel is 
right.  Stay tuned...
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com

hey all i am doing a paper on virtual communities..and wanted to get some 
thought from  you guys about netravers/cybertribe! please send your 
replies back to me so not to bother the lists...(:...thanx susie (:

How has recieving a a weekly rave calender influenced your raving?

Do you normally read all of your list mail?

Do you ever go to list gatherings/netravers/cybertribe parties/raves?

If yes, are they different in anyways?

What does it mean to you to be a net raver/cybertriber?

Has the net influenced raves or have raves influenced the net? explain...

Have you ever met other netravers/cybertribers? (which term do you prefer?)

Do you ever wear anything that marks the fact that you are a 
netraver/cybertriber? (ie badges, pins?) Why or why not?

Do you ever vrave? if yes does what does it add to your experience on the 
net?  Have you ever vraved from a party/rave or been on vrave while 
someone from a party was logged in? if yes explain

Are they any terms,acronyms,vocabulary about raves that were 
created by your list?  If yes what are they?

DDo you feel more or less of a part of your local rave community because 
you are on the net?

Do people refer to you by your net name/address or your real name?

Feel free to enlighten me on anything i might have missed...any anadotes 
or stories would be wonderfully welcomed!...thanx...susie (:

Brad, Josh, Scottie, Stonie

At Le Chateau

DIRECTIONS:

Exit University Ave.

Take Dwight up past Telegraph, and make a RIGHT on Hillegass

Earth Sound System" because this is not a free outdoor MESS party, but an 
indoor house party, to profit the co-op where it is being held, and to 
give us some money to invest in our sound system - after all, 3 bucks 
aint a whole lot to ask for at least 6 solid hours of good music and 
fellowship! :)

hi adam,
i have a few things to say. please don't take this as a flame. i just don't
see how rave music fits in with the whole music establishment . i mean ,
the goal of establishment music, a BUSINESS really,
is to move a product, mass ,popular music. rave musick is about being
underground ( NOT alternative). 'alternative' music, which MTV does really
well, is now part of the establishment - we can ( and probably should )
argue about this . there are 'alternative' raves, but i hope there will be
some part of it which stays underground. and i don't think this is elitist.
it is about having the proper 'knowledge', vibe , to let go and connect
with other folx without goals like being 'cool', 'hip', 'with-it'. i hope
mtv continues its alternative musick, since it exposes many people to
really new musick which it would not be heard otherwise. i give
mtv all the  credit to bringing 'alternative' music into the mainstream.
i just hope underground musick stays there.  so maybe mtv can be a gateway
to the undeground, without  trying to bring it 'above ground'.
 curious for any comments you might have.
take care/shalom/acid+bass
ovid

       "AWESOME NEWS" (Apr 25,  6:04pm)

To: resonate@netcom.com (analog resonate), sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU

On Apr 25,  6:04pm, Resonate boomed:
} 	if you haven't heard, as of october 1st the Presidio becomes
} 
} 			a park
} 
} 	which means tons of new gorgeous space for our city
} 	and tons more space for small renegade parties.

Except, it's going to become a *National* park, which means we'll be
able to party there about as well as we could expect to be able to
party at Yosemite.  Additionally, in a dangerous precedent, the
Department of Interior is determined to see that the park "pays for
itself", which is in direct violation of the spirit of the national
park system, and which means companies and institutions will be filling
up the empty offices.  Oh well.  Some interesting political maneuvering
is going down with PG&E and the Presidio - the Bay Guardian has been
following the issue pretty closely, for further reading.

	Brian



From sfraves-owner  Mon Apr 25 20:01:14 1994

Subject: Re: No rest for the Wicked

>The party was going to be at 1015? Really? But isn`t Martini's
>The WICKED party was
>your standard sweaty e-pit type WICKED, in the basement, hot,
>smokey,steamy, sexy and killer music.  When I got there at about 1:00,
>Bones was going off on the decks, warming the crowd up (as if it needed
>it).  I ran into jsl and complained to him about the temperature in the
>basement, he made a very prophetic statement when he said something
>like "It don't matter, the true believers will all be down there before
>the night is over"

I gotta agree with you there Geoff, it was a REAL WICKED in every sense.
It was held in their old watering hole, there was alot of good energy, and
the cracker-jack crew was in full force.  It was a wonderful site!  I am
also amazed at the diverse crowd WICKED seems to be gettin of late.  People
groove to get down at WICKED's which is why it remians one of my favorite
parties.  Nice, sweaty, hot, sensual, it was ALL THAT.  Fucka full moon,
I'm all about the REAL madness!

>Markie took control around 3:00, and proceeded to
>slam it.

As everyone knows, I admire Markie's talents.  However, for some reason he
was slow to warm up, and he seemed to be holdin' back quite a bit.  I have
heard Markie get on the decks and blow-the-doors off!  He usually takes no
more than 30 minutes to get in that "pocket".  But for some reason, and I
can't tell you why, I felt as though he was being restrained, and waas
holding back the goods.  The set was, as usual, BRILLIANT, but it did not
reorganize my brain like he normally does.  Coulda been me, but after
listening to Markie for years now, I could tell he did not pull out all of
the stops.  I guess even DJ's have a conscience :)

>It was hot and smokey which seriously interfears with my
>ability to dance, but I went for it anyway, as I looked around, I saw a
>lot of "old-skool" in the house, people I haven't seen in months, some
>of the Martini's crowd would filter in, most couldn't stand the heat
>and left but a few remained... to have their minds blown open.  I must
>say that the smile factor was high but the craker-jack factor was even
>higher (can I get a witness jsl? )  Markie had muthafuckers jumpin and
>screamin and carrying on in 100 deg. heat.

I dunno wassup wit Markie!  That man is a danger on the decks, and should
rightly be arrested for the lunacy he causes people to engage in!  When
Markie spins, people like, go on autopilot.  He releases something in
people that gets them wilder, wilder, and wilder.  Bodies begin to mesh,
push & pull.  People go fucking OFF!  It is a truly incredible site to see!
Markie has undoubtedly set a new standrd for what I would call excellent
spinning!  He ALWYAS comes out with differnt ways to do the do.  And he is
a maniac when he totally let's loose.  Even on this night, which I would
characterize by his spinning as restrained, it was enough to get
muthafuka's OFF!  Incredible!!!

>Anyway by 4:30 am the place was
>"out of control" when I saw Jeno push through the crown and open his
>crates, jsl and I looked at each other, we both knew what was about to
>happen, I said "Aw shit, here we go", Jeno was _relentless_ it is
>definitely the best set I've heard him play all summer, (I hear he's
>been practicing and it shows) I had a feeling that he would have to
>bust it open _way_ past Markie and I'm glad Markie set the marker way
>up high so he really had to go for it, and go for it he did!

I gotta say, although I have heard the ups-and-downs of the Master (as he
is called by other DJ's), I felt his set was the most restrained.  Note, I
left @ 5:30 thereabouts, so I did not hear the entire thing.  But after the
10th song I easily recognized, and the super long mixesx of old tunes, I
was not impressed.  I understand that he really fucked it up in the end.
But before I left, people had started to leave the dance floor.  It had to
be the ONLY time I had seen Jeno clear a floor somehwat.  But then again,
it coulda been the weaklings who left, and allowed the headstrong to go
off.  I dunno, I felt as though he coulda done alot better in his set.  I
look forward to the next Wicked to see how he does.  This was an aberration
for Jeno, I look forward to his next session.

>Even in
>the heat, "old-skool" was in the back tranced out, doing flips, twirls,
>summersaults,and floor dives :) It was so intense that some folks
>couldn't take it any more and had to take their asses home :) (Can I
>get another witness jsl? :).  But in the end John you were right the
>true believers did wind up in that basement in the morning.

I know I HAD to take my sorry ass home!  After listening too all those
grooves by Markie, my head was impatient for more restrcuturing excersizes.
I went home, smoked a fatty, and got where I needed to be.  I know Jeno
won't let me down next time!

If you are hard-core IMO, Wicked is the place to be.  Basement, warehouse,
anywhere.  As long as they keep that sweaty style that is theirs, it will
be a party I will eagerly attend. I am not interested in the outdoors, I am
interested in the FUNK.  Wicked has got dat!

>
>Oh I forgot about my episode with Sgt.Buchard, the one man raver hating
>task force.  This guy has been hassling south of market clubs for the
>last year or so, he really has it in for WICKED, I'm upstairs at the moment
>trying to deal with a kid that has taken one hit too many and is screaming
>"help me, sombody help me" at the top of his lungs.

I did not see this incident (a VERY good example of a tweeker).  I was to
busy hugging, kissing, loving the world when this went on.  I had a couple
of friends there with me since we were watching out for each other (too
messed up to be alone ;).  In any case Tami took care of me, getting me
water and the like, really cool person (another one of the SJ posse) (It
seems the coolest of cool people come from SJ.  It has GOTTA be the
freindliest bunch of partiers I have met in my travels.  These folx will
put you up, smoke you out, and just watch out for you as if you were their
own.  They are genuine and REAL.  They are also the biggest bunch of
cracker-jacks I have met, but the shit is under control!  SJ has it goin'
on!  Right ON!!!).  Sgt Asshole has a problem, I think he works too much.

Wicked gets my undisputed ;) ALL THAT <- (I plan on using this until its
really old hee hee) AWARD.  With the dancing, music, sensuality, and
straight-up cracker-jackin' I doubt I will ever miss one of their parties.
I do hope that they feature an SF local every now and then, instead of one
of the English posse (c'mon guys, Josh, James, Buck are all GREAT.  Better
than Garth or Thomas.  Give 'em some respect, and give 'em their due.  They
are just a few of the pioneers here, so get them on baord every once in
awhile.  It's called "giving back some".  Too much posse!).

CYA (esp GeoffW) at the next Wicked!

Oh yeah, I gotta say this:  I am GLAD that I'm married.  If I weren't I
would be in hella trouble at Wicked!!!!  DAMN!!!!


Audi 5 & stayin' alive,
John

	Except, it's going to become a *National* park, which means we'll be
	able to party there about as well as we could expect to be able to
	party at Yosemite.  Additionally, in a dangerous precedent, the
	Department of Interior is determined to see that the park "pays for
	itself", which is in direct violation of the spirit of the national
	park system, and which means companies and institutions will be filling
	up the empty offices.  Oh well.  Some interesting political maneuvering
	is going down with PG&E and the Presidio - the Bay Guardian has been
	following the issue pretty closely, for further reading.
	
		Brian

Kathleen Blohm recently asked on idm:

> What is up with the grand canyon this summer(august?)...is this for real,
> if so who's performing? 

There's been discussion of this on both idm and sfraves. The actual
facts seem to be that the "zippies" will not be at the rainbow gathering
and the rainbows will not be at the canyon anyway. However, there may be
something there that was just horribly misreported in Wired.

Personally, I think that if there isn't something happening there, someone
ought to think about planning something. Enough people have heard about
the week-long rave at the start of August that if one is actually held,
it should be easy to get the word out and bring in thousands of people
from all over the place....

	id AA14591; Tue, 26 Apr 94 11:14:34 PDT

  (5.65c/IDA-1.4.4 for sfraves <sfraves@techno.stanford.edu>); Tue, 26 Apr 1994 11:13:58 -0700
Date: Tue, 26 Apr 1994 11:13:57 -0700 (PDT)
From: Ben Sims <sunshine@halcyon.com>
Subject: inner-peace.
To: nw raves <nw-raves@wimsey.bc.ca>
Cc: sfraves <sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9404261035.A4790-0100000@coho.halcyon.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU



watch for signs of peace.  the hearts of a great many have already been 
exposed to it and it seems likely that we could find our soceity 
experiencing it in epidemic proportions, which then, of course, could 
pose a serious threat to what has up to now seemed a fairly stable 
condition of conflict in the world!

some signs and symptoms of inner peace:
	1. tendency to think and act spontaneously rather than from fears 
based on past experiences.
	2. an unmistakable ability to enjoy each moment.
	3. loss of interest in judging other people.
	4. loss of interest in judging self.
	5. loss of interest in inerpreting actions of others.
	6. loss of interest in conflict.
	7. loss of ablility to worry.  (this is a very serious symptom)
	8. frequent, overwhelming episodes of appreciation.
	9. contented feeling of connectedness with others and nature.
	10. frequent attacks of smiling through the eyes from the heart.
	11. increasing tendency to let things happen rather than make 
them happen.
	12. increase susceptibility to love extended by others as well as 
the uncontrollable urge to extend it.

	warning:
if you have all or even most of the above symptoms, please be advised 
that your condition of PEACE may be so far advanced as to not be 
curable!  if you are exposed to anyone exhibiting several of these 
symptoms , remain exposed only at your own risk. this condition of PEACE 
is probably in its' infectious stage.

-Saskia Davis

Subject: Ladle Red Raving Hut-(Humor)
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Ladle Red Raving Hut--or Answer to Geek Wonk

The Geek/Wonk Alert---Gee, I haven't written anything in days because I've
been trying to go through my dictionary to find the meaning of such words as
Modula-2, Comal, Mugwumps, Smtp, Algol-w. or Foo-bar. Why aren't any of these
words in the dictionary?   I wonder, If a word isn't in the dictionary, does
it exist? Does it have a right to exist? Now I ask you, if you e-mail a
message to a computer in a forest, and there is no one there to read it, does
the e-mail exist? The computer? The E-mailer? 

Since I am interested in the linguistic exclusivity associated with increased
technological specialization, I've noticed that Sfraves is developing certain
linguistic idioms which might run counter to our notions of openness and full
frontal acceptance, i.e., IMHO, BTW, and the ever ubiquitous "X." If we
continue this "thread" I imagine that one day our computer screens will look
something like the following; thus precluding any need for secrecy, or
private  access codes. Little Rave Riding Hood:

" Wants pawn-term, dare worsted ladle rave gull how lift wetter murder inner
ladle cardage honor itch offer lodge dock florist. Disk ladle rave gull
orphan worry ladle rave cluck,  dock shows, wetter putty ladle rave hut end
fur disk raisin pimple caulder "Ladle Rave Rotten Hut" 

Wan moaning Rave Rotten Huts murder colder inset Ladle Rave Rotten Hut heresy
ladle basking winsome burden barter end shirker pot cocklers. Tick disk ladle
basking tudor Isaid hows offer groin murder how lifts honor udder site offer
florist. Shaker lake, dun stopper laundry wrote, end yonder nor sorghum
stenches dun stopper torque wet SFRAVERS."

Robertj............MRP
Robert

howdy

first: the dictionary is a historical system.  it does not deal with the
present use of a word ( new meaning of an older word or a new word
altogether ).  therefore, every word in existence was in use before that
word was written into the dictionary.

second: cyber-type-cultures have little respect for vowels, CAPITAL
letters, and words that are a) completly written out b)spelled
"correctly" (back to the spellings of the past, the dictionary) rather
than phonetically (s/b fonetikly) c) used often but not abbreviated,
IMHO

knowing your background here is a humourous relpy to your post.

WP in SC w/b game on the check-out 2

  ;)

Cya
CHE

 	id <m0pw158-000o5sC@mail.teleport.com>; Tue, 26 Apr 94 21:18 PDT
Message-Id: <m0pw158-000o5sC@mail.teleport.com>
X-Sender: matts@mail.teleport.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Tue, 26 Apr 1994 21:18:46 -0800
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
From: matts@teleport.com (Matt Stevens)
Subject: What a weekend!
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I just wanted to tell everyone what a great time I had this weekend, and
put things into perspective about the great scene you have.

I drove down from Portland on Friday to stay with Jeno over the weekend and
prepare for a Monday interview.  I arrived Saturday evening and went out to
dinner with Jeno and Stephanie.  After dinner we went back a napped before
going to Organic.

Now here's where my bit of perspective comes in...  I agree that $20 is a
lot to pay, but as Ethan pointed out, it really was a quality show.  The
thing that I envy about your scene is that you have CHOICES, up here in
Portland we usually have one event per night if we're lucky.  The fact is;
yes Organic cost a bit of money, but it wasn't the only game in town.  So
remember what it's like elsewhere before you complain about your plethora
of opportunities.

Now back to our story :)  Organic was great!  The visuals were wonderful,
and Jeno was feeling better after resting.  Those of you who heard him
Friday heard the effects of a week of moving piled on top of little sleep. 
But Saturday he went off!  The problems with the sound system were
annoying, but Jeno was his usual quiet self and just accepted it and
overcame it.  The morning ended well with Markie playing some fun stuff, he
wasn't at his best, but it's still always a pleasure to here him spin. 
After breakfast and another nap (lot's of naps, little sleep this weekend) 
it was off to Light-n-Up.  I thought Jeno played well Sat. night, but his
the start of his set on Sun. just blew me away.  You guys are really lucky
to have him.  I wanted to stay for the Full Moon, but time ran out and work
(or rather bills payed by work) called me back north.

I hope I get a chance to meet more of you next time I'm down.  The marathon
nature of my visit precluded any advance planning.  Hope everyone who
enjoyed themselves this weekend!  And I just want to thank Jeno for letting
me impose upon him for the weekend.
--
matts

On Mon, 25 Apr 1994 humphrey@unity.ncsu.edu wrote:

> i agree with laura about hearing techno music in places other that rave 
> related. if techno were played in other places, and it's as good as we 
> know it is, more people will like it. that will mean more possibilities 
> for 'ravers' to have fun with the rest of society. 
> 
> while i sort of like the fact that most of the music i listen to, most 
> people i know have never heard of and will never hear, it would be nice 
> to be able to buy music at a store in the same town i live in and not 
> have to mail order everything. it would be nice to go to the park with 
> friends and bring a boom box and play some music that my friends have 
> heard of before and like. it would be nice to go more events with the 
> rest of my friends who have not been introduced to 'rave music' and not 
> have it be at a rave. 
> 
> a lot of my friends don't live the same scedule and aren't willing to stay
> up all night. i'd still like for them to get a chance to listen to good
> music. 
> 
> i know there are also some drawbacks to rave music becoming more popular, 
> like exploitation of the scene and capitolism ruining some aspects. 
> aren't we strong enough to overcome that though? 
> 
> actually, i'm not certain what the outcome will be when rave and rave 
> associated music reaches more mainstream bandwiths. i think it is bound 
> to happen though, and we should think about it so that we can hopefully 
> guide it and let it grow in to something good. can we change the world 
> with music? that seems to be a reacurring cycling philosophy with 
> sub-cultures around the world. maybe this is it? maybe it can happen? 
> we'll see. i know i'm gonna try my hardest.
> 
> /////////////////////////////////////////////////////
> //////////  john     humphrey@unity.ncsu.edu ///////
> /////////  rainbow   john_humphrey@ncsu.edu ///////
> ////////  humphrey   pgp key upon request  ///////
> /////////////////////////////////////////////////

John,

	Sorry to have to drop some cynicism your way...but:  you speak of
wondering what it would be like if rave became more mainstream and more
people beyond the scene became involved.  Well, what was 1992?  This was
the year that the underground sound DID enter the mainstream, and
unfortunately (in my opinion), like any on the fringes artistic movement,
it resulted in a sad dissolution to where going to a rave was (literally)
like going to a fucking frat party--meaning jock-o's w/o shirts, their
perfect tan girlfriends, and an egotistical-top40danceclub-attitude that
completely ruined the warm, postive vibe.  In addition, corporate rave
promoters became involved, major labels became involved, and I thought for
certain the scene was dead for ever (on a national scale).  Luckily, the
hardcores went back underground to escape (I'm talking Northwest here, but
before you guys dis me, I'm sure this is applicable to other areas of the
west coast and country...), and speaking for Seattle, there is once again
a close-knit, positive vibe going on.  
	Overcoming exploitation?  Look at what happened to the grunge scene...
It became (and still is) SO mainstream that Kurt Cobain reached the
frustation point to where he simply told the macho-asshole types to STOP
buying and supporting their music...these are the same mall-shopping
fucks that make me bloody ashamed I have something in common with with
them when they drive by in their BMW's blasting Orbital going "WOOOOOOOOO!"
	Before the rave-techno thing re-emerges to the mainstream, which
it invevitably, I agree, will, we again have something temporarily special.
Yeah, I know I shoudn't be such an elitist, but there are precious few
havens from our americanized, commericialized, and homogenized society and
culture that I cannot help but be vehemently defensive (and cynical) about
this topic.  

	It is my belief that the drawbacks you speak of DO outweigh the
advantages of the scene remaining less than conspicious.

		A northwest perspective,

			>andrew<



Do you recognize the sound, the sound of the underground?

							Irr.Force/Morris

From: Seth Joshua Horvitz <acid23@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Christian techno
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9404270026.A13530-0100000@uclink.berkeley.edu>

Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


Relating to the recent "Jesus raves" thread, there's a CD at KALX by the 
name of "Dance House Children", a full-length album of Christian techno.  
It's really hilarious.  By today's standards, the music is pretty bad (I 
think it came out in '91 or so), but the samples are funny as hell.  

In the liner notes, it talks about how they support good, pure, family 
values, along with a bunch of other right wing ideals.  They end by 
saying something like, "we will continue to use whatever kind of music 
we think is popular to spread our message to young people." That's not 
exactly it, but something very similar.  It's interesting to see techno 
being used as a purely functional means of spreading the News...

Andrew Monko:

>it resulted in a sad dissolution to where going to a rave was (literally)
>like going to a fucking frat party--meaning jock-o's w/o shirts, their
>perfect tan girlfriends, and an egotistical-top40danceclub-attitude that
>completely ruined the warm, postive vibe.  In addition, corporate rave

I just can't let this slide.  For me, my experiences in my fraternity
were overwhelmingly positive.  I realize that this is not true for
many people at many universities, but this depends on the attitude of
the school and the members of the house(s) --- for example, the U of
Washington fraternity system makes me positively ill.

I just feel compelled to say that this stereotype is just that, a
stereotype, and if you were talking about skin color or religion or
ancestry, people would call you on it for being way out of line.

Bob "yes, I was a frat-boy, and never had a perfect tan girlfriend,
where do you sign up for one?" 



From sfraves-owner  Wed Apr 27 13:22:33 1994

Date: Wed, 27 Apr 94 13:02:03 PDT
From: winston@lurnix.COM (Mark Guthrie)
Message-Id: <9404272002.AA05668@cassy.lurnix.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU

>how come w/ such musings the hopi & mayan elders, the ones whose
>actual charge is to interpret these prophecies, never seem to
>getting around to support such events.  more arguelles crap?  
>well-meaning new-age dilletantes?  

>please, have your own visions, interpret the prophecies that 
>move inside you, and stop claiming legitimacy from stuff you 
>know little about.  if it's a true prophecy, you will feel it
>grow inside you.  if some ancient tradition needs your help or
>interpreetation, believe me, they'll contact you themselves.

>peace anyway,
>alpha-10

From other similar posts of your Randy/alpha-10 I know that your
an avid defender of Native American rights and culture and I 
highly respect that. But how do you know the previous poster
doesn't know about the culture or that hopi elders won't be invited
to this Grand Canyon thing?  I also think it's O.K. to speculate
when you know little as long as what you do know isn't mis-
information that your helping spread.

Culturaly/historicly, the person who has visions or prophecies
isn't always the interperater of them and I think anyones'
interpritations can be right/wrong, valid/invalid.

Not that you said this but, I also want to point out that I don't
think non-Native American people shouldn't study or speculate any
facet of the culture.  That's not exploitation. I don't go around
telling non-European Wiccans that they're stealing from my culture.
I didn't mind, infact enjoyed, seeing a Japanese-American wearing
a kilt and dancing Scottish rheels at last years Solano Stroll.
One of my great-great-great grandmothers was full- blood Cherokee
and an other great-great-great grandparent on the other family side
was apparently full-blood Native American, probably also Cherokee
(not sure yet, family trees take LOTS of time and work).  Does this
mean, in accordance to the views of some, that I have 1/8 of a right
to enjoy or participate in Native American culture?

I do think Native American culture has and is being exploited by
certain new-agers but I don't think all new-agers using the culture
are exploiting it.  I've also read about, and I'm sure you probably
know much more about this than I, certain Native Americans exploiting
there own culture as well as I'm sure there are non Native Americans
who were taught accurate tradition by Native American elders.  Just
like my 1/2 black, 1/2 white Kung Fu teacher is better than many
chinese who teach/practice.  It would be a racist stereotype to
claim that people can only find merrit or practice facets of there
own culture and I don't see Native Americans as different from
anyone else except they happen to be the local exploited culture.

I would like to re-emphasize the part of your message that encourages
people to study or find out exactly what they're talking about before
spreading information.

Lastly, many Native Americans do need help, again something you
probably know way more about than I, and they haven't specificly
contacted me.  I think there is an open call for help from Native
Americans to anyone that can help.

And to tye this in with rave, does anyone know how this event
supposedly does tye in with hope/mayan prophecies or is that
BS that Alpha-10 and the rest of us have a right to be 
annoyed/angry with?

-Winston

	id AA00360; Wed, 27 Apr 94 14:26:05 PDT
Date: Wed, 27 Apr 94 14:26:05 PDT
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9404272126.AA00360@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: Recent Thoughts
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Ethan speaks:
> First off Launch Pad:
> Really sorry this one didn't happen as planned (a first for us!) but my
> take on the situation (and others, though not all involved) was that rain
> was an easy possibility in addition to which the wind was positively
> howling and the air temp was the coldest I've felt since winter proper.

I agreed (and was somewhat relieved) with this decision.  Although I 
admire resiliency in the face of adversity, I think the days are over
where a lot of people will go through *anything* to attend and stay
at a party, even one thrown by friends.  Outdoor parties work best when
we can be in a certain amount of harmony with the elements - good call.   

> Organic:
>[...] I decided that, like it or not, I'd fallen
> prey to the exact cliquishness, posseishness, us/them-ness that is really
> chopping this scene up. More often than not it's easy to dress this up and
> rationalize it, saying for instance; they're killing this scene by throwing
> $20 parties, by only ever playing *their* djs, by always using the same
> stupid nightclub, blah, blah, blah.

Almost all parties have *something* to offer, and I for one am glad that
there are different kinds to choose from.  Different parties for different
moods.  The one thing I learned, though, is that I am never be assured of
having a great time at *any* party, (except Park parties :-).  There
are too many variables involved, especially the ones in my own head.

I personally don't think there's anything wrong with charging $20 for a 
party if people are willing to pay it.  At worst, it helps perpetuate a 
party atmosphere in this town and increases the demand for cheaper events
and renegades.  I'm actually glad to see some people make money at it. 
There's a lot of hard work involved in throwing *any* party.  Some people
will pay $7.50 to go to a 2 hour movie, so $20 for 6 hours of fun is not 
terribly unreasonable.  What might be missing from the scene here is 
regular parties that cuts across the tast barriers can enjoy.  Two years 
ago, the weekly GG Park parties and monthly ComeUnitys did a lot to bring 
people together.  Maybe Light-n Up will help fill this gap? 

> Well, yesterday while talking with
> Matt Fox (I'm gonna let that settle for a while before I post) 

That meeting left me with some very mixed feelings and I'm not quite ready
to express a suitable subset of them here yet either.  I probably should
mention that I recorded much of that meeting and if enough people express 
an interest, we can have it transcribed and made available.  I found the
meeting and subsequent discussions to be very intense.

> ...Religions are like lifeforms evolving
> thru time, christianity is one of these. Do we really want it gone, dead,
> extinct or, despite the fact the some of us detest it, does it nonetheless
> have some value to the world? I would ask the same about Organic or any of
> the 'biggies'. 

Not to open up the religion debate or anything, but Organic has never 
done much that can be considered detrimental to any specific groups of
people that I know of.  They haven't tried to have other parties shut down,
nor have they tried to take over the scene in any major way.  IMO, parties
like Organic help the scene much more than hurt it. 

> more often than not I found what I wanted there: smiles, warmth,
> massive sound, nifty visuals, release. People, maybe not us of late, are
> still finding these things at raves. Do we want them gone? I don't know.

As long as the music is good, the people friendly, and my participation
does not support of some obvious freedom-repressing power structure, I'll
go to these and other kinds of parties and hopefully continue to have 
some great times with them.  Here's one vote for Pluralism.  The cool thing
about our scene, is that small groups of people have the power to make a
real impact if they want to.   
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com

From sfraves-owner  Wed Apr 27 15:01:09 1994
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA09567; Wed, 27 Apr 94 15:01:09 PDT
Received: from WordPerfect.com by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA09556; Wed, 27 Apr 94 15:00:58 PDT
Received: from Gateways-Message_Server by WordPerfect.com
	with WordPerfect_Office; Wed, 27 Apr 1994 16:00:51 -0600
Message-Id: <sdbe8c33.041@WordPerfect.com>
X-Mailer: WordPerfect Office 4.1
Date: Wed, 27 Apr 1994 16:00:32 -0600
From: Luke Youngblood <LUKEY@WordPerfect.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject:  Warning, please read.
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

	I meant to post this earlier, but I haven't been at work for a
couple of days.  Let me first introduce myself.  My name is Luke, and
I'm a house and ambient DJ here in Salt Lake City, Utah.  I've been
fairly heavily involved in the scene around here for a while, and
I've helped a lot of organizers throw parties, and I've also spun at
a lot of the local parties as well as a couple out of state ones.
	A couple months ago, I was asked if I would like to spin at a party
in Salt Lake that was being thrown by an out of state promoter.  The
promoter's company was called E-Core, and he goes by Eagle.  His real
name is Elijah Lewis, and he lives in Denver.  The party I was to
spin at was called Orbital Dawn, and happened April 23rd.
	I've been communicating with Eagle over the internet, and when I
found out that only a few days before the event was to happen, there
was NO LOCATION lined up, I decided I would help him out and I
introduced him to my friend Greg.  Greg owns a non-profit performance
arts center called Playscool, and he and Eagle were able to work out
terms for the rental of the space, sound, and lights.
	Apparently Eagle has a way of doing business no matter which city he
goes to, where he expects a local promoter to cover all expenses, and
then pays them back at the end of the night.  Because of this Greg
had him contractually bound to pay the specified amount.

	Basically, what happened was this:

	A few months ago, Eagle had met with Blaine Lincoln over the
internet, who lives here locally in Layton, Utah.  Blaine had agreed
to do local promotion for the Orbital Dawn event, but this never
panned out.
	Blaine did not go to one party to hand out flyers and promote the
event.  The only thing he did was leave flyers at the door of
Playscool one night, and leave flyers at a local clothing store.
	Blaine had informed me that I would be spinning in the main dance
area.  A day before the party, I found out differently, that Eagle
had decided to bump me out of my slot in the main area into the
ambient room.  This was alright, however, as I do have a lot of
ambient music as well.
	The night of the event, there were 2 cancellations in the ambient
room, so I ended up going on early and playing for 4 hours instead of
the 1 or 2 that I was planning on.  This was alright as well.  I
didn't plan on charging Eagle anything extra for doing this, because
I basically spin just for the love of spinning.
	Due to Blaine's lack of promotion, and Eagle's lack of pre-planning,
only about 140 give or take a couple people showed up at the party,
and this was entirely too few to cover expenses.  I didn't find out
about this until the night was almost over due to the fact that I was
in the ambient room DJing most of the night.  The only way I found
out was when the 2 DJs that drove up with Eagle came up to me and
said goodbye.  At that moment, Eagle was seriously trying to walk out
the door without even paying me, or talking to me at all. I grabbed
Blaine and told him to go get Eagle, and he did.  Eagle informed me
that not only had he not made enough money to cover expenses, he
could not pay me any money at all, and had been unable to cover Greg
even the cost of the sound and lights that Greg had rented for his
event.
	My warning is this:  Don't trust this guy one bit.  He has no job,
nor financial backing to promote parties with, and relies on local
promoters to carry all the risk.  If it pans out and there is a good
turnout, he might actually pay the people that paid for the party,
but several times that night he actually tried to leave town with
what little money he had and not pay anyone.  I don't know exactly
how much he owes Greg, but it is in the hundreds of dollars, and he
hasn't paid me one cent for my time DJing, or for my time helping him
get this party together that wouldn't have even happened had I not
connected him with my friends.  Jon Bishop and Shaheen Shary played
there also, and they probably got paid since he has them booked to do
other parties in other states, but since we're just local promoters
and local DJs that don't really matter to him, he just decided to
fuck us over.
	Watch out for this guy; he's very unethical, and in his own words
"just tries to get enough money from one party to support himself
until the next one..."  If anyone has any questions about this
situation, please ask and I'll be happy to answer them.  I also have
several friends that can attest to the truth of this.  Thanks for
taking the time to read this long post and hopefully he won't try to
rip you off too.

Luke

P.S.  Eagle, if you decide to pay Greg and I back all the money you
owe us, I will publically retract this statement, but you better pay
us back quickly, as you have seriously harmed the ability for
Playscool to continue to run a non-profit performance arts center for
the good of the public, and you've caused Greg to have to put his
personal money into Playscool just to keep it running.

>>> Elijah Lewis <jahlewis@csn.org>  4/26/94, 07:10pm >>>

front all the money for his events, and he has no sound, lighting, or
permits.

What does he contribute to the party, then?  And why is it to anyone's

that you couldn't do better locally.

Personally, I am fascinated by themes of inevitable new age evolution, 
as opposed to Revolution and alienation. Technology, 
Capitalism(Trilateralism), and the new spiritual attitudes which coincide 
with this inevitable destiny. The world will be one big rave with a 
machine enhanced beat. We will own only what we have in our backpacks and 
rent the rest (some of us might have chill spaces). We will creatively 
consume and produce to the high energy muzak. Every once in a while a 
cute fashionable person will bring by a plate of fruit. 

This is the best possible future.

salutations, allen@ameba

It's --among other things--what I call "virtual
duologues" like the recent one between ethan and lee
on Organic, Mathew Fox, the scene, tthe nexus--if any--
with organized religion, that keep we a loyal lurker
and sometime participant in the ongoing sfraves online
community.  I believe through the medium of internet we
have a distinctly new and valuable form of discourse that
is both humane and technologically advanced, as old as
the concept of the Greek chorus where all the community
participated by listening in and eventually having their
say and as cutting edge as the information explosion
where more and more of us are being grown through mmore
and more information exchange!

Does that make sense?

Cheers,
Will

Will Penna               408.423 8907
Peace on earth will come from making peace inside yourself
and bringing it with you into the world.

I went to a party Eagle threw in Denver (where he lives).  Here
is my experience:

Before the party Eagle mailed me a plane ticket.  I flew out to
Denver on the appointed day.  My friend Eric met me, we hung
out and went to the rave site.  It was beautiful, well set-up,
and well run.  I spent a good part of the night talking to Mike,
who did the lights there.

Turnout was low but the party was huge amounts of fun.  I got
paid 60% of my fee, which is more than I usually get.  Based
on my experience I agreed to go back for a party he is doing in 
May in Albequerque.

I don't know Eagle well and I don't know about pre- or post-
production at the Denver party, but what I did see worked out
well.

Laura

sold out...He and his girlfriend,Judy still live here in the city,and are

>From jahlewis@csn.org Wed Apr 27 19:01:41 1994
Received: from teal.csn.org (teal.csn.org [128.138.213.22]) by soda.Berkeley.EDU (8.6.8/PHILMAIL-1.10) with SMTP id TAA09510 for <laura@soda.berkeley.edu>; Wed, 27 Apr 1994 19:01:37 -0700
Received: by teal.csn.org id AA14585
  (5.65c/IDA-1.4.4 for laura@soda.berkeley.edu); Wed, 27 Apr 1994 20:01:33 -0600
Date: Wed, 27 Apr 1994 19:26:24 -0600 (MDT)
From: Elijah Lewis <jahlewis@csn.org>
Subject: "Orbital Dawn"
To: laura@soda.berkeley.edu
Message-Id: <Pine.3.05.9404271924.A11769-d100000@teal>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Status: ORr


Hi San Fran Ravers!

My name is Eagle of E-core Productions based out of Denver, Co.  This
letter is in defense to what Luke from Salt Lake City<SLC>, Utah has been
posting about on a list I don't even belong to.

"Orbital Dawn" in SLC, UT on April 23rd was a event I put on there in
association with Blaine of HipSway Productions.

with DJs Jon Bishop <SD>, Shaheen the percussionist <LA>, Intensity
<ALBQ>, D-Quest <Orlando>, and locals Mechinized, Merman, Luke, and live
act Dreamscape Unlimited

I had the biggest sound...and 4 intellabeams with dataflashes, and extras
for lights, as well as a REAL smart Bar from Boulder, co, there was a main
room with an Ambient chill room.

Well the local guy I was working with did not go out and promote the event
very well at all, and some of the local hardcores of the scene called me
asking what they could do to help out.  Greg of Playskool offered to let
me use the location, plus get sound/lights, security, and new flyers and
ticket sales all for $1500. Which I found was fair. This was agreed to
Wednesday before the event.

Well the night of the event, everything went down hill. The tickets had to
be sold at the Mechinized Store for .50 cents surcharge cause of how the laws 
work in SLC. that is fine and that is what I agreed to. At 2:30am I went to 
the store to get the money to organize it all and deal with it. the event only
had 148 ticket sales which equal $1480 in cash. Well Jodie who owns the
store with her boyfriend DJ MEchinized was there with a "large" associate.
with 148 ticket sales that should have been $74.00 paid for ticket chage
to the Store, well Jodie desides  to say $200 minimum and I can't leave
the store till I pay. That is not what we agreed to, but I had to pay or
get beat up.

Then I got to the event and talked to Greg of Playskool about the problem
of being short on cash. He said "Screw your Djs, and give me ALL the money"
Well I am sorry, but I am not going to screw Talent that works hard to
make kids happy and dance, I paid Jon $200, Shaheen $350, D-Quest $80,
Intensity $80, and I gave Mechinized $50...but he gave it to greg and
bailed from the party without spinning "not gonna play for this bunk ass
party". and then I gave Greg about $630, which is all the money I had
left.  Add that all up 200+200+350+80+80+50+630= $1590...which means I put
in my own money to do what I could. I left town broker then arriving
getting back with my DJ paying Gas money. I told Greg I would pay him back
the $800 I owed him before I would ever do an event in SLC again.

As far as Luke saying I tried to skip town...that is untrue..I purposely
went to the Store not in my own car, while my DJs were the ride anyway and
spinning at the party. Secondly Luke was the last person I talked to cause
he was the least of my worries. But I told him I would pay him back $100
as well when I came back. Luke as not been around as much as he says he
was.

A note about Dj Mechinized, he had the gall to come up to Jon Bishop and
say "You gonna get off now so I can spin for MY crowd" 30 minutes into his
set. Mechinized has pulled up 20 records from front to back in order
before this, He is known for playing the same set for the last year, but
because of the Utah Laws and everyone needing, not neccessarily wanting
the Mechinized store he plays at every event. well except mine. and Kids
came up to me and said they were glad they didn't have to listen to him
for once.

The Quote Luke said I said was only half there, and this is what it is "As
Long as one event pays for itself and gets the next going and gets me
there, I'm happy, and if not as long as the crowds smiles its worth the loss"
I am not greedy, but I would like what I put into it to come back. Luke is
right I have no job, I am not a trust fund brat, nor am I a drug dealer.
And how I work with my local promoters in each town is they do some
upfront cost and so do I, and none of us gets paid back till the end of
the night. And if there is profit it is split up by those who invested.

I had kids saying it was one of the best events they had been too, and
asked when I was coming back. Mechinized is also a promoter and they
events have half as much as what i gave their crowd. Perhaps they are
jealous and greedy and now have to work harder to live up to that. 

To greg of Playskool..proper respects and thanks for hard work
to Luke..quit whining
to the Mechinized crew..perhaps greed will get you one day, trying to be
controlling of a scene and allowing to things get stagnant will get you 
nowhere
to the Kids of SLC...thanks for the thanks.....

to SF ravers...I may never do a party there cause its out of my area, but
I love to party there!

Eagle of E-core
jahlewis@csn.com
303/575-1330 <VM>



:w! eagle

I'm from SL city and have been in the scene there since shortly after it 
began. I live in Portland now so i wasn't in SL for this 
party. I know greg, luke, and the mechanized crew...have hung out with 
them, seen the way they work, and have been to plenty of their parties.  So 
here is my two cents on this whole eagle thing.  


> That is not what we agreed to, but I had to pay or get beat up.

Mechanized may not be the greatest business people in the world, and 
Chris(DJ Mechanized) is definately not one of the greatest dj's.  However 
i can not picture them beating anyone up or even threating to do such.

> Then I got to the event and talked to Greg of Playskool about the problem
> of being short on cash. He said "Screw your Djs, and give me ALL the money"

WOW!!!(hella surprised)  would of liked to been there to hear Greg say 
that.  Greg and his partner Devin have been the greatest thing that have ever
happened to the SL scene. He has constantly worked to keep the scene alive and
the vibe good without screwing anyone over.  He tries to stay away from the BS 
politics.  

> Well I am sorry, but I am not going to screw Talent that works hard to
> make kids happy and dance

Seems to me like greg also worked hard and fronted alot of money to "make 
kids happy and dance".  I don't think you should screw over dj's but it 
doesn't make sense to screw over the person who saves your ass and makes 
the party possible.  It's the responsability of the production group to 
pay everyone and take losses themselves.  


> As far as Luke saying I tried to skip town...that is untrue..I purposely
> went to the Store not in my own car, while my DJs were the ride anyway and
> spinning at the party. Secondly Luke was the last person I talked to cause
> he was the least of my worries. But I told him I would pay him back $100
> as well when I came back. Luke as not been around as much as he says he
> was.

Is there guarantee you will be back in SL soon, and be able to pay them 
back.  Large IOU's to people you don't know well aren't responsible 
promotion.

> And how I work with my local promoters in each town is they do some
> upfront cost and so do I, and none of us gets paid back till the end of
> the night. And if there is profit it is split up by those who invested.

I wonder how much luck you'll have in the future doing it in this way.


> To greg of Playskool..proper respects and thanks for hard work

he deserves it, and $900 on top of that that!

> to Luke..quit whining

weak flame :(

To: Mark Metz / Future Forum <mmetz@soda.berkeley.edu>,
        sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: Allen's Fascination
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Mime-Version: 1.0
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Aside from Allen's Amusing Fascination for cute fashionable people bringing
plates of fruit, I wonder if anyone here has seen Doug Rushkoff's new book
'Cyberia' which I got today and has a lengthy section on the early SF
rave scene (Toon Town and the like).  I haven't read it much but there's
a whole bit about Mark Heley and also the whole gamut of groove gurus
(Tim Leary, Terrence McKenna etc.)  Rushkoff has some fanciful ideas
about the music -- "dub [house], coined from Gibson's Neuromancer for
Reggae-influenced house" (like hell, dub in the dance music tradition
which covers disco all the way to melodic techno just means remixed
with minimal vocals, and doesn't generally employ the reverb and
effects of real reggae dub, and *certainly* has nothing to do with
Gibson, but no matter).  And the book seems kind of superficially
focused on 'personalities' in the scene, but that's not too surprising.
I'm looking forward to reading it in depth before making any real
judgements.

Jose on a Wednesday night , I highly recomend it!

own SFRaver Scott Nozawa ( DJ Tamotsu ) was laying down such great music,
that I started dancing as soon as I got into the space! Both he and 
MOTION "house" DJ Loren have some amazing selection of techno/tribal/acid
jazz stuff that sounds great! ( I hope that Scott will be able to post his
playlist from last night ...).
 There is usually one drummer there as well , but last night there were
two ... I hit a great "head/body" trip by dancing next to them! There's
just something that good real-time drummers can bring to a rave music
setting that really does it for me.
 Oh yeah, Simon was good too(!) , but I had to leave after 1/2 hour of his
set in order to get some pre-work sleep ( speaking of work - gotta sign
off now! ).

>>> Laura La Gassa <laura@soda.berkeley.edu>  4/27/94, 05:16pm >>>

I went to a party Eagle threw in Denver (where he lives).  Here is my
experience:

Before the party Eagle mailed me a plane ticket.  I flew out to
Denver on the appointed day.  My friend Eric met me, we hung out and
went to the rave site.  It was beautiful, well set-up, and well run. 
I spent a good part of the night talking to Mike, who did the lights
there.

Turnout was low but the party was huge amounts of fun.  I got paid
60% of my fee, which is more than I usually get.  Based on my
experience I agreed to go back for a party he is doing in  May in
Albequerque.

I don't know Eagle well and I don't know about pre- or post-
production at the Denver party, but what I did see worked out well.

Laura

what happened to me.

I thought it a bit odd that Luke's original post was made only
to sfraves rather than mtnraves.  Mtnraves is a list covering
the geographic area where the bulk of the affected parties live,

made more sense because until late last night Eagle didn't even 
belong to sfraves, and also because then the affected parties and

Subject: Re: Warning, please read. -Reply

In Hollyweird, if you provide financing or truly key elements to a
production, you are *executive* producer.  If you provide the dance floor or
the sound system, at your financial risk, you're the producer.  If you
provide a portion of the other key elements, you're an *associate* producer.

and if you bring a couple of DJs, you're the *chauffeur.*  (Unless it's a
union production, in which case you're the *driver.*)

?-)
alpha-6&1/2

my reputation

hard and we all took losses. I have the deepest respect for greg of
Playskool.

smiling, coming up to and saying thank you, and asking when your
coming back cause they thought you had one of the raddest events in
awhile, it makes lossing money almost worth it.  and though things
went bad and screwy behind the scenes, there is no reason to effect

to pay us, then I will take back what I've said about him.  Until
then, I have every right to tell people what we've experienced in
doing business with him.

ATTENTION!! To all SFRavers....

   I have an opportunity to address city officials tommorrow at a rehersal
for the upcoming "Global Tea Party",  an international awareness gathering
to help solve local and global problems.    There will be a "Space Bridge"
connecting several European sites,  where this hi-tech meeting will be
geared to discuss such problems.

   I've been invited to talk about local social problems,  and plan to
bring up the SF social problem of the lack of suitable sites for young people
to have a plave to dance.    Because I was invited,  I've been given the
"go ahead" to invite as many people as I need to help substantiate this
awareness and problems the SF rave community has in Obtaining permits, 
lack of suitable venues,  and constant harrassment by the police.

  This is somewhat short notice,  primarily do to the fact that I had to
go to Redding to find work.   I returned late last night and was given the
go ahead just this morning.

   This gathering rehersal is scheduled for 10 am tommorrow,  and if anyone
wants to go,  please RSVP to me immediately,  and I'll send you the address
of the location in SF (Pacific Heights) on where this is to take place.
Bill McCarthey,  a prominent rock promoter who promoted Peter Gabrial,
the US Festival,  and a number of other popular events will be heading
the promotion of the main Tea Party to take place sometime in June.

   For those RSVP'ing,  please include your phone number so I can phone you
to discuss the details.

John D.

From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9404282311.AA27288@pilot.njin.net>
To: Elijah Lewis <jahlewis@csn.org>
Cc: Luke Youngblood <LUKEY@wordperfect.com>, grigsby@agames.com,
        laura@soda.berkeley.edu, sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Why are we here?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.05.9404281417.C26926-a100000@teal>
References: <Pine.3.05.9404281417.C26926-a100000@teal>
	<sdbf8b45.073@wordperfect.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

When one starts using second person tense, i.e. "you this" and "you
that," then it's time to take it to email.

First we have a major complaint posted to sfraves...including a lot of
accusations about someone not even in the bay area and who does not
throw parties in the bay area. Then we have the accused joining
sfraves with the sole purpose of engaging the first person in a
public argument.

Why are we here? I've begun to wonder about that lately.  The last six
months has shown a dramatic rise in flame wars and personal attacks.
It seems we can't disagree about something without invoking the "you"
word.

Regardless of what the charter for sfraves is, and for what we want it
to be, it is what it is. Everything we post here every day is the
spirit and soul of our community, our public message.

We've all made mistakes. Are we going to repeat them? Are we creatures
of intent or action?

I've had no less than three people tell me recently that they felt the
sfraves crowd was exclusionary and clubbish, and they didn't want to
have much to do with them because of their vibe. And I was surprised
to hear it, but who knows, maybe I have a deficit of perspective
lately. And these were mature, very friendly people who said this,
people I know and respect, so I consider their words carefully.

Someone once told me that when someone says something that's
impossible, instead of your first reaction being to refute it, it
should be to search for answers to "In what ways could this possibly be
true?"

How *could* people be seeing sfraves as an undesirable crowd? Could it
have something to do with the viciousness and negativity expressed
here? Does it leak over into "real life", or perhaps it is the
unrestrained online expression of real life feelings? Or is it
something else? Why would anyone say that?

I don't know. All I know is I see too much self-protection, too much
judgement. It makes one weary and sad.

Personally, I think I'm going to back-out a while, and start getting
personally involved with parties and proactive action. I *love* most
of you people. I just wish I weren't losing faith in our collective
ability to love, accept, and understand.

I wish you the best,

Sean

Speaking of magazines...

Keyboard Magazine, has some very good interviews and so forth with Richard
James (Aphex Twin, Polygon Window), Vapourspace, and some other really
great artists this month.  It describes a lot of Mr. James' equipment, that
it seems he built himself, which I consider a tremendous accomplishment,
considering how great his music is.

Just an FYI, I had a lot of fun reading it.  It should be available at any
Waldenbooks or magazine selling chainstore.

Subject: RE RE: Why are we here?
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU

Sean asks Why are we here ? and makes some interesting observations about
flames, perceptions etc. 

Being new to the internet, sfraves and RAVES - boy have I been lost ! I am
absorbing it all at a rapid rate and geez am I being taught !!!

First although I have yet to meet any of you outside of cyberville I feel
that I am learning about each of you from just hanging around out here. I
feel that I already like Sean for his "sense of fairness" amoung other things
and do not want to see his imput diminsih from the list. 

After analyzing my first post - which initiated a flame cycle I came to
realize something about technology - it can make us "crazy". I am
particularly focusing on any form of "distance" technology. Consider:
Driving - in our isolation mobiles don't we flame each other, cut each other
  off Etc. ? Would we act this way face to face ?
TV - don't we bitch at people on the tube in ways we would not dare if we
    were face to face.
Recordings - it's much easier to blast someone's latest recording than to
    blast away at them face to face. Perhaps we could see in their face
    some reflection of how we all fear critical bitching.
And finally the cyberspace "discussions" 

  It seems to be far too easy to jump to conclusions and release the 
  flamethrowers. Certainly when pressing the flesh we probe a bit longer
  before we go to war and the immediate nature of direct communication
  facilitates the process. In cyberspace it seems that we need to reflect
  longer when something strikes us as being amiss. Perhaps it would also
  help if we took our negative thoughts into direct email as a first course
  of action rather than group posting ? If direct contact did not solve our
  perceptions we could then bring up appropriate communications at the
  group level. Groups are strange beasts to tame or even understand.



I have learned more than I can even begin to communicate about Raving from
the posts I read on sfraves - so as a beginning explorer of the scene and
the music I must say that I appreciate what the list gives to me and I am
able to get over my perception that maybe the group is too negative or
whatever... every family has a squabble now and again.

Bottom line: What the group seems to be about is sharing the scene. Sean
seems to be a rather large and very positive part of that sharing - but
certainly not the whole by any means. So set back - chill refortify the
faith and just keep the best vibe going possible and before posting that
flame pretend for a minute that a real person is before you and have your
post reflect the humanity of that individual.

 Just went to my first SPAZ last night and I liked it much.. A small 
 gathering with some DJ's that I and my music partner Jim find to be
 warm people. Jennifer often seems to start their music sets with a more
 ambient type of groove and things move from there. She played a 
 reggae oriented piece last night that sounded to us like the "theme
 from Gilligan's Island" on dope :-) ! I like them perhaps because we
 met them in the basement of Close Encounters and got on well from there.
 One note: I noticed SPAZ was 21+ Please don't start flaming that.. I've 
 already read those threads and know pretty much how they wear :-).

 Without getting into flames and negative bursts - do others of you have
 groups of people that you have found to be very positive? I am in search
 of the most positive of responses. In other words where would you tell a
 friend to check out ?  Ameba BBQ ? Funky Buddha? Reviews I want reviews!
 I'm a not much of a joiner so it's easy for me to gladly move from group
 to group without much concern for becoming a tight part of a clique. I
 will gladly share postive vibes wherever I find them and the more the
 better..

 In case you might wonder I'm not ignoring sfraves but have not been able
 to be free for a lunch and I have noticed the postings giving thumbs up
 to Motion? in SJ. I'm just new enough that I am trying to survey the best
 the scene has to offer. Also, for listening I love things that move
 toward the ambient side of the house - and I love to listen since it
 affects what I play....

 Keep on dancing... Keep on listening... and let us know what you find..

 Mike

Subject: Re: this is
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Thu, 28 Apr 94 17:50:07 PDT
In-Reply-To: <013.00658154.FKDV20A@prodigy.com>; from "MR BLAINE E LINCOLN" at Apr 28, 94 7:37 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

>   Truly this is a shame to see no less
> than 3 mailing lists virtually destroyed with this.

Destroyed?  Far from it.  SFRaves has been through worse.  I
used to let this kind of stuff get me down, but it doesn't
so much anymore.  Perseverence in the face of adversity will
only strengthen us.  I've seen our scene take some hits,
pull back, regroup, and come back out with positive vibe
fully intact.  The rave scene has its ups & downs, just like
life.  I've seen people who have flamed the shit out of each 
other shake hands and dance side by side at a party.  To
anyone who is bummed over some recent petty negativism, I recommend
taking a longer view: raving will survive because we can
express our *entire* nature to each other - the good, bad &
ugly - and *still* go out and transcend it all.  

We are the weird - If feeling good was so easy, then it wouldn't feel
so good to feel good.  Or something. d:~]
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com

To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
From: rth@netcom.com (Robert Hughes)
Subject: Re: GUIDELINES FOR POSTING TO SFRAVES
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Well it's been about a year since Brian posted this to the list. I
hope he does'nt mind me posting it again. I'm especially fond
of guideline 2a. 



>From: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf)
>Date: Tue, 4 May 1993 13:03:28 -0700
>X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
>To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
>Subject: GUIDELINES FOR POSTING TO SFRAVES
>
>Some guidelines for posting to SFRaves.   Print this out and tape it to
>your computer for handy reference.  This list will be given to all new
>members from now on.
>
>1)  First realize that
>
>        a) SFRaves is a large mailing list.
>
>        b) The volume is already quite high.
>
>        c) For every editorial or opinion there are hundreds of
>           possible replies.
>
>        d) Topics of world import such as feminism and race relations
>           will *always* be with us, at least for the current generation,
>           and while discussion about them is important the issues *won't*
>           be resolved by just talking about them here on the list.  They
>           are appropriate here as long as they aren't more appropriate
>           in soc.feminism, etc.
>
>        e) Ego has NO PLACE on the mailing list.
>
>        f) Even with a high signal-to-noise ratio, a high volume means more
>           people skim articles than actually read them.  This is a bad thing.
>
>2)  Now for the general rules:
>
>        a) NO PERSONAL ATTACKS - even if someone is being a complete
>           jerk and everyone agrees, please refrain from flaming him/her
>           in public.  Send him/her all the private email you want.  If
>           they flame you first, be the wise one and take the argument
>           off the list.  If he/she is truely being a jerk everyone knows
>           it anyways.  The difference between a well-reasoned argument
>           and a personal flame should be quite clear.
>
>        b) Try and set an upper limit to your number of posts to 2 a day.
>           Making more is fine, but as you're typing your third make *sure*
>           it's something that's worth the time of the 250 people you are
>           sending it to.
>
>        c) BREVITY IS THE SOUL OF WIT.  Paragraphs prove you have a point.
>
>        d) Ranting is the opposite of raving (thanks to rth@netcom.com for
>           reminding us)
>
>        e) Don't reply to a post until you have read your entire mail
>           queue and made sure no one else has replied exactly what you
>           would say.
>
>        f) Refrain from making "me too" posts, where you simply add "I agree"
>           to the bottom of a quoted message.
>
>        g) If you reply to a post someone makes, READ EVERY WORD THEY SAY
>           CAREFULLY, and in the absence of facial and hand gestures interpret
>           their comments in the best possible light.  It's very hard for the
>           "TV" generation (which we are whther you own a TV or not) to know
>           how to communicate without visual cues.  Make sure you understand
>           what the other person is saying.  
>
>        h) If a conversation turns into a particulary heated argument, wait
>           at least an hour before making your reply, to allow you to see 
>           what they are saying in the absence of a testosterone rush.
>
>        i) Be SURE of what you are saying when you say it.  Proofread your
>           comments several times.  Make sure your use of certain words is
>           the generally accepted use by the community at large, not what
>           *you* think that usage should implicate.
>
>
>We are at the brink of something BIG here, and SFRaves can be a part of
>it.  But only if we keep ourselves as high quality as we've been in the
>past, and these guidelines are a part of it.  Anyone who's spent a good
>deal of time on the net knows these as part of an unwritten policy, but
>they bear repeated for those who are new.  
>
>The Conciousness Revolution has begun.
>
>        Brian
>
>

> .... In other words where would you tell a
> friend to check out ?  Ameba BBQ ? Funky Buddha? Reviews I want reviews!

Last Saturday I went to a party with friends and then we wanted to go out.
I was sorta looking forward to the doubled-up free party thinking the
price was right and maybe more people would be there (being two parties).

I guessed that Organic would be expensive.

Anyway, we went to Funky Buddha mostly because there was supposed to be
House and HipHop/AcidJazz.  We arrived at 3.  Only payed $2.50 each because
it was late (I guess) - I think it was $10 earlier.  I had never been there
before. 

I expected a total singles scam scene because it was Saturday night.
It wasn't so bad.  Some people said hello - which I thought was pleasant.
Unfortunately, the House room (larger of the two) was really loud and gave
me an instant headache.  The HipHop dj's stopped right as we got there.
Got water for free and tipped the friendly bartender.

Overall, I'd say it was mostly a bar/club atmosphere.
We didn't stay too long cuz everyone seemed to be leaving - I concluded
that it isn't much of an "after-hours" place.
It had a nice view of downtown though ...

Dave
