WIRED 2.04

Electrosphere

The End Of Privacy

Did you know there's a working group of security agents and telecommunications
companies designing backdoors into the information infrastructure? Now you do. 

By Brock N. Meeks 

[Note: The following article will appear in the April 1994 issue of WIRED. We,
the editors of WIRED, are net-casting it now in its pre-published form as a
public service. Because of the vital and urgent nature of its message, we
believe readers on the Net should hear and take action now. You are free to pass
this article on electronically; in fact we urge you to replicate it throughout
the net with our blessings. If you do, please keep the copyright statements and
this note intact. For a complete listing of Clipper-related resources available
through WIRED Online, send email to with the following message: "send
clipper.index". - The Editors of WIRED] 

If privacy isn't already the first roadkill along the information superhighway,
then it's about to be. The panel members didn't try to finesse the subject. They
went right for the privacy jugular, saying law enforcement agencies wanted to
"front load" the NII with trapdoor technologies that would allow them easy
access to digital conversations, including capturing electronic communications
midstream. 

But these are tools the "good guys" said would be used only to catch the "bad
guys." Honest. We hard-working, law-abiding citizens have nothing to fear from
these cops selling out our privacy rights to make their jobs easier. Nope, we
can rest easy, knowing that child pornographers, drug traffickers, and organized
crime families will be sufficiently thwarted by law enforcement's proposed
built-in gadgetry, which they want to hang off every telephone and data network,
not to mention fax machine and PBX. 

There's just one small crack in this logic: No law enforcement agency has yet
proven it needs all these proposed digital trapdoors. In fact, "Right now most
law enforcement personnel don't have any idea what the NII is," this according
to Assistant US Attorney Kent Walker, who appeared on the panel. 

Gore Gives Go Ahead

In January, Vice President Gore had promised that the White House would work to
ensure that the NII would "help law enforcement agencies thwart criminals and
terrorists who might use advanced telecommunications to commit crimes." Panel
members representing the Justice Department, FBI, and US Attorney's office said
they had taken his promise as a tacit approval of their proposals to push for
digital wiretap access and government-mandated encryption policies. 

Gore buried those remarks deep in a speech he made in Los Angeles in which he
fleshed out how the administration planned to rewrite the rules for
communications in a new, perhaps more enlightened age. His pledge went unnoticed
by the mainstream press. 

Notwithstanding that it fell on reporters' deaf ears, Gore dropped a bombshell.
Forget Ross Perot's NAFTA-inspired "giant sucking sound." This was the dull
"thump" of Law Enforcement running over the privacy rights of the American
public on its way **at the on-ramp??**to the information superhighway. The real
crime is that the collision barely dented the damn fender. 

Walker blithely referred to this cunning, calculated move to install
interception technologies all along the information superhighway as "proactive"
law enforcement policy. Designing these technologies into future networks, which
include all telephone systems, would ensure that law enforcement organizations
"have the same capabilities [they] enjoy right now," Walker said. 

For today's wiretap operations, the Feds must get a court to approve their
request, after supplying enough evidence to warrant one. But Walker seemed to be
lobbying for the opposite. Giving the Feds the ability to listen in first and
give justification later amounts to "no big difference," he said. Besides, "it
would save time and money." 

And Walker promised that law enforcement would only use this power against evil,
never abusing it. "Frankly, I don't see the empirical evidence that law
enforcement agencies have abused [wiretap authority]," he said. With a straight
face. 

It's Us vs. Them

For Walker, privacy issues weighed against law-enforcement needs is a
black-and-white, or rather good-guys-versus-bad-guys, issue. For example, he
said, the rapid rise of private (read: not government-controlled) encryption
technologies didn't mean law enforcement would have to work harder. On the
contrary, "it only means we'll catch fewer criminals," he said. 

But if law enforcement is merely concerned with the task of "just putting the
bad guys in jail," as James Settle, head of the FBI's National Computer Crime
Squad insists, then why are we seeing a sudden move by government intelligence
agencies into areas they have historically shied from? Because law enforcement
agencies know their window of opportunity for asserting their influence is open
right now, right at the time the government is about to make a fundamental shift
in how it deals with privacy issues within the networks that make up the NII,
says David Sobel, general counsel for Computer Professionals for Social
Responsibility, who also addressed the Working Group on Privacy. 

"Because of law enforcement's concerns (regarding digital technologies), we're
seeing an unprecedented involvement by federal security agencies in the domestic
law enforcement activities," Sobel said, adding that, for the first time in
history, the National Security Agency "is now deeply involved in the design of
the public telecommunications network." 

Go ahead. Read it again. 

Sobel backs up his claims with hundreds of pages of previously classified memos
and reports obtained under the Freedom of Information Act. The involvement of
the National Security Agency in the design of our telephone networks is, Sobel
believes, a violation of federal statutes. 

Sobel is also concerned that the public might soon be looking down the throat of
a classified telecommunications standard. Another move he calls "unprecedented"
is that - if the National Security Agency, FBI, and other law enforcement
organizations have their way - the design of the national telecommunications
network will end up classified and withheld from the public.**These two
sentences are the same** 

Sobel is dead on target with his warnings. 

The telecommunications industry and the FBI have set up an ad hoc working group
to see if a technical fix for digital wiretapping can be found to make the
bureau happy. That way, legislation doesn't need to be passed that might mandate
such FBI access and stick the Baby Bells with the full cost of reengineering
their networks. 

The industry-FBI group was formed during a March 1992 meeting at the FBI's
Quantico, Virginia, facilities, according to previously classified FBI documents
released under the Freedom of Information Act. The group was only formalized
late last year, under the auspices of the Alliance for Telecommunications
Industry Solutions. The joint group operates under the innocuous sounding name
of the Electronic Communications Service Provider Committee. 

The committee meets monthly, pursuing a technological "solution" to the FBI's
request for putting a trapdoor into digital switches, allowing agents easy
access to phone conversations. To date, no industry solution has been found for
the digital-wiretap problem, according to Kenneth Raymond, a Nynex telephone
company engineer, who is the industry co-chairman of the group. 

Oh, there's also a small, but nagging problem: The FBI hasn't provided concrete
proof that such solutions are needed, Raymond said. Sobel, of Computer
Professionals for Social Responsibility, raised this same point during the panel
discussion. 

The telecommunications industry is "trying to evaluate just what is the nature
of the [digital-access] problem and how we can best solve it in some reasonable
way that is consistent with cost and demand," Raymond said. One solution might
be to write digital wiretap access into future switch specifications, he said. 

If and when the industry does find that solution, do you think the FBI will put
out a press release to tell us about it? "I doubt it very much," said FBI agent
Barry Smith of the Bureau's Congressional Affairs office. "It will be done
quietly, with no media fanfare." 

Underscoring Sobel's warnings was the little-noticed move by the Commerce
Department to establish the Federal Wireless Policy Committee. The work of this
seemingly benign committee will be "invaluable" as the administration evaluates
key issues in wireless communications with the NII, said Larry Irving,
administrator of the National Telecommunications Information Agency. But the
devil is in the details. The policy committee's four subcommittees include
Policy, Standards and Requirements, Security and Privacy, and Acquisitions.
Standards and Requirements is headed by Richard Dean, a National Security Agency
official. And Security and Privacy is to be chaired by Raymond Kammer of the
National Institute of Standards and Technology. Kammer's organization, of
course, is knee-deep responsible for the government's Clipper Chip encryption
scheme. 

Is it just me or are these headlights getting awfully close? 

The FBI's Settle is also adamant about trapdoor specifications being written
into any blueprints for the National Information Infrastructure. But there's a
catch. Settle calls these "security measures," because they'll give his office a
better chance at "catching bad guys." He wants all networks "to be required to
install some kind of standard for security." And who's writing those standards?
You guessed it: The National Security Agency, with input from the FBI and other
assorted spook agencies. 

Settle defends these standards, saying that the "best we have going for us is
that the criminal element hasn't yet figured out how to use encryption and
networks in general. When they do, we'll be in trouble. We want to stay ahead of
the curve." 

In the meantime, his division has to hustle. The FBI currently has only 25 "Net
literate" personnel, Settle admitted. "Most of these were recruited two years
ago," he said. Most have computer science degrees and were systems
administrators at one time, he said. 

You think that's funny? Hell, the Net is still a small community, relatively
speaking. One of your friends is probably an FBI Net snitch, working for Settle.

Don't laugh. 

The law enforcement establishment doesn't think you really know what you expect
when it comes to privacy. 

Assistant US Attorney Walker said: "If you ask the public, 'Is privacy more
important than catching criminals?' They'll tell you, 'No.'" 

(Write him with your own thoughts, won't you?) **e-mail addresses here for our
outraged readers to express themselves - We haven't got addresses for Walker.
There's president@whitehouse.gov and vice- president@whitehouse.gov....** 

Because of views like Walker's, the Electronic Communications Privacy Act "needs
to be broader," said Mike Godwin, legal counsel for the Electronic Frontier
Foundation. The act protects transmitted data, but it also needs to protect
stored data, he said. "A person's expectation of privacy doesn't end when they
store something on a hard disk." 

But Walker brushed Godwin aside, saying, "It's easy to get caught up in the
rhetoric that privacy is the end all be all." **correct cliche is "the be- all
and end-all"** 

Do you have an expectation of privacy for things you store on your hard disk, in
your own home? Walker said that idea is up for debate: "Part of this working
group is to establish what is a reasonable expectation of privacy." 

That's right. Toss everything you know or thought you knew about privacy out the
window, as you cruise down the fast lane of the information superhighway. Why?
Because for people like Walker, those guardians of justice, "there has to be a
balance between privacy needs and law enforcement needs to catch criminals." 

Balance, yes. Total abrogation of my rights? Fat chance. 



Brock N. Meeks (brock@well.sf.ca.us) is a frequent contributor to WIRED. He is a
reporter for Communications Daily, a Washington, DC-based trade publication.

From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9404291524.AA22717@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: meclay@netcom.com
Subject: Positive stuff
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU, sfraves-planners@techno.Stanford.EDU
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Mike asks:
> do others of you have
> groups of people that you have found to be very positive? I am in search
> of the most positive of responses. In other words where would you tell a
> friend to check out ? 

Well this Sunday, Ovid and I will be hanging out at Light-n Up.  One room
features acid jazz and another is your standard techno/house.  I usually 
always have a good time there and it's the type of party where you can
dance/trance *and* socialize.  I'll be there dropping teaser flyers for
_In The Light_  and I'll have extras with me in case anyone wants to help
flyer for SFRaves's upcoming party in the park.

I'll be wearing a hat with a question mark on the back of it.  If Ovid
and I seem to be overly engrossed in a conversation about raving's link 
to the Quantum mechanical nature of reality, feel free to interrupt us;
the Universe isn't going anywhere just yet.  If you're new to SFRaves, 
I will be happy to introduce you to every SFRaver I know who happens to 
be there.

Light-n up is at 1015 Folsom.  It doesn't really start hopping until about
1pm.  I plan to be there at around 12:30.

It has been generally agreed that the consistantly best party over the
last 3 years has been ComeUnity, also at 1015 Folsom.  It happens once a
month, and is happening again this Wednesday nite.  I will be there, and
so will a lot of SFRavers.  If you want to meet some of us, or just want
to go to a great party, this one is it.  I highly recommend that people go
to these parties because 1015 Folsom, one of the best indoor venues in
the City, is having some legal troubles; i.e. enjoy it while you still can.

> I'm a not much of a joiner so it's easy for me to gladly move from group
> to group without much concern for becoming a tight part of a clique. 

The reported cliquishness of SFRavers is a bit overblown.  Some of us are
more friendly than others, some of us have strong friendships outside the
SFRaves sphere.   SFRavers come in all sizes and shapes - and yes, we can 
be assholes too.  Many SFRavers happen to be more comfortable socializing
from behind terminals, or mainly with silicon-based entities.  For many, 
raving is a way to just *be* with people without having to get real close 
to them.  I too have never been much of a "group" joiner, preferring to 
connect with people on an individual basis.  The only real clique I belong 
to is the one I have with my wife. :-)

>I will gladly share postive vibes wherever I find them and the more the
> better..

I think you'll find that there are plenty of positive vibes around;
sometimes they lie just beneath the surface, waiting to be prodded into
the open.  Our society continues to train us to mistrust one another, so
it is no surprise that empathy/acceptance/love doesn't happen 
automatically wherever we go, even at raves.  Anyway, Ovid and I look
forward to meeting you.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com

On Thu, 28 Apr 1994, Gregg Helt wrote:

> 	So was there a FMR?  We followed a rumor Monday night, then heard 
> it would be Tuesday.  Did it happen?

Yes, it did happen. We got to Tuesday/Wednesday's Full Moon around 3:30.
After going to the park off Central, we tried a few more places before
going to Pt. Reyes. There was Markie spinning. It seemed like 'regular'
(whatever that is) house music and then he got into a bit more trippy
stuff. It was a small crowd of less than a 100. Everyone seemed to be have
a good time. I know I did. Garth came on later and played music that was
different but still trippy. The cops came about 7:30 to tell 'em to turn
the music off. Garth played one more record and just let it play as they
all started packing. Allen, Trisha, and Garth danced behind the turntables
while the music finished. The two cops and guy just talked until the record
ended.
 
I ended up staying at the park until about 1:30. It was a beautiful day out
and some even played in the 6 foot tall dried plants over the other side of
the park. What a fun afternoon. I got to see friends which I hadn't for a
month which was very nice.

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----

Show your concern for cyberspace civil rights and make fun of the NSA at
the same time!

At the last Computers, Freedom and Privacy conference, an interesting
idea for a t-shirt was jokingly suggested, ironicly, by one of the 
participants from the NSA.   I thought it was a cool idea, so I arranged
to have some printed.  Roughly, it looks like:


         1984
         +---+
         |(O)|   <---- halftone of an eye
         +---+
     "We're Behind
        Schedule"
National Security Agency


The design will be printed in white ink on a black, dark blue, dark
green, or maroon shirt.  The back of the shirt is the "Cyber Rights
Now!" logo from Wired magazine.  It will only cost $15 to get one for
yourself, which includes postage for shipping within the United States.

The design looks great, but you don't have to trust me.  To see the
design for yourself, fire up Mosaic,Lynx or other WWW client, and
connect to:
http://phoenix.aps.muohio.edu/users/jdblair/t-shirt.html

Mosaic will show you a bitmap of the design, and ascii based clients
should allow you to download a gif of the image.

The design is also available via anonymous ftp from:
ftp.atd.ucar.edu:/pub/Crypto
ftp.wimsey.bc.ca:/pub/crypto/shirt

Be sure to set the transfer method to Binary.

The Web page describes how to order the shirt, as well as prices for
shipping outside of the United States.  If you don't have access to
a Web client, e-mail me at:

jdblair@nextsrv.cas.muohio.edu

for more information.

If you're interested, I will be accepting orders for the first printing
run until April 27.  I realize that this day is approaching quickly... I
will be printing extras, and if necessary will arrange for a second 
printing run.


- -john.

- --------------------------------------------------------------------------
John Blair: <jdblair@nextsrv.cas.muohio.edu>         voice: (513) 529-4877
http://phoenix.aps.muohio.edu/users/jdblair/home.html            KILL YOUR
PGP public key available upon request                           TELEVISION

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----

1984 NSA T-Shirt Ordering Information


What will it look like?

The design will be printed in white ink on a dark colored shirt. The 
front design is:

         1984
         +---+
         |(O)|  <--- half-tone picture of an eye
         +---+
     "We're Behind
        Schedule"
National Security Agency

The text is EuroStyle Extended.  The eye will be rendered in a coarse
half-tone, which should silk-screen pretty well.  The back of the shirt is
the "Cyber Rights Now" fist and lightning logo from Wired Magazine. 
The shirts are 100% cotton.  Available shirt colors are black, navy, 
dark green, and maroon. Available sizes are L, XL, and XXL.  3XL is also
available for an extra $2/shirt in the same colors, excluding maroon.


Where can I see the design?

The design is available via WWW clients at:
http://phoenix.aps.muohio.edu/users/jdblair/t-shirt.html
Mosaic will display the images directly.  Lynx, as well as other ascii 
based systems, should let you download the gifs to your local system.

It is also available via anonymous ftp at:
ftp.atd.ucar.edu:/pub/Crypto
ftp.wimsey.bc.ca:/pub/crypto/shirt


How much does it cost?

The t-shirt is priced at $15 if sent to an address within the United
States. For addresses in Canada, the price is $16. For addresses in
most of Western Europe, the price is $18. If you wish the shirt to be
shipped outside of these areas, please e-mail me for pricing information.
If you can come pick it up from me personally, the charge is only $13. 


How do I get one? 

Unfortunately, the Cypherpunks don't have any digicash on-line (yet), so
you'll have to snail-mail me the money.  To guarentee a shirt, I must 
receive your order by Wednsday, April 27. I realize this day is approaching
quickly... I will be printing extras in case I receive orders after this
day, and will arrange for a second printing run if there is interest.
If all goes well, the shirts will be mailed by Saturday, May 14th. 

Make out your check or money order to: 
                John Blair

and send it to: 
                1984 T-Shirt 
                John Blair 
                210 Mary Lyon Hall 
                Oxford, OH 45056

Be sure to include the size, and color of the shirt you want, as well as a
snail-mail address where I should send the shirt, and an e-mail address
for confirmation of the order. Be sure to include a snail-mail address
that will be valid after May 14. 

Money order is preferable. If you send a check, I will have to wait until
the check clears before sending your shirt. 

Notice for international orders: Payment must be in U.S. Dollars. 

For more information, please e-mail me at: 
jdblair@nextsrv.cas.muohio.edu

I hope you enjoy the design. Thanks to all who offered suggestions while I
was refining the design, and for the un-expected interest. 


This file was last updated on 20.Apr.94.

Subject: Bad stereotype
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I've had no less than three people tell me recently that they felt the
sfraves crowd was exclusionary and clubbish, and they didn't want to
have much to do with them because of their vibe. And I was surprised
to hear it, but who knows, maybe I have a deficit of perspective
lately. And these were mature, very friendly people who said this,
people I know and respect, so I consider their words carefully.
------------------------------------------------------------------------

This is bullshit.  This list is so wide and varied that this just can't
be truthfuly said.  Are these people that were on the list?  Probably not
which means they don' know what the hell they're talking about because
most of us have only met up to 20 other sfravers (rough estimate) so
I know there's no way non sfravers have met enough of us to form a valid
blanket opinion about us.


How *could* people be seeing sfraves as an undesirable crowd? Could it
have something to do with the viciousness and negativity expressed
here? Does it leak over into "real life", or perhaps it is the
unrestrained online expression of real life feelings? Or is it
something else? Why would anyone say that?
-----------------------------------------------------------------------

Gee, I don't know Sean, why didn't you ask them?

-Winston

Mark Guthrie writes:
[In response to some people I know saying they don't like the sfraves vibe]

 > This is bullshit.  This list is so wide and varied that this just can't
 > be truthfuly said.  Are these people that were on the list?  Probably not
 > which means they don' know what the hell they're talking about because
 > most of us have only met up to 20 other sfravers (rough estimate) so
 > I know there's no way non sfravers have met enough of us to form a valid
 > blanket opinion about us.

How could it possibly be bullshit? Everyone's experience is valid to
them, and until we start acknowledging this, how can we project
acceptance?

I won't name the people, or disclose whether or not they were on the
list. Because if I do, regardless of how enlightened they are, it will
only result in people attacking their credentials or motives, rather
than an open minded discussion of the issue. I would really like to
believe that this is not true, and it _is_ true for some, but even one
such attack is one too many.

 >> Why would anyone say that?

 > Gee, I don't know Sean, why didn't you ask them?

Sometimes we answer our own questions. Perhaps this sort of dripping
sarcasm is what turns some people from our group. I don't know. Can we
discuss something without being mean?

Instead of being automatically defensive, why don't we take a deep
breath, sit down, and think of ways to make things better. Think about
how we project ourselves both online and off.

Maybe my friends are just stupid. Maybe not. Why not give them the
benefit of the doubt, and think of ways we might be turning people
away, and strive to make it better?

Sean

The music video show I first reported to the list several months ago is 
finally making its San Francisco debut (barring any unforeseen act of god).

The vast majority of SFRavers felt the show should air on Sunday rather 
than Thursday nights. So... This Sunday at 10PM and every Sunday night 
thereafter,  Flux Television can be seen on Viacom Cable Channel 47.

The first show leans a little alternative, but in the coming month we will 
have the new Future Sound of London video, an interview with Richard 
James, and more features.

We welcome your requests and feedback at <flux@netcom.com> or (415) 
281-3377.  -Jonathan Wells

On Wed, 27 Apr 1994, Bob Ramstad wrote:

> 
> Andrew Monko:
> 
> >it resulted in a sad dissolution to where going to a rave was (literally)
> >like going to a fucking frat party--meaning jock-o's w/o shirts, their
> >perfect tan girlfriends, and an egotistical-top40danceclub-attitude that
> >completely ruined the warm, postive vibe.  In addition, corporate rave
> 
> I just can't let this slide.  For me, my experiences in my fraternity
> were overwhelmingly positive.  I realize that this is not true for
> many people at many universities, but this depends on the attitude of
> the school and the members of the house(s) --- for example, the U of
> Washington fraternity system makes me positively ill.
> 
> I just feel compelled to say that this stereotype is just that, a
> stereotype, and if you were talking about skin color or religion or
> ancestry, people would call you on it for being way out of line.
> 
> Bob "yes, I was a frat-boy, and never had a perfect tan girlfriend,
> where do you sign up for one?" 
> 
> 

Bob,

	In my rant against 'mainstreamification' of rave  music/culture
I may have gotten carried away in my descriptions, but I believe it is
obvious the kind of pretentious crowd I referred to, and was not meant to
insult fraternity people who do not fit that description.  Stereotype, or
otherwise, I cannot recall ever attending a function with frat. people
where there was not a sickening atmosphere of meat-market machoism and
elitism. This kind of environment kills any possibility of a
friendly/positive vibe, be it SF, Seattle, or wherever.  Being from the
northwest, I guess I AM speaking of the U of W frat crowd, and if your
frat system differed in any way regarding attitude of this sort, could you
encourage them to move here?  If you indeed wish to debate this further,
let's do it e-mail.
  
	Again, my initial point was an ardent apprehension to encouraging
MTV-related personnel getting involved in the promotion of rave music/culture.
But as a blurb in the latest Newsweek affirms, Mr. Curry indeed has quit
MTV for internet pursuits, and I encourage his endeavor.
	

			>>>andrew<<<

	very into building stuff onto the house

Requirements:

	$550/mo rent subject to slight change if lease amount changes in
	august- I sign and maintain the lease.
	$550 deposit
	Need to demonstrate ability to pay rent either through employment
	or other support
	Non smoker
	No pets of *any* kind
	Needs to be able to maintain an immaculate household- sterile
	kitchen and bathroom
	not a heavy meat eater- i don't mind light chicken and fish cooking
	but no massive amounts of pork and cowbutt oven projects
	
Preferences:

	Musician
	Internet dweller

The room will be available to move into on August 1st although we can
probably get some stuff stored downstirs beforehand.
I am accepting applications NOW for this room. 

Sorry but no compromises on the "requirements" section.

>From phred@teleport.com  Mon Apr 25 13:15:38 1994
Date: Mon, 25 Apr 94 13:15 PDT
From: phred@teleport.com (Fred Heutte)
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: April Showers

  I came down to San Francisco this weekend with a mission . . . two
missions, actually.  One was to help my friend Mark the Lawyer witha
computer project.  The other was to get in some actual DJ time playing
music for actual people instead of just myself for a change.  So I'm
pleased to report, now that I'm back in sunny (!) Portland: mission(s)
accomplished!

The logistics for this weekend were complicated by the fact that I need
to move (like, *this week*!) from the house where I've lived the last
eight years to some as yet unidentified place.  But I felt that not
being around to apartment-search over the weekend would not be a major
loss, as I've got some good leads already.  And I really needed to get
out of town after a hellish month dealing with taxes, campaign spending
reports, hardware failures and all that other usual workaday stuff.

It was an unusual weekend, the first time in probably at least two years
I've gone to SF and not paid dime one to attend a 'rave'-related event.
In fact, where I was *nobody* paid admission.  I made up for it, though,
by going to see Pink Floyd at the Oakland Coliseum (stadium) on Friday
night (for -- gack -- 38 bux!!) thanks to an extra ticket from a friend
of mine.  I used to be a major Pink Floyd fan in, oh, about 1972 (oops,d
displaying my advanced age again :) but lost interest when Dark Side of
the Moon became some kind of generational anthem.  If you've never 
listened to pre-Dark Side Floyd, you should give it a try, especially
Meddle and Saucerful of Secrets and (in some parts, anyway, because it
was an overbloated, self-indulgent mess) Ummagumma.  A very interesting
look at a band trying to find a focus.  Well, they did find the focus,
it's that minor-major key change that underlies virtually everything they
do and gives their stuff that bittersweet bleak sound everyone loves about
the band.  

But mostly I went for the cultural experience, as a long-time fan (at 
least of their earlier work) I'd never actually seen them play and have
had little interest in seeking them out because I generally abhor the
mega-concert scene.  It was a mellow crowd, mostly, and quite a bit
older than I expected although the age range seemed fairly wide.  But
talk about huge!  55,000 tickets sold *each night*, I'm told, which
works out to a gross of about $2.5 million each night.  There are 39
cities listed on the tour t-shirt so probably at least 60 shows, each
likely to gross $1 million average.  We're talking major major major
bucks.  I think one Pink Floyd concert probably equates to an entire
week of admissions to all the clubs and raves and what-have-yous in
our circuit . . . times FIVE!

OK, cut to the chase -- the weather was fine, cool with little flu**y
clouds and a nice moon.  The music -- predictable, smoothly played.
I especially liked 'One of These Days' played at the end of the first
set, the only pre-Dark Side tune I recognized.  The second was less
interesting, plus there was continuous MTV-style video reaching the
usual levels of vapidity amidst high production values.  Excellent
light show, uninteresting lasers.  

Saturday afternoon I fulfilled part one of my mission by going over to
Ameba and taking a spin on the wheels of steel for about an hour and 45
minutes.  It was definitely my Sampler Set, including a special one-off
(which I affectionately dubbed the 'Change Will Come' segment) of
South African mbaqanga ('township jive') in honor of this week's elections.
Felt pretty good, actually, and though I didn't really have a full
complement of tracks from the various styles it was fun.  Got a big
reaction again to some of the stuff from the 'Havana Condensed' double
pack.  

It was around this time that news of the postponed Launch Pad came around.
Shortly thereafter, Bog from Spiral Jive dropped in to say that they were
going to try a renegade in Golden Gate Park starting at midnight and,
oh by the way, one of their DJs might not show up and would I be interested
in coming over, no promises about playing?  And I said of course!  Even
the idea of just being in the park with good sound despite the weather
(which had been alternating between sunbreaks and downpours all day) . . .
of course!

Allen and I and others stopped for a couple of hours at a party with
some of the Nux Vomica folks (interesting people and excellent home brew!),
then they dropped me off at the park on their way to the Troc for Organic.
I found the site easily enough, the sound was quite loud from a good
distance.  When I arrived, maybe a dozen folks were there with turntables,
a portable generator and two smallish but nice speaker cabinets; all
this not too far from the Great Highway so it was quite windy and chilly.

After a while Bryce and then Mike Wertheim, Cindy and other folks showed
up and we had a good time groovin' with the tunes and chatting it up.
But it *was* cold and by 3 there was still no indication that I'd get
a slot, so I prevailed on Bryce to give me a ride and I called it a night.

Sunday the weather improved somewhat.  I would have been interested in
meeting with Mathew Fox but Mission #2 superseded, so I dealt with that
during most of the afternoon.  Back to Ameba around 5 to find Allen
preparing the grill for the Ambient Tofu BBQ.  I'm sure Bryce will want
me to tell you he's *not* just an ambient DJ, but I'm also glad he
brought his good stuff and gave us a solid couple of hours.  It's
very pleasant out back of Ameba, it's the site of the old Haight St.
Theatre and Allen is recycling the spot for that particular use by
projecting films on one of the walls encircling a scrubby-grassy
sort of area incorporating the backyards of all the shops on the block.
Unfortunately the projector wasn't available last night but we made do
with a nice fire, marshmallows and graham crackers, you know, the whole
bit.  I spun after Bryce, then Topher and a little by Dave the Rave at
the end.  There were only about a dozen of us but it was nice until
around 10 when it began to rain.  I don't really have an 'ambient'
collection as that
s normally defined, so I picked out some interesting relatively beat-less
things to play ranging from my still-favorite Jade Warrior (from 1972!)
to Tangerine Dream to recent Alien Signal and Guerilla in Dub tracks.
And here's one for the dumb-mistakes-by-DJs confessional: I didn't notice
Bryce had pitched down one of the 1200s to -8 for his last track (at 45),
so when I put on an old John Martyn thing called 'Small Hours' I was
aghast at the error, but even the vocals didn't sound all that bad so
I faded it and went on . . . wonder if anyone noticed :)

It's a rare time I would miss both a Wicked and an Organic in the same
weekend, but that's what happens under constricted time conditions. 
I'll be back in May!

As for the Spiral Jive/Launch Pad thing, I only want to say it's my
observation that Allen was simply trying to help glue things together
in the scene; my observation of the Spiral Jive folks is that they are
much fewer in number and resources than sfraves, but they seem like
nie folks and are organized and have good ideas about how to pull
things off.  As I said when the idea came up, it seemed like a g ood
idea to me to have the two organizing groups communicate, but trying
to merge things at the last minute is tough under any circumstances.
And I don't mind that Launch Pad was postponed; the weather was just
not congenial.

This week I get to look for a place to live AND keep working on my
promo tape . . . stay tuned!!

And thanks again to Allen@Ameba for the hospitality. . .

phred


----------------------------------------------------------------------

>From robcamp@seas.gwu.edu  Tue Apr 26 09:03:21 1994
Date: Tue, 26 Apr 1994 12:02:27 -0400
Message-Id: <199404261602.AA08310@gwusun.seas.gwu.edu>
To: nacb@gwuvm.gwu.edu, fringeware@io.com, seraves@american.edu,
        ne-raves@umdd.umd.edu, sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: "Cyberia" program guide, April 1994

Program Guide: "Cyberia"

Episode #15 April 1994


This is the final episode for this season, and we loaded it 
up with lots of computer animations.  They include works from
The Rochester Institute of Technology Brown University,
Texas A&M, George Tech, Ohio State's ACCAD, and Wisconsin,
plus computer animated music video from Microglobe and
Biosphere. 

C O M P U T E R   A N I M A T I O N

"Uaguzi"
Chris Walsh
Rochester Institute of Technology

It a period piece about a time when life was very simple ---
you hunted wild animals for food, and painted pictures on
your cave walls.  Those were the good ol' days 


"Deus Ex Machina"
Various Students
Georgia Tech

An old decrepit factory coming to life.
 

"The Visitor"
Rob Berry
Ohio State University

The feeling of mysterious energies making their presence
known.  


Various Works
Various Students
Texas A&M University

Four short works.  Pinball games, The Terminator, New agey
stuff, and a frog are the themes.


"Mr. Cube and the Dinosaur" - Jeff Beall
"Untitled" - Matthew Fanuele
Brown University

Tired of purple dinosaurs?  Jeff Beall comes up with an
ingenious way to kill off that Barney nemesis.  Matthew
Faunele's work is a real head turner


"Techno Rebel"
 Joe Tojek
University of Wisconsin

The skate punk lifestyle clashes with authoritative figures
who tell you how you should live your life.  It's almost
enough to make you puke.


M U S I C   V I D E O


"High on Hope"
Microglobe
>From the video compilation: "X-Mix-1: The MFS Trip"

This in an engaging 2-D animation.  Makes extensive use of
color cycling that moves at the same pace as the beats.  The
transitions evolve fluidly throughout the song.  Snowflakes
and flowers are the primary images.


"Cloudwalker"
Biosphere
>From the video compilation: "3-Lux-3: A Journey through
ambience"

Total ambience.  Three humanoid figures move around in a 
circular motion.  Planetoids orbit the galaxy.  Scenes at
dusk.


PLEASE NOTE:  "Cyberia" is broadcast only.  It airs on U
Network, a national network of college TV stations.  No
tapes are available for sale.  A list of U Network affiliate
stations is available via anonymous ftp on
techno.stanford.edu
get /pub/raves/media/television/CyberiaTVstations


Robert Campanell
Producer, "Cyberia"

----------------------------------------------------------------------

On Sat, 30 Apr 1994, Bob Ramstad wrote:

> 
> >insult fraternity people who do not fit that description.  Stereotype, or
> >otherwise, I cannot recall ever attending a function with frat. people
> >where there was not a sickening atmosphere of meat-market machoism and
> >elitism. This kind of environment kills any possibility of a
> 
> listen.  i am a brother of a fraternity, and i assure you, dozens of
> cool events go off here in SF where i am in attendance.  please
> re-read what you've said, and realize how incredibly offensive it
> could be to someone who considers himself a "frat person" and is an
> active contributor to the rave scene here.
> 
> Bob


	Gosh, Bob, why don't YOU read, in its entirety, my last post,
instead of, seemingly for further conflict's sake, displaying a portion 
of it out of context and subsequently responding to it with the SAME basic
retort as your first one.  I adequately compensated for any offense you
may have taken to my intial post, and CLARIFIED the orgin of my perceptions.
This was meant to calm the waters, Bob, and I fail to see why any further
negative response on your behalf is warranted (assuming you read and
understood my post from yesterday...).  The orgin of my stereotype comes
from the NW, where you yourself expressed disdain for the UW system.  To
take this much offense to my impetuous use of the word fratboy must
indicate that you indeed are involved in a positive system in SF. If I
didn't realize how offensive my remarks were, I would not have sent my
last post.  If your frat system is of such merit like you suggest, than I
truly empathize with you regarding the negative perceptions you must
encounter concerning frats in general, because as I'm sure you know, MANY
frat systems at MANY colleges do portray a negative image to the public,
and therefore 'fraternity` has hardly become synonymous with 'rave.`  Due to
my experience, you (and others like you) are an exception (I'm glad there
IS one...), and it is to those that I recant from using the frat reference.  

andrew
